fields.headline: Plodders in, legends turfed out
fields.standfirst: The cheapening of the Wembley myth: a first hand account
fields.trailText: The cheapening of the Wembley myth: a first hand account.
fields.body:
If you have entered one of the many competitions to win a piece of Wembley turf, don't get too hopeful. I was there on Tuesday night and there seems to be very little of the stuff left. It was always Wembley's proudest boast that, however bad the sightlines, however absurd the price of M&Ms in the refreshment bars, it was home to the best playing surface in the land.

Not any more. Two weeks of end-of-an-era private games, staged at the rate of four a day, generally in the bucketing rain, and the hallowed turf now looks as if it has just staged a month of pro-celebrity motocross.

Not that it matters for those lucky enough to get to play there: the legend still holds good. A colleague once told Kenny Dalglish, after spending an hour in an interview trying to extract something quotable, that he was off to play at Wembley in a media tournament.

"What a disgrace," was the gist of Dalglish's response. "Many an honest pro has toiled throughout his career and never got there. Now a tosspot like you can play."

Bad news, Kenny: it's got worse. In the stadium's soggy twilight, even I have been allowed in. I was invited to play by the Football365 website, in a game against a team of individuals who had bid up to £1,000 each on the auction website QXL for the chance to play.

365 had bolstered their side with Peter Beardsley and Ian Rush, neither of whom seemed to worry the old place had started doing impressions of a Flanders battlefield. It was an odd thing about the surface: whenever I went to kick the ball, it invariably struck a divot, cannoning off shins or ballooning comically over outstretched feet.

But Rushie or Beardo (as we team-mates called them) skipped around as though playing on a carpet. Although there were several good players on display (the QXL goalie led such a charmed life he must have been called Tomaszewski) the two old pros resembled nothing more than a couple of dads indulging their kids in a park kickabout.

While Beardo coaxed colleagues through one-twos (in my case, just ones), Rushie was putting more chances on a plate than he can have done in his entire career. Only two of several dozen were taken and eventually he felt obliged to score himself, just to show how it's done.

After we had been presented medals by a Queen lookalike, wallowed in the vast Wembley bath and dug up a few straggles of the remaining grass, Beardo was to be found in the bar, chatting with the handful of spectators. One little boy wanted to know how he rated his team-mates.

"Well," he said. "Some of them were so bad they faced the wrong way at kick-off."

I may be wrong, but I think he was looking at me as he said it.

webTitle: Weah not the champions' - maybe that was the problem

fields.headline: Weah not the champions' - maybe that was the problem
fields.standfirst: Why George couldn't find a place in his heart for City
fields.trailText: Why George couldn't find a place in his heart for City.
fields.body:
Some imaginative conspiracy theories have spun round the bars of Manchester to explain the disappearance of George Weah. Just three months into a lengthy contract, the former world player of the year has legged it to the south of France as things did not work out as he expected at City.

Was it Joe Royle's fault? Was George too demanding? Was the fans' traditional theory - the love triangle - involved?

Perhaps the closest explanation for Weah's disillusionment, though, was being aired in a pub near Old Trafford before Wednesday's meeting with PSV. Some United fans had purloined the tune of Dirty Old Town and were singing:

"And George Weah said/I thought they played in red."

webTitle: There is no future for a league of also-rans

fields.headline: There is no future for a league of also-rans
fields.standfirst: NTL's reticence this week suggests the Premier League bubble may not have burst but it is certainly going flat
fields.trailText: NTL's reticence this week suggests the Premier League bubble may not have burst but it is certainly going flat.
fields.body:
This week the Premier League has experienced a series of tremors which, while none may have registered more than a notch on the Richter scale, could still amount to something more than a rattling of tea cups.

Take NTL's withdrawal from a proposed £328m pay-per-view deal, add in the failure of the smaller Premiership clubs to win a bigger share of the new £1.6bn television windfall, spice things up with the financial losses reported by Chelsea and Newcastle United and it is clear that all is not well in boomtown.

Even Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds United chairman, while reporting a profit on last season, still pleaded for more investors if his club was to get within financial striking distance of Manchester United. The truth is that for the moment, when it comes to earning capacity, there is indeed only one United.

It is not a healthy situation either financially or in terms of the quality of the product. The Premier League is rapidly becoming becoming polarised between the elite and the rest and this is evident as much on the field as it is on the balance sheets.

There have often been periods when the game has been dominated by one or two clubs - Huddersfield in the 20s, Arsenal in the 30s, Wolves in the 50s, Manchester United in the 50s and 60s, and Liverpool in the 70s and 80s - but until now no one club has put as much distance between itself and its rivals as United have done over the last eight years.

Good for Sir Alex Ferguson, whose United teams have set standards of excellence and consistency previously achieved only by Bob Paisley's Liverpool and, at present, only challenged by Arsène Wenger's Arsenal. The rest of the Premier League has been left to pay players more that it can afford in an effort either to catch up or stay up.

No wonder NTL had second thoughts about spending more than £100m a season on the assumption that it would make a profit on pay-per-view. To have made a profit from pay-as-you-view football they would have had to make £2.7m on each game covered which would have meant at least 600,000 punters forking out at least a fiver a time.

Inexpensive maybe, but when the essential tribalism of football's support is taken into account it is hard to see Liverpool fans spending a penny to watch Manchester United or vice-versa while a match between, say, Charlton Atheltic and Middlesbrough would do well to draw an armchair crowd of five figures.

For the Premier League the uncomfortable truth is that the better Manchester United get the poorer the bulk of the competition becomes by comparison. Matches involving Arsenal, Liverpool or Leeds, when everyone is fit, can still combine excitement and entertainment with a high quality of performance but much of the football seen this season has confirmed the impression that the Premiership is silting up with dross.

It was formed in order to earn the members of the old First Division a bigger slice of revenue from television and sponsorship as well as giving them more voting power in running things their own way. But when, on Thursday, the 20 Premier League chairmen discussed Coventry City's proposal to distribute the new TV money more fairly among the less well-off clubs, the motion failed to get the required two-thirds majority.

The opposition of the big clubs was expected and Chelsea and Newcastle were probably not feeling particularly charitable at that moment, but what were Derby County and West Ham doing supporting them?

On the evidence of Derby's performance against Liverpool at Pride Park on Sunday, when Jim Smith's team decided not to mark or tackle and lost 4-0, they are going to need all the handouts they can get. And not long ago West Ham were having to sell players to keep their bankers happy.

It is not as if Manchester United, Arsenal and the other plutocrats will leave it there. Renewed talk of a breakaway is guaranteed every time the clubs vote on money matters but the underlying threat of a TV-oriented European league (or the Atlantic league to give it its latest title) is real enough.

Already a situation has been reached in which Manchester United can field a team of bench-warmers in a top-of-the-table clash - last Saturday's match at Leicester - and win comfortably while preserving their strongest fire for a Champions League match against PSV Eindhoven four days later. Already the Premier League plays second fiddle to a far richer competition.

The prospect of Manchester United and Arsenal, not to mention Rangers and Celtic, meeting the top Italian and Spanish sides on an even more regular basis might persuade the likes of NTL to reassess their attitude to pay-per view, although if the deed is ever done the clubs involved would probably broadcast the matches themselves.

But for the rest of football, clubs and fans, the game would be up and the Premier League, like the old Football League, would become a rump of also-rans. Television money has made the Premier League the success it is. Spent elsewhere it could also break it.

webTitle: I'd swap scouting up north for Delia's dip-dip-dip

fields.headline: I'd swap scouting up north for Delia's dip-dip-dip
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the doghouse
fields.trailText: Be fair ... isn't it? ... a minor tussle after a charity match ... hmm? ... But when someone suggests Ron was not a "track-suit" manager ... to be fair ... the Manager name besmirched! ... the blood runs wild ... the red mist descends ... the inevitable kerfuffle ... Robbie Williams cowering behind Ken Bates ... Ali G's Fanta all over Big Ron Atkinson's "strides" ... Mrs Manager wading in ...
fields.body:
Be fair ... isn't it? ... a minor tussle after a charity match ... hmm? ... But when someone suggests Ron was not a "track-suit" manager ... to be fair ... the Manager name besmirched! ... the blood runs wild ... the red mist descends ... the inevitable kerfuffle ... Robbie Williams cowering behind Ken Bates ... Ali G's Fanta all over Big Ron Atkinson's "strides" ... Mrs Manager wading in ...

"Take your hands off my Ron or I'll kick you from arseholes to breakfast-time!" Er ... Eastenders, isn't it? ... video evidence dammit! ... and I'm done up like a kipper!

Still, nothing like a long touchline ban to spark rumours of the FA's interest in me for the England job ... er ... I haven't been approached but if they're looking for someone who "knows the lingo" ... Ron Manager speaks the lot!

Well ... from "oop north" to "dahn sarf" ... there's always something special about derby games ... not Derby County games ... ho ho, only joking ... Where's my scooter, Bald Eagle! ... no ... local derbies! ... bit of an edge ... hmm? Except perhaps in Sheffield in the early days ... bit one-sided ... one played on a Wednesday ... and the other er ... didn't ...

So up to the north-east to watch Newcastle prepare for their local tussle against Middlesbrough ... one to relish! ... and ... I speak fluent Geordie! ... "divvent ye kna hinny!"

... so Solano and Cordone seemed a little bemused ... haven't a clue what they're on about, either!

Ah! Shearer! ... local lad! ... son of a sheet-metal worker ... we can't all be skilled ... I asked if he'd reconsider his international retirement in England's time of need ... but he gave me short shrift! Suggested Haddaway and Sheight ... who must be ... er ... products of the youth academy.

And down to the Riverside! ... Two minor contenders for Kev's vacancy squaring up ... Robson vs Robson ... hmm? The Boro supporters think Bryan's the man! ... they'd love him to take the England job!

The press are out in force ... and after a rather unfortunate headline "Ron Manager on Drugs" ... and ... thank you, Ken ... I could sue! ... everybody wants to know ... did I inhale! ... What? ... Pot?

Well, let me level with you ... I did! ... oh yes ... I did inhale! ... but I never actually smoked any of the stuff ... In my day ... just good honest alcohol and a few pep-pills!

Enough! ... the Newcastle team's coming out the tunnel ... Shearer ... Given ... Dyer ... Speed ... Well, no wonder he's lost half a yard of pace! ... well, we were often sold a dummy ... a purple heart, a slight shade of mauve ... Big Norm was frequently nut-megged down the "Whiff of Lavender" in Soho!

Er ... and a reader's letter from Mr Tim Roscamp of Hartlepool!

"A draw in Finland? ... What a bunch of divvies! Tommy Miller's the gadgy for England ... deffo!"

Ho ho! ... comprende , Mr Wenger? ... that's Teesside talk! ... and with my comprehensive knowledge of the "English" game ... of course I've heard of the Pool's midfield wonder-kid ... he's from up north, Tel! You know, I always fancied myself as a scout ... and Big Norm ... always fancied me as one as well ... and he's met enough! ... quick glance at the fixture list ... and we're off!

So Wednesday night ... while your fair-weather football fan's sitting glued to the box ... PSV ... a type of adhesive ... isn't it? ... we're chugging into Brighton on the Football Special! ... eager to check out the talent.

Ho ho, "hangin' " with the Poolie Massive, isn't it? ... er ... isn't it ? what is it? ... I dunno ... it's not very big, whatever it is ... and I'm just as bemused as they are by Brighton's idea of pub-grub! ... Tapas? ... eh? ... Jerk chicken? Why would anyone do that! ... Down to Withdean stadium ... unfortunately not "with-roof" ... complimentary paper-towels on heads ... bellies grumbling ... and it's pissing down!

A glance at the programme A veritable who's who ... er ... isn't it! Bang! ... Hartlepool score! ... Goooal! ... Oof! ... oh! They're in their away strip ... er ... "haway" lads ... anyone can make a mistake! ... Brighton go three goals up ... their goalie throws the ball into the net ... Now Hartlepool come back strongly ... a short break ... someone with a bucket fills a mysterious hole ... ho ho ... er ... marvellous! ... End to end stuff ... Four-two! ... football as you remember it! ... bloody awful!

... Slight element of offside about the Seagulls' fourth? ... more than there was an element of beef about my burger afterwards ... standard of catering ... shocking!

... Norwich! ... that's the place to be! ... Tough-talking TV cook Delia Smith! ... "Are you roight!" ... that's East-Anglian, Mr Lippi! ... " Ev you got a loight, boy?" Come on Delia, how about an invite! ... sort out the grub! ... "Boil the hot-dog sausage for two days? ... enjoy! ... you scum!"

Delia could teach your grandmother to suck eggs ... three programmes, maximum!

And now, Ron takes a peek at the European scene! ...

...er, well, I haven't because I've been "on the pot" since my burger on Wednesday night ...

And today's one to watch! ... George Weah! He's off to Marseilleah! ... he's on Question of Sport! ... couldn't get in the side at Man City ... I watched his frustration on the bench ... urging on the forwards as they chased City's trademark hopeful long punt upfield ...

"Get that Dickov!"

fields.headline: Grimandi given three-match ban
fields.trailText: Two issued with bans in the wake of Wednesday's ill-tempered draw in Rome.
fields.body:
Lazio's Sinisa Mihajlovic was banned for two Champions League matches last night for racially abusing Patrick Vieira. The repercussions of Arsenal's ill-tempered draw in Rome were also felt by Gilles Grimandi, who was suspended for three games for assaulting Diego Simeone.

Grimandi's ban will not hit Arsenal too hard because the first two matches he misses, against Sparta Prague next Wednesday and Shakhtar Donetsk the week after, are relatively meaningless now Arsenal have qualified for the second group stage.

They will determine nothing other than whether Arsène Wenger's team finish top of their group. Grimandi will also miss the first match of the second group stage.

Uefa said Mihajlovic's ban was the result of "sustained racist insults directed at Arsenal FC players throughout the match". Vieira claimed the Yugoslavia defender had called him a "fucking black monkey" and had started the onslaught before the match when the teams shook hands.

"The Yugoslav player admitted the verbal abuse, alleging he had previously been provoked," Uefa said. "Uefa's control and disciplinary body considers this to be a serious violation of the sporting principles which Uefa has always defended, especially bearing in mind the grossly humiliating nature of the verbal abuse."

Mihajlovic insisted he had been called a "Gypsy" by Vieira but there was no mention of punishment for the Arsenal midfielder in the sanctions handed out.

Grimandi's ban comes after he struck Simeone off the ball, leaving the Argentine with six stitches in a head wound. His actions were condemned yesterday by Wenger.

"You must always keep control of your behaviour," the manager said. "That's part of your responsibility. I encourage my players always to concentrate on the game.

"He knows he shouldn't have reacted at all but Simeone is quite well known for provoking people. He is not an angel."

It is the second time in 11 days the Frenchman has been banned for an incident missed by the match officials. Last week he received a one-match suspension for stamping on the hand of Liverpool's Gary McAllister at Highbury.

Grimandi was also sent off against Barcelona in last season's Champions League for elbowing Josep Guardiola. "It's surprising because basically he is a fair player," Wenger said. "But when he is upset he sometimes has an uncontrolled reaction."

Arsenal will not contest the suspension or the £8,300 fine they received for three offences: arriving on the pitch three minutes late before the match, having to be called three times before they emerged from the dressing-room for the second half and their part in a fight after the final whistle.

Lazio were fined £29,000 after objects were thrown at players and match officials, and for Simeone's and Juan Veron's more serious roles in that post-match scuffle with Arsenal players.

Uefa and Fifa have joined forces to try to convince Europe's heads of state that football should have a special place in European law which would prevent the transfer system from being overturned as illegal by the European Commission.

"We call on the EU and national governments to act now and help us safeguard the future well-being of European football," read a statement from Uefa's 51 members, who met a joint Fifa-Uefa task force yesterday.

Football has until October 31 to offer an alternative system to the EC. "We're optimistic," a Uefa spokesman said.

Vieira claimed the Yugoslavia defender had called him a "fucking black monkey" and had started the onslaught before the match when the teams shook hands. "The Yugoslav player admitted the verbal abuse, alleging he had previously been provoked," Uefa said. "Uefa's control and disciplinary body considers this to be a serious violation of the sporting principles which Uefa has always defended, especially bearing in mind the grossly humiliating nature of the verbal abuse." Mihajlovic insisted he had been called a "Gypsy" by Vieira but there was no mention of punishment for the Arsenal midfielder in the sanctions handed out. Grimandi's ban comes after he struck Simeone off the ball, leaving the Argentine with six stitches in a head wound. His actions were condemned yesterday by Wenger. "You must always keep control of your behaviour," the manager said. "That's part of your responsibility. I encourage my players always to concentrate on the game. "He knows he shouldn't have reacted at all but Simeone is quite well known for provoking people. He is not an angel." It is the second time in 11 days the Frenchman has been banned for an incident missed by the match officials. Last week he received a one-match suspension for stamping on the hand of Liverpool's Gary McAllister at Highbury. Grimandi was also sent off against Barcelona in last season's Champions League for elbowing Josep Guardiola. "It's surprising because basically he is a fair player," Wenger said. "But when he is upset he sometimes has an uncontrolled reaction." Arsenal will not contest the suspension or the £8,300 fine they received for three offences: arriving on the pitch three minutes late before the match, having to be called three times before they emerged from the dressing-room for the second half and their part in a fight after the final whistle. Lazio were fined £29,000 after objects were thrown at players and match officials, and for Simeone's and Juan Veron's more serious roles in that post-match scuffle with Arsenal players. Uefa and Fifa have joined forces to try to convince Europe's heads of state that football should have a special place in European law which would prevent the transfer system from being overturned as illegal by the European Commission. "We call on the EU and national governments to act now and help us safeguard the future well-being of European football," read a statement from Uefa's 51 members, who met a joint Fifa-Uefa task force yesterday. Football has until October 31 to offer an alternative system to the EC. "We're optimistic," a Uefa spokesman said.

fields.headline: Smith unfazed by tangerine nightmare
fields.standfirst: Graham Spiers meets the man whose job it is to turn things round at Tannadice
fields.trailText: Graham Spiers meets the man whose job it is to turn things round at Tannadice.
fields.body:
If Paul Jewell thinks he has it bad at Sheffield Wednesday he should try on Alex Smith's hard hat for size. The little Dundee United manager is currently vying, in competition with Jewell and one or two others, for the title of Britain's most embattled boss.

Jewell, at least, has not had to contend with a club chairman resigning after an alleged contretemps with a BBC reporter. The Jim McLean affair continues to resonate around Tannadice, Tayside police having charged him with assault.

This afternoon a paltry 400 United fans will travel to Glasgow for the once-alluring fixture between United and Celtic, so mangled has their faith in the club become.

Last week's 4-0 defeat by Hearts did not just push United's chairman over the edge - it produced the loudest yelp yet from a club seemingly lacerating itself. Dundee United, the recent unlikely ransackers of Europe, have yet to win a league game this season and are approaching a full year since they last won a Premier League match at home.

Bottom of the league, they are now capable of going hours without scoring. Their sixth manager in eight years is facing the task of his life.

Yet Smith, an old-fashioned Scottish manager in the Bill Shankly mould, has formidable qualities. A streetfighter from the old industrial heartlands, like Shankly, he is imbued with a natural, gritty intelligence. He is held to be an astute "reader" of the game and his past club teams, such as Aberdeen in the early 90s, were renowned for their cultured players and fine passing.

But Smith has also known the great baloney of the Scottish game. He won the Scottish Cup with St Mirren and got sacked soon afterwards. He rebuilt Aberdeen from their post-Alex Ferguson blues before being ousted there as well. Hence, when you meet Smith today, he wears a ready smile despite all of United's woes - testimony to a tumultuous football life.

"What has happened at this club in the past week regarding Jim McLean has been one of the greatest tragedies I've known in football, but our task still goes on here," says Smith. "What Dundee United needed, ironically, were men such as Jim McLean, who know football and love this club, working with our young players. You cannot beat the kind of know-how and experience someone like Jim has.

"It is for this reason that I've brought Tommy McLean back on board our coaching staff. I've taken stick for this because Tommy is Jim's brother, but he is one of the best football coaches I've known and he was available to us. To me, should anything else matter except getting the best men working for United?"

Confronting a resurgent Celtic, some fear for United's safety today. Alex Mathie, another player to have left the club recently, has said he can hardly think of a worse spirit engulfing any club.

Time was when United, donning their famous tangerine, would come to Glasgow and teach the Old Firm a thing or two. But if they win today, it will be proof of what theologians once called the compassion of the divine.

Dundee have signed the Trinidad and Tobago goalkeeper Clayton Ince on a three-month loan. Next Saturday's match against Dunfermline, meanwhile, will be televised live in South America due to the enormous interest surrounding the Argentine legend Claudio Caniggia.

fields.headline: Scowling Stoichkov ignites the Fire
fields.standfirst: Spencer Vignes checks out how Hristo Stoichkov has settled in the States.
fields.trailText: "There is still one place in Chicago where you can see a scowl more intimidating than Al Capone at his meanest." Spencer Vignes checks out how Hristo Stoichkov has settled in the States.
fields.body:
Chicago has spent the best part of the last 80 years trying to shake off its gangster image. Now one of the Unites States' most popular tourist destinations, the Windy City has successfully reinvented itself as a halfway house between New York attitude and LA celebrity backslapping. Yet there is still one place you can go in town to see a scowl more intimidating than Al Capone at his meanest.

When Hristo Stoichkov signed up to play for the Major League Soccer side Chicago Fire this March few eyebrows were raised outside his adopted city of Barcelona. Despite being officially tied to the Japanese club Kashiwa Reysol, the former European footballer of the year had spent most of the previous year playing exhibition football for fun in Spain. He was out of condition and severely lacking match practice.

Six months on and the 34-year-old Bulgarian, now back to full fitness and still sporting his permanent five o'clock shadow, has been instrumental in leading the Fire to this season's two major MLS cup finals. In Sunday's league decider in Washington they unexpectedly lost 1-0 to a Kansas City Wizards side featuring Mo Johnston.

Today at Chicago's Soldier Field stadium they have the opportunity to make amends in the Open Cup against the Miami Fusion. For Stoichkov, winner of the golden boot at the 1994 World Cup, it could be the last big stage in an impressive but often controversial career.

"Hristo has been a tremendous addition to our club," says Fire's head coach Bob Bradley. "His experience, his passion and determination meant he came to the US with the idea that he would take a tremendous responsibility in trying to help our young players, and he's certainly done that. You can't imagine how important a player like Bryan Robson was to someone like Paul Scholes or David Beckham at Old Trafford. Hristo has been like that for us. The youngsters see how professional he is, how he handles himself, and it goes a long way towards the development of those players."

A succession of minor injuries during the first half of the season restricted Stoichkov to 18 appearances in a Fire shirt but he still bagged 13 goals. Instead of sitting at home during his lay-off, he threw himself into helping out at coaching, his natural skill and enthusiasm more than compensating for the language barrier.

Yet, despite winning the confidence and respect of Bradley and his team-mates, that notorious temper remains. Journalists and referees are still there to be hated, though today the abuse is more likely to be verbal than physical. In 1985 he received a life ban from the Bulgarian FA - lifted when Bulgaria qualified for the 1986 World Cup finals - for his part in a brawl during a cup final. On Wednesday, after a particularly tough challenge during a training session, he subjected a reporter to a hail of abuse, delivered in Spanish, for daring to take a loud intake of breath.

Following today's final Stoichkov will meet club officials to decide his future. A one-year contract or a coaching rolehas been mentioned, or both. Bradley for one is desperate to keep him. "I believe all that he has done for the Fire has been positive and my hope is that we will have him here with us again next year."

fields.headline: Boro break bank for £8m Ehiogu
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson starts the bail out in time honoured fashion at the Riverside.
fields.body:
Bryan Robson yesterday took his spending to almost £79m since becoming manager of Middlesbrough in 1994 after completing the £8m signing of Ugo Ehiogu from Aston Villa.

Ehiogu, 27, signed a five-year contract and will make his debut at Charlton this afternoon. The fee for the central defender, capped once by England, is a club record, although Robson is adamant Ehiogu is worth every penny.

"There's no risk at all spending that kind of money," he said. "Ugo has proved himself to be one of the best central defenders in England over the last five years. He's good enough to play for his country."

The club where Ehiogu started his career, West Brom, will also profit from the deal, collecting £3m of the transfer fee having negotiated a sell-on clause when he moved to Villa nine seasons ago.

"I felt I was going a bit stale at Villa and I needed a fresh start," Ehiogu said yesterday. "I didn't get on too well with John Gregory; over the last few months I have been the lowest I've ever been. You can understand it when you're not playing just for football reasons, but that wasn't the problem for me. It was a clash of personalities as well."

As if to prove the point, the Villa manager took one last swipe at his former player. "I always thought when he talked of playing for a bigger and better club where he could win things and enhance his England career that he was talking about Arsenal or Manchester United or someone like that," he said.

Meanwhile, Robson has put his £2m move for the Milan midfielder Zvonimir Boban on hold. "We're still looking to improve the squad but I'm still waiting to recoup some of the [Christian] Ziege money from Liverpool," he explained. "Hopefully the two clubs will reach an agreement on that front in the near future."

webTitle: Wild child takes walk on the mild side

fields.headline: Wild child takes walk on the mild side
fields.standfirst: Arrogant hothead or media victim? Daniel Taylor meets the Leeds striker Alan Smith
fields.trailText: Arrogant hothead or media victim? Daniel Taylor meets the Leeds striker Alan Smith.
fields.body:
In football, getting a bad name has always been easier than losing one. Mud sticks and when you play for a club of Leeds United's family tree the stains don't always come out in the wash. Alan Smith, their tempestuous young striker, will be 20 next week and his critics would say it is time for him to start growing up or face the consequences.

With every flailing lunge, every gnashing of his teeth and every acidic headline, Smith's notoriety is spreading all the time. And that is sad. Under David O'Leary's paternal hand he has been the best player at Elland Road this season, but he is still better known for the sharpness of his studs than his finishing.

The danger is that, having dug his own hole, Smith could find himself in over his head. He seems to be nurturing his reputation as a throwback to Elland Road days of old with the loving care of a gardener tending his roses. With this spiky character around, the potential for trans-Pennine feuding when Leeds renew hostilities with Manchester United today will never be far removed from Old Trafford.

Last season Smith was a key player in the infamous on-pitch rumble with Spurs and, in 20 appearances, he racked up more cards (five yellow, one red) than goals (four). After a summer operation to clear an ankle injury, the ratio is now more in his favour. But his prolific start to the season - eight goals and a call-up to the full England squad - has still incorporated a Champions League suspension and a sending-off for England Under-21s against Finland.

With his blond locks and all-year tan, Smith would not look out of place in a boy band. Yet when he pulls on his boots he can be as crude as one of the Gallagher brothers. "I just hate losing and that's what gets me into trouble. But I don't set out to get into bother - no one does," he says.

"Things happen and when you are out there you can get carried away. When I was sent off for the Under-21s I had been getting kicked and stamped on all night, and I just lashed out. It was stupid really.

"Sammy Lee took me to one side afterwards and said they were gunning for me because they recognised me as being dangerous. It's a compliment, I suppose, but at the time you don't see it that way. It's hard sometimes to keep your cool. It's in my mind now that people might be talking more about the bad things than the good things.

"The gaffer here has spoken to me a few times about it and, to be fair, he's shown a lot of faith in me. He told me about his experiences as a young lad and one of his games for the Republic of Ireland, when they were playing in South America, and he was getting lumps kicked out of him. I think he retaliated and was sent off. He said that he had learned from it and that I should too."

It is easy to have preconceived ideas when you are meeting a footballer, especially a teenager who drives a top-of-the-range BMW. But sometimes they can surprise you with their humility. Off the field, Smith is nothing like the crabby individual that emerges every Saturday.

He has an infectious effervescence for life and a deep affection for the game. "He's one of the most lovely lads you could ever meet," says one of the ladies at Thorp Arch, the Leeds practice ground. And it is, indeed, easy to warm to him. You just cannot help but wince every time he goes in for a tackle.

Like most teenagers, Smith also has a touch of self-righteous innocence about him. "I've been scoring a few goals this season and doing quite well, but I've found that a lot of people have been taking away from my football.

"When we played Spurs this month there were seven goals and it was a great game, but one newspaper based their entire match report around me supposedly having a run-in with Ramon Vega all afternoon. If you asked any of the Spurs players I'm sure they would say I never went near him. But the media make stuff of it because of me. I couldn't really believe it.

"To be honest, I don't usually like doing the press. I would much rather keep myself to myself and let my football do the talking. I don't like going to the tabloids because they will turn it into something it isn't. They've done that to me before.

"We played against Sheffield Wednesday last season and afterwards I was in a rush to get away. Some paper asked me for an interview and, when I said I didn't have time, it was all over the tabloids the next day that I was arrogant because I wouldn't talk to them.

"It can be hurtful because they make you out as a bad person. Anyone who reads it has no reason not to believe it because they don't know what you're really like. You can get misunderstood."

There should be no misunderstanding Smith's ability. Slight yet wiry, with pace and perception, he not only has the best positional sense of any Leeds striker since Joe Jordan but the calmness in front of goal that sets natural finishers apart from the rest.

His form is one of the main reasons why a Leeds side cruelly depleted by injuries is heading a Champions League group featuring Barcelona and Milan, while at the same time remaining in contention of qualifying next time round. With the news yesterday that Michael Bridges will be out for six weeks, much rests on Smith's young shoulders.

"The lad drives me mad sometimes," says O'Leary. "We have had big words and there are probably a few more to come. But it is wrong for people to think of him as arrogant. He's nothing like that at all. He is a good player and a nice lad."

There are many ways in which Smith, for all the bone-crunching challenges, is also a true professional. Behind the scenes at Elland Road he is one of the most amenable players towards doing community work. In training he is usually one of the last off the pitch. And he is a teetotaller too.

"I've never been one for alcohol. All the way from being a lad it has never appealed to me.I know that might be unusual because, yeah, footballers do get a lot of free time. I enjoy a good night out but I always stick to the soft drinks. Drinking is just something I have never done."

Smith still lives with his parents at the house in Rothwell where he grew up. His bedroom walls are covered with posters of David Batty and Vinnie Jones (who else?). He says being around his family and schoolfriends helps to keep his feet on the ground. Which, after all, is better than an opponent's ankle.

fields.headline: Robson sidesteps England question
fields.standfirst: Rumours swell that the FA want Newcastle's veteran manager back in some capacity
fields.trailText: Rumours swell that the FA want Newcastle's veteran manager back in some capacity.
fields.body:
Bobby Robson yesterday refused to discuss the England situation as rumours swept Newcastle that he was about to be approached by the Football Association to act in what could be a consultancy role.

"Don't ask me about England. All I'm prepared to talk about is Newcastle," the 67-year-old Magpies manager said.

The Football Association last night refused to rule out asking Robson to become involved with the England set-up and no approach has yet been made to Robson's club Newcastle United. But at the very least the FA may seek his advice on who should become Kevin Keegan's long-term successor as coach.

An FA spokesman said: "No official approach has been made to Newcastle United and the decision-making is still very much in the consultancy stage. Adam Crozier [the FA's chief executive] has already said that he will be making the final decision." Despite protestations from his chairman Freddie Shepherd, Robson has expressed a willingness to help his country on a temporary basis in preparation for next month's friendly with Italy in Turin.

webTitle: Winterburn happy to hammer old pals

fields.headline: Winterburn happy to hammer old pals
fields.standfirst: Arsenal's visit is no problem for a former stalwart, writes Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Arsenal's visit is no problem for a former stalwart, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
Nobody who watched any of Nigel Winterburn's heart-pumping, fist-clenching 440 games for Arsenal would doubt that he would have run through a brick outhouse for the club. What has not been generally known until now is that, along with his former team-mates, he also leaped over hurdles and bounded over hoops for Arsenal as part of a new science, known as plymetrics, initiated by their manager Arsène Wenger to build the players' explosive energy.

Wenger also introduced food supplements and hired a chef so that the players' diets could be strictly regulated and monitored. All of which must have made Winterburn believe he had crossed London by Tardis when he arrived at cosy old West Ham, where dear old 'Arry Redknapp is more comfortable with the F-word than the F-plan.

As a great old pro, of course, Winterburn, 37 in December, has taken it in his admittedly slowing stride. And though for the first time today, he will walk out for a West Ham-Arsenal scrap from the claret-and-blue corner, his Highbury memories will be locked away as securely as all the medals he earned in north London.

The fixture, like most London derbies, has a history of bad blood, and much spilling of it, last year's game at Upton Park descending to gutter level when Arsenal's Patrick Vieira was shown a red card and showered Neil Ruddock with spittle on the way off. Winterburn will not be surprised if the rules are again less adhered to than they were expected to be in this morning's Mike Tyson-Andrew Golota fight.

He says: "As you can imagine, I looked up the date of this match as soon as the fixture list came out. I'm not expecting too many problems from my old Arsenal pals, but if it does kick up a bit rough, I will still be the first to offer a handshake at the end.

"I've always said that it is only a game of football but, while you're out on that pitch for 90 minutes, it's more or less your life, and fans want to see that, they want to see you getting stuck in and working hard. At the end, though, all the players should be man enough to shake hands."

For a man renowned for his bulging-eyeballs style and goalscoring celebrations that could get him a place in an American relay squad, Winterburn is quite philosophical on the quiet. One might expect him to harbour resentment against Arsenal, where he had hoped to finish his career, or at least demonstrate only sulky acceptance of playing out his days at West Ham. Yet he says: "I would never change anything I've had or anything I've got. When I look back and remember being shown the door as a kid at Birmingham City and look where I am now, I really haven't got much to grumble about.

"I had a choice in the summer: to stay at Arsenal for sentimental reasons or come here and play regularly. Once I came to the conclusion that I couldn't live without playing, the decision was easy. And I'm fully committed to West Ham. Otherwise, I wouldn't have joined, I would have packed the game in."

Winterburn had long known that a cocky young kid with a wicked left foot would one day bound into Arsenal's marble halls and work happily as his apprentice for a year or two before showing his gratitude by seizing the shirt off his dressing-room peg. When Winterburn observed the Brazilian brilliance of Silvinho in training, he knew the future had arrived.

He says: "Trying to be friendly to someone and at the same time trying to keep them out of the team takes a special mentality. That's what I was trying to do - to stop it for as long as possible and make it as difficult for him as possible. But he is a very good player, and his forward play, the quickness of his feet, is fantastic."

West Ham, remarkably, have yet to win at home, though despite facing an Arsenal side unbeaten in Europe or the Premiership since the opening day - a 1-0 defeat to Sunderland - Winterburn is confident today could be one when they blow away reputations rather than bubbles.

The Hammers rounded off a tremendous performance against Manchester United at Upton Park with two goals in the final four minutes to secure a draw, and came from behind to get a point against a Liverpool side who were content to escape with one. Winterburn says that they could easily have won both games, while conceding, surely proof that he is now fully versed in the capriciousness of life at West Ham, that they almost threw both away.

He does not linger on such things, any more than he lingers on the incomprehensible fact that, in an era when England can barely find a player to stand on his left foot, let alone kick with it, he has only two caps. Putting on his philosopher's hat again, he says: "I think it can be very damaging to worry about something you cannot change so I have tried not to do that."

He admits, however, that he would love to have played for his country a few more times and he is disappointed that Arsenal did not find their true Champions League form while he was still there. So regrets, yes, he has a few. But given his background, too few to mention.

webTitle: England's batsmen warm to their task

fields.headline: England's batsmen warm to their task
fields.standfirst: Trescothick ton lays foundation for victory. Paul Weaver reports from Karachi
fields.trailText: Trescothick ton lays foundation for victory. Paul Weaver reports from Karachi.
fields.body:
On the Muslim Sabbath England's cricketers had their own supplications ultimately answered here yesterday but it was hardly a performance to banish memories of their last, shoddy performance in Nairobi or encourage them to exorcise the ghosts of Pakistan past.

This is their first visit to Pakistan since the infamous tour of 1987-88, if one forgets their brief appearance in the 1996 World Cup and it is best one does. For their opening match, against the Governor's XI, they chose the side that succumbed so miserably against South Africa in the ICC Knockout Trophy nine days earlier. Their batsmen, at least, atoned with brio, scoring 323 for seven.

Marcus Trescothick, with his first century in England colours, and Graeme Hick, who scored 50 from 45 deliveries and then added another 32 from 15, led the romp in the National stadium. But in the field, before Darren Gough started reverse-swinging, England were given an awful fright by this Pakistan second-string side and particularly by Salim Elahi, who scored 120 from 103 deliveries, his second century in three days. Elahi, who made a century on his one-day international debut against Sri Lanka and whose elder brothers Manzoor and Zahoor have played Test cricket, hit a six and 16 fours as he attempted to club his side towards an audacious victory.

England must have felt they were on their way to a straightforward win when the dangerous opener Shahid Afridi was caught behind off Andy Caddick to the first ball he faced. But Elahi carried his side more than halfway to their target before he was fourth out with the score at 179 in the 32nd over. The Governor's XI were finally all out for 242 in the 47th.

At the start of this day-night warm-up for the three one-day internationals that start on Tuesday there were eerie reminders of those strange happenings of 13 years before. For one thing no one was here at the start. It was like the beginning of the opening Test in 1987-88, in Lahore, where only 150 could be counted. And one of the umpires yesterday was Shakeel Khan. Forget about Shakoor Rana; it was Shakeel who really upset England in that first Test with a series of outrageous decisions. He index-fingered them to an innings defeat and set the tone for a bitter series.

His gait is a little more stately now to accommodate a girth that swells like a prize marrow. And his good looks are a little bloated these days. But here he was. And it was enough to put a shiver up anyone with half a memory. Yesterday, however, there was not so much at stake. This match, and then one against Pakistan A on the same ground tomorrow, are merely acclimatisation.

England's batting was ultimately awesome. It was shaped by Trescothick, who straight-drove Mohammad Akram for a muscular four in the first over. Trescothick made 66 on his Test debut and 79 in his first one-day international, so little, not even a new country, is likely to faze him. Here he found a pitch even flatter than his beloved Taunton and he thrived on it.

Until he tired in the 29th over, when he top-edged an attempted sweep to short fine leg, he drove and pulled - sometimes off the front foot - until the bowlers despaired. He faced 93 balls and there were three sixes and a dozen fours.

He put on 41 for the first wicket with Alec Stewart (17) and then 126 for the second with Nasser Hussain (44). The decision to play Hussain at three, however, was a surprisingly dunder-headed piece of thinking by the normally astute captain and the coach, Duncan Fletcher.

Because of his sharp fielding and thoughtful leadership Hussain is just about worth a place in the one-day side. But clearly he must open the batting or not play at all, a fact he realised himself in South Africa and Zimbabwe last winter when he went in first with Nick Knight and did well.

Yesterday he did not play badly. But he still received 64 deliveries while Trescothick dominated from the other end. His effort was put into context by Hick whose 82, including two sixes and nine fours, took the England total to its heady heights.

The point is that this is where pinch-hitting was invented. On England's green and seaming surfaces it can be a questionable tactic. But on these flat pitches the first 15 overs are absolutely vital and, although England's score of 91 at this stage was fair, it might have been even more if Trescothick had been sup ported by one of the big hitters. Hick did not turn up until the 29th over; Andrew Flintoff did not arrive until the 42nd.

These are the mightiest strikers of all. If Hussain intends to keep his place, and he does, he must replace Stewart, who would be equally at home in the middle order.

webTitle: Slow growth likely to peg interest rate

fields.headline: Slow growth likely to peg interest rate
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hopes that interest rates would remain at 6% for the rest of the year were raised yesterday by news of a slowdown in economic growth.
fields.body:
Hopes that interest rates would remain at 6% for the rest of the year were raised yesterday by news of a slowdown in economic growth.

Weaker activity in the services sector trimmed the pace of growth in the third quarter of this year, but it stayed above its long-term average.

Provisional data published by the office for national statistics showed GDP grew by 0.7% between July and September compared to the previous three months and was up by 2.9% over the year.

In the second quarter, the corresponding figures were 0.9% and 3.2%.

The slowdown was concentrated in the services sector, where output expanded by 0.7% in the quarter and 3.3% over the year, down from 0.9% and 3.5% in the second quarter.

After shrinking at the turn of the year, manufacturing recorded its second successive quarter of growth, although the ONS was unable to say by how much because of incomplete data. Philip Shaw, economist at Investec in the City, said that judging by the slowdown in services, manufacturing output probably accelerated to 0.6% from 0.4%.

"Certain areas of the sector, notably technology oriented firms, do seem to be thriving," he said. "However we would shy away from inferring that the economy as a whole is well balanced and instead remain of the view that the strength of sterling against the euro keeps alive the dangers of a two-speed economy."

The figures, which were in line with expectations in the City, gave ammunition to both sides of the interest rates debate.

Jonathan Loynes, of Capital Economics, said they would come as a relief to hawks on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee and meant that the cost of borrowing, on hold for the last eight months, had peaked at 6%.

But Geoff Dicks, of the Royal Bank of Scotland, pointed out that despite the slowdown, the economy was still growing above trend, reckoned to be about 0.6% a quarter or 2.5% a year, and putting upward pressure on capacity and inflation. According to his estimate, output is running at 1% above its assessed maximum.

Mr Shaw said the underlying strength of demand remained too strong to prevent one more quarter-point increase in rates, although he added that sterling's strength on the foreign exchanges probably meant it would be delayed until early next year.

The only thing that could spoil that relatively benign scenario would be a major pre-election giveaway by the chancellor Gordon Brown.

The ONS said the British economy has now had 33 successive quarters of growth since the bottom of the last recession in the second quarter of 1992, a post-war record.

Since then, GDP has grown by 27%, service sector output by 34% and manufacturing output by nearly 12%.

Previously, the longest expansion lasted 24 quarters from the third quarter of 1984 to the second quarter of 1990.

fields.headline: No stakeholder fees, says Barclays
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays yesterday moved to take a large share of the forthcoming stakeholder pensions market by announcing the introduction of a pension plan free of all charges for almost two years.
fields.body:
Barclays yesterday moved to take a large share of the forthcoming stakeholder pensions market by announcing the introduction of a pension plan free of all charges for almost two years.

The bank, which is keen to rebuild its image after a series of public relations blunders, announced a stakeholder pension with no management charge being applied from April 6 next year until January 1 2003.

But some observers said it was hard to see how the bank would make any money from what one called such an "improbably generous" offer. Thomas McPhail, pensions development manager at independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, called the move "recklessly ambitious" and said: "I cannot see how they are ever going to make a profit from this."

Barclays also said it is joining Prudential, Standard Life and HSBC in cutting charges for 400,000 existing pension customers.

Stakeholder pensions are the new low-cost, flexible pension plans that go on sale in April. The maximum a company will be able to charge for managing an individual's fund is 1% a year. By October next year, all businesses that do not have a company pension scheme must offer staff access to a stakeholder pension, unless they have less than five employees.

fields.headline: The Messiah
fields.standfirst:
Showroom Cinema, Sheffield
****
fields.trailText:
Showroom Cinema, Sheffield
****
fields.body:
Photographer and film-maker William Klein turned tin cans into icons well before Andy Warhol got his hands on Campbell's soup. The fame of Warhol eluded him, but his influence has been quietly pervasive. In the 1950s, he took photographs of New York that portrayed the city as slummy, trashy and damaged. Reviled in America, they were eventually published in France in a book called Life is Good and Good For You in New York: Trance Witness Revels. Klein said bitterly that the city got the book it deserved.

Klein's then-original techniques are now commonplace but he has lost none of his edge. His latest film is a quasi-documentary about Handel's Messiah, in which the oratorio is paired with a startling array of images, from gamblers in Las Vegas and a passion play in Andalusia, to the antics of Bodybuilders for Christ, who crumple aluminium pans as easily as you or I would crush a piece of card. At times images set themselves in ironic opposition to the music, and crucially the libretto. "Behold the Lamb of God that taketh away the sins of the world," for instance, is paired with shots of the Dallas police department flicking through mugshots of criminals. "Rejoice greatly" sees Christmas celebrations in a hostel for the homeless in Paris, where baffled, putty-faced derelicts plod round the dancefloor as stiffly as marionettes.

At other times, the ecstatic metaphor of the text is reduced to the concrete in disturbing fashion. "The crooked shall be made straight" sees the scene move from a rocky valley to a New York cityscape, where gleaming, silvery skyscrapers stand bolt upright like mercury in a thermometer.

The film would be cheaper if it were pure satire. It is not. It is also celebratory. The good news told by neon signs and advertising hoardings is certainly not the good news of Handel's oratorio - but through Klein's lens these altars to Mammon take on their own wild beauty. Klein also knows when to let the music - as powerful and uplifting a score as has ever been written - slip away from the condition of soundtrack and come to the fore. The Messiah has got the film it deserves.

Screened tomorrow. Box office: 0114-275 7727.

Pop

It's Jo And Danny

Rocket, Leeds **

Someone has written nasty things about It's Jo And Danny, and they are not best pleased. "We're a 'hippy folk duo', " spits Jo with palpable disgust. For the next eight minutes, the pair do their best to refute the slur. Baggy grooves evoke Primal Scream and the Rolling Stones in their flirting-with-devil-worship period. Jo drinks from the bottle while pounding her electric guitar into the floor.

"Rock'n'roll!" she cries. It's only after the tumult ceases that you notice the bottle contains mineral water. It's true: they are not a duo - singer Jo and bassist Danny are accompanied by a turntable man, a trumpet player and a very unhippyish loud drummer. However, despite their protestations, there is something terminally indie, hippy and indeed drippy about them.

They follow their raucous entrance with the kind of Corrs-like niceness that presumably prompted the insult. They even have a song called Hippy Thinking. Former record company workers disillusioned with the industry, they subsequently proved they can take it on at its own game. Their praised Lank Haired Girl to Bearded Boy album proved that a cottage industry can mix it with the big boys, and they have since obtained heavyweight representation. Now if only they'd apply the same fire to their music.

Instead, seagull noises and the chords from Tim Buckley's Kangaroo can't disguise standard indie fare. The album's grooves make fleeting appearances, but there's something problematic about Jo's Sandy Denny voice. God has intended her to sing folk music, and, however she may fight it, trying to do otherwise is like a nightingale attempting to bark. After a set that lasts just 30 minutes, everybody is sure which one is the Lank Haired Girl and which the Bearded Boy (although he has shaved), but Jo and Danny's musical identity seems confused. Perhaps they should bite the bullet and settle into a long career as a hippy folk duo.

At Bristol Louisana tonight (0117-926 59780); Brighton Pressure Point on Monday (01273 702333); and London Borderline on Tuesday (020-7734 2095).

Dance

Urban Bush Women

Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester *****

These Afro-American girlies don't beat around the bush. They're feisty, funny, strong and sexy and revel in their womanhood, especially all the wobbly bits, which they shake and shimmy with pride.

Hot from New York for Manchester's Re-Flex, Dance of Black Origin festival, the all-dancing, all-singing company gives girl power real meaning, as the performers celebrate the voluptuous pulchitrude of the female form.

The programme veers from strong statements calling for social change, to poignant pieces on personal struggle backed by soaring gospel voices, to a celebration of the love of music to pleas for the homeless, danced to clever, angry lines from poet Hattie Gossett.

But best of all must be Batty Moves, a paean to the female pelvis and the captivating properties of the buttocks. In Jamaica, particularly, your batty is your bottom, and artistic director Jawole Zollar's defiant, triumphal piece appeals to all "big mamas" to accept and proclaim their curves. You won't hear these women asking: "Does my bum look big in this?" It probably does and they don't care.

An infectious mix of ballet, contemporary and African tribal moves, with juddering shoulders to focus on the breasts, and every permutation of gyration imaginable to show off the rear, Batty Moves is introduced by Afro-Cuban Carolina Garcia, a pint-sized powerhouse who fuses Latino rhythms with traditional African steps, wickedly poking fun at thrusting bad girl rappers. The women form a chorus line, T-shirts tied round their waists, and waggle their bums every which way. After being joined by singer Topaz Wise, who makes Rubens's models look undernourished, the women strut their stuff in sassy solos extolling their virtues and vices.

Physically punishing, the choreography switches from fast and flashy to bump-andgrind erotic, and the whole thing is one huge girls' night out. We clapped and whooped and ululated and wanted to jump on the stage.

In contrast, Shelter was a sober look at how we could all find ourselves, as the poet put it, between a rock and a hard place. The dancers portray street women who live on squares of cardboard, explode in bursts of desperation, huddle together for comfort and obsessively flick off unseen dirt. The piece is accompanied by sizzling percussion from Michael Wimberly and Wise's huge voice.

Garcia was also superb in the poignant solo Give Your Hands, raging against the machine, her hands clenched in fists of anger, open to soothe and heal, or reaching out to struggle until reposed in final peace.

Final performance tonight. Box office: 0161-907 5278.

fields.headline: Go against the flow to maximise your retirement pot
fields.standfirst:
Are policies that rely on shares too risky? Phillip Inman says not.

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The term investment trust pension sounds like the kind of wild and risky venture only the foolhardy or wealthy would take on.
fields.body:
The term investment trust pension sounds like the kind of wild and risky venture only the foolhardy or wealthy would take on.

Relying solely on a bunch of stocks and shares inside an investment trust to produce a pension pot is not seen as a sensible way of preparing for old age.

And the inner workings of investment trust pensions are seen as complicated compared with other "hands-on" investment vehicles. The advent of the stakeholder pension, which limits charges and gives investors greater flexibility, is another good reason to stick with the traditional pension and steer clear of esoteric rivals.

Or at least, that is what many financial advisers will say. They have a vested interest - commission.

Supporters of investment trust pensions say the combination of low running costs and flexible management with a route to the potentially high returns offered by the world's stock markets gives them an edge.

A personal pension plan is simply a wrapper for an investment which offers certain tax benefits while the planholder is saving up for retirement.

A wide variety of assets can go into the wrapper - with-profits funds, property, bonds, cash, shares in unquoted companies or overseas stocks. Investment trusts are a further category with five major groups - AIB Govett, Alliance, Edinburgh Fund Managers, Fleming, and Foreign & Colonial all offering off-the-peg schemes.

Pension buyers can put other trusts into bespoke plans known as self-invested personal pensions. But the five with their own schemes offer low, transparent costs.

Nick Perryman of the independent financial adviser Douglas Deakin Young says: "They are wonderfully low cost and perform well, especially over the longer term."

If you get past the complexities of investment trusts you can enjoy the combination of low charges and flexibility, coupled with the pension tax allowance. Typically, a fund will charge a £200 upfront fee, a £50 administration charge and a 0.5% annual management charge. This compares with standard pension management charges that range from 1.5% to 5%. The Fleming Pension Account, run by Chase Fleming Asset Management, has no upfront charges, and a 0.5% annual management fee. The costs even compare favourably with the stakeholder pension which limits annual management charges to 1%.

Investment trusts find it harder to match other stakeholder requirements, however. The government says stakeholder pensions should accept monthly payments as low as £20 a month. Edinburgh Fund Managers demands minimum payments of £50 a month, £500 annually or a £1,000 lump sum. It says the minimum figures are being looked at in the light of the stakeholder rules but no decision has been taken yet.

Mr Perryman points out that many investment trusts also fail to offer a "waiver of premium" that allows investors to reduce or skip payments should they become sick or temporarily out of work. This is also true of some standard personal pensions as well.

Lesley Drummond at Edinburgh maintains that most investment trusts offer greater flexibility, with fully managed and other funds available. "You can start with the managed fund and once you've got used to the way it works you can switch to the selector fund with any additional cost," she says.

Once inside the pension wrapper, the same rules apply to investment trust pensions as any other type of personal pension when it comes to taking retirement. Investors must take their money out between the ages of 50 and 75 and purchase an annuity that will give a fixed income until death.

You can read more at the Chase Fleming Asset Management website, www.chaseflemingam.co.uk; Edinburgh Fund Managers at www.edfd.com; and Foreign & Colonial at www.fandc.co.uk.

AITC publishes a free factsheet on investment trust pensions, which is available on 0800 707 707.

webTitle: Experts predict that floods will increase

fields.headline: The hell of high water is set to swamp us all
fields.standfirst:
Environmental experts predict that floods will increase by up to 10 times over the next century. Elizabeth Langton reports.

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Environmental experts predict that floods will increase by up to 10 times over the next century. Elizabeth Langton reports.
fields.body:
Everyone puts together a personal checklist when they go house hunting, whether it is a south-facing garden, period features, utility room or cellar. But how many people make a mental note to check the likely impact of global warming on their chosen residence?

Environmental experts say that soon more and more of us will be assessing the chances of flood damage on our prospective homes. With many people in the UK still on flood watch, the Environment Agency said 5m people live in flood-risk areas and the prospect of being engulfed in water is now a fact of daily life in England and Wales. The agency says flood reports have doubled in the last 100 years.

Climate change means residents could see up to a "10-fold increase in flood risk over the next century. A typical flood that might now happen on average once in 100 years could occur as frequently as every 10 or 20 years in future. In short, today's extreme floods could become tomorrow's norm," the agency adds.

The floods that swept through the south-east last month are offered as proof of the seriousness of the situation. The floods, the worst in 40 years, forced residents in East Sussex and Kent from their homes and businesses when rivers broke their banks.

Lewes was stranded when the River Ouse overflowed. Hundreds of homes in the Kentish villages of Yalding, Wateringbury, East Farleigh, Laddingford and East Peckham were also flood when the Medway and its tributaries burst their banks.

When the water subsides householders surveying the wreckage might find it hard to believe their home isn't blighted and impossible to sell. However, a spokesman from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors says all is not lost.

"Homeowners shouldn't have any problems selling a house that has been properly dried out and had the electrics and gas checked," he says. But if buyers know the area has been flooded in the past it may have an effect on the value of the property.

Ever the optimists, estate agents deny that the floods will have an impact on property prices in the area. A spokesman for Hoskin, a Crawley-based agent that covers the area where some of the worst flooding occurred, said that Lewes in East Sussex would continue to be a desirable place to live. "There is a relatively limited supply of property and a lot of people want to live there," he said.

Residents of towns like Lewes, built many years ago on spots vulnerable to flooding, have little choice but to weather whatever nature sends them. But with 3m homes planned for the south-east by 2016 there are growing concerns about where developers are siting new developments.

Earlier this month, the Association of British Insurers (ABI) published research into the potential impact of inland flooding.

It is not surprising that the insurers want to cut the number of homes at risk from flooding - after all, the industry found itself meeting a £12m bill for the damage caused by floods in Yorkshire and County Durham in June. In recent weeks there have been hints at premium hikes unless more care is taken over homes in vulnerable areas.

Insurers have called for a halt to all developments on flood plains or for improved drainage and specially designed buildings. In response the government has promised tighter guidance and stronger powers for local authorities to prevent homes being built in particularly risky areas.

For ordinary homes, RICS says most materials should dry out with the help of dehumidifiers. Brickwork, concrete, timber in good condition and plaster should all survive a soaking. Plasterboard, chipboard and plywood, on the other hand, are unlikely to survive.

Floods are not bad news for everyone. Sussex police warned that cowboy builders were launching their own brand of clean-up operation, exploiting flood-stricken homeowners. RICS urges res idents to take advice from insurers or a professional such as a surveyor to determine the extent of the damage and the remedies needed.

The Environment Agency urges householders in risk areas to be prepared by taking some commonsense precautions. Keep a list of useful numbers to hand, including the floodline, 0845-988-1188.

Have sandbags or floorboards available to block doorways and airbricks. Make up a flood kit including torch, blankets, waterproof clothing, wellingtons and key personal documents. Consider a flood plan and discuss it with your family or neighbours. Make sure you know how to switch off gas and electricity. Think about where you would move your pets and your car and get into the habit of storing valuables upstairs or high up.

After flooding, the Buildings Research Establishment recommends householders check for structural damage, check gas and electricity supplies are off and whether drainage is working, photograph the damage, contact insurers and remove wet carpets and fur niture. Clean walls and floors and open windows and doors to start the drying process.

Although experts are reluctant to blame the recent floods entirely on global warming, climatic changes in general are giving the Environment Agency more than a little cause for concern. It hopes, with the help of an advertising campaign, that it can persuade householders to take the risk just as seriously.

Insurers: www.abi.org.uk;

Environment Agency: environment-agency.gov.uk the environment agency.gov.uk. For a free information pack, tel: 0845-988-1188.

fields.headline: The wisdom of Salomon
fields.standfirst:
OAE/Brüggen
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
OAE/Brüggen
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Aiming to recreate on period instruments actual concert programmes of the 18th and 19th centuries, the South Bank's Pioneering Orchestras series was launched by one such modern-day ensemble: the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment (OAE).

Though billed as a homage to the famous orchestra of the London impresario Johann Salomon, this first concert turned out to be more of a tribute to Haydn, whom Salomon tempted away from Vienna to London in 1791 to become his very own composer-in-residence. Works by other composers were also on the programme, but those by Haydn consistently came off the best under the thoughtful direction of Frans Brüggen.

Most of these involved only the orchestra, without a soloist to distract attention from BrÙggen's own simple rapport with music of this period. His slight, often hunched figure frequently looked almost still to those behind him, while the smallest movements of his arms conveyed what seemed an inverse amount of guidance and confidence to the players in front. Two of Haydn's "London symphonies", Nos 93 and 100, brought out the best in the orchestra - precise playing, dramatic dynamics and warm, detailed textures.

Brüggen shaped the phrases delicately, drawing crescendos in the opening movement of No 100, mustering their forces as if organically. And there was wit to balance the high drama. In the third movement of the same symphony, he played around mischievously with the tempo of the trio section, letting the snappy violin figures fall down the slope of their melody before bringing them up short. Soprano Lynne Dawson joined the orchestra for Haydn's melodramatic Scena di Berenice. This is a testing piece, and Dawson seemed to flag until the closing phrases, when she nonetheless found enough in reserve to hit her high C squarely.

Her tone was resonant, in her higher range especially, but a certain amount of unevenness put her performance of Mozart's aria Per Pieta at a disadvantage - as did some messy playing from the wind section. The other solo performer was the OAE's lead cellist, David Watkins, in a concerto by Ignaz Pleyel, Haydn's pupil. A contemporary journalist describes how Pleyel was "becoming even more popular than his master; as his works are characterised less by the intricacies of science than the charm of simplicity and feeling". Those last 12 words could have been omitted - Watkins was a persuasive soloist but couldn't change the fact that, although Pleyel wrote enjoyable, charming music, he was no threat to his master in terms of skilful harmonic invention.

The short, sharp shock of the Earthquake from Haydn's Seven Last Words closed the concert, demonstrating the composer's pre-eminence in the face of all pretenders - and proving, again, the wisdom of Salomon.

webTitle: The captivating properties of urban buttocks

fields.headline: The captivating properties of urban buttocks
fields.standfirst:
Urban Bush Women
Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester
*****
fields.trailText:
Urban Bush Women

Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester
*****
fields.body:
These Afro-American girlies don't beat around the bush. They're feisty, funny, strong and sexy and revel in their womanhood, especially all the wobbly bits, which they shake and shimmy with pride.

Hot from New York for Manchester's Re-Flex, Dance of Black Origin festival, the all-dancing, all-singing company gives girl power real meaning, as the performers celebrate the voluptuous pulchitrude of the female form.

The programme veers from strong statements calling for social change, to poignant pieces on personal struggle backed by soaring gospel voices, to a celebration of the love of music to pleas for the homeless, danced to clever, angry lines from poet Hattie Gossett.

But best of all must be Batty Moves, a paean to the female pelvis and the captivating properties of the buttocks. In Jamaica, particularly, your batty is your bottom, and artistic director Jawole Zollar's defiant, triumphal piece appeals to all "big mamas" to accept and proclaim their curves. You won't hear these women asking: "Does my bum look big in this?" It probably does and they don't care.

An infectious mix of ballet, contemporary and African tribal moves, with juddering shoulders to focus on the breasts, and every permutation of gyration imaginable to show off the rear, Batty Moves is introduced by Afro-Cuban Carolina Garcia, a pint-sized powerhouse who fuses Latino rhythms with traditional African steps, wickedly poking fun at thrusting bad girl rappers. The women form a chorus line, T-shirts tied round their waists, and waggle their bums every which way. After being joined by singer Topaz Wise, who makes Rubens's models look undernourished, the women strut their stuff in sassy solos extolling their virtues and vices.

Physically punishing, the choreography switches from fast and flashy to bump-and grind erotic, and the whole thing is one huge girls' night out. We clapped and whooped and ululated and wanted to jump on the stage.

In contrast, Shelter was a sober look at how we could all find ourselves, as the poet put it, between a rock and a hard place. The dancers portray street women who live on squares of cardboard, explode in bursts of desperation, huddle together for comfort and obsessively flick off unseen dirt. The piece is accompanied by sizzling percussion from Michael Wimberly and Wise's huge voice.

Garcia was also superb in the poignant solo Give Your Hands, raging against the machine, her hands clenched in fists of anger, open to soothe and heal, or reaching out to struggle until reposed in final peace.

Final performance tonight. Box office: 0161-907 5278.

webTitle: A moonlit pogo with Eastbourne's finest

fields.headline: A moonlit pogo with Eastbourne's finest
fields.standfirst:
Toploader
Shepherd’s Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Toploader
Shepherd’s Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
Bolshie piano and guitar riffs, big hair and a liberal dose of charm are Toploader's characteristics. The British five-piece offer a raucously chipper antidote to indie miserabilism and, as they swagger onstage to a rapturous reception, it's evident that they're loved for it.

Few other contemporary rockers, aside from America's Ben Folds Five, would put keyboards centre-stage. Not only are they integral to Toploader's music, from crashing bluesy piano effects to spiralling northern soul-style melodies, they also offset the outfit's animated performance. As his bandmates reel and pogo around him, Joseph Washbourn remains seated to sing and play, like some super-funky Joe Jackson. He bashes out tunes with one hand and gesticulates with the other, then leaps to his feet to throttle a tambourine.

Washbourn proudly introduces "the one that got it started for us": the Motown cover Dancing in the Moonlight, which has the crowd punching the air and noisily proving they know the words. Bathed in a mirrorball's swirling illumination, the theatrical setting suddenly resembles some kind of beautiful school disco.

Showcasing much of this year's acclaimed debut album, Onka's Big Moka, Toploader offer upbeat tunes with simple themes, such as Let the People Know, and Just Hold On, laced with Washbourn's powerfully drawling, earnest words of encouragement.

And so sweetly enamoured are they of their native Eastbourne ("the blue-rinse capital of the world"), that they've written a new song about it, This is Our Home.

Rock music can be as formulaic as any bubblegum pop, and there's little deviation from Toploader's retro-flavoured ingredients, even with a couple of ballads and country rock-themed new number Leave Me Be thrown in. That said, these proficient musicians muster a convincing soulfulness that elevates them well above Ocean Colour Scene-style beery singalongs.

By the time they launch into their blustering, strobe-lit finale with Achilles Heel, it's hard to tell who's more excited - the audience or the band themselves.
