webTitle: A day in the life of Linda Mullholland

fields.headline: A day in the life of Linda Mullholland
fields.standfirst:
As the government calls a summit to halt irresponsible lending Tony Levene sees the work being done by money advice workers to limit the damage for borrowers who are in serious trouble

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the government calls a summit to halt irresponsible lending Tony Levene sees the work being done by money advice workers to limit the damage for borrowers who are in serious trouble
fields.body:
Britain's lenders spend, at a conservative estimate, tens of millions persuading people to borrow. But Britain's money advice centres have just a tiny percentage of that sum to deal with the ravages of problem debt: relationship break-ups, bad health, homelessness or suicide.

This week the government hauled in banks, credit card companies and other lenders to a "debt summit" in a bid to call a halt to "irresponsible loans".

The Department of Trade and Industry is concerned at the ease with which credit is made available and the lack of checks on the ability of borrowers to repay. But while the move is welcome, it will do little to ease queues outside money advice centres.

This week, Jobs & Money went to see the reality of Britain's growing debt difficulties, spending a day with money advice worker Linda Mullholland, in Bristol. Linda, 43, is a gamekeeper turned poacher. After her two children were born, she took a part-time job chasing debtors for consumer loan company Welbeck Finance.

"I felt the work was immoral. I spent most of my time after people persuaded into borrowing when they had little hope of repaying if they suffered the slightest mishap. I was told to squeeze blood out of stone," she says.

She started with the Bristol Debt Advice Centre (BDAC) in 1990 as a volunteer. Now she works four days a week.

9.00 am : Her day starts at the BDAC office in run-down Easton - a far cry from the luxury homes in Clifton, waterside warehouse conversions and new financial sector offices that Bristol prefers to show the world.

9.30am: She motors to her destination for the morning's outreach work on a 1940s council estate. Knowle West has the unenviable twin reputations of being the poverty and heroin capital of the south-west. In Knowle West she holds a once a week session in the Filwood Hope drop-in advice centre, a local churches-backed project surrounded by boarded-up shops, a bookie's and a sweetshop where the goods are kept behind security screens.

10.15am: Her first customer is Alison Wilson. Until recently, Alison, husband Jimmy and their three children had been keeping their financial heads above water. Now they owe nearly £7,000, mostly to the Inland Revenue but also to Lloyds-TSB, and consumer loans.

The family's problem stems from self-employed builder Jimmy's back injury. After seven months on a hospital waiting list he had a disc removed. But he is unable to work and may never do so again. Alison is studying to be a nursery nurse but will qualify late next year.

The family lives on £135 per week income support and £35 per week child benefit, a total of £166 a week or £4.74 per person per day. Their rent, community charge and school meals are paid for. They have no savings, so offering to pay a proportion of the debts is impossible.

10.45am: After outlining her problems, Alison says her husband thinks bankruptcy could be a way out. But Linda Mullholland knows the Wilsons cannot afford bankruptcy fees, normally £370, but cut to £250 for those on income support. "There is no point in offering anything, as we have nothing. Going bust would make a fresh start," says Alison.

But Linda warns her that this action would still leave her - as opposed to Jimmy - with bank consumer loan debts. However, she thinks a court would probably order repayment at £1 a month.

The £250 bankruptcy fee is a real stumbling block. But until they can find it, Linda will write to the family's creditors telling them what is likely to happen.

Finance companies will be less likely to waste time and money chasing the Wilsons if they know Jimmy is petitioning for bankruptcy. But Alison is worried about bailliffs. Linda reassures her. She says: "They're not interested in normal furniture or in your broken-down van. Nor will the official receiver waste time and money pursuing you. Just make sure you do not get left money or win the National Lottery."

She tells her about Yorkshire Building Society's Cash Transactor which gives undischarged bankrupts a basic account provided they can find £25.

11.30am: Alison says she feels "a bit happier, a bit lighter. I won't panic if the Inland Revenue sends heavy letters. This service is brilliant - you can never get through on the phone. Our whole life is having to change. But if we can start again, we could make a go."

11.45am: Linda meets Debbie Jones, 23, and eight month son Trent. Debbie has two part-time jobs and her husband, Darren, 29, is in full-time work although recent cut backs have slashed his overtime. They both have bank accounts.

12.00pm: Debbie's big worry is being threatened with a fine for not paying the TV licence. But it is clear there are multiple problems - they owe rent, their working families tax credit book has been impounded for a "scanning check", their phone is cut off, they're behind with water payments and buy gas and electricity expensively through pre-payment meters.

And Linda discovers more "forgotten" debts. They owe Darren's mum £290. They are behind on cash owed to door-to-door lenders Provident Financial and £579 to credit company HFC. The Social Fund is still after Darren for a 1993 debt. He also owes the taxman nearly £3,000 from the same period. Including benefits, the family has £265 a week coming in. They are being threatened with eviction for rent arrears.

12.10pm: Linda phones the council housing department to see how near the family is to losing their home. She fails to find the right official.

12.15pm: Although Debbie is still talking about Christmas and birthday presents, she now realises how serious her position is. "The eviction is the big number one priority. The consumer loans and the Inland Revenue are way down the list," says Linda.

12.30pm: Debbie admits to having only a vague idea of the family's weekly spending. With Linda's help, she draws up a statement of income and expenditure - essential if Linda is to persuade creditors to reduce their demands.

12.45pm: The family could, Linda calculates, afford to pay £25 a week off their loans. She says she will write to tell creditors. She sets up a plan of action but it will cost £50 to remove the eviction warrant from the court. Debbie promises to take cash to the rent office as soon as Darren gets paid. She is told about Easicash, a Post Office plan to help with TV licence arrears. She gets a helpline number if bailiffs appear.

1.30pm: Returns to the office with a sandwich grabbed from behind the security grille at the local baker.

2.00pm: She chases the council again to get Debbie's eviction forestalled.

2.15pm: She starts to work on writing to Alison's creditors - a mix of standard letters and individual pleadings. "I give them 14 days to get back. Otherwise I chase them. One client had 27 creditors. Creditors can be more reasonable if you explain what's happening. They won't want to waste money on unrecoverable debts."

2.45pm: She faxes the benefits agency to get a client on Fuel Direct so gas and electricity payments are paid out of income support.

3.15pm: Linda finally gets through to the council about Debbie's eviction. It is closer than anyone feared. She starts to try to stop it with offers of a firm payment later that week and court action to remove the warrant.

3.45pm: Phones Charter Trust, a hire purchase firm threatening to repossess a car. The client is six months in arrears, amounting to some £840. But the car will fetch little. She hopes an offer of £100 a month will suffice. They promise to get back to her.

4.15pm: Phones a client threatened with eviction by the council. She had already arranged one rescheduling of this debt. The client only has a temporary tenancy, over which the courts have no discretion. So it is down to pleading on her behalf. "She has mental health difficulties. Maybe she paid the money into the wrong account," says Linda.

All client names have been changed

fields.headline: Be afraid - be very afraid
fields.standfirst:
The government hopes to shock us into making provision for old age with statements revealing just how little we will get. Rupert Jones reports.

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government hopes to shock us into making provision for old age with statements revealing just how little we will get.
fields.body:
Tim Stoller, 23, is one of the first people in Britain to get one of the new combined pension statements - and he admits he was "shocked" when he read its contents.

The statements will set out the income people can expect when they retire by giving a combined estimate of both their state pension and private pension provision.

Tim, who works for London radio station Kiss 100, had his statement presented to him by social security minister Jeff Rooker this week. It revealed to him that he is currently on course for a state pension of less than £6,000 a year.

Tim, who earns between £25,000 and £30,000 a year and doesn't belong to the company pension scheme or have a personal pension, says: " I was a bit shocked actually. On the right-hand side it says when I retire, if I retire at 65, I'm going to get about £5,700 a year.

"You don't expect the state to support you but you know there is the state pension and you expect to be able to live off it - but that's something you clearly can't live off."

He adds: "I've always planned to sort out a pension with the company but it was not until then that it made me think I'd better sort it out sooner rather than later."

fields.headline: Shun the student debt hangover
fields.standfirst:
David Smith suggests ways to help tomorrow's graduates to a future without financial burdens.

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, the squeeze started on students when the Conservatives froze grants and introduced student loans. New Labour meant new costs for undergraduates - grants have now disappeared and annual fees add to the financial burden.
fields.body:
Ten years ago, the squeeze started on students when the Conservatives froze grants and introduced student loans. New Labour meant new costs for undergraduates - grants have now disappeared and annual fees add to the financial burden.

While all parents can dream of the proud moment of their child's graduation, the post-graduation debt can be a ball and chain, and one that is likely to grow heavier.

The Association of Investment Trust Companies estimates that a three-year course could now carry a price tag of up to £20,000. Parents who want to pay the bill will have to be wealthy enough to fund annual costs approaching £7,000 or save up while their child is younger. The flexibility, relatively low costs and diversification benefits of investment trusts makes them an excellent way for far-sighted parents to reduce the handicapping effects of student debt.

Since investment trusts typically offer a portfolio of 50 or more companies the investment is likely to grow gradually in line with the stock market rather than at the whim of investors in an individual company's shares.

Their low costs mean the investor gains more of benefits of the investment. And they are flexible enough to allow the investor to decide whether to make a one-off lump-sum payment (perhaps of several thousand pounds) or ongoing regular savings (of perhaps a few hundred pounds a month).

Different investment trust shares have different levels of risk and these can be selected and combined to most efficiently achieve the investment target. For example, zero dividend preference shares of investment trusts offer a very low-risk way to grow capital over a given period of time.

At present an investor who buys a zero can expect to gain an average annual return of perhaps 8%, entirely in the form of capital gains, which can be offset by his or her capital gains tax allowance - investors are allowed to make £7,200 a year in capital gains without tax liability. But since zeros are very low-risk investments the returns are not outstandingly high.

These may suit parents who have a reasonable amount to invest and can achieve their target with modest returns. Or they may suit parents with only a short period until their child heads for academia and who are more interested in growing the amount of money they can provide in support but are unwilling to assume much risk.

Alternatively, for parents with a slightly longer timeframe or those willing to take on slightly more risk, well-diversified global investment trusts might be ideal. Trusts such as Foreign & Colonial and Witan have an enviable record for providing steady and respectable growth over reasonable periods of time without too much risk.

Edinburgh Fund Managers believe that the need for the young people of today to finance their student days plus the lessons in basic personal finance added to the national curriculum will make children more financially astute than their parents. It has a special InvestIT plan aimed at children.

For parents who can make do without spending the child benefit, Edinburgh suggests using it to fund a savings plan.

"Over the long term - and for a young child going eventually to higher education we might be talking 15 years - higher returns could be achieved from investment trusts than bank accounts," says Edinburgh's Lesley Drummond.

"Child benefit is over £60 a month for the first child and is paid until 16 but is extended if the child is still at school or equivalent."

Over 15 years, a £62.40 monthly contribution (the current child benefit for the first child) would have produced £32,443 in the middle of the road Edinburgh Investment Trust - almost double the £17,427 from top-paying building society accounts.

The scheme costs nothing other than stamp duty, although there is an £11.75 fee for withdrawals. It can be stopped without penalty if conditions change - or if investors want to put their money elsewhere.

And the fund managers will set up a trust account free of charge so that the money will be made available when the child reaches university age.

David Smith is investment funds editor at www.citywire.co.uk

Case study: New home for child benefit

Electronics engineer Alan Graham (right) decided to go for a higher risk when he switched the family's child benefit from helping to pay the grocery bill to a long-term investment trust savings plan.

"I sent off for a free booklet on investing for children from Flemings. I liked the idea of their investment trust savings scheme because it was very flexible," says Alan, 44, from Lancaster.

The family's child benefit is worth around £100 a month so Alan has split the money between Jack, six, and Tom, three. "The idea is that I keep saving at this level until they reach 18."

And because Alan, who has shares of his own but no investment trusts, is looking at a minimum of 12 years, he is willing to go up a notch or two up the risk scale by investing in the 250 biggest companies outside the Footsie index.

"I'm hoping that investing £9,000 for each boy over the next decade will turn into £15,000," he says. "If it doubles I'll be really pleased."

webTitle: Somersaulting dialogue at the Royal Court: Exposure (part two)

fields.headline: Somersaulting dialogue at the Royal Court: Exposure (part two)
fields.standfirst:
Drag-On
Royal Court, London
***
fields.trailText:
Drag-On
Royal Court, London
***
fields.body:
Adolescents are apt to surprise their elders with crocus-bursts of talent or cheek, and when they can do it in front of a whole crowd of adults, so much the better. Sixteen-year-old Emmanuel De Nasciemento had a good stab at it in the second part of the Royal Court's young writers' festival.

In his short play Drag-On, the plot - boy meets girl, discovers girl is actually a boy - was carried by the sheer energy and vernacular crispness of the jittery young man Ziggy, played by Johann Myers. There were some vivid touches and great one-liners, such as: "She plays you like a Gameboy." But theatre is an exacting medium, and Ziggy's move in a matter of minutes from young black man seeking pussy to lovestruck, sensitive gay Romeo rang all the wrong bells.

At 23, Arzhang Pezhman, recently graduated from an MA in playwriting at Birmingham, has had longer to hone his skills. Local was a red-blooded creature thrashing with real-life passions and concerns of its own. Set in a Wolverhampton newsagent's, the play focused on Merdod (Raad Rawi), an Iranian immigrant left by his British wife to bring up his son Darius (John Marquez) alone.

Darius was back from college; things had changed. His father's old friend, Ardeshir, had become competitive; Jeff, the alcoholic, racist neighbour, was increasingly abusive; Yas, Ardeshir's daughter, was a sudden new love interest.

Pezhman writes clear-sightedly and dumps the fond illusions of youth for something more gritty. In the first scene, Jeff, played with a well-judged dose of contempt by Alan Williams, bumbled into the newsagent's at five in the morning, demanding whisky.

Darius, a patient type but gradually riled, danced bitterly around him in clever wordplay, leading Jeff to later accuse him of "using my language to get the better of me". With that, he put his finger on the slippery theme of ownership, which glistened rudely at every twist of the play.

Kim and Rob Wilcox (Tricia Kelly and David Armand) were a warm-hearted mother-and-son combo who sprinkled light relief upon situations engulfed by the weight of racial, generational or cultural grievance or bogged down in bouts of ideology and exposition. Mostly, though, the dialogue somersaulted deftly around, showing Pezhman capable of hoisting and sustaining tension around issues as tricky as riots for more than an hour.

The biggest letdown was the ending, which abruptly pulled the curtain on one of the play's main characters without warning. Still, it was a measure of how much the audience cared that the applause was uncertain - as if they did not want the play to have ended.

fields.headline: Bad deals on wheels
fields.trailText: If you're in need of a new buzz-phrase to worry you, how about "car negative equity"? Falling prices should usually raise a cheer from consumers, but it's more likely to be a deep groan if you bought a new car a year or so ago because the sharp decline in new and used car prices could mean that you owe much more on a car loan or on hire-purchase than your car is worth.
fields.body:
If you're in need of a new buzz-phrase to worry you, how about "car negative equity"? Falling prices should usually raise a cheer from consumers, but it's more likely to be a deep groan if you bought a new car a year or so ago because the sharp decline in new and used car prices could mean that you owe much more on a car loan or on hire-purchase than your car is worth.

"Big changes in a marketplace are going to create winners and losers, so if you've just bought a nearly-new car you could have done very well, but if you bought a new car a year ago you could be absolutely stuffed," says Doug McWilliams, chief executive of the Centre for Economic and Business Research.

For instance, if you bought a shiny new Ford Mondeo a year ago it would have cost around £15,000 and now, a year older, the car is worth about £7,500. This sudden price puncture means that if you borrowed to pay for the car you could well be stuck with a fat wedge of negative equity.

Of course, you might not have to sell and could carry on with the repayments, but imagine if the car was stolen or written off in a crash.

That gloomy scenario would see the Mondeo buyer receiving the market value of the car from the insurance, which could be only half the amount still owed on repayments. End result: you still owe thousands on the loan and don't have a car any more.

So if you're a would-be car buyer, tempted by something you've seen at this week's Motor Show in Birmingham, but you're concerned that prices could still fall, what can you do to limit the risk of losses?

In terms of insurance, the Association of British Insurers suggests that you should look for motor insurance which will replace like with like in the first year of a new car's life if it's stolen or written off. This means that even if the value of the car has disappeared in a plume of exhaust smoke the insurance will give you a new car of the same make and model.

But if the car disappears after the first year, you could still be left in the lurch. So it's worth looking at "gap" insurance, a policy in addition to your ordinary car insurance which will reimburse you with the full amount of money that the car cost you, rather than the value of when it's lost.

This type of insurance was once the preserve of fleet buyers, but now it's being offered to consumers as a way of reassuring people worried about loss of value. It's usually sold as a one-off payment, covering a set number of years, and is often sold through car dealerships rather than directly from insurers.

Another financial comfort blanket you might be offered in the showroom is to buy a car using a personal contract purchase or PCP. This is a payment system designed to cut down on the initial outlay, which defers part of the purchase price for a number of years, but it is also being pitched as a reassurance to buyers nervous about price falls.

These schemes provide buyers with deals variously described as "guaranteed equity" or "guaranteed future value", which means that there is a pre-determined value for the car at the end of the agreement which can be used as equity when buying your next car.

If you want to keep the car, you'll have to pay the balance of this pre-arranged valuation - which, if prices fall again, could mean paying above the market rate. There isn't an option to take the cash and the only other alternative is to give the car back to the dealer and walk away with nothing, so this is far from a clear-cut benefit to the anxious buyer.

But what car buyers will most want to know is which way will the price pendulum swing next?

According to Doug McWilliams, the shakedown in prices is going to continue and he forecasts a second round of price reductions next spring. So far, price cutting has encouraged buyers to wait and see - sales were down 7% last month even after the biggest price reductions in years - and he expects this "buyers' strike" to continue to push down prices until the market stabilises in the middle of next year.

This is rejected by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, which says: "People are beginning to realise that prices are not going to get any cheaper." And a spokesman for Volvo, one of many car makers to cut its prices, says that manufacturers "simply can't afford to go any lower".

So if you get your timing right you could end up driving a hard bargain, but if it goes wrong, you could end up on the financial hard shoulder.

Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: It's Jo And Danny
fields.standfirst:
Rocket, Leeds
**
fields.trailText:
Rocket, Leeds
**
fields.body:
Someone has written nasty things about It's Jo And Danny, and they are not best pleased. "We're a 'hippy folk duo', " spits Jo with palpable disgust. For the next eight minutes, the pair do their best to refute the slur. Baggy grooves evoke Primal Scream and the Rolling Stones in their flirting-with-devil-worship period. Jo drinks from the bottle while pounding her electric guitar into the floor.

"Rock'n'roll!" she cries. It's only after the tumult ceases that you notice the bottle contains mineral water. It's true: they are not a duo - singer Jo and bassist Danny are accompanied by a turntable man, a trumpet player and a very unhippyish loud drummer. However, despite their protestations, there is something terminally indie, hippy and indeed drippy about them.

They follow their raucous entrance with the kind of Corrs-like niceness that presumably prompted the insult. They even have a song called Hippy Thinking. Former record company workers disillusioned with the industry, they subsequently proved they can take it on at its own game. Their praised Lank Haired Girl to Bearded Boy album proved that a cottage industry can mix it with the big boys, and they have since obtained heavyweight representation. Now if only they'd apply the same fire to their music.

Instead, seagull noises and the chords from Tim Buckley's Kangaroo can't disguise standard indie fare. The album's grooves make fleeting appearances, but there's something problematic about Jo's Sandy Denny voice. God has intended her to sing folk music, and, however she may fight it, trying to do otherwise is like a nightingale attempting to bark. After a set that lasts just 30 minutes, everybody is sure which one is the Lank Haired Girl and which the Bearded Boy (although he has shaved), but Jo and Danny's musical identity seems confused. Perhaps they should bite the bullet and settle into a long career as a hippy folk duo.

At Bristol Louisana tonight (0117-926 59780); Brighton Pressure Point on Monday (01273 702333); and London Borderline on Tuesday (020-7734 2095).

fields.headline: Stop digging deeper when you're in a financial hole
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mortgages of up to five times the applicant's income; offers of unsecured loans screaming from press, poster and TV ads; new credit card launches whose main target is those who may already hold multiple plastic; remortgages to consolidate owings; second-hand car finance operations targeted at those already deep in money trouble: wherever you look, loans and the temptation to borrow even more are facts of life.
fields.body:
Mortgages of up to five times the applicant's income; offers of unsecured loans screaming from press, poster and TV ads; new credit card launches whose main target is those who may already hold multiple plastic; remortgages to consolidate owings; second-hand car finance operations targeted at those already deep in money trouble: wherever you look, loans and the temptation to borrow even more are facts of life.

Adverts and mailshots suggesting "guaranteed acceptability" for sums often up to £10,000 are part of this easy-credit atmosphere.

Someone earning £20,000 a year - around £1,200 a month after deductions - would pay some £600 a month interest on a home loan of five times salary.

Banks say they only lend to those who have a bright earnings future. But if there is the slightest setback - failure to get promotion, loss of overtime, redundancy, illness, relationship breakdown or death - the borrower could be plunged into money misery.

According to a recent survey from the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, debt and the problems associated with it are increasing dramatically.

Consumers coming to them with difficulties have increased by 16% over the past year and 37% over two years. Local CABs in England and Wales handled more than 500,000 new debt cases in the past year. "This has fuelled fears that people are being encouraged to borrow more than they can afford," says Nacab chief executive David Harker.

He cites:

The 65-year-old man who was sold a £2,600 secured loan which will take 15 years and £14,000 to repay.

A man who borrowed £7,000 and then lost his job. His lender was taken over, the new finance company was tougher and he now owes £39,000.

A 37-year-old man whose £600 credit card debt soared over three years, with interest, to £4,500.

But while the CABs offer free help there are many organisations which earn profits from money problems. Fee-charging debt management companies come in two flavours; those that charge the debtor and those that deduct a percentage from an agreed settlement before handing cash on to the lender.

Hereford-based Brookvale charges debtors "sums according to the work done" for a variety of solutions led by "individual voluntary arrangements" (IVAs).

These allow individuals in financial difficulties a chance to make a formal proposal to agree debts with their creditors within a fixed time period. Typical IVAs, Brookvale claims, "provide light at the end of the tunnel for debtors and a better return for creditors."

Not-for-profit Paylink takes 9% of money raised from debtors. It has teamed up with PayPoint, which collects money owed to utilities and landlords via a corner-shop chain. It has recently set up a swipe card scheme so all creditors can be paid fairly through one pre-agreed amount a month. "This prevents one creditor making demands and getting paid at the expense of others," it says.

With fees swallowing up an average 15% of debtors' cash, many debt counsellors are against charging. There is some evidence that money does not always end up with creditors; that some do not work out which debts are priority and which can be ignored; and few bother about income maximisation, such as applying for state benefits.

"We feel charging is unethical," says Martin Green at the Bristol Debt Advice Centre. "We believe that good quality independent and free money advice is good for both debtors."

National Debtline can be contacted at 0808-808-4000

Adverts and mailshots suggesting "guaranteed acceptability" for sums often up to £10,000 are part of this easy-credit atmosphere. webTitle: Somersaulting dialogue at the Royal Court: Exposure (part one)

fields.headline: Somersaulting dialogue at the Royal Court: Exposure (part one)
fields.standfirst:
Goodbye Roy
Royal Court, London
**
fields.trailText:
Goodbye Roy
Royal Court, London
**
fields.body:
Traditionally an incubator for future playwriting stars - Joe Penhall, Michael Wynne and Rebecca Prichard recently passed through - this year's Royal Court young writers festival opened with two works that demonstrate their writers' promise, but make arduous viewing in their own right. Both fix an unflinching eye on emotional crisis. But they do so by means of characters that too directly confront their crises, giving neither performers nor audience anywhere to hide - or anything to intuit for themselves.

This double bill suggests young writers see theatre as a vehicle for heavyweight drama. They will learn that the ruthlessly stark presentation of that drama and its attendant angst do not alone amount to a satisfying play.

Fifteen-year-old Holly Baxter Baine's Goodbye Roy is about a middle-aged woman, Prya Lal, doomed to repeatedly relive her experience of child abuse. The play flashes from a conversation on the London underground back to the woman's upbringing in India. Designer Liz Cooke's tube-train slats lift to reveal a feebly gurgling geyser, which denotes the agrarian poverty that drives Prya's dad to brutality. The family home is tensely realised in Annabelle Comyn's production, although Antony Zaki struggles to characterise the father as anything other than monstrous.

Tantalising plot points - young Prya is told she's descended from a Scots missionary - are left undeveloped as Goodbye Roy returns to the present and its hysterical conclusion. This is a brave stab at a thorny subject but, by dramatising abuse through the eyes of an adult protagonist, Baxter Baine has made her job doubly difficult.

Twenty-five-year-old Leo Butler's Made of Stone gives guttural voice to the residents of the Sheffield community of Pitsmoor, where the writer grew up. Here, a mother and three sons are processing dad's recent death. Pete is suicidally depressed; loose cannon Miles is incapable of forming relationships; Gary is taking on dead Dad's responsibilities. Butler's premise is engaging enough but, with unsparingly naturalistic dialogue and circuitous pacing, the play develops more like TV than theatre.

The writing also lacks the sensitivity required to solicit our concern for ranting, objectionable Miles (Giles Ford) or sullen Pete (Greg Chisholm). But there are some likeable moments: Chisholm's Pete and Sarah Cattle's Carol handle their offbeat sex scene with comic delicacy; Joanna Bacon is attractively brassy as the tart-with-a-heart mum.

With some merciless editing, it could be a revealing, plainspoken snapshot of a family learning how to move on after bereavement.

fields.headline: Pretty Ugly
fields.standfirst:
Linbury Studio, London
**
fields.trailText:
Linbury Studio, London
**
fields.body:
It may sound as if Amanda Miller named her company in a fit of gruff self-deprecation, but Pretty Ugly was originally the title of a work that Miller made back in 1986. It refers to the extreme contrasts she aims to encompass within her style - pretty, ugly; disco, ballet; old, new; hard, soft.

The piece was made when Miller was still a member of William Forsythe's Frankfurt Ballet, and Forsythe's influence is scattered throughout - not only in the fierce, off-kilter style of classical dance but also in the aggressively gloomy lighting and the abrasiveness of the electronic soundscore.

Miller's own voice emerges though her drastic collision of dance modes and, within the bodies of her five hard-working dancers a range of styles jostle and clamour for dominance. Soaring leg work jolts to a stop as a man pulls a leery grimace; classical footwork segues into tap, and alienated solos resolve into couple dances.

The piece is a marathon for its dancers, and you have to admire the skill and stamina they bring to it. But while Miller is never short of a step, she seems to have no vision of where the material is heading: the dancing just carries on noisily and furiously until the music stops. There is no powerful architecture to contain it, no atmosphere for it to resonate in, and no persuasive underlying rhythm to carry us through.

In the 1997 piece Four for Nothing, which Miller made for her current Freiburg-based company, the stage is filled with lyric, athletic dance in the style of Paul Taylor. Let loose among it, though, is a hyperactive narrator who wanders between the dancers gabbling a stream of facts and quotations. Sometimes he takes refuge in a small orange wigwam in the middle of the floor; sometimes he drags around some extraneous props. Miller gives us old- fashioned dancerly order rubbing up against postmodern disorder but, as in Pretty Ugly, this play of opposites doesn't add up to much that's new.

By far the most impressive work of the evening is Meidosems, a duet set to music for prepared piano by John Cage. The score has a sibylline oriental quality, which Miller wonderfully re-creates in her movement, especially the choreography for the female role (performed by ex-Royal Ballet dancer Deborah Jones).

Within a virtuoso sweep of dance, Jones articulates exquisite calligraphic detail, odd serendipitous gestures, and a kind of crabbed, archaic style of footwork.

It's a genuinely thrilling chemistry between choreographer and performer, and it makes the work seem huge. In this work, at least, Miller makes dance that is far more than the sum of its parts.

fields.headline: McLean charged by police
fields.trailText: The former Dundee United chairman Jim McLean has been charged by the police over an alleged assault last weekend.
fields.body:
The former Dundee United chairman Jim McLean has been charged by the police over an alleged assault on the BBC television reporter John Barnes last weekend.

McLean quit the club and apologised to Barnes the following day. But Tayside police have charged him over the alleged incident, which came during an interview after the 4-0 home defeat by Hearts. McLean will also be the subject of a report to the procurator fiscal in Dundee.

Emerson Leao, who is Brazil's fifth most capped player but has won few titles in his 13 years as a manager, was yesterday appointed coach of Brazil's national side.

The 51-year-old former goalkeeper, currently with Sport of Recife, took the job after it was refused by several top coaches including Carlos Alberto Parreira, who coached the 1994 World Cup-winning side.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: English clubs are good enough to dominate Europe again

fields.headline: English clubs are good enough to dominate Europe again
fields.trailText: How good it is to see our teams on top of their groups in the Champions League. Watch out Europe - our sides are at last getting back into the pre-Heysel groove.
fields.body:
Results this week have confirmed my view that Arsenal or Manchester United can win the Champions League. And how pleasing it is to see the three Premiership representatives on top of their groups this morning.

Since the Champions League took in more than just the title winners in 1997, one English side has fallen at the first hurdle each season. First it was Newcastle, then Arsenal two years running.

Now Arsène Wenger's team are in the next round, Manchester United will surely join them, and there's a real chance that Leeds will make it through. I feel our sides are getting back into the pre-Heysel groove.

English clubs dominated Europe from the late 70s until the ban in 1985. Of the nine European Cups from 1977 to that awful night in Brussels, our sides won seven of them and reached the final of another. The more we play again, the more I can see us being successful.

United showed it can take a couple of seasons to find your feet in Europe. Experience certainly helps, but I don't think tactically our sides have too much to learn. More important may be respect, and by that I mean not over-respecting opponents. Gilles Grimandi said this week that Arsenal might have been guilty of that in the past.

If a player has an 'o' at the end of his name everybody thinks he can do all sorts of ball-juggling tricks and beat the world. The fact is that our players compare very favourably with some of the so-called best.

That's why Leeds's win at home to Milan was such a catalyst for them. They came off and realised Milan weren't all magicians who were far superior to them. They knew if they stuck to their game and hunted and hassled they could do well, and they've gone on from there.

I thought Leeds might struggle for depth and experience, particularly with all their injuries, and Barcelona at home next Tuesday will not be easy. But if they're lively and sharp and don't show too much respect, I won't be surprised if they win. Barca are just as capable of rank bad defending as wonderful football.

Leeds, like Arsenal and Manchester United, play the right way. You can't go into Europe and play long-ball stuff because if you don't retain possession teams will pick you off. But that doesn't call for a slow-tempo game. One- or two-touch quick passing is effective, as United have proved, and all three can do that.

Leeds's visit to Besiktas brought back memories of my first European tie, a Uefa Cup game with West Brom against Galatasaray in 1978. We went to Izmir because Galatasaray had been banned from playing in Istanbul, and we stayed in the worst hotel imaginable.

It had no restaurant and was so bad that the night before the match I took the boys out to a bar by the port and said: "You're not going back to that dump too early, stop here and have a couple of lagers."

We had a meal at a roadside cafe and the day before the match I took them to the local swimming baths and we had a gala. The team enjoyed that sort of thing and we won 3-1.

Manchester United's victory over PSV by the same score leaves them in a strong position. You'd expect them to be in the shake-up and I've had a sneaking fancy for Arsenal for a couple of years. They now look equipped to go a long way.

Against Lazio they made players such as Juan Veron and Marcelo Salas look very ordinary. Patrick Vieira is one of the world's most complete midfielders and they're a resolute team with explosive players.

The main worry for them would be David Seaman's fitness if Alex Manninger is out, whether they've got enough central defensive cover and whether Grimandi gets a long ban for his clash with Diego Simeone. He was excellent in Rome and of course he can play centre-half.

As for United, the obvious question is whether their defence is strong enough. They'll want Jaap Stam back and if they don't cave in they can win anywhere. They've got arguably the world's best midfield and can always put on strikers who will score.

It was as United manager in 1984 that I enjoyed one of my best European nights, beating Diego Maradona's Barcelona 3-0 at Old Trafford to reach the Cup Winners' Cup semi-final having lost the first leg 2-0. Sadly Juventus beat us 3-2 on aggregate in the semi, winning with the last kick in Turin. I sense there will be better luck for our Champions League teams this season.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Thorpe pads up with a point to prove

fields.headline: Thorpe pads up with a point to prove
fields.standfirst: Paul Weaver  in Karachi reveals Pakistan pitches hold no terror for Surrey maverick
fields.trailText: Graham Thorpe has much to prove this winter. Paul Weaver talks to him about playing the Pakistan pitches and facing the off-spin of Saqlain Mushtaq.
fields.body:
Graham Thorpe concedes that if he were a professional footballer - and he was good enough to represent England Schools Under-18s - he would probably disappear in a flurry of red cards.

If he were a bowler, he maintains rather wistfully, he would probably get into trouble for abusing opponents. His introversion, he insists, is partly professional: batsmen are meant to be self-contained and poker-faced.

There are people, however, and people who should know him well, for whom this appears a rather glib explanation; they have questioned his attitude.

Mike Gatting, when a Test selector, said Thorpe "brought nothing to the table bar runs". And last year the former England coach David Lloyd used words such as "surly", "divisive" and "nonconformist" to describe the man who, for most of the 90s, was England's premier middle- order batsman.

This is also the man who was fined by the England management for not turning up at a pre-World Cup bash for Kent members, who has not always observed the team dress code and was one of those criticised for adopting a negative attitude when England toured Zimbabwe in 1996-97. He chose not to tour last winter and was not awarded a central contract last year.

Then there is his playing record. It started brilliantly, with an unbeaten century on his Test debut against Australia at Trent Bridge. But it is now two years since his latest Test fifty. In 1999 he scored only 93 in six knocks against New Zealand and last year his best was 46 against West Indies.

So in Pakistan and Sri Lanka this winter he has much to prove. On the field and off it. Off it he could scarcely look more relaxed, whether he is lounging in the pool or playing table tennis with team-mates who, incidentally, swear by him rather than at him.

"I feel completely different," he said. "My whole attitude towards the game has changed. The pressures I used to feel within the game are not as big as they used to be. I don't have a fear of failing and because I've been away from the England side I know that my life away from cricket is going along quite nicely.

"I am still dependent on the game financially, but not emotionally. I felt a couple of years ago that I was playing big cricket, big cricket non-stop. Some of the enjoyment went out of it. But that is no longer the case. And I'm aware of the fact that I'm 31 and want to win as much as I can."

He feels hopeful about matters on the field too. "The decks are pretty good out here. We were here four years ago for the World Cup so we know a little bit about the conditions. Basically, the pitches don't seam. Maybe a little bit in the morning.

"There is the problem of reverse swing to negotiate. I am trying to open my stance a little so I don't find my front pad planted down the middle of the pitch and have to play round it. I am trying to play more of the ball. The thing is, Pakistan are firm favourites and they have this extremely talented attack with great variation. When you're up against that quality you're never really in."

He refused to answer the real question: how do you play Saqlain Mushtaq, one of the world's two leading off-spinners, whose repertoire also includes a fierce leggie which he unleashes with no discernible change in action. After all, Thorpe and Saqlain have shared the dressing room at the Oval since 1997.

"He averages about 14 runs a wicket for us and I'm full of admiration. But I'm not going to say whether I can pick him or not. Even if I could, picking a bowler and playing him are two different things.

"There are batsmen who say they can pick Shane Warne's flipper but who still get into trouble against it. If I said I can play Saqlain and then put my foot in it first ball I would look very foolish. So I'm saying nothing, except that we will discuss him before the matches.

"He's one of those who make the game look very easy. He plays it the way I might play club cricket. We all feel very proud of him at Surrey." Dangerously for England, Pakistan feel proud of Saqlain too.

I am trying to play more of the ball. The thing is, Pakistan are firm favourites and they have this extremely talented attack with great variation. When you're up against that quality you're never really in." After all, Thorpe and Saqlain have shared the dressing room at the Oval since 1997. "He averages about 14 runs a wicket for us and I'm full of admiration. But I'm not going to say whether I can pick him or not. Even if I could, picking a bowler and playing him are two different things. "There are batsmen who say they can pick Shane Warne's flipper but who still get into trouble against it. If I said I can play Saqlain and then put my foot in it first ball I would look very foolish. So I'm saying nothing, except that we will discuss him before the matches. "He's one of those who make the game look very easy. He plays it the way I might play club cricket. webTitle: Flintoff's England future put in doubt

fields.headline: Flintoff's England future put in doubt
fields.trailText: Andrew Flintoff's future as a Test all-rounder is in doubt after it was announced he will play no Test cricket this winter due to a recurrence of his spinal problems .
fields.body:
Andrew Flintoff's future as a Test all-rounder looks bleaker than ever with the news that he will return to England after the one-day series against Pakistan and play no Test cricket this winter.

The Lancashire player is suffering from a recurrence of his spinal problems and has been unable to meet the management's pre-tour condition that he must be fit enough to bowl in the three-Test series against Pakistan. He will be replaced by Surrey's Alex Tudor.

Flintoff, 22, may be back in England colours after Christmas for the one-day matches in Sri Lanka but will not be considered for the three Test matches in that country.

He bowled in the nets here on Tuesday but, because of that, was unable to bowl on Wednesday or yesterday. The management made their decision at a meeting at the team hotel on Wednesday evening.

The coach Duncan Fletcher, who in the past has been disappointed with the player's attitude and weight problems, made it clear that the decision to send him home was based on fitness alone.

"He's pretty disappointed," Fletcher said. "But he knew all along that he would have to be able to bowl. Every cricket side is looking for an all-rounder and England have been looking for some time. Freddie would have been a very effective all-rounder.

"He now faces a very difficult decision. Does he have an operation? Or does he leave it, in which case it might be two or three years before he can bowl again? If you don't bowl for that length of time you lose a lot of experience.

"I think, in time, he could be a very good batter. I just think sometimes he gets confused how to play the game. He's such an exciting player; he can take any attack apart. But he doesn't know when to defend and when to attack."

Flintoff's problem has baffled specialists, more of whom he will meet on his return to England. He is suffering the symptoms of a stress fracture but there is no stress fracture per se . When he bowls he suffers pain in his lower back, on the left side of his spine.

"For such a young man there are parts of his spine that are very weak and worn," says Dean Conway, the tour physio. "There is scar tissue and some evidence of stress fractures when he was 16 or 17. The trouble is there is nothing clear-cut. He has had injections and now maybe there is a case for surgery. But I still think we could one day have him running in as he did in South Africa last winter."

Flintoff was the last England cricketer to be handed the poisoned chalice that identified him as the successor to Ian Botham. He was never going to fill those oversized boots but his potential, like his size, is immense. He is a spectacular striker of a cricket ball and, when fit, can generate real pace from a short run-up.

For brute strength he is more than a match for Botham. But the skill will probably never measure up, and the fitness and stamina certainly never will.

Flintoff made his Test debut in the 1998 home series against South Africa and scored a half-century on his one-day international debut, against Pakistan in Sharjah the following year. Last winter he played in England's first four Tests in South Africa but was flown home after suffering a stress fracture of the left foot during the Cape Town Test.

He appeared in the first three Tests of this summer before more back trouble caused him to miss the remaining Tests, and he played as a specialist batsman in the inaugural NatWest Series.

Last summer, however, it was an injury to his pride which he found most painful. The England management, disappointed by his easy-going attitude, revealed that he weighed 17st 12lb - heavier than Lennox Lewis. His England team-mates called him FS, standing for Fat Slogger. And even when he played well he was greeted by such tabloid headlines as "Praise the Lard".

Since then he has trained well and lost weight. The fat-boy jokes have dried up. This morning there is something more serious to discuss. A considerable talent has reached a career crisis point.

 Pakistan's squad for Tuesday's first one-day international against England includes four spinners - Shahid Afridi, Mushtaq Ahmed, Shoaib Malik and Saqlain Mushtaq - but there is no place for the experienced batsman Ijaz Ahmed.

Pakistan squad: Moin Khan (capt), Inzamam-ul-Haq, Saeed Anwar, Salim Elahi, Imran Nazir, Shahid Afridi, Yousuf Youhana, Faisal Iqbal, Wasim Akram, Waqar Younis, Abdur Razzaq, Azhar Mahmood, Saqlain Mushtaq, Mushtaq Ahmad, Shoaib Malik.

webTitle: Rebels deal blow to Welsh coalition

fields.headline: Rebels deal blow to Welsh coalition
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: Labour's hopes of achieving a period of stability in the Welsh assembly after its coalition deal with the Liberal Democrats suffered an embarrassing early blow yesterday when the party's official candidate was defeated in a secret ballot for the post of deputy presiding officer.
fields.body:
Labour's hopes of achieving a period of stability in the Welsh assembly after its coalition deal with the Liberal Democrats suffered an embarrassing early blow yesterday when the party's official candidate was defeated in a secret ballot for the post of deputy presiding officer.

A handful of rebel Labour assembly members joined forces with Plaid Cymru and the Conservatives to elect the maverick Labour MP and AM John Marek.

Dr Marek, who was proposed for the job by Plaid Cymru and the Tories, was elected by 28 votes to 27, narrowly defeating his fellow Labour AM Rosemary Butler, who lost her job as education secretary in this week's cabinet reshuffle. It is thought that at least four Labour AMs voted for Dr Marek.

The Labour first minister, Rhodri Morgan, said he was not surprised at an "unholy alliance of Tories and nationalists". But he regretted that some Labour AMs had supported them. It is not clear whether Dr Marek will face disciplinary action by the Labour group for allowing his name to go forward against the group's nominated candidate.

The Tory group leader, Nick Bourne, said the vote was a "massive blow" to the first minister. He said Mr Morgan had attempted to impose his choice and the move had backfired.

fields.headline: Nurses' leader to quit
fields.standfirst: Veteran nurses' leader to quit RCN for foreign role
fields.trailText: Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, has told staff she will leave early next summer the post she has held since 1989.
fields.body:
Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, has told staff she will leave early next summer the post she has held since 1989.

Ms Hancock's departure follows her nomination for election as president of the International Council of Nurses, which involves extensive foreign travel and is regarded as incompatible with her role at the RCN.

She was the sole nominee for the position, which she will formally assume in June.

Ms Hancock is credited with modernising the RCN and promoting the role of nurses, who have been given a leading part in NHS reforms.

Nurse practitioners have been brought in with almost equivalent functions to GPs. Ward sisters have been given budgets for refurbishments.

At the RCN's annual general meeting on Wednesday the leadership won a vote on extending membership to some healthcare assistants. The victory is seen as a feather in Ms Hancock's cap.

She was personally associated with the decision to tear up the RCN's no-strike rule in 1995, though the college has not taken any industrial action.

fields.headline: Pluto dogs Reuters
fields.standfirst: With its internet floats in doubt and a sticky industrial tribunal coming up, Reuters could do without the potentially negative influence of Pluto, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.trailText: October 20: Pluto's subterranean influence isn't good news for Reuters, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Ever since the evolution from Baron von Reuter's carrier pigeons to telegraphy, Reuters (registered February 20 1865) has pioneered information technology, well shown at its birth in a brilliant combination involving Mercury, planet of trade and communication, and high-tech Uranus. In this game marking time is not an option, and the race is on to create the IT landscape for next generation of cyber-capitalism.

Reuters is in pole position, but there are clouds on the horizon. The float of its successful internet start-up investment arm, Greenhouse, has been shelved because of the weakness in e-stocks. Its other projected float, the Instinet trading platform, is also in doubt.

These wobbles appear to be a symptom of the subterranean action of the underworld planet, Pluto. The current Jupiter-Pluto opposition has been making a series of hits across the finance axis of the Reuters chart. November 13 is a key date, and it would be no surprise if this precipitated the Instinet float.

Pluto has dragged something unpleasant into the light and, although it seems small enough now, it points to problems next spring.

Reuters faces an industrial tribunal claim by former senior employees, Kim Usher and Jonathan Birt, accusing it of constructive dismissal, sexual discrimination and bullying. CEO Peter Job is alleged to have talked of women in management as "adding a bit of spice to the pie". The day set for the tribunal, May 1, has the sun exactly on the organisation's Pluto, suggesting unwelcome light on shady places.

It looks likely that former editor-in-chief (now managing director, Reuters Content), Mark Wood will give evidence against his boss and, quite apart from the facts of the case, this manifestation of internecine strife is the worst possible image to project. Among several tough indications, Job (July 13 1941) is in the middle of his second Saturn return, and this planet can be a grim reaper of high ambitions.

He would be advised to seek a rapid closure to this saga, or he may soon be closing a chapter with Reuters.

fields.headline: Voting where it counts
fields.standfirst: Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk
fields.trailText: Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk
fields.body:
The background to Scottish Labour's convulsions after Donald Dewar's death is the fact the Labour party no longer has sole control of executive government in Edinburgh or Cardiff, where a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition is being formed.

Looked at from London, this must look worrying. The personal contacts and friendships that would help ensure that devolution did not bring about dangerous division are no longer reliably in place. But viewed from Edinburgh and Cardiff, the picture looks very different.

Labour may have introduced devolution but it has had difficulty profiting from it. The party performed poorly in the first devolution elections. In Scotland its 34% share of the party list vote was lower than in any Westminster election since 1931. In Wales, its 35% share broke records as far back as 1918.

This was not some mid-term protest reaction to the performance and policies of the Blair government. In both Scotland and Wales more people thought things had improved since Labour had come to power than thought they had got worse, at least as far as living standards, education and unemployment were concerned. Whatever people thought of the record of the government seemed to make little difference to whether or not they remained loyal to Labour in their new national elections.

Labour's difficulties lay elsewhere. People who were still willing to vote Labour for Westminster proved reluctant to back the party when it came to the Scottish or Welsh contests. Many opted for the nationalists instead.

In Scotland, Labour's share of the vote was no less than 9% adrift of what it would have secured in a Westminster election. In Wales, the equivalent figure was as much as 13%. Without this devolution gap Labour would have done pretty much as well as it had in 1997. There would be no need of a coalition in Wales and maybe not even in Scotland.

Meanwhile, the nationalists rode high. In Scotland they were 7% better off than they would have been in a Westminster byelection. In Wales they were no less than 17% ahead. Without the devolution gap, the "quiet earthquake" experienced in last year's Welsh election would not have registered on the Richter scale at all.

Nothing that Labour has done in the first year of devo lution has closed the devolution gap. For example, the most recent Scottish poll puts Labour and the Scottish National party (SNP) even stevens when it came to people's intentions on voting for the House of Commons, but no less than 14% behind in the race for the Scottish parliament.

So what accounts for the devolution gap? Why did voters who would not consider voting nationalist in a Westminster election do so when it came to the devolved elections?

Unsurprisingly, perhaps, many voters in Scotland and Wales are doubtful about how far London looks after them. In both countries no more than one in three believes that the UK government works in their country's best long-term interests "just about always" or "most of the time". So when invited to elect a parliament for Scotland and an assembly for Wales, many were looking for a party that would use the new institutions to redress the balance.

Many doubted Labour fitted the bill. Just 40% of people in Scotland trust Labour to look after their interests. In Wales, the equivalent figure is 44%. In contrast 68% in Scotland trust the SNP to look after Scots' interests and in Wales 82% say the same of Plaid Cymru.

And it was these perceptions that brought new votes into the nationalist camp. Our research looked at those who said they would not have voted nationalist in a Westminster election who actually did so in last year's devolved election, broken down by the level of trust they had in the ability of various institutions to advance Scottish/Welsh interests. We found voters who were distrustful of the UK government in general and of New Labour in particular were more likely to switch to the nationalists. In Scotland, it was the former perception that was the more important while in Wales it was the latter - a reflection, perhaps, of the particular opprobrium Labour heaped upon itself by attempting to block Rhodri Morgan's progress towards leadership of the Welsh assembly. Voters were even more likely to switch if at the same time they trusted the SNP or Plaid Cymru (as most of them did).

The Scottish and Welsh Labour parties themselves were unable to escape from the long shadow cast by New Labour at Westminster. Voters did take a more charitable view when they were asked whether Scottish or Welsh Labour looked after the interests of people in their country. As the chart shows, substantially more trusted their national Labour parties over Labour at large.

But these perceptions were unable to stem the tide to the nationalists, which proved equally strong among those who trusted the Scottish or Welsh Labour parties as among those who did not.

The lesson for Labour in both Scotland and Wales is clear. Voters want those running their new institutions to advance their interests. If they are not to conclude that only the nationalists will do so, then Labour needs to show it can do things differently in Scotland and Wales than in London. Preserving the United Kingdom's unions means allowing the devolution child to grow up, not keeping it tied to its umbilical cord.

John Curtice is deputy director of the Economic and Social Research Council's Centre for research into elections and social trends.

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk

webTitle: Two enter contest to succeed Dewar

fields.headline: Two enter contest to succeed Dewar
fields.trailText: The battle to become the first minister of Scotland started yesterday, just a day after Donald Dewar's funeral, as two Scottish cabinet ministers declared their intention to stand.
fields.body:
The battle to become the first minister of Scotland started yesterday, just a day after Donald Dewar's funeral, as two Scottish cabinet ministers declared their intention to stand.

The contest will be as brief as it has come swiftly: the finance minister, Jack McConnell, and the enterprise minister, Henry McLeish, have until tomorrow to garner support for their campaigns.

In a controversial move, Labour has put its usual election rules to one side and set up a fast-track procedure to elect an interim leader on Saturday. The winner will be nominated as first minister.

Under the terms of the Scotland Act, a new first minister must be in place by November 7. Labour says its usual electoral college system - comprising MSPs, unions and the party's executive - cannot provide a candidate in time.

The party intends to follow up tomorrow's vote with a full election later in the year. But it is understood that whoever wins a majority from the 54 MSPs and 27 executive members who will vote in Stirling this weekend will stand unopposed in the full election.

The move has led to backbench claims that Labour is trying to bypass democracy.

The Scottish National party leader, John Swinney, said: "Labour's apparatchiks are dodging a real leadership con test and cutting their ordinary members out of the process."

In the days after Mr Dewar's death, supporters of Mr McLeish, 52, launched a campaign to have him appointed without opposition. The move played badly with backbench MSPs and Mr McConnell, 40, has refused not to stand.

Mr McLeish, the MSP for Fife Central, is the favourite to win tomorrow's vote. Supporters claim he has the backing of every Scottish cabinet minister and many of their deputies.

The swift contest may, however, benefit Mr McConnell, MSP for Motherwell and Wishaw. Some backbenchers are annoyed at what they see as an attempt to deny them a vote. Mr McConnell is also said to have less support among the full electoral college than Mr McLeish.

Mr McLeish, a former professional footballer, helped Mr Dewar steer through Westminster the legislation which created the Scottish parliament. He is the most experienced minister and has a long-held desire to be first minister.

He is believed to be the favoured choice of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, but a perceived reticence to enter political tussles when things are going wrong for Labour may play badly for him among the backbenchers.

Launching his campaign, he said: "This is a time when unity, experienced leadership and solidity of purpose will be needed most of all."

Mr McConnell is a former general secretary of the Scottish Labour party, but is relatively untested as a minister.

His supporters say he is a talented backroom fixer and he might take the Scottish party on a more radical path than Mr McLeish.

webTitle: A battle for personalities and not brave hearts

fields.headline: A battle for personalities and not brave hearts
fields.standfirst: As the Scottish Labour party prepares to elect its new leader, Scotland correspondent Gerard Seenan looks at the candidates - and what they're fighting for
fields.trailText: As the Scottish Labour party prepares to elect its new leader, Scotland correspondent Gerard Seenan looks at the candidates - and what they're fighting for
fields.body:
The battle to become leader of the Scottish Labour party and Scottish first minister is a very strange sort of contest. We have two candidates who are fighting it out for the chance to offer almost exactly the same thing.

They claim, of course, that this is a not a personality contest: not a choice between stable-but-boring Henry McLeish and radical-but-inexperienced Jack McConnell.

But never have two leadership candidates been more tied by the actions of their predecessor.

For, north of the border, there is a very different sort of politics going on. The first coalition government on mainland Britain since the second world war sees to that - and it will ensure also that, whoever wins tomorrow will continue on the rigid path laid down by Donald Dewar.

When, in the late 1990s, Labour agreed to demands from the Liberal Democrat and Scottish National parties for proportional representation for the Scottish parliament elections, they showed more than a degree of political generosity.

The political map of Scotland has, since the 1950s, been almost uniformly red. But, under PR, that could only change.

So, in May 1999, it was no surprise when Labour did not win an overall majority in the Scottish parliament.

They needed the help of the Lib Dems; and the Lib Dems were happy to taste power again after so long a drought.

In sessions that lasted long in to the night, the two parties drew up a detailed framework for coalition government. That coalition agreement all but dots the i's and crosses the t's of every policy until the next elections.

Whoever wins the battle to become leader of Scottish Labour will have to abide by it - or the coalition will fall.

To the winner may go the spoils, but there is precious little they can do with them.

So the contest is not so much a battle for the present, but for the future.

Mr McLeish is tried and tested: 13 years as an MP, a former Westminster minister, the favoured candidate of the Chancellor, Gordon Brown (who represents Downing Street's thinking on all matters Scottish).

He will steer a competent but dull Scottish parliament.

Then there is Mr McConnell. More combative, better at bashing the Nats, inexperienced, a good backroom fixer, and the man who seems to be galvanising the support of the backbenches.

He may take the parliament on a more radical agenda in coming years and show that devolution can fashion very different countries within the UK.

But all that's the future: for the present it's apple pie policies with a large dollop of personality on the side.

webTitle: Politics: Labour loses control in the regions

fields.headline: Voting where it counts
fields.standfirst: Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk
fields.trailText: 20 October, analysis: Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk.
fields.body:
The background to Scottish Labour's convulsions after Donald Dewar's death is the fact the Labour party no longer has sole control of executive government in Edinburgh or Cardiff, where a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition is being formed.

Looked at from London, this must look worrying. The personal contacts and friendships that would help ensure that devolution did not bring about dangerous division are no longer reliably in place. But viewed from Edinburgh and Cardiff, the picture looks very different.

Labour may have introduced devolution but it has had difficulty profiting from it. The party performed poorly in the first devolution elections. In Scotland its 34% share of the party list vote was lower than in any Westminster election since 1931. In Wales, its 35% share broke records as far back as 1918.

This was not some mid-term protest reaction to the performance and policies of the Blair government. In both Scotland and Wales more people thought things had improved since Labour had come to power than thought they had got worse, at least as far as living standards, education and unemployment were concerned. Whatever people thought of the record of the government seemed to make little difference to whether or not they remained loyal to Labour in their new national elections.

Labour's difficulties lay elsewhere. People who were still willing to vote Labour for Westminster proved reluctant to back the party when it came to the Scottish or Welsh contests. Many opted for the nationalists instead.

In Scotland, Labour's share of the vote was no less than 9% adrift of what it would have secured in a Westminster election. In Wales, the equivalent figure was as much as 13%. Without this devolution gap Labour would have done pretty much as well as it had in 1997. There would be no need of a coalition in Wales and maybe not even in Scotland.

Meanwhile, the nationalists rode high. In Scotland they were 7% better off than they would have been in a Westminster byelection. In Wales they were no less than 17% ahead. Without the devolution gap, the "quiet earthquake" experienced in last year's Welsh election would not have registered on the Richter scale at all.

Nothing that Labour has done in the first year of devolution has closed the devolution gap. For example, the most recent Scottish poll puts Labour and the Scottish National party (SNP) even stevens when it came to people's intentions on voting for the House of Commons, but no less than 14% behind in the race for the Scottish parliament.

So what accounts for the devolution gap? Why did voters who would not consider voting nationalist in a Westminster election do so when it came to the devolved elections?

Unsurprisingly, perhaps, many voters in Scotland and Wales are doubtful about how far London looks after them. In both countries no more than one in three believes that the UK government works in their country's best long-term interests "just about always" or "most of the time". So when invited to elect a parliament for Scotland and an assembly for Wales, many were looking for a party that would use the new institutions to redress the balance.

Many doubted Labour fitted the bill. Just 40% of people in Scotland trust Labour to look after their interests. In Wales, the equivalent figure is 44%. In contrast 68% in Scotland trust the SNP to look after Scots' interests and in Wales 82% say the same of Plaid Cymru.

And it was these perceptions that brought new votes into the nationalist camp. Our research looked at those who said they would not have voted nationalist in a Westminster election who actually did so in last year's devolved election, broken down by the level of trust they had in the ability of various institutions to advance Scottish/Welsh interests.

We found voters who were distrustful of the UK government in general and of New Labour in particular were more likely to switch to the nationalists. In Scotland, it was the former perception that was the more important while in Wales it was the latter - a reflection, perhaps, of the particular opprobrium Labour heaped upon itself by attempting to block Rhodri Morgan's progress towards leadership of the Welsh assembly. Voters were even more likely to switch if at the same time they trusted the SNP or Plaid Cymru (as most of them did).

The Scottish and Welsh Labour parties themselves were unable to escape from the long shadow cast by New Labour at Westminster. Voters did take a more charitable view when they were asked whether Scottish or Welsh Labour looked after the interests of people in their country. As the chart shows, substantially more trusted their national Labour parties over Labour at large.

But these perceptions were unable to stem the tide to the nationalists, which proved equally strong among those who trusted the Scottish or Welsh Labour parties as among those who did not.

The lesson for Labour in both Scotland and Wales is clear. Voters want those running their new institutions to advance their interests. If they are not to conclude that only the nationalists will do so, then Labour needs to show it can do things differently in Scotland and Wales than in London. Preserving the United Kingdom's unions means allowing the devolution child to grow up, not keeping it tied to its umbilical cord.

 John Curtice is deputy director of the Economic and Social Research Council's Centre for research into elections and social trends.

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk
