The jingle for the Gillette commercial claimed that the new twin-blade swivel head with lubrastrip was "the best a man can get". I thought that this was a pretty bold claim for a disposable plastic razor. A new Ferrari maybe or a night in bed with Pamela Anderson might arguably have the edge for most men, but not according to this singer, no, give him a good shave any day of the week. Then The Apartment came back on and I thought, No, this is the best a man can get: just being tucked up warm and cosy, watching a great film with tea and toast and nothing at all to worry about. When people asked me what I did I generally mumbled that I was "in advertising". I used to say that I was a composer or a musician, but I found this prompted a level of fascination that wasn't fulfilled when they discovered this meant I'd written the music for the Mr Gearbox ad on Capital Radio. I was a freelance jingle writer - although other people in the business were too pretentious to call them jingles - working at the bottom end of the freelance jingle-writing market. If the man who composed "Gillette! The best a man can get!" was the advertising equivalent of Paul McCartney, that made me the drummer for the band that came fifth in last year's Song for Europe. People always presume there's lots of money in advertising, but I was beginning to sense that I was never going to make a fortune writing twenty-second radio jingles, even if I took it upon myself to start working an eight-hour day. There had been a time in my life when I'd really believed I was going to be a millionaire rock star. When I'd left music college I had returned to my home town and formed a group that played in pubs and at university summer balls. Call me immodest, but I think I can honestly say there was a point in the late Eighties when we were the biggest band in Godalming. Then it all fell apart when our drummer left the group because of "musical differences". We were musical, he wasn't. Despite being the crappiest drummer I'd ever heard, he had been the most important member of the band because he had been the one with the van. I found you couldn't fit many amplifiers on a moped. After that highpoint I had carried on recording songs and trying to form bands, but now all I had to show for those years was a box of demo tapes and one precious copy of my flexi-disc single. I got out of bed and played this track again as I got dressed. I was still proud of it, and had never quite forgiven John Peel's producer for saying they didn't play flexi-discs. The journey to my place of work involved walking from one side of my bedroom to the other. Before I started I generally preferred to convert the room from bedroom to studio, which involved transforming my bed back into a sofa and removing any socks or underpants that I had left on top of my keyboard. As well as my Roland XP-60, the recording studio side of my room contained a computer, an eighteen-channel mixing desk, a sampler, a reverb unit, a midi-box, several redundant sound modules, amplifiers and tape decks and, behind it all, seven and a half miles of intertwined electrical cable. If you knew nothing at all about music I suppose all this gear might look quite impressive, but the reality was far more chaotic. The more equipment I acquired, the longer I had to search every time a mystery buzz made it impossible to do any work. Generally I relied upon the keyboard, with its built-in sound module and my multi-talented sampler, which would gamely have a stab at the noise produced by most musical instruments. Although there appeared to be a lot of state-of-the-art technology on display, the stuff was either several years out of date or would be by the time I'd worked out how to use it. Because I'd never got round to reading the manuals I was like the owner of a Ferrari who only drove around in first gear. I lumbered into the bathroom and stared in the mirror. During the night the grey strands on the side of my head had fought their way to the front and a whole swathe of hair above my ears had acquired a silvery sheen. Those of the wiry grey variety were thicker and stronger than the wispy dark hairs they were gradually replacing. The greys were still in a minority, but I knew that, like the squirrels of the same depressing colour, once a few had got a foothold eventually all the indigenous hair would be pushed to the brink of extinction, with maybe a couple of breeding colonies remaining on either eyebrow and perhaps a few shy black hairs that would occasionally be spotted peeking out of my nostrils. On the side of my nose a large yellow-headed spot had ripened and was deftly milked with the dexterity that came from nearly twenty years' practice. In my teens I think I'd presumed there would be a golden period in my life after my spots cleared up and before my hair started to turn grey. Now I realized that was hopelessly naive of me; in my early thirties I was already past my physical peak. The summer seems to have only just begun when you realize the nights are already drawing in. Continues

webTitle: Comment - Runnymede report has been misrepresented

fields.headline: Get your facts right first, please
fields.standfirst:
The Runnymede Trust's report has been grossly misrepresented
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: The Runnymede Trust's report has been grossly misrepresented
fields.body:
The furore over the Runnymede Trust's commission on the future of multi-ethnic Britain was vivid testimony to the continuing power of race to unsettle the nation. The mendacious account of the report by the Daily Telegraph, and subsequent selective and distorted quotations in an interview with one of the commissioners led to a feeding frenzy by the piranhas of Fleet Street, followed by hate-mail, hate-messages and death threats sent to the Runnymede Trust.

The report did not say that the UK should be redefined as a community of communities. It did not say that the word British should not be used to refer to the inhabitants of the UK. The report did not call for abolishing the terms "Britain" or "British".

Most importantly of all, it did not say that the term British has racist connotations. "Racial" connotations yes, but "racist" no. Consider the difference between calling a group of, say, Chinese a "racial" group as opposed to a "racist" group.

The word British - rather like Chinese - conjures up many images. And just as you or I would be unlikely to imagine a black or brown face when thinking of the word Chinese, so the images brought to mind with the word British are more likely to be of an Anglican church rather than a Sunni mosque, warm beer rather than a cold lassi, a white face rather than a black or brown one.

It's changing, of course. But the meaning embedded in words often lags behind reality. The report was pointing this out and encouraging the process by which the word "British" could evoke a set of images that includes all the cultures and peoples who have made this country their home.

Certain newspapers playing fast and loose with words is hardly a revelation. One predictable reason was the opportunity it provided to attack New Labour. An equally uninteresting and unimpressive reason was lazy journalism - unprepared to take the trouble to read the report and get the quotes right.

What was so shocking was the way the Telegraph's interpretation was so readily and uncritically accepted. Even the Guardian's own headline "British tag is 'coded racism'" followed the herd rather than the text of the report.

Read the report and be surprised. You might even take the view of the report that led to the headline "Critics of a 'racist' Britain are misguided, says report". The article began its story with the words: "Race relations in Britain are the best in Europe - says Bhikhu Parekh author of the report." Where was this? Oh, in the Sunday Telegraph before its sister paper decided that truth could be a casualty in this war.

At the heart of the many pieces written over the past week was a simple thought: we tolerate you - tolerance is one of the great British virtues, after all - but don't get above yourselves. And in particular don't dare to comment on, or seek to shape and alter this country's culture, values, future or history. Ah, history.

When it is reported that we are seeking to "rewrite" British history, the very soul of Britain is being called into question. Words of extraordinary ferocity have been used: "wicked", "what Stalin did", "a corrupting process". This last phrase from a leader in the Mail asking how ministers could welcome a report that claims "the Scots, Irish and Welsh have histories that are 'different' from the English story?" Hello? Culloden?

Those that came out last week, particularly those politicians who took the opportunity to proclaim their pride in being British and lent support to the attack on the Runnymede Trust and the report, should look into their souls and ask if they are happy to find themselves with those that seek to preserve a narrow definition of Britishness.

The report does talk about "re-imagining" the national story. Rewriting of history is what historians do. Every generation of historians re-interprets the national story. Sometimes this is based on the unearthing of new primary sources, sometimes it reflects the new zeitgeist. Take the British empire. A hundred years ago the story of empire was the unfolding of liberty, as uncivilised nations were given the rule of law and democracy. The dominance of socialist ideology in the post-independence world led to the empire being seen as the story of rapacious exploitations through capitalism and imperialism. The Oxford History of the British Empire, based on new scholarship, suggests that the empire was as much a creation of the ruled as the rulers.

A nation's story is continually being rewritten. This is only a threat to those who wish to preserve a certain myth, a certain story. What was happening for the past 10 days was the emergence of that voice in full cry: a last ditch defence of a Britain that is passing by. Slipping into history, one might almost say.

 Samir Shah chairs the Runnymede Trust. Its report is The Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain (Profile Books).

webTitle: Do try this at home, kids!

fields.headline: Do try this at home, kids!
fields.standfirst: If you've put away your childish things, you'd better get them out again.  Susannah Conway  delves into the dressing-up box
fields.trailText: If you've put away your childish things, you'd better get them out again. Susannah Conway delves into the dressing-up box
fields.body:
These clothes may be the next chapter in fashionland's obsession with customisation. With seams falling apart, suede patches on sleeves and felt flowers stuck to skirts, they could be scaled-up versions of the clothes you made for your dolls.

Welcome to hobbyhorse chic, to be found in dressing-up boxes in attics across the land. When your modern black uniform starts pinching your sides with its grown-up severity, free yourself into a fantasy of jellybeans, Plasticine and Fuzzy-Felt landscapes. This has nothing to do with earnestly searching for that perfect vintage piece - these are the clothes you wore when you were eight. To finish the look, add sticky peppermint lipgloss, make-up the colour of wax crayons and hair in need of a brush.

Moloko's singer, Roisin Murphy, is the fairy godmother of hobbyhorse chic with her shiny cheekbones and hotchpotched outfits of glitter, leather and all things spangly. It's no coincidence, then, that the cover of the band's latest album, Things to Make and Do, features colourful felt toys with bobbly eyes, like those for sale at junior school summer fetes.

Fashion's designer magpie, Jessica Ogden, creates clothes that have history cross-stitched into them, with skirts made from mattress ticking and antique duvets fashioned into coats. The inevitable step on from girlie and frilly, the trend is evident in collections from labels such as Zambesi, Jorando and Paul & Joe. A few years ago, children's departments were raided by girls in search of the perfect snug-fit T - but these patchwork skirts, loose-knit jumpers and billowing smocks take this nostalgic look as far as you can get from the mini-Spice uniform of today's little girls.

So delight in your second childhood and marvel at how, in true Enid Blyton style, the pieces of Fuzzy-Felt your younger brother stole in 1978 have mysteriously found their way on to your vest tops in 2000. When the fashion world is reliving its sartorial teens in batwing jumpers and fuchsia leg-warmers, take that one step further back. Grazed knees optional.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers are saying

fields.headline: Through a distorting telescope, darkly
fields.trailText: As the Middle East crisis continues, Derek Brown looks at how the papers in the region are viewing the violence.
fields.body:
The distorting telescope of Middle East reporting, which always magnifies your own side's grievances and diminishes the other's, is on view in the Israeli papers following the bloody gunbattle between Jewish settlers and Palestinians.

The Ha'aretz daily opens its coverage: "One settler was killed and four were wounded yesterday when Palestinians opened fire on a tour bus on Mount Eval, near Nablus, igniting a battle with the Israel Defense Forces that lasted for more than five hours."

It goes on to report the grave fears of political and military leaders about the implications for the ceasefire, and their doubts about the Palestinians' willingness to observe it.

Only six paragraphs later, and in passing, do readers learn that a Palestinian was also killed, and up to 20 wounded.

The Jerusalem Post is also in no doubt who is to blame for the latest gunbattle. It features an analysis suggesting that Palestinian president Yasser Arafat is deliberately stoking up the violence in advance of the Arab summit in Cairo this weekend.

"The Palestinian leader hopes the summit will end with a resolution that can boost his popularity at home, internationalise the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, and somehow increase his chances of achieving a better deal with Israel if peace talks resume," writes Janine Zacharia.

The view from the other end of the telescope is, of course, quite different.

There is little press coverage from within Palestine on Friday, the Islamic sabbath, but the Jordan Times has an extensive report of the latest clashes, stressing the gross imbalance between Palestinian and Israeli firepower, and quoting local officials' claims that the Nablus gunbattle was started by the Israelis.

The Jordan Times also has a detailed analysis of the forthcoming Arab summit, which is expected to expose deep divisions among regional leaders, with moderates trying to shore up the crumbling peace process and hardline states like Syria calling for a renewed diplomatic and trade boycott of Israel.

The seething popular mood of the region is underlined by the Cairo Times , which focuses on unruly demonstrations in Egypt by "normally quiescent" students.

The Gulf News in Dubai issues an almost certainly forlorn call for Arab unity.

"The Arab summit in Cairo this weekend has to spell out to the world a clear and united position from all the Arab nations that what is happening in Palestine, and Jerusalem in particular, is totally outrageous.

"The summit should come to some specific resolutions which hurt Israel, and force others to recognise the Arab fury at what has been evident over the past weeks."

fields.headline: Dale takes helm at Granada/Sky pay-TV venture
fields.trailText: 4pm: Granada Media and BSkyB have hired Gary Dale as chief executive of their pay-TV channels joint venture, Granada Sky Broadcasting.
fields.body:
Granada Media and BSkyB have hired US new media executive Gary Dale to be the chief executive of their pay-TV channels joint venture Granada Sky Broadcasting.

Mr Dale is joining GSB from Broadband Studios, the US interactive TV and gaming content producer, where he was also chief executive.

He will take up his new post, overseeing GSB channels Granada Plus, Granada Breeze and Granada Men & Motors, on November 1.

He replaces Jeff Henry, who left GSB in the summer.

fields.headline: Reality bytes
fields.standfirst:
Search engine AltaVista is the latest dot.com to learn that in the new economy, the old business rules still apply, writes Vic Keegan
Net news
fields.trailText: Search engine AltaVista is the latest dot.com to learn that in the new economy, the old business rules still apply, writes Vic Keegan
fields.body:
If you want to understand the troubles of Altavista - whose chief executive, Rod Schrock, resigned today - look no further than the bottom line.

The company, which was bought by CMGI in 1999 for $2.3bn, lost a staggering $307m on revenues of $98m in the three months ended July 31 on its portals and search engines division. No wonder its flotation keeps being postponed.

A year ago that may not have mattered when dot.com mania was at its height and making big losses was almost a virility symbol. Now it has all changed. After the crash of high tech stocks in the US (notwithstanding yesterday's mild recovery) investors have abandoned notions that New Economy companies should be judged on different criteria to traditional ones. Profitability - or at least a Path to Profitability, another P2P to get our minds around - must be established before companies will get a second look.

The low barriers to entry in the internet world mean that there are plenty of search engines and portals to turn to if your current favourite isn't up to scratch. And all are for free. This is not because the portals don't want to charge money; they simply can't, because punters will simply move to the next one.

A year ago web start-ups still thought they could recoup their huge investments by charging for "banner" adverts on the screen. But consumers don't like them and advertising revenues are now slowing down.

Virtually every company selling to consumers through the web has felt the force of the hurricane that has been destroying swathes of the dot.com economy. One of the latest casualties was the hitherto highly regarded CD-seller Boxman.com, which this week admitted that it faced liquidation unless it found a buyer.

Tony Salter, chief executive of Boxman, commented to the FT: "I've never really believed in B2C (business-to-consumer)... the barriers to entry are low and B2C companies have a tendency to drive margins to zero and marketing costs to infinity."

I've never read a more succinct critique of the B2C problem. Salter deserved better than to be buried in his own Boxman.

webTitle: Union appeals to Smith over BBC education plans

fields.headline: Bectu appeals to minister over BBC education plans
fields.trailText: 8am: Broadcasting union Bectu has told minister Chris Smith that the BBC's plans for its education department are in breach of its charter, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Broadcasting union Bectu has written to the culture secretary, Chris Smith, claiming that the BBC's plans for overhauling its education department are in breach of its charter.

Bectu warns that the proposals "will phase out television transmissions [for schools] over a three-year period and move to the online delivery of a Digital Curriculum."

Under the terms of its charter, which was renewed in 1996, the BBC has to consult with the public on the launch of any new services, or material changes to existing services.

The union claims that the proposed changes represent a material change, and that public consultation has been inadequate. The letter to Mr Smith claims that although the BBC had asked him formally for approval, it had put in place the infrastructure to deliver the services beforehand.

Bectu also charged the BBC with inadequate public consultation about the services, claiming the questionnaires had not been made available to schools and that questions were phrased in such a way as to elicit a positive response.

The union added that there were concerns about the BBC's ability to maintain editorial independence from the government, in the light of the corporation's plan to work very closely with the DfEE.

The BBC plans to dismantle BBC Education and switch staff into Factual & Learning, Drama, Children's or Worldwide departments.

A BBC spokeswoman said: "The way the BBC organises itself internally is not covered by the charter. But the BBC recognises that the introduction of the digital curriculum represents a significant development, indeed a whole new service. Our agreement with the secretary of state requires us to consult with the public before seeking his approval and we are in that process now."

She denied that the questionnaire had not been available in schools, claiming that a leaflet providing access to the questionnaire had been sent to 36,000 schools.

A spokeswoman for the department of culture, media and sport would not be drawn on whether the BBC's plans represented a material change.

Consultation on the BBC's digital curriculum services ends this week.

webTitle: Explained: has Blair gone cold on the euro?

fields.headline: Has Blair gone cold on the euro?
fields.standfirst: The prime minister, Tony Blair, has said that, if asked to decide today, he would vote no to joining the euro. Mark Oliver and Julian Glover ask where the government now stands
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, has said that, if asked to decide today, he would vote no to joining the euro. We ask where the government now stands.
fields.body:
Why is the euro in the news again?
Tony Blair yesterday said he was against joining the euro at the "present time". He added that the government still want to be part of it, in principle, but only if the economic conditions are right. It was vital for Britain to keep the option open, he said. His remarks follow last month's victory for the "no vote" in Denmark's euro referendum. This has diminished the government's hopes of winning a similar referendum in Britain, which Mr Blair had hoped to hold after the next election.

Has there been a change of government policy?
Mr Blair insists not. The comments were made in an off-the-record briefing to journalists travelling with him to Seoul. But, after meeting Asian investors last night, Mr Blair decided to come off the fence in public. Although, later, he said the government's policy had not changed. It is still to "prepare and decide" before putting the issue of British membership before the public to vote on. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, sets great store by the five economic "tests" he has devised to determine whether the time is right to join and will not advocate membership until these criteria have been met.

What, then, is the significance of the prime minister's most recent remarks?
The importance of Mr Blair's comments is they appear to signal, at least, a subtle but vital change of approach and tone, if not policy. They show he is not now willing to risk losing political ground by trying to improve the public's perception of the euro. As well as the blow of the Danish referendum, the value of the euro has been falling against the dollar despite central bank attempts to prop it up. On Wednesday this week, the euro fell to a record low of 83.25 US cents. The pro-single currency in the cabinet had been pushing for a more upbeat approach from the government on joining, led by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, a keen supporter of Europe. But Mr Blair has now shown he is firmly behind Mr Brown, whose strategy is to avoid making the euro an election issue.

Why is it such a thorny political issue?
Because opinion polls show voters are against joining monetary union by more than 2-1. But there exists, in the Labour party, broad support for the belief it is the right thing to do. Mr Blair's remarks will help him avoid making the euro an election issue and must diminish the prospects of a post-election referendum. The feeling among commentators is Mr Blair will only hold one if he feels he can win it. The Conservative leader, William Hague, reacted to his comments by accusing Mr Blair of "attempting to abandon his own policy" in an attempt to camouflage his plans to scrap the pound. Mr Blair is worried at Mr Hague's capacity to exploit public disquiet at the euro.

So were the comments a shrewd move?
On balance, perhaps they were. But by apparently throwing his support behind Mr Brown's euro approach, Mr Blair risks aggravating splits on the issue in the cabinet. Mr Blair's main objective is keeping a united front. He is all too aware that division on the euro helped tear the Tory party apart when they were in power. Mr Brown and others are unenthusiastic about the prospect of membership (though none seems to want to rule it out altogether).

Others, such as the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and Mr Cook, believe the government must speak out about the possible benefits of membership if it is to have any chance of persuading the public to vote for it in a referendum. That said, neither the chancellor nor the foreign secretary thinks that Britain should join the single currency immediately, and neither of them wants to rule it out all altogether.

So they really agree?
Not quite. Robin Cook and Gordon Brown might agree about the broad sweep of policy towards the euro, but they certainly disagree when it comes to the matter of tone. The chancellor's early enthusiasm for the single currency, in 1997 and 1998, has been replaced by a cautious neutrality. In contrast, the foreign secretary - always a pro-European - has become openly keen on joining. A draft of a speech he gave earlier this year, for instance, included a promise that the government "would not let Britain lose by staying out" - words the chancellor would be unlikely to use.

Is the government dangerously split on the issue, then?
To a degree. Apart from the foreign secretary, two other leading ministers, Mandelson and trade secretary Stephen Byers, would like the government to be more openly enthusiastic about the euro. But the real issue is not a fundamental split between pro-Europeans and anti-Europeans, but a concern on the part of pro-Europeans that the single currency is not an issue on which the government should or can remain neutral.

Do Mr Blair's comments restrict his ability to be flexible on the euro?
One reaction to his remarks on the euro which will worry Mr Blair is that of the Business for Sterling chief executive, Nick Herbert. He said: "It suits the government to play down the euro issue before the election. But if the prime minister is saying the conditions for entry are not right now, it would be impossible for him to claim they have changed were he to move towards a referendum in the next year or two."

Has the Danish referendum made all the difference?
In theory, it should not have done. Denmark is far smaller than Britain, its currency is already tied to the euro and its economy is less international. What's right for Denmark isn't necessarily right for Britain.

On the other hand?
On the other hand the Danish vote has immense significance for Britain. Firstly, it means if Britain does decide to keep the pound it won't be the only EU country outside the euro. That's important. Secondly, it gives heart to opponents of the euro in Britain: they have worked closely with Danish "nej" campaigners and will now be confident they can win any referendum in Britain. Thirdly, the Danish vote will terrify New Labour.

Ministers fear that defeat in a referendum may destroy their ability to make progress on all sorts of other issues. The Danish vote suggests it may be impossible for the government to endorse euro membership in a referendum and expect to win. And if they come to believe that, there may be no referendum in Britain at all.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week ten

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week ten
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Here we go
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £115.85, Sean Ingle = £89.98, Paul MacInnes = £71.50, Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.02
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £115.85, Sean Ingle = £89.98, Paul MacInnes = £71.50, Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.02

Scott Murray

Newcastle v Everton: Everton to win @ 5/1 - £5

Newcastle are in third place and on a roll. Everton, meanwhile, are hanging around the relegation zone playing a brand of football not suffered by the Goodison faithful since, oh, 1998. So surely this one's got home banker scrawled all over it in one of those little bookie pens with chewed ends that don't work.

Perhaps. But take another look at Newcastle's home form. Bobby Robson's unstoppable Toon Army have only scored five goals in four home games, and three of those came against the collapsing jalopy passing for the Derby County side at the moment. A goal-less draw here, a loss to Premiership new boys Charlton there even the hapless Rams managed to score twice. Dear me.

And although Everton haven't won in six, their last victory was away at Middlesbrough a club from the north-east. Ooh, those parallels.

Sean Ingle

1x 50p accumulator and 4 x £3 trebles: Cambridge United to beat Colchester at @ 5/4; Norwich to draw with Sheffield United @ 9/4 Millwall to beat Stoke @ 7/4 and Porto to beat Sporting Lisbon @ 9/4

Gambling is beginning to grip me, and nothing is too meaningless to wade through. ITV's Champions League highlights and Football League review double bill on a Monday? Count me in! Advice from other professional pundits on other websites? Give me your suggestions and watch me go! And as for Blue Square's Patrick Murray, keep laying it on, because I want to keep learning. (Any advice on a staking plan, by the way?)

Mr Murray may not believe me, but this week I wanted to lay a couple of single bets on Cambridge to beat Colchester at 5/4 - which surely is the value bet of the week - and Coventry to get something at Chelsea starting with 1¼ goals on the Asian handicap system. But Blue Square's (and everyone else's) rules won't allow me, so once again I'm enticed by seedy and unprofitable world of accumulators. Forgive me Mr Murray for I don't know what I do.

On to my bets. Cambridge are fantastic value at 5/4 to win away at Colchester. The home side have lost their last five and have dropped into the relegation zone. Cambridge, meanwhile, are unbeaten in their last three and are challenging for promotion. I also think Millwall are also over-valued at 7/4 to beat Stoke. Millwall are unbeaten in the league under Mark McGhee and will be promoted and Stoke are struggling, so I fancy the Lions.

Elsewhere, I've gone for Porto to beat Sporting Lisbon in the big Portuguese game this weekend. Sporting were thrashed by Spartak Moscow in midweek and there is unrest in the camp with rumours that Peter Schmeichel has been dropped for missing training on Thursday. So Porto, the Portuguese leaders, must be good value at 9/4.

Finally, I think Norwich and Sheffield United is a good draw prospect. Norwich have drawn three out of their last six at home, while this match has produced three draws in five games. Of course that doesn't mean the trend will continue, but I think 9/4 offers value.

Paul MacInnes

Liverpool v Leicester: Asian handicap, Leicester to win (+3/4) @ evens - £10

Perhaps it's the week away that's done it - the eyesight feels sharper, the trademark mental agility has returned, even my lucky nose is twitching. But for some reason, I'm not only ready to take the plunge back into the world of the punt, I'm also convinced that I'm going to win. Oh yes.

Admittedly, I'm not going to win all that much, because I have backed Leicester against Liverpool, using the Asian handicap system, with odds one can only describe as "evens". Just to quickly recap (to make sure I've got it right myself), with a handicap of +3/4, if Leicester win, I win. If they draw, I win on half my stake, and if they lose by one goal, I get half my stake back.

This, I think, covers a fair number of likely eventualities. Leicester have a good recent record at Anfield having won both of the last two Premiership encounters. They've also got a rock solid defence, and Liverpool - despite whomping Derby - are yet to convince this season.

I just hope I'm not made to rue picking the handicap system ahead of the mouth-watering odds of 5/1 on a straight Leicester win. Yes indeed, that's the only thing I'm worried about.

fields.headline: Horrocks joins Society of Editors board
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: The editor of the Manchester Evening News, Paul Horrocks, has been elected to the board of the Society of Editors, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The editor of the Manchester Evening News, Paul Horrocks, has been elected to the board of the Society of Editors for a three-year term.

Ed Curran, editor of the Belfast Telegraph, was confirmed as president for 2000-2001 At the society's annual general meeting in Cardiff, while Liz Page, editor of the Evening Press, was confirmed as vice-president.

Mr Horrocks replaces Geoff Elliott, former editor of the Porstmouth News, who comes to the end of his term as president.

Mr Horrocks joined the Manchester Evening News in 1975 as general reporter, becoming crime correspondent in the 1980s, where he covered the Stalker affair and the reopening of the Moors Murders case. He was made editor in 1997, and presided over the launch of Manchester Metro News, an MEN free morning title.

webTitle: Ehiogu completes Boro move, Boban to follow?

fields.headline: Ehiogu completes Boro move, Boban to follow?
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough have completed their club-record £7.5m signing of central defender Ugo Ehiogu from Aston Villa. The Tessiders hope to add another major recruit this weekend, the Croatia midfielder Zvonimir Boban.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough have completed their club-record £7.5m signing of central defender Ugo Ehiogu from Aston Villa. The Tessiders hope to add another major recruit this weekend, the Croatia midfielder Zvonimir Boban.

Ehiogu today signed a a five-year deal with Boro after passing a medical and goes straight into the squad for tomorrow's Premiership trip to Charlton Athletic. Bryan Robson was not in the country to seal the deal. He is currently in Milan attempting to wrap up a £2m deal for Boban.

Robson was in the San Siro on Wednesday night to see Boban come on as a 69th-minute substitute for Milan against Barcelona. The 32-year-old is keen to join his fellow countryman Alen Boksic in the Premiership; if Middlesbrough cannot unveil him today they hope to conclude the deal early next week.

Meanwhile, Manchester City are discussing personal terms with Newcastle's Laurent Charvet over a £1.5m move, and Liverpool's £3m French winger Bernard Diomede may be out for up to six weeks after being told he needs knee surgery.

Leicester will not make an announcement about Stan Collymore's future until late next week. He met the manager Peter Taylor yesterday and gave his version of Monday's dressing-room brawl with his team-mate Trevor Benjamin, who has also given a statement.

Joe Kinnear is back in football as a consultant to Oxford. The former Wimbledon manager, 53, will assess the club, bottom of the Second Division, and suggest improvements.

Crystal Palace and Nottingham Forest have been fined £20,000 and £15,000 respectively by the FA after a "mass confrontation" by players in their August game.

fields.headline: Freeserve pushed off top table
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's dominant internet service provider, was last night ejected from the FTSE 100, the index of Britain's leading companies.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's dominant internet service provider, was last night ejected from the FTSE 100, the index of Britain's leading companies.

Since March, Freeserve's valuation has fallen from £10bn to £1.6bn. Its plight reflects a wider malaise that Merrill Lynch says has wiped more than $50bn (£35bn) off the value of Europe's listed internet companies since the start of September.

Britain's high-profile consumer-focused internet companies have been at the centre of the bloodbath. Online auctioneer QXL.com's value fell from £2.6bn to £99m as its shares slid from 800p in April to last night's low of 27p.

Lastminute.com has fallen from its high of 487.5p and 380p issue price to 132p.

Shares in Interactive Investor International (iii), the online personal finance firm, are worth just 47.5p, effectively a third of their issue price and a tenth of their March high.

365 Corporation, the content and telecoms company that floated in a blaze of publicity a year ago, wallows at a fifth of its March high at 60.5p. The shares were issued at 160p.

"From the peak the decline in prices has been nothing short of brutal," said Peter Bradshaw, internet analyst at Merrill Lynch.

Several factors have influenced the selling and the performance of the technology laden Nasdaq index in the US has, as ever, set the tone.

In macroeconomic terms concerns about a slowing of the global economy, signs of inflation and a tightening of credit had a big impact on valuations. When credit was cheaper and inflation lower, the appetite to back emerging, and more risky, technology stocks was greater.

The market capitalisations of blue-chip internet stocks such as Yahoo!, Amazon and eBay have been radically revised as observers started to question their long-term revenue prospects.

Priceline.com, for example, trades at a 20th of its March price and its business model appears to be in tatters. The Nasdaq composite has fallen more than 20% since September 20.

"The US market has been friendless for the past six months," Mr Bradshaw said.

The saying that when Nasdaq sneezes technology stocks around the globe become flu cases has never been more apt.

There are other influences at work in Britain. The collapse of the likes of Boo.com, Boxman and ClickMango hardly helped sentiment. Institutional investors appear to have deserted many UK internet stocks. "In this sort of environment you look for companies with visible earnings and cash flow," said one analyst at another major investment bank.

"If you are a fund manager you don't want to have to explain to your investors why you're sitting on some dot.com shares that are a mile under water. OK, at these levels they may double but equally they may halve again and it's not worth the risk."

The relentless selling of QXL.com shows how sentiment can destroy a stock and how little there is underpinning the shares. Earlier in the year it was confidently using its high share price to drive consolidation in the internet auction space and was on the way to becoming a credible rival to eBay. But when its share price collapsed so did its acquisition strategy.

Analysts say its share price has probably fallen too far but if it remains there the company will not be able to raise the cash it needs to take it through to profitability. eBay could let the shares fall further then pick up QXL at a bargain price.

As Lastminute.com has shown, a share price can continue to fall even if the business plan is being executed ahead of expectations and there is enough money to see the venture through to profitability. Freeserve faces similar issues. Motivating staff whose own share options are almost valueless is an added difficulty.

Merrill Lynch believes some of the thousands of private investors sitting on big paper losses could yet get their money back. "There is a light at the end of the tunnel for some of these companies but the trend for the next few months is likely to be flat or downwards," Mr Bradshaw said.

For others, the internet boom will have been a painful investment lesson.

In macroeconomic terms concerns about a slowing of the global economy, signs of inflation and a tightening of credit had a big impact on valuations. When credit was cheaper and inflation lower, the appetite to back emerging, and more risky, technology stocks was greater. The market capitalisations of blue-chip internet stocks such as Yahoo!, Amazon and eBay have been radically revised as observers started to question their long-term revenue prospects. Priceline.com, for example, trades at a 20th of its March price and its business model appears to be in tatters. The Nasdaq composite has fallen more than 20% since September 20. "The US market has been friendless for the past six months," Mr Bradshaw said. The saying that when Nasdaq sneezes technology stocks around the globe become flu cases has never been more apt. There are other influences at work in Britain. The collapse of the likes of Boo.com, Boxman and ClickMango hardly helped sentiment. Institutional investors appear to have deserted many UK internet stocks. "In this sort of environment you look for companies with visible earnings and cash flow," said one analyst at another major investment bank. "If you are a fund manager you don't want to have to explain to your investors why you're sitting on some dot.com shares that are a mile under water. OK, at these levels they may double but equally they may halve again and it's not worth the risk." The relentless selling of QXL.com shows how sentiment can destroy a stock and how little there is underpinning the shares. Earlier in the year it was confidently using its high share price to drive consolidation in the internet auction space and was on the way to becoming a credible rival to eBay. But when its share price collapsed so did its acquisition strategy. Analysts say its share price has probably fallen too far but if it remains there the company will not be able to raise the cash it needs to take it through to profitability. eBay could let the shares fall further then pick up QXL at a bargain price. As Lastminute.com has shown, a share price can continue to fall even if the business plan is being executed ahead of expectations and there is enough money to see the venture through to profitability. Freeserve faces similar issues. Motivating staff whose own share options are almost valueless is an added difficulty. Merrill Lynch believes some of the thousands of private investors sitting on big paper losses could yet get their money back. "There is a light at the end of the tunnel for some of these companies but the trend for the next few months is likely to be flat or downwards," Mr Bradshaw said. For others, the internet boom will have been a painful investment lesson.

webTitle: Publicis's Bendel steps into regional role

fields.headline: Publicis's Bendel steps into regional role
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Publicis Groupe has promoted UK chairman Rick Bendel to the new role of regional chairman covering the UK, Nordic and Baltic countries, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Publicis Groupe has promoted Rick Bendel, its UK group chairman, to the new role of regional chairman covering the UK, Nordic and Baltic countries, as part of a reorganisation.

The move follows the retirement of Georg Baums, the network's chairman of Germany, Austria and Switzerland. Walter van der Mee, who until now looked after the Nordic and Baltic regions, takes on Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the Benelux countries.

Maurice Levy, president of Publicis, said: "Georg Baums' leadership is one big reason why Publicis' growth in Europe has been and continues to be remarkably strong. When he joined us in 1989, we were only among the top 15 agencies in Germany; today we are a solid number three."

fields.headline: Riefenstahl downplays Hitler involvement
fields.trailText: Controversial German film-maker Leni Riefenstahl has claimed that she only worked for Adolf Hitler for seven months and wished she had never met him
fields.body:
Controversial German film-maker Leni Riefenstahl has claimed that she only worked for Adolf Hitler for seven months and wished she had never met him, according to Yahoo News.

The 98-year-old director, in Frankfurt for the press launch of a new pictorial biography of her career, said that she regretted meeting Hitler and wished she had gone to the US instead to work as an actress.

Riefenstahl won critical acclaim for the striking visual style displayed in 1934's Triumph of the Will, about the Nazi party, and 1936's Olympia, about the Berlin Games, but the films brought her notoriety as they were used by Hitler as propaganda. At the launch, she claimed that Hitler never wanted her to make Olympia, afraid that such a film would aggrandise the achievements of Jesse Owen, the black, gold medal-winning American star of the games.

On the subject of the Jodie Foster biopic of her life, Riefenstahl said that negotiations fell through when she failed to win assurances that she would have approval on the final cut. Foster has since gone on to court controversy with her plans and there is also another German-funded project about Riefenstahl's life in the pipeline (see our earlier story).

Riefenstahl was in defiant form, facing down a barrage of questions and camera flashes at the launch: "I am used to this from the beginning of my career as a dancer through to being a film actress," she said. But in a moment of vulnerability, she revealed that she had had four operations in the past six months, saying, "I was so ill. I was between life and death. My body was more iron than bone."

webTitle: A battle for personalities and not brave hearts

fields.headline: A battle for personalities and not brave hearts
fields.standfirst: As the Scottish Labour party prepares to elect its new leader, Scotland correspondent Gerard Seenan looks at the candidates - and what they're fighting for
fields.trailText: As the Scottish Labour party prepares to elect its new leader, Scotland correspondent Gerard Seenan looks at the candidates - and what they're fighting for.
fields.body:
The battle to become leader of the Scottish Labour party and Scottish first minister is a very strange sort of contest. We have two candidates who are fighting it out for the chance to offer almost exactly the same thing.

They claim, of course, that this is a not a personality contest: not a choice between stable-but-boring Henry McLeish and radical-but-inexperienced Jack McConnell.

But never have two leadership candidates been more tied by the actions of their predecessor.

For, north of the border, there is a very different sort of politics going on. The first coalition government on mainland Britain since the second world war sees to that - and it will ensure also that, whoever wins tomorrow will continue on the rigid path laid down by Donald Dewar.

When, in the late 1990s, Labour agreed to demands from the Liberal Democrat and Scottish National parties for proportional representation for the Scottish parliament elections, they showed more than a degree of political generosity.

The political map of Scotland has, since the 1950s, been almost uniformly red. But, under PR, that could only change.

So, in May 1999, it was no surprise when Labour did not win an overall majority in the Scottish parliament.

They needed the help of the Lib Dems; and the Lib Dems were happy to taste power again after so long a drought.

In sessions that lasted long in to the night, the two parties drew up a detailed framework for coalition government. That coalition agreement all but dots the i's and crosses the t's of every policy until the next elections.

Whoever wins the battle to become leader of Scottish Labour will have to abide by it - or the coalition will fall.

To the winner may go the spoils, but there is precious little they can do with them.

So the contest is not so much a battle for the present, but for the future.

Mr McLeish is tried and tested: 13 years as an MP, a former Westminster minister, the favoured candidate of the Chancellor, Gordon Brown (who represents Downing Street's thinking on all matters Scottish).

He will steer a competent but dull Scottish parliament.

Then there is Mr McConnell. More combative, better at bashing the Nats, inexperienced, a good backroom fixer, and the man who seems to be galvanising the support of the backbenches.

He may take the parliament on a more radical agenda in coming years and show that devolution can fashion very different countries within the UK.

But all that's the future: for the present it's apple pie policies with a large dollop of personality on the side.

fields.headline: Freeserve suspends unmetered sign-ups
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Freeserve has suspended sign-ups to its unmetered access service following problems coping with demand. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet service provider Freeserve has suspended sign-ups to its unmetered access service, Freeserve Time, following problems coping with the demand.

A statement from the company said the decision was taken to try to improve the service for existing customers. But the move, coming in the wake of Freeserve's decision to kick off so-called heavy users from the service, casts a shadow over its expansion into new access packages.

Freeserve said that the move was in accordance with its policy stated at launch. It added that it was taking measures to improve the service, such as increasing the network's capacity and removing "abnormal" customers.

The statement said: "We have received high demand for our unmetered access offers following the withdrawal of unmetered offers by several other ISPs, and we have been limiting new sign-ups to only a few thousand per week, compared with 10,000 a week when the service was launched in April."

Freeserve reported earlier this month that there were 250,000 active registered accounts on its two unmetered access services (Energis-based and BT-based).

While analysts have welcomed the uptake of unmetered access, concern has been expressed about how much Freeserve is subsidising the service - around 250p per month per subscriber.

It is thought that the move towards ending new subscriptions to the Energis-based unmetered service will be superseded by an announcement shortly about Freeserve's plans for a Flat Rate Internet Access Call Origination (Friaco) service, which would offer better margins.

Freeserve's share price was today down 4.8p, at 161.3p - a far cry from its high of 987.5p at the start of the year.

The slump has prompted reports that the final humiliation for Freeserve will occur on Monday when it is expected to be kicked out of the FTSE 100.

The FTSE actuaries committee meets quarterly to review the constituents of the top index, removing those whose market value ranks them below the top 120 companies on the FTSE. Freeserve is expected to be among a number of hi-tech companies to move down to the FTSE 250 index.

webTitle: Sainsbury's/Oddbins in online wine retail joint venture

fields.headline: Sainsbury's and Oddbins in online wine retail joint venture
fields.trailText: 1pm: Sainsbury's and Oddbins are to launch an online wine retail joint venture early next year, says Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's and Oddbins are to launch an online wine retail joint venture early next year, going head-to-head with Richard Branson's Virginwines.com.

The 50:50 joint venture will run alongside both retailers' existing businesses and operate under both the Sainsbury's and the Oddbins brand-names.

It will offer more than 3,000 premium wines in the £4-plus sector, most of which will be sold by the case.

Allan Cheesman, director for wine at Sainsbury's, said: "This proposed venture is another step forward in Sainsbury's e-commerce strategy. We are creating a venture with unparalleled appeal for consumers seeking to explore and experience with confidence the world of wine."

fields.headline: Bugs on the menu
fields.standfirst: All the online data you need to get the full lowdown on entomophagy, aka critter cuisine
fields.trailText: All the online data you need to get the full lowdown on entomophagy, aka critter cuisine.
fields.body:
1. The bright boys and girls over at Revolution magazine have come up with a new wheeze to freshen up our lifestyles: they want us to eat bugs.


2. The cool term for insect eating is critter cuisine. The proper word is entomophagy.


3. In fact, eating bugs is not such a bad idea. They're packed with protein. There's lots of recipes available - more choccy-covered ants, Nigella? - and some conversation-worthy cookbooks.


4. If you're into self-sufficiency, you can easily raise your own livestock.


5. Those who have doubts about the mess and morality of killing God's nastier little creatures, can get their bugs ready-prepared. A nice selection of canned crawlies from Thailand is only a click away. And if you fancy a bug-lolly, you can try here .


6. You could always follow the example of US survivalist nutters , and collect your own. Woodlice make tasty fritters, for example. (Yes, yes, smartypants, the woodlouse is not an insect; it's an isopod crustacean. Everyone knows that. Don't be so picky.)


7. There are pages and pages of entomophagic info on the internet. There's earnest anthropological and educational material, and even some vaguely pathological stuff.


8. The best single site is eatbug.com, set up by 17-year-old Aletheia Price, who is deeply into insect consumption. She's also, oddly enough, pro-life.


9. There are even groups of human insectivores. The Bay Area Bug Eating Society (Babes, geddit?) has links to lots of appetizing pictures of their favourite food.


10. Attractive little chaps, some of them.

webTitle: Hollywood's staple diet unpalatable for Attenborough

fields.headline: Hollywood's staple diet unpalatable for Attenborough
fields.trailText: Screen maestro Sir Richard Attenborough has criticised Hollywood for refusing to distribute his new film, Grey Owl, because it doesn't contain enough sex or violence
fields.body:
Screen maestro Sir Richard Attenborough has criticised Hollywood for refusing to distribute his new film because it doesn't contain enough sex or violence.

The 77-year-old director told Radio 4's Front Row arts programme that without these "prerequisites", US movie distributors had no idea how to distribute Grey Owl (pictured), the story of an Englishman who masquerades as an Iroquois trapper in 1930s Canada, starring Pierce Brosnan.

The £20m production has been hived off as a straight-to-video release in the US, though it will get a UK cinematic release on November 3.

"[They said that] it does not have a sufficient scale, does not have sufficient special effects and does not demonstrate or illustrate either the pornography of violence or sex," huffed Lord Attenborough.

When quizzed if he thought it would have fared better had he included a few more explosions or torrid sex sessions, Lord Attenborough said: "Oh yes, there's no question."

But he firmly eschewed current trends: "I don't mind sex in terms of a movie if age considerations are placed on it, but I don't accept the pornography of violence under any circumstances and if that's a prerequisite to getting a distribution in America, I'll accept the non-distribution."

webTitle: Truancy drive puts onus on parents

fields.headline: Truancy drive puts onus on parents
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government has made little progress in reducing truancy, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has made little progress in reducing truancy, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, admitted yesterday.

The main obstacle was parents who condoned and even encouraged their children's unauthorised absence from school, he said.

Despite tougher penalties for parents, truancy rates have remained high since Labour came to power, with 50,000 children skipping school every day in England.

With Jack Straw, the home secretary, Mr Blunkett yesterday announced a renewed national crackdown involving police, schools and local authorities, backed by £43m of extra funding and more powers for the courts.

The Department for Education and Employment and the Home Office are joining forces to hit the government's target to cut unauthorised absence by a third by 2002.

Regular "truancy sweeps", or random visits by police and local authorities, have shown that many children out of school without permission are accompanied by their parents. Every local authority is being ordered to carry out more sweeps - in which truants are rounded up and returned to school - while schools are encouraged to use the extra money available to employ learning mentors or attendance officers.

"We have made progress in reducing the number of excluded children, but we have made very little progress in terms of persistent truancy," Mr Blunkett said on a visit to Quintin Kynaston school in St John's Wood, north-west London. He blamed parents who had "a contempt for education _ and who are frightened that it is separating them from their children".

Legislation now before parliament will increase maximum fines on parents from £1,000 to £2,000, while parents face arrest if they do not turn up in court.

Mr Blunkett hailed the action being taken by the head at Quintin Kynaston school, once a popular comprehensive which later ran into difficulties. Attendance rates have risen from 87% to 90% in the past five years.

Mr Straw pointed to the clear links between truancy and crime, with 72% of truants found in one survey to have committed at least one offence. "I have never met a young offender who hasn't been involved in regular truanting," he said.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said: "While I welcome moves to encourage more involvement from the police to get children back to school, I fear that simply increasing fines for parents whose children fail to attend will not work.

"How much faith can parents have in a government which penalises the parents rather than addressing the core problems of why their children are persistently truanting?"

The announcement drew a mixed reaction from teacher unions. The National Association of Head Teachers welcomed the extra funding to tackle truancy. Its president, Mick Brookes, said the union "urges the government to take a very firm line on parents who condone unnecessary absence, because in the early years this sets a pattern and an expectation in pupils that school does not matter".

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers warned: "The government needs to do a lot more than simply rounding up the rogues and frog-marching them back to school. Increasing powers of the courts to fine largely dysfunctional parents for conniving with their children's truancy makes good headlines but does precious little to impact seriously upon the problem."

The Professional Association of Teachers said: "The government must tackle the social and family problems that are often the root cause."

'Have to buy hamster' a top excuse

In Sheffield, where David Blunkett has his constituency, sweeps of the city centre found the majority of children not at school were of primary school age and accompanied by parents. Three-quarters of the reasons proffered for not being at school were classed as unauthorised absence, the three most common being sunburn, hayfever, and buying a hamster.

A sweep near Kempton Park racecourse in Surrey on a weekday morning identified 99 children who should have been at school - 81 accompanied by one or more parents.

In Newham, east London, police officers have embarked on truancy sweeps riding mountain bikes as well as in cars and vans. During sweeps in the north of the borough, car crime fell by 70%; while during sweeps in the south street crime fell by 17%, burglary by 39%, car crime by 37% and robberies by 25%.

In York sweeps take place up to five times a month. More than one in two truanting children is found to be accompanied by a parent. Youth crime has decreased by 67% since the regular sweeps were publicised.

In London 10- to 16-year-olds are responsible for 40% of street robberies, 25% of burglaries, 20% of criminal damage, and 33% of car thefts.

Three-quarters of the reasons proffered for not being at school were classed as unauthorised absence, the three most common being sunburn, hayfever, and buying a hamster. A sweep near Kempton Park racecourse in Surrey on a weekday morning identified 99 children who should have been at school - 81 accompanied by one or more parents. In Newham, east London, police officers have embarked on truancy sweeps riding mountain bikes as well as in cars and vans. During sweeps in the north of the borough, car crime fell by 70%; while during sweeps in the south street crime fell by 17%, burglary by 39%, car crime by 37% and robberies by 25%. In York sweeps take place up to five times a month. More than one in two truanting children is found to be accompanied by a parent. Youth crime has decreased by 67% since the regular sweeps were publicised. In London 10- to 16-year-olds are responsible for 40% of street robberies, 25% of burglaries, 20% of criminal damage, and 33% of car thefts.

fields.headline: Broken rail 'likely cause' of crash
fields.standfirst: The interim report
fields.trailText: A broken rail was the likely cause of the Hatfield train crash, the government's health and safety executive said today.
fields.body:
A broken rail was the likely cause of the Hatfield train crash, the government's health and safety executive said today.

Its interim report into Tuesday's derailment blames track defects on the intercity line out of London King's Cross for the accident that claimed four lives and left many more injured.

"From the evidence so far, there is no reason to believe that either the signalling or the rolling stock were at fault.

"But until all avenues have been thoroughly explored, including underlying root causes, it would be unwise to draw any final conclusions," it said. The report said the GNER train was travelling at approximately 115mph when it was derailed about half a mile south of Hatfield station. The Intercity 225 train, hauled by a Class 91 locomotive, had eight passenger carriages, a buffet car and a driving van trailer, and was carrying staff and about 100 passengers.

The derailment happened on curved track between Welham Green and Hatfield where the permitted line speed is 115mph. No speed restrictions were in place.

"The derailment resulted in the locomotive and front two passenger coaches remaining on the track, while the rear eight coaches derailed," the report said.

"Six carriages and the driving van trailer remained upright, two were at almost on their side and the buffet car was on its side with the roof ripped off (apparently on impact with an overhead power lines stanchion). Debris was spread over a wide area and into homes and gardens adjacent to the railway."

The HSE report said its investigation would try to answer the following three main questions:

 Why did the derailment occur?  What remedial action needs to be taken to prevent further incidents?  Is enforcement action (including prosecution) appropriate? The report said that up to 14 HSE inspectors had been on the crash site and were conducting a parallel investigation with British Transport Police.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.standfirst: The latest missives from Football Unlimited readers, broken down into one handy digest
fields.trailText: Big Ron: right and wrong
fields.body:
Big Ron: right and wrong

Big Ron waxed lyrical this morning about the improving fortunes of English club sides in Europe. He believes a return to the glory days of the 70s could be imminent, and Andy Bouskill has noted another parallel between now and then.

"Isn't it strange," he writes, "that the last time we were as strong in Europe during the 70's our international sides which contained great players like Emlyn Hughes, Kevin Keegan and Peter Shilton were quite poor, qualifying for a single World Cup between 1971 and 1981, a gap of 10 years. And here we are, with three teams in the Champions League all doing well, performing poorly at international level."

Iain McPherson however spots a slight factual inaccuracy in Ron's comments. "According to Ron," he writes, " 'If a player has an 'o' at the end of his name everybody thinks he can do all sorts of ball-juggling tricks and beat the world. The fact is that our players compare very favourably with some of the so-called best.'

"Where's Ron been for the last five years? Hasn't he noticed it's 'our' players who have an 'o' at the end of their name these days. Come to think of it its England who have an 'o' at the end: England 0 Germany 1, or Finland 0 England 0."

Cagatay Arslan, in the latest of his several mails following Leeds' match against Besiktas, pulls up Big Ron for criticising hotels in the Turkish town of Izmir "ARE YOU SERIOUS???????", Cagatay asks after Ron described the facilities as "the worst hotel imaginable". "IT IS A SHAME THAT YOU DONT SAY ANY WORD ABOUT SCANDALOUS REFEREE THIS DOESNT FIT TO GUARDIAN."

The logical choice

Jon Blowers offers a foolproof way of choosing the next England boss.

"I find it difficult to believe that the Football Association cannot work out who is the best man for the job of England Manager," he writes. "By their own recognition, the most outstanding candidate by a long mile is Terry Venables."

At this point, Jon gets technical.

"Problem: He has a shady past and possibly a shady future.

"Solution: In the interest of English football and national well-being, ask the Home Secretary to grant him immunity from any prosecution relating to anything he has done up to the date he is appointed.

"Justification: Immunity has been granted in the past to murderers, drug dealers, crime barons and many other such people who have given far more offence than Terry and this immunity has been granted, in some cases, for far more trivial reasons.

"The time to act is now."

Roman lore

"Mihajlovic is not the only right-wing connection with Lazio", writes Jim Byrne in the latest of many mails following Patrick Vieira's revelations of racist abuse from Lazio's Yugoslav defender Sinisa Mihajlovic.

"The whole club is complicit in the Italian right-wing and numbers among its suppporters many of the most reprehensible individuals of the New Right in Italy. City-rivals Roma on the other hand draw their support from the working class of the city and use players from across the ethnic and religious spectrum.

"Don't believe me? Count the number of black or 'coloured' players who have ever played for Lazio. Finished already? Now count those who currently play for Roma."

Oh, just one more thing

Haris Smijac asks: "David Lacey, why are you so quiet on the Arsenal renaissance?" Indeed.

fields.body:
61, Conservative MP for South Staffordshire

Majority: 7,821 over Labour

Seat: Staffordshire South (since 1983, former seats Staffordshire SW 1974-83; Cannock 1970-74) A safe Tory suburbanised seat on the edge of the west Midlands, formerly rural

Outlook: Shrewd, rebellious centrist; "one of the finest parliamentarians" (Michael White, The Guardian); was among the first Conservatives to realise how completely they had lost middle England over their greed, incompetence, incessant quarrels over Europe and by moving too far to the right; a mainstream traditionalist; a monarchist loyal to the Prince of Wales; orotund of figure and speech; a churchy leader of the sanctimony school; a canny fighter for old buildings, historic buildings, the genteel of modest means, Euro-enthusiast

Traits: Rotund, owlish, fruity-voiced, "the air of the people who say sshh to you in public galleries" (Matthew Parris, The Times)

History: Joined Young Conservatives at 16, 1955; overturned Jennie Lee's 11,000 majority to win Cannock, 1970; seconded Peter Lilley for the Conservative leadership, May 1997; was named deputy shadow leader of the Commons, June 1997; opposed proposals of new Commons leader Ann Taylor to clear out many old commons customs, possibly allowing clapping, August 1997

fields.headline: Reuters fails to name day for Greenhouse float
fields.standfirst: Media Medium: Pluto dogs Reuters
fields.trailText: 12pm: Reuters has confirmed that no firm date has yet been set for the flotation of its internet and technology incubator, the Greenhouse Fund. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Reuters, the giant financial news and information provider, has confirmed that no firm date has yet been set for the flotation of its internet and technology incubator, the Greenhouse Fund.

The company, which today unveiled strong third quarter 2000 results, said in a statement that discussions were underway instead with "various organisations" about a private round of financing for the Greenhouse Fund, which had now become the next objective for the internet investment oufit.

Reuters also said the Greenhouse Fund had "taken advantage of investment opportunities in current market conditions to accelerate the pace of investments". The fund, which was set up in 1995 to invest in internet start-ups, has committed £105m to 79 projects so far this year.

The news and information provider also announced plans for the partial flotation of the electronic broking arm, Instinet, in the US. Reuters said money raised from the float would be used to boost Instinet's "geographic, customer and product expansion and provide acquisition currency if required".

Instinet's revenues grew by 46% year on year to £189m in the three months to September 30, contributing to total Reuters turnover for the quarter of £888m. This beat analysts' forecasts of £840-850m and constituted a 16% year-on-year increase for the company as a whole.

Reuters' chief executive, Peter Job, said: "Our core business in Reuters Financial is thriving in good market conditions. We are also reaping substantial rewards from our decision three years ago to offer lower-priced financial information feeds which our customers use in servicing their own client bases through electronic links."

Mr Job added: "Reuters news and pictures are selling in profusion to general websites as the internet wave spreads out beyond the US to all our global markets. The vision of transforming the corporation for the internet remains right in our minds and the spending programmes to achieve this are moving ahead."

fields.headline: Voting where it counts
fields.standfirst:
Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: Labour may have introduced devolution, but it is having a hard time profiting from it. The Scots and the Welsh are choosing their own folk
fields.body:
The background to Scottish Labour's convulsions after Donald Dewar's death is the fact the Labour party no longer has sole control of executive government in Edinburgh or Cardiff, where a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition is being formed.

Looked at from London, this must look worrying. The personal contacts and friendships that would help ensure that devolution did not bring about dangerous division are no longer reliably in place. But viewed from Edinburgh and Cardiff, the picture looks very different.

Labour may have introduced devolution but it has had difficulty profiting from it. The party performed poorly in the first devolution elections. In Scotland its 34% share of the party list vote was lower than in any Westminster election since 1931. In Wales, its 35% share broke records as far back as 1918.

This was not some mid-term protest reaction to the performance and policies of the Blair government. In both Scotland and Wales more people thought things had improved since Labour had come to power than thought they had got worse, at least as far as living standards, education and unemployment were concerned. Whatever people thought of the record of the government seemed to make little difference to whether or not they remained loyal to Labour in their new national elections.

Labour's difficulties lay elsewhere. People who were still willing to vote Labour for Westminster proved reluctant to back the party when it came to the Scottish or Welsh contests. Many opted for the nationalists instead.

In Scotland, Labour's share of the vote was no less than 9% adrift of what it would have secured in a Westminster election. In Wales, the equivalent figure was as much as 13%. Without this devolution gap Labour would have done pretty much as well as it had in 1997. There would be no need of a coalition in Wales and maybe not even in Scotland.

Meanwhile, the nationalists rode high. In Scotland they were 7% better off than they would have been in a Westminster byelection. In Wales they were no less than 17% ahead. Without the devolution gap, the "quiet earthquake" experienced in last year's Welsh election would not have registered on the Richter scale at all.

Nothing that Labour has done in the first year of devo lution has closed the devolution gap. For example, the most recent Scottish poll puts Labour and the Scottish National party (SNP) even stevens when it came to people's intentions on voting for the House of Commons, but no less than 14% behind in the race for the Scottish parliament.

So what accounts for the devolution gap? Why did voters who would not consider voting nationalist in a Westminster election do so when it came to the devolved elections?

Unsurprisingly, perhaps, many voters in Scotland and Wales are doubtful about how far London looks after them. In both countries no more than one in three believes that the UK government works in their country's best long-term interests "just about always" or "most of the time". So when invited to elect a parliament for Scotland and an assembly for Wales, many were looking for a party that would use the new institutions to redress the balance.

Many doubted Labour fitted the bill. Just 40% of people in Scotland trust Labour to look after their interests. In Wales, the equivalent figure is 44%. In contrast 68% in Scotland trust the SNP to look after Scots' interests and in Wales 82% say the same of Plaid Cymru.

And it was these perceptions that brought new votes into the nationalist camp. Our research looked at those who said they would not have voted nationalist in a Westminster election who actually did so in last year's devolved election, broken down by the level of trust they had in the ability of various institutions to advance Scottish/Welsh interests. We found voters who were distrustful of the UK government in general and of New Labour in particular were more likely to switch to the nationalists. In Scotland, it was the former perception that was the more important while in Wales it was the latter - a reflection, perhaps, of the particular opprobrium Labour heaped upon itself by attempting to block Rhodri Morgan's progress towards leadership of the Welsh assembly. Voters were even more likely to switch if at the same time they trusted the SNP or Plaid Cymru (as most of them did).

The Scottish and Welsh Labour parties themselves were unable to escape from the long shadow cast by New Labour at Westminster. Voters did take a more charitable view when they were asked whether Scottish or Welsh Labour looked after the interests of people in their country. As the chart shows, substantially more trusted their national Labour parties over Labour at large.

But these perceptions were unable to stem the tide to the nationalists, which proved equally strong among those who trusted the Scottish or Welsh Labour parties as among those who did not.

The lesson for Labour in both Scotland and Wales is clear. Voters want those running their new institutions to advance their interests. If they are not to conclude that only the nationalists will do so, then Labour needs to show it can do things differently in Scotland and Wales than in London. Preserving the United Kingdom's unions means allowing the devolution child to grow up, not keeping it tied to its umbilical cord.

John Curtice is deputy director of the Economic and Social Research Council's Centre for research into elections and social trends.

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk
