Looked at from London, this must look worrying. The personal contacts and friendships that would help ensure that devolution did not bring about dangerous division are no longer reliably in place. But viewed from Edinburgh and Cardiff, the picture looks very different. Labour may have introduced devolution but it has had difficulty profiting from it. The party performed poorly in the first devolution elections. In Scotland its 34% share of the party list vote was lower than in any Westminster election since 1931. In Wales, its 35% share broke records as far back as 1918. This was not some mid-term protest reaction to the performance and policies of the Blair government. In both Scotland and Wales more people thought things had improved since Labour had come to power than thought they had got worse, at least as far as living standards, education and unemployment were concerned. Whatever people thought of the record of the government seemed to make little difference to whether or not they remained loyal to Labour in their new national elections. Labour's difficulties lay elsewhere. People who were still willing to vote Labour for Westminster proved reluctant to back the party when it came to the Scottish or Welsh contests. Many opted for the nationalists instead. In Scotland, Labour's share of the vote was no less than 9% adrift of what it would have secured in a Westminster election. In Wales, the equivalent figure was as much as 13%. Without this devolution gap Labour would have done pretty much as well as it had in 1997. There would be no need of a coalition in Wales and maybe not even in Scotland. Meanwhile, the nationalists rode high. In Scotland they were 7% better off than they would have been in a Westminster byelection. In Wales they were no less than 17% ahead. Without the devolution gap, the "quiet earthquake" experienced in last year's Welsh election would not have registered on the Richter scale at all. Nothing that Labour has done in the first year of devo lution has closed the devolution gap. For example, the most recent Scottish poll puts Labour and the Scottish National party (SNP) even stevens when it came to people's intentions on voting for the House of Commons, but no less than 14% behind in the race for the Scottish parliament. So what accounts for the devolution gap? Why did voters who would not consider voting nationalist in a Westminster election do so when it came to the devolved elections? Unsurprisingly, perhaps, many voters in Scotland and Wales are doubtful about how far London looks after them. In both countries no more than one in three believes that the UK government works in their country's best long-term interests "just about always" or "most of the time". So when invited to elect a parliament for Scotland and an assembly for Wales, many were looking for a party that would use the new institutions to redress the balance. Many doubted Labour fitted the bill. Just 40% of people in Scotland trust Labour to look after their interests. In Wales, the equivalent figure is 44%. In contrast 68% in Scotland trust the SNP to look after Scots' interests and in Wales 82% say the same of Plaid Cymru. And it was these perceptions that brought new votes into the nationalist camp. Our research looked at those who said they would not have voted nationalist in a Westminster election who actually did so in last year's devolved election, broken down by the level of trust they had in the ability of various institutions to advance Scottish/Welsh interests. We found voters who were distrustful of the UK government in general and of New Labour in particular were more likely to switch to the nationalists. In Scotland, it was the former perception that was the more important while in Wales it was the latter - a reflection, perhaps, of the particular opprobrium Labour heaped upon itself by attempting to block Rhodri Morgan's progress towards leadership of the Welsh assembly. Voters were even more likely to switch if at the same time they trusted the SNP or Plaid Cymru (as most of them did). The Scottish and Welsh Labour parties themselves were unable to escape from the long shadow cast by New Labour at Westminster. Voters did take a more charitable view when they were asked whether Scottish or Welsh Labour looked after the interests of people in their country. As the chart shows, substantially more trusted their national Labour parties over Labour at large. But these perceptions were unable to stem the tide to the nationalists, which proved equally strong among those who trusted the Scottish or Welsh Labour parties as among those who did not. The lesson for Labour in both Scotland and Wales is clear. Voters want those running their new institutions to advance their interests. If they are not to conclude that only the nationalists will do so, then Labour needs to show it can do things differently in Scotland and Wales than in London. Preserving the United Kingdom's unions means allowing the devolution child to grow up, not keeping it tied to its umbilical cord. John Curtice is deputy director of the Economic and Social Research Council's Centre for research into elections and social trends. J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk

webTitle: Polio vaccine recalled in BSE alert

fields.headline: Polio vaccine recalled in BSE alert
fields.trailText: An oral polio vaccine, Medeva, regularly used to inoculate children and travellers was today recalled amid fears over BSE.
fields.body:
NHS Direct:
 Telephone 0845 4647
 NHS Direct homepage
Read the Chief Medical Officer's recall statement

A polio vaccine regularly used to inoculate children and travellers was today recalled amid fears over BSE.

The risks to humans of catching CJD - the human form of BSE - was "incalculably small", the Department of Health has said.

GPs were being advised that, as a precautionary measure, all stocks of the Medeva oral polio vaccine should be withdrawn immediately, with replacement supplies made by Smith Kline Beecham being brought in as quickly as possible.

Health chiefs said there had been a breach of health guidelines in the manufacture of the vaccine. European rules say oral medicinal products should not use bovine materials from countries in which there are known cases of BSE.

The Department of Health said the recall affected only one particular brand of polio vaccine, which was due to be replaced anyway.

A spokesman said: "As the national supply of polio vaccine has already switched to a different manufacturer, the impact of the recall on the polio vaccination programme is likely to be minimal."

Smith Kline Beecham confirmed it has sufficient supplies to meet demand, the health department said, though this may mean smaller but more frequent deliveries.

The recall is based on the discovery of a breach of European guidelines issued in 1999 as a precautionary measure to protect public health in the light of developing information about the theoretical transmission of BSE.

The first guidance, issued by the Committee on Safety of Medicines in 1989, asked that UK-sourced bovine materials should not be used in the manufacture of injectable medicinal products.

The implementation of this guidance led to a phasing out during the early 1990s of vaccines that had used UK-sourced bovine material in their manufacture. From 1989 onwards, the MCA had sought and received assurances from drug companies that they were implementing this guidance.

The chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, has written to all GPs today advising them of the recall.

He said: "I know that this recall will worry parents, but it is important to remember that polio is a potentially lethal disease which we have virtually eliminated from this country.

"As late as 1955 there were nearly 4,000 cases in England and Wales. Only by keeping our children vaccinated can we ensure it does not return to this country.

Anti-vaccine campaigners said the recall was another example of the hidden dangers of inoculations.

Ann Coote, a spokeswoman for JABS, a self-help group for people worried about vaccines, said: "This will scare parents. They will want to know: 'Why weren't we told before? What really is the risk?'

"The government always says the risks are 'minimal', but we won't know, will we, until and unless someone gets the human form of BSE."

62, Conservative MP for Central Suffolk & North Ipswich

Majority: 3,538 over Labour

Seat: Central Suffolk and North Ipswich since 1997 (former seat Central Suffolk 1983-97)

Outlook: A staunch Maastricht rebel, neutralised as a firm but fair deputy speaker; strongly anti-EU and an opponent of jargon; on subjects he knows about tends to raise questions rather than find flip solutions.

Traits: Balding, clubby, square face, pleasant, modest, authoritative, former Cambridge rugby blue, cricketer, was banned for speeding on A140, which he had campaigned to make safer.

History: Joined Young Conservatives 1956; campaigned and voted against remaining in the EU, 1975; elected for Central Suffolk, June 1983; supported rugby tour of South Africa, 1984; rebelled against Maastricht treaty, 1993; voted to restore capital punishment, 1994; was made deputy speaker, May 1997; sent Serjeant at Arms into voting lobbies to speed up voting of Tory MPs, 1997

59, Liberal Democrat, North East Fife

Majority: 10,356 over Conservatives

Seat: The prosperous rural bulk of the ancient kingdom of Fife, sprinkled with villages, resorts and solidly-Conservative towns

Outlook: "Few other LibDem spokesmen sound as authoritative" (Peter Riddell, The Times), "is said to impress Tony Blair" (Steve Richards, New Statesman), the active, mainstream Scots QC, who recaptured Asquith's old seat for the Liberals on his third try, a former athletic star, he admits to being "obsessed" by anabolic steroids

Traits: Tall, balding, "notably-stylish" (his wife), when he left a suitcase behind en-route to a party conference, he phoned Austin Reed to order a suit to be despatched to him; self-assured; clear minded; ex-runner (on Olympic team Tokyo, 1964)

History: Elected for north-east Fife, June 1987; became defence spokesman, September 1988; became defence and foreign affairs spokesman, 1994; recalled he had once raced 60 yards indoors to beat a (then) obscure American athlete called OJ Simpson, November 1996

fields.headline: D'Arcy rolls out road safety campaign
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: A new government campaign aimed at encouraging children to take care on the roads will launch on nationwide TV tomorrow, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A new government campaign aimed at encouraging children to take care on the roads will launch on nationwide TV tomorrow.

The campaign, which was created by government ad agency D'Arcy, will feature the popular cartoon hedgehogs dancing and singing a specially-adapted version of 70s disco classic Staying Alive.

The ads will appear in slots on prime time TV and will be followed by a new ad later this month encouraging children to make sure they can be seen on the road.

Lord Whitty, the transport and environment minister, said: "Child road accidents are still too high, with most of these accidents happening close to home and on residential roads. It is vitally important that road safety skills become almost second nature to children, and that is what the campaign is trying to achieve."

Outlook: A leading stalwart of the "lost generation" of Labour MPs first elected in 1979 and therefore too old for the ageist Blair administration 18 years later; a very bright, never fully-numerate, soft-left, eurosceptic, Scots engineer; understands phone tapping from previous career with Post Office; defender of defence industry

fields.trailText: Career is not progressing. Passed over in reshuffle. Lost £491 at backgammon. Must stop. I'm not at all a well man.
fields.body:
Saltwood, 1972-1982

Been v depressed. The moat's leaking and Hoare's are pressing me to reduce the o/d. Debts now total £80,000 Again. What if the Tate defaults on the Saltonstall? Took a couple of 1000mg Redoxons but am still not a well man. Temperature of 99.3 and feel shattered, puis. It's probably my prostate. Caught sight of myself in the mirror. So lined, so grey, so old. Despite this I still feel healthily randy. If only the blondes hadn't dumped me.

Back to Plymouth for constituency business. God, I loathe the place. They haven't liked me much since I openly lent my support to Enoch. Will no one stand up for Britishness? If APC quits Folkestone, I'll try my luck there. My political career is not progressing. I don't mind being snubbed by John Patten, who is so ambitious he wouldn't dream of acknowledging any inferior, but Ian Gow walked straight past me. Should I be reading anything into this?

Met Uncle Harold on my way out of the commons. "Off to my club," the old PM said. "Whites or Brooks?" I asked. "The Carlton, you fool," he snapped. Is this a good sign? Went to Brooks where I lost £742 at backgammon. I'm not at all well. My back is playing up and the tip of my penis is quite numb.

Had a small spot of bother with a woman who was threatening to go to the papers. Asked Jonathan Aitken what I should do. "Pay her off," he advised. I gave her £5,000. JA said he would have bargained for £4,000.

Let it be known in a roundabout way that Francis Pym could be next PM. He visibly swelled. Ian invited me for a drink with Margaret. An extraordinarily attractive woman. A few signs of getting a little broad in the beam, though. Hope she doesn't adopt the dowager look.

Made a speech that was rather well received. Worried about using the word, 'insouciance', but the papers picked up on it and like it. Jotted down a few pensees d'escalier for the Telegraph. Ian implied I might be in line for Margaret's PPS. How loathsome Lawson, oily Gummer and totally bonkers Joseph will have to crawl. For me it will be a K, the FO and the leadership.

60, Labour MP for South Shields

Majority: 22,153 over Conservatives

Seat: South Shields (since 1979, Colne Valley 1970-74), a coal mining and shipbuilding city at the mouth of the Tyne

Outlook: The sacked cabinet minister who went bald awaiting his press-heralded execution; his widely-admired Freedom of Information White paper was the subject of tussles with Lord Irvine and Jack Straw, but the year-long negative briefing was attributed to Peter Mandelson, who allegedly coveted his job. Clarke was previously one of the victims of Blair's last-minute switches in ministerial appointments in '97; the defence secretary post to which he seemed entitled by his long and patient search for a consensus among Labour MPs went to George Robertson as recompense for losing the post of Scottish secretary to Donald Dewar. Instead, he was landed with a Freedom of Information Act which could pass Lord Irvine's scrutiny; when it did, to general acclaim, it was too late to cancel his execution; his pre-election achievement of a multi-lateralist consensus was also under-estimated.

Eurosceptic, pro-NATO, basically an environmentalist crusader, badger-protector, footpath-bulldozer and libertarian rambler who made green issues sexy.

Traits: Blond, retreating hair; genial; earnest; dedicated; worthy; hardworking

History:Joined Labour party 1959; won Colne Valley from Liberal Richard Wainwright June 1970; lost it February 1974; elected for South Shields 1979; quietly resigned as deputy spokesman on defence because his views were not in keeping with those of the Labour party nationally; named spokesman on the environment November 1986; named chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster in the cabinet office, with responsibility for open government, May 1997; was sacked from the cabinet, blaming it on his insistence on living in the north east and missing out on the London cocktail circuit, July 1998

fields.headline: Polio vaccinations
fields.standfirst: The health authorities are trying to calm fears over whether polio vaccinations have been infected with CJD. Mark Oliver explains the issue
fields.trailText: The health authorities are trying to calm fears over whether polio vaccinations have been infected with CJD. We explain the issue.
fields.body:
What is the scare about?
An oral polio vaccine, Medeva, has been recalled amid fears over CJD, the human form of BSE or "mad cow disease". Medeva is partly made up of bovine materials from the UK, where there have been cases of BSE. The fear is the vaccine may include BSE contaminated traces. The guidelines that should ensure suspect medicines are prohibited have been breached, and the discovery of this fact by the Medical Controls Agency has triggered today's recall.

What are the risks of this vaccine giving someone CJD?
"Incalculably small" according to the Department of Health, which insists that the recall is a precautionary one and that the vaccine was due for replacement anyway. The vaccine contains tiny traces of a foetal calf growth serum, but this is classified under the European guidelines as in category IV, which stands for "no detectable ineffectively". Also, the manufacturing processes used to make the vaccine are designed to remove the serum. The Department of Health stress that it is balance of these points which makes them confident it is unlikely anyone will contract BSE from the vaccine.

How widely is Medeva used?
It has been given to hundreds of thousands of patients, usually on sugar cubes, to children or travellers. The vaccine has been used since the early 1980s and, up until this September, accounted for a third of all polio inoculations. Alternatives are available and supplies by Smith Kline Beecham are being increased with haste.

How has this happened?
It is not yet clear exactly how the vaccine has remained in use, but the government have said that assurances were repeatedly "sought and received" from Medeva that they were implementing new guidelines on bovine materials that came into force last year. The Department of Health, whose suspicions were raised in June, have said that they now know these assurances were inaccurate. Medeva today said they were preparing a statement on the recall.

What is the advice for people who are concerned?
GPs are being advised by the Department of Health on the scare, and the NHS Direct call line (0845 4647) can answer specific anxieties. The government have told doctors that immunisation programmes should continue with alternative vaccines. If you or your child have had a Medeva vaccination, there is no urgent need to have any kind of check up, as the current advice is that there is such a tiny risk of contracting BSE.

Are there other concerns?
The fears of the British Polio Fellowship are that the scare might deter people from being vaccinated. In a statement, the fellowship said that there was still a "real risk" of polio and cited a case in Holland a few years ago where a religious community decided against vaccinations and there was an epidemic. They also called for more stringent monitoring processes on BSE risks.

The Department of Health stress that it is balance of these points which makes them confident it is unlikely anyone will contract BSE from the vaccine. How widely is Medeva used? It has been given to hundreds of thousands of patients, usually on sugar cubes, to children or travellers. The vaccine has been used since the early 1980s and, up until this September, accounted for a third of all polio inoculations. Alternatives are available and supplies by Smith Kline Beecham are being increased with haste. How has this happened? It is not yet clear exactly how the vaccine has remained in use, but the government have said that assurances were repeatedly "sought and received" from Medeva that they were implementing new guidelines on bovine materials that came into force last year. The Department of Health, whose suspicions were raised in June, have said that they now know these assurances were inaccurate. Medeva today said they were preparing a statement on the recall. What is the advice for people who are concerned? GPs are being advised by the Department of Health on the scare, and the NHS Direct call line (0845 4647) can answer specific anxieties. The government have told doctors that immunisation programmes should continue with alternative vaccines. If you or your child have had a Medeva vaccination, there is no urgent need to have any kind of check up, as the current advice is that there is such a tiny risk of contracting BSE. Are there other concerns? The fears of the British Polio Fellowship are that the scare might deter people from being vaccinated. In a statement, the fellowship said that there was still a "real risk" of polio and cited a case in Holland a few years ago where a religious community decided against vaccinations and there was an epidemic. They also called for more stringent monitoring processes on BSE risks.

webTitle: BSE advisers see danger in European beef

fields.headline: BSE advisers see danger in European beef
fields.standfirst:
Safety committee member will not eat French meat
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The government's advisers on BSE risked starting a new row with France yesterday when they suggested British beef was now safer than that in other European countries and that tourists should be told of potential risks of catching the human form of the disease from infected cows abroad.
fields.byline: James Meikle and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
The government's advisers on BSE risked starting a new row with France yesterday when they suggested British beef was now safer than that in other European countries and that tourists should be told of potential risks of catching the human form of the disease from infected cows abroad.

Harriet Kimbell, the consumer representative on a committee made up mostly of scientists, said she had made a personal decision not to let her family eat French beef or beef products on holiday, but ministers should stop short of telling other people to follow suit.

"I would like information in the public domain so people can make their own choices," she said. "People should be made aware of countries where BSE is increasing.

"I would not have the British government saying, 'Don't eat beef in France.' I made up my mind for my family. I would not dream of telling everyone else what to do for their particular families."

Mrs Kimbell, who lectures at the College of Law, Guildford, and is deputy chairwoman of the Consumers' Association, said she had stopped her sons, Andrew, 17, and Ben, 14, eating beef when on holiday in the French Alps last year. She had taken them round the buffet in the dining room at the centre where they were staying and "told them what to eat and what not to eat".

Tourists and other Britons travelling abroad should, she said, "be made aware that it may well be British beef is safer than beef in some European countries, and then they can make up their own mind if they want to incur the risk of eating beef elsewhere".

Peter Smith, acting chairman of the spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee, said he "did not feel uncomfortable" eating British beef, although animals in other countries might be going into the food chain further into the BSE incubationperiod. There was a "cogent case" that British beef might now be safer than that in other countries even if the size of their epidemics was far smaller, he added.

The committee has asked the food standards agency to review checks that beef from cattle infected with the disease, but not showing outward signs, is not slipping into Britain illegally. All European countries are now required to ban parts of cattle thought to be most at risk of spreading BSE infection to humans, but in addition Britain bans all animals more than 30 months old, including imports from countries with BSE.

The food agency said there were no grounds to advise against consumption of legally sold EU beef, while a source at the French agriculture ministry said people were entitled to their point of view.

He added: "We do not pretend that our preventative measures against BSE are perfect and we are ceaselessly improving them in consul tation with our scientists."

France, which has refused to lift its ban on British beef and has reported more than 150 cases of BSE in all - including 71 so far this year - exports nearly 5,000 tonnes a year to the UK. Ireland, where there have been 500 BSE cases, is Britain's biggest supplier, sending 77,000 tonnes annually. Other countries with BSE include Portugal, where there have been 452 cases, and Switzerland, where there have been 359 cases.

Despite the decline in the BSE epidemic in Britain, there have already been 962 cases this year, bringing the total to 177,314. Many thousands of infected animals are thought to have entered the food chain during the late 1980s before the first BSE controls were introduced.

Last year Britain still had 472 BSE cases for every million cattle more than 24 months old. France had 2.8 for every million.

Most animals struck down by BSE are far older than 30 months and scientists in the UK now believe that only one British cow a year over 30 months, and likely to display BSE if not killed, is slipping through the net.

The advisory committee has also recommended new experiments to ensure pigs and poultry cannot carry "hidden BSE" and infect people eating their meat. Tests in the early 1990s suggested this was not possible but new research using mice and hamsters injected with a BSE-like disease has reawakened fears.

webTitle: BSE and polio: A history of incompetence and complicity

fields.headline: A history of incompetence and complicity
fields.standfirst:
James Meikle says we should not be surprised to learn that material from British cows has been used in polio vaccine throughout the BSE crisis
Polio vaccine recalled in BSE alert
fields.trailText: James Meikle says we should not be surprised to learn that material from British cows has been used in polio vaccine throughout the BSE crisis.
fields.body:
Today's shocking revelation that a common polio vaccine grown using material from British cows has been in use since early in the BSE crisis should perhaps not really be so surprising.

The history of incompetence in identifying and managing risk, and a tendency to cohabit with the beef industry rather than with consumers displayed by agriculture and health officials during the crisis, has been glaringly exposed during the two year BSE inquiry whose report is published next week.

The possibility of people catching a human form of the incurable cattle condition from medicines was identified by some advisers as early as autumn 1987 but the then chief medical officer and his ministers were not informed even of the disease until March 1988.

Since 1989 there has been a succession of guidelines from Whitehall and, later, Brussels on sourcing material, usually calf serum for growing vaccines, from countries which have no history of BSE. But only in March next year will these have the full force of law.

More surprisingly, EU guidelines have explicitly covered oral vaccines - as well as injected alternatives - only since 1999. Nevertheless, the spirit of the guidance was always meant to cover all types.

It has been taken largely on trust that the medicines industry follows such guidance. Until very recently, it hid behind confidentiality clauses when journalists or the public tried to find out how many products still used British-sourced cattle products. The health department has always argued that scares about vaccine safety would be more dangerous than what it first called the "theoretical", and more recently "remote", risk of BSE infection, as huge numbers of parents might stop inoculating their children. It therefore allowed stocks of vaccines using British bovine sources to be used well into the 1990s without even telling the public about the concerns.

But its pathetic excuse over the Medeva polio vaccine - that "the assurances by the company have proven inaccurate" - shows just how poor the regulation of drugs really is. Most scientists in the field do not believe that vaccines are the cause of the present human BSE epidemic, which has so far killed 77 Britons and infected seven others.

But conspiracy theorists who believe the government was happier to let the farming industry endure years of penury and penitence for feeding Britons poisoned meat rather than see profitable pharmaceutical companies embarrassed will have had their worst suspicions confirmed.

webTitle: Vodafone takes on BT in fixed-line service

fields.headline: Vodafone takes on BT in fixed-line service
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Vodafone, Britain's largest mobile phone operator, yesterday stepped up the competition for BT's core fixed-line customers.
fields.body:
Vodafone, Britain's largest mobile phone operator, yesterday stepped up the competition for BT's core fixed-line customers.

The mobile operator is to extend its fixed-line service to include residential customers and small businesses and market it under the Vodafone name.

For the past two years it has included Energis, Cable & Wireless, and First Telecom fixed-line services in its communication packages for its large corporate customers.

A Vodafone spokeswoman said the new service would undercut BT services by 33% for business users and 25% for residential customers. Calls to Vodafone mobile phones would cost just 5.5p a minute.

The company has signed a contract with Atlantic Telecom, which will provide the technology, network, back office and billing facilities for the new service. Vodafone will be responsible for its sale and marketing.

Graham Duncan, the executive chairman of Atlantic Telecom, said the deal was the first fixed-line contract the company had struck with a major operator.

It would help offset the tens of millions of pounds which Atlantic was spending every year on expanding its fixed-line and wireless networks in Britain, Germany, Holland and France.

Atlantic, which is still losing money, will get a commission of up to 30% on calls by the Vodafone customers.

Industry sources said that Vodafone would be in a strong position to sell the service to its existing 10m mobile customers.

Initially the service will only be available in the south-west, in central and north-east London and in Yorkshire. A decision on whether to roll it out nationwide will be taken early in the new year.

fields.headline: TiVo's results exceed expectations
fields.trailText: 11am: TiVo has exceeded Wall Street expectations in its third-quarter results, reports Claire Cozens
fields.body:
TiVo, the US company that is poised to revolutionise TV habits by allowing viewers to create their own schedules, has exceeded Wall Street expectations in its third-quarter results.

The company reported a net loss of $64m (£41.8m) - or $1.72 (£1.12) per share - for the third quarter. Analysts expected its losses to be around $2.3 (£1.5) per share.

Revenue was up 39% on the previous quarter and topped $1m (£652,699) for the first time. In the third quarter of last year, TiVo reported £21,599 in revenue.

The company said its subscriber base had risen from 48,000 to 73,000.

TiVo, which launched in the UK last month, works by storing up to 40 hours of programming on the hard drive of a set-top box. The UK version is being marketed alongside BSkyB, although users do not need to be Sky subscribers.

The company has said it will put the consumer in full control of their viewing. The box can store programming according to viewing habits, recording programmes according to genre, such as soaps or documentaries.

But there are concerns that viewers will also use TiVo to fast-forward through most advertising, which would prove disastrous for commercial channels.

Viewers of the channel will have access to 52,000 text entries, 3,000 photographs and 470 maps.

fields.headline: Schrock exits AltaVista
fields.trailText: 11.30am: AltaVista's chief executive officer, Rod Schrock, is leaving the internet search company, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AltaVista chief executive officer Rod Schrock is leaving the internet search company to spend more time with his family.

In a surprise move, Mr Schrock leaves the company immediately, although it has been reported that he told fellow executives about his decision a few weeks' ago.

Mr Schrock said he took the decision to quit in September after "working like hell for 15 years". He said he was confident that AltaVista would continue towards profitability.

However, AltaVista has recently failed to launch a much-hyped unmetered service in the UK and laid off around 25% of its US workforce last month in a bid to get closer to profitability.

CMGI, which is currently going through its own restructure, owns about 83% of AltaVista.

fields.headline: In brief: In Beautiful Disguises by Rajeev Balasubramanyan
fields.trailText: This is the book that took our longlisters by surprise: a novel of fantasy versus reality set in the mind of an Indian teenager who imagines herself as Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's while battling with the expectations of her southern Indian society.
fields.body:
This is the book that took our longlisters by surprise: a novel of fantasy versus reality set in the mind of an Indian teenager who imagines herself as Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's while battling with the expectations of her southern Indian society.

Judging by the paucity of critical response, it took everyone else by surprise too. It was reviewed in only two places, with Andrew Biswell in the Daily Telegraph praising its ability to combine a bawdy, comic style with moments of seriousness and emotional depth. In the Guardian, meanwhile, Lisa Darnell found it colourful, spirited and crackling with charm.

But the reading group at Borders in Cheshire Oaks - one of four that are helping to decide the shortlist for the award - were not quite so impressed. They found the characters a bit cartoonish, although they felt its underlying themes were strong, and particlarly liked the way it dealt with class.

fields.headline: In brief: Ubiquity by Mark Buchanan
fields.trailText: The ability to put complex ideas simply is much sought-after in this pop-science era. The problem is finding a specialism that hasn't already been explained to death. In his controversial debut, Buchanan makes the case for applying the laws of physics to weather reports, history and even politics. His theory is based on some very complicated scientific theories that are, in turn, based on simple observations: if you create a pile of rice, grain by grain, sooner or later it will topple. You can predict the likely frequency of the avalanches, but not when they will happen or what size each will be.

On the critical side would be specialists who found flaws in the data: Lavers himself wasn't too impressed with Buchanan's approach to the death of the dinosaurs. But this didn't invalidate the thesis. "I wish there were more juicy, thought-provoking books like Buchanan's on the popular-science shelves," he concluded.

fields.headline: Rock on
fields.standfirst: The vogue for vintage chic comes as no surprise to designer Anna Sui: she's been doing it for decades.  Hadley Freeman meets the queen of retro
fields.trailText: The vogue for vintage chic comes as no surprise to designer Anna Sui: she's been doing it for decades. Hadley Freeman meets the queen of retro
fields.body:
20s, 40s, 80s - any decade but this one seems to be the current mantra of the biggest designers, judging by this season's fashion weeks. From puffball skirts to off-the-shoulder jumpers, retro fashion, in particular the 80s - once seen as the enclave of the few more experimental designers - has become the byword for this year's style.

But while many fashion watchers have gushed over these re-interpretations of the styles of their youth, New York designer Anna Sui (pronounced Swee) remains blase, citing historical precedents. "Fashion has always looked back, you know. The New Look [of 1947] was not a new look; Dior was doing the clothes of the 1860s, the 1870s, those fitted coats with the peplum. He changed it, but that was the influence. Even disco clothes and Versace in the 80s, they were almost Grecian or Roman, so I don't think there's anything new."

One could forgive Sui, though, if she has a bit of a gloat in private. After all, her fashion has been looking over its shoulder since she started her label in 1980. Unlike the current ironic references to fashion from the past, Sui's clothes have no time for tongue-in-cheek homages. From the sweetest and wispiest of chiffon dresses to velvet BoHo jackets, these are clothes that look as though they actually come from the vintage store and from the decades to which they refer. And not at too fashion-fantastic prices: a dress will cost you roughly £200.

It was not until the early 90s that New York's fashion scene was able to accommodate Sui rather than relegate her to outsider status. Her pretty floral dresses and shiny trousers provided an oasis of colour in the sea of sleek black polo-necks and tasteful wide-leg trousers that, until a few years ago, dominated New York fashion. (Surprisingly, this was exactly the outfit Sui was wearing when we met.)

Her first catwalk show was in 1991, over 10 years after she launched her signature line - "It took a while for me to get the confidence!" Ever since, her little tea dresses, skinny-leg trousers and rock star-style slashed bustiers have been spotted on the likes of Madonna, Christina Ricci and Jennifer Lopez. It is a style that proclaims the wearer is, quite frankly, cooler than you: here is a girl (or guy - Sui does a limited men's range) who doesn't kowtow to fashion dictators. Here is someone with vintage nous and here is a little thing they just, oh, you know, found in a flea market outside Berlin. Her flagship boutique in New York's SoHo showcases finds from her vintage hunts around the world, alongside her clothes, shoes and recently launched cosmetics and perfume range. It is small, dark, and probably described as "a treasure trove" in shopping guidebooks.

Sui's solemn appearance is at odds with her reputation as the rock chick of fashion - one of her closest friends is James Iha of the Smashing Pumpkins and Anita Pallenberg turned up at her recent perfume launch in London. Her voice, too, is not what one might expect from the designer of babydoll dresses and frilly viscose skirts - she has a low monotone, which muffles the potential mumbo jumbo-like nature of some of her statements ("I try to transport my designs into the space I aim to create"). In the main, though, she is cogent, plain-speaking and very intelligent.

So what does Sui think of this return to the 80s? "It seems the twentysomething generation is always looking for some kind of rebellion, choosing something other people aren't quite going to understand," she says, smiling benevolently. "And I think the mall fashion of the 80s was pretty wretched back then. So for people to make it kind of cool makes it kitsch, I guess ... When it doesn't work, then hopefully it will go away." Which, from polite American PR-speak into English, translates as, let's hope the madness ends soon.

Sui's approach to fashion is itself in vogue: aside from the culling of decades, her intellectualisation of design is now seen as respectable and right rather than eccentric. Just look at the adulation ladled on conceptual designers such as London's self-consciously cerebal Hussein Chalayan. Sui's work always has direct references (like last season's Fauvist collection) and is thoroughly researched. For her 1996 English Arts and Crafts collection, Sui visited Sissinghurst and Charleston, homes of Vita Sackville-West and Vanessa Bell. "I see it as part of my continuing education," Sui says, smiling shyly. "I feel that, y'know, maybe I missed out not going to a proper college, spending four years studying fashion. So now I research everything that interests me."

It is not just in the fashion world that Sui has laboured under the tag "different". Born in 1955, she was the only daughter of first generation Chinese immigrants in Detroit, the sole Chinese family in the neighbourhood. "It kind of made us a novelty," she says, with a fading Midwest twang. "It set us aside a little and it kind of worked for us rather than against."

Even within her family, Sui stood out. While in the 70s her brothers were training to be stockbrokers in Michigan, Sui was hitting the New York underground punk scene with a vengeance and training to be a fashion designer at Parsons School of Design.

It was the music scene that helped Sui lose the "unusual and eccentric" tag. The babydoll dresses and fishnet tights she showed in 1994 dovetailed perfectly with the growing American grunge scene - as that doyenne of grunge, Courtney Love, recognised.

"That was such an exciting time," Sui says. "One day I got a call from the shop saying Courtney was there and she'd turned it into a teenage girl's bedroom - there were clothes everywhere and she was getting dressed in the middle of the room. This was not the first time Sui had been helped out by someone in the public eye. Her dresses were first brought into the spotlight when her friends Naomi Campbell and Linda Evangelista sported them while running between fashion shows in Paris a decade ago. When she finally put on her first catwalk show, Steven Meisel, celebrity photographer and best friend from her days at Parsons, helped her with the staging.

"During the 80s, the fashion shows were ruled by the big guys, like Versace and Chanel," Sui says. "So it was almost impossible for me to break through that stronghold."

The irony is that, with the rise of designers such as Donatella at Versace, Tom Ford at Gucci and now Yves Saint Laurent and Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton, we are back to a similar position. Just as fashion is returning to the 80s, so is its hierarchy. The difference for Sui this time around is that she is being feted alongside them. In fact, in what was largely a heavily criticised New York fashion week, Sui stood out as being one of the few designers not derided for blandness or lack of imagination. To be different is to be celebrated.

As Sui leaves, she suddenly adds a final, unexpected thought: "Y'know, this 80s fashion is really just nostalgia. The present is uncomfortable and scary: you can watch a war on television, kids are bringing weapons to school. People are reverting back to comfort clothes."

Whoever would have thought batwing jumpers would bring solace?

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.standfirst: ... "Whassup!"
fields.trailText: ... "Whassup!"
fields.body:
Gosh, don't you love a catchphrase? So funny, so inclusive, so ironic, so now. And we just lap them up. The dancing Budweiser frogs, Nicole et Papa, Victor Meldrew, not to mention the Catchphrase King himself, Austin Powers.

But then those misguided advertising folk have to come along and burst the ironic bubble. The new Budweiser ad has done for catchphrases what Galliano has done for eccentric chic: taken it that little bit too far and therefore ruined everything, showing all of us what fools we were in the first place.

Sorry, guys, "Whassup!" is just too deliberate, too calculated, too obviously aiming to be a catchphrase, and instead of being funny, it is downright annoying. Kind of like watching your misfit uncle groove on down with your mates - it's not cool, it's embarrassing. Yesterday, stuck on the tube, three guys next to me conducted an entire conversation slurring "Whassup!" at each other, laughing hysterically. For the rest of us, locked up in the carriage between Edgware Road and Baker Street, life rapidly began to lose meaning.

People, quite rightly, make fun of fashion victims for blindly wearing what they are told ("Kate's got a haircut? I'll get a haircut!"), but catchphrase victims are even more tragic. Never again need you want for witty little bons mots - simply shout out an oft-repeated quote from a film ("Excellent!") or a particularly irritating advert ("Hello, boys!") and conversation will sparkle once more.

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about...
fields.standfirst: ... Ann-Louise Roswald
fields.trailText: ... Ann-Louise Roswald
fields.body:
The British are coming! Well, one did, anyway, adding a dash of welcome British individuality to the sleekness of last month's New York fashion week.

Ann-Louise Roswald first came to prominence when she was chosen to design those sunny and funny clogs for Marni in the spring/summer 1999 collection - the ones that shod the elegant feet of all gold-blooded fashionistas last year. Her clothes can be found in an eclectic selection of shops, ranging from the trendy, such as The Cross and Joseph, to the more formal, such as Harrods, reflecting the wide appeal of her designs. (For stockist enquiries, tel 020-7250 1583.) Her clothes have a decidedly British feel to them - Roswald utilises Scottish fabrics, designs and techniques, topped off with stylish twists, such as bright stripy cashmere jumpers and wool tea dresses. With the recent resurrection of Burberry, Daks, Mulberry and The Scotch House (another Roswald stockist), this style could not possibly be more in fashion if it darn well tried.

Nor has Roswald's talent gone unappreciated. This year she was selected for the New Generation Award at London fashion week for the second season in a row. New York is equally besotted with her and she was invited to show her spring/summer 2000 collection there last month. Roswald was the only British designer chosen to take part in the Tencel "7th on Sixth" collection, an annual show that promotes international hotshot designers. Roswald printed some of her characteristic colourful patterns on to Tencel (a fabric a bit like nylon) and, rather intriguingly, managed to knit with Tencel.

Another rising British star, perhaps? Try to grab her stuff before those greedy Americans snaffle her away.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ... Prada skincare
fields.trailText: ... Prada skincare
fields.body:
Once it was Prada bags, then it was Prada shoes, now it's Prada skincare that is the ultimate style statement a high-maintenance fashionista can make. After months of rumours, hints, promises and denials, at last, at last, Miuccia's moisturisers have arrived. Just as we were getting tired of our Creme de la Mer, too.

True to form, style is everything with Prada's skincare, rendering the implausible cool. Items are individually wrapped and sealed "for modern lifestyles requiring total mobility, accessibility, flexibility", the company bigwigs say, rather lyrically. Admittedly, some of the products look rather more like the apparatus for safe sex than for skincare. But then Miuccia is the woman who made the bowling bag the final word in style last year, so who knows? No doubt contraceptive cosmetics will soon be the only kind of cosmetics to have in your Philippe Starck bathroom cabinet.

There are 26 products in the range, all of which emphasise cleanliness and simplicity, such as the Purifying Face Gel and Reviving Eye Cream. Available from this week at Harrods, Knightsbridge, London SW1 and Prada, 43-45 Sloane St, London SW1, each is sold in a plain white box, priced from £43 to £90for a 30-day supply - a mere snip compared with your usual Prada wares.

As for whether it's any good, who cares? The name retains its cachet and whacking a bit of Prada Shielding Balm on your chapped lips is far more stylish than smearing on a bit of Vaseline. It may all be in the label... but what a label.

webTitle: About to die: Hollywood's take on gladiators

fields.headline: About to die: Hollywood's take on gladiators
fields.trailText: It was thumbs down at the British Museum for the Hollywood history of gladiatorial combat, from Quo Vadis through Ben-Hur and Spartacus to this year's Gladiator
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It was thumbs down at the British Museum for the Hollywood history of gladiatorial combat, from Quo Vadis through Ben-Hur and Spartacus to this year's Gladiator.

According to Ralph Jackson, British curator of the first major exhibition on the true history of the Roman games, no thumb was ever turned down to condemn a gladiator to death; no gladiator ever bellowed in the arena "We who are about to die salute you!"; the bloodied losers were carried off carefully on stretchers, not dragged away with hooks.

Most shockingly of all, relatively few died and many lived on to the ripe old age of 35. "The sign for death was a thumb raised," said Dr Jackson, a historical consultant on the blockbuster film Gladiator, which did at least get this bit right.

"The sign for life was probably the thumb hidden away behind the other fingers. As for the shout of 'We who are about to die', we can only find one reference to one fighter saying it on one occasion, and that was not in the arena."

Where Gladiator erred, he said, was in the spectacle of an amphitheatre heaving with gladiators engaged in mass warfare: great movie scene, bad history. In reality, gladiators fought in pairs, in highly choreographed bouts, which ended not with one man being chopped into cat's meat but signalling surrender: most of the complaints by Roman writers were not that the games were barbarous, but that they were boring.

Gladiators, after years of training and wearing expensive handmade armour, capable of winning small fortunes in prize money and large fortunes in bets, were valuable commodities.

"I am not suggesting that the owners looked after their gladiators out of the goodness of their hearts," said co-curator Paul Roberts. "But they were very costly property, they were well taken care of, and the owners were shouting for them to win, not to be killed."

The exhibition, which originated in Germany but has been expanded in London, brings together an unprecedented collection of gladiatorial items from 22 museums in Europe, ranging from cheap souvenirs sold to fans in gift shops at the amphitheatres, to a 2.5-tonne marble grave slab from near Pompeii.

It records the first recorded outbreak of stadium violence, when a punch-up started in the amphitheatre at Pompeii between supporters of the home team and the visitors, which led to a riot in the town and the games being banned for 10 years.

The two most embarrassed warriors in history were on display at the British Museum yesterday, and will be making sporadic appearances during the exhibition.

Blushing under cover of their massive bronze helmets, and tottering under 18kg of kit, were Tim Chamberlain and Tim Clark, the only members of the museum staff who fitted into the replica armour recreated by a German archaeologist from real sword-slashed pieces found in excavations. In fact, the two Tims, though in their 20s, would in historical terms have been getting on a bit as gladiators.

 Gladiators and Caesars is at the British Museum from tomorrow until January 21.

fields.headline: The candidates profiled
fields.trailText: One of Britain's best-known and best-informed political biographers, Andrew Roth examines the MPs who are competing to be the next Speaker.
fields.body:
One of Britain's best-known and best-informed political biographers, Andrew Roth has kept track of the doings and sayings of Britain's MPs over the last four decades. In these exclusive extracts from his series, Parliamentary Profiles, he examines the MPs who are competing to be the next Speaker.

Michael Martin | Sir George Young | Gwyneth Dunwoody | Alan Beith | Menzies Campbell | David Clark | Sir Patrick Cormack | Sir Alan Haselhurst | Michael Lord | John McWilliam | Richard Shepherd | Nicholas Winterton

The front runners

Michael Martin, 55, Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn

Majority: 17,326 over SNP

Seat: Labour's most rock-solid stronghold in Glasgow; its unemployed number among Glasgow's highest; suffers from heavy drug problems

Outlook: Elevated to deputy speaker with his more-in-sorrow-than-in-anger approach; a plain-spoken, warm-hearted, locally-rooted, mainstream moderate Glasgow trade unionist; approaches abortion and homosexuality from a Catholic point of view

Traits: Retiring white hair with sideboards, a square face, with underchin; matey; hill walker; Italian speaker; comic five-a-side footballer

History: Joined Labour party 1967; elected for Springburn 1979; was promoted deputy speaker, May 1997

Sir George Young, 59, Conservative MP for North West Hampshire

Majority: 11,551 over Liberal Democrats

Seat: Hampshire North West since 1997 (formerly Ealing Acton, February 1974-1997). Prosperous rural seat between LibDem Newbury, Romsey and Winchester.

Outlook: Very able, socially conscious; warm and witty liberal; "the bicycling baronet"; widely popular and highly competent; friendly with John Major; changed seats in a 1997 "chicken run"

Traits: Very tall; long nose; he brings a family doctor's manner to the chamber; sent his children to comprehensive school

History: On Lambeth council with John Major; elected February 1974; under secretary for health, May 1979; sacked by Margaret Thatcher, September 1986 voted against poll tax, December 1987; restored to whip's office, July 1990 ("the greatest political comeback since the release of Nelson Mandela", Michael White, The Guardian); promoted to minister of state at the Department of the Environment, November 1990; said he would like to see the nation's cigarettes on a bonfire, November 1990; entered cabinet as secretary of state for transport, 1995; shadow defence secretary, May 1997; became shadow leader of the House of Commons, June 1998; resigned to allow his name to go forward as a candidate for Speaker, September 2000

Gwyneth Dunwoody, 69, Labour MP for Crewe & Nantwich

Majority: 15,798 over Conservative

Seat: Crew and Nantwich, since 1983 (formerly Crewe 1974-83; Exeter 1966-70) A working-class island in Cheshire plus affluent Nantwich market town

Outlook: A brave, bouncy centre-right radical; Eurosceptic; Labour's longest-serving woman MP; opponent of Brussels; also against Trotskists, tokenism for women and smoking; tends to make up with strident verbal hand-bagging for lightness of preparation

Traits: Rotund ("the Battling Butterball"); "I'm not employed for my dress sense"; lively, punchy, vivid speaking style, multi-lingual (Dutch, French and Italian), narrowly escaped eviction proceedings from Barbican flat by paying £5,000 in rent arrears, April 1986; bailiffs seized her furniture over arrears of £7,000, May 1987

History: Joined Labour party 1947; elected to bottom place in shadow cabinet, October 1981; seconded Betty Boothroyd for nomination as Speaker, April 1992; was listed as one of "Blair's bastards" in Hull University research because she had voted 23 times against the party leadership, September 1996; as a veteran, resisted the "potentially dangerous situation" of the over-enthusiastic efforts of the Commons modernisation committee, June 1997

The outside bets

Alan Beith, 57, Liberal Democrat MP for Berwick-upon-Tweed

Majority: 8,042 over Labour

Seat: England's vast (about 1,000 sq. miles), rural constituency: it has tourism, fishing and mining

Outlook: Shrewd, sensible, worthy, realistic, hard-working, well-informed, conscientious deputy headmaster type in the centre-right of mainstream LibDem politics; a Eurofanatic; an upright Methodist; anti-Sunday trading, porn, abortion, drink, tobacco, fluoride, Trident

History: Won Berwick by-election with 53-vote majority, September 1973; became Alliance treasury spokesman 1987; defeated in contest for Liberal Democrat leadership, July 1988; became deputy leader of Liberal Democrats, 1994; became spokesman on home affairs, July 1994;

Traits: Owlish, a waddling bustler, near-teetotal

Menzies Campbell, 59, Liberal Democrat, North East Fife

Majority: 10,356 over Conservatives

Seat: The prosperous rural bulk of the ancient kingdom of Fife, sprinkled with villages, resorts and solidly-Conservative towns

Outlook: "Few other LibDem spokesmen sound as authoritative" (Peter Riddell, The Times), "is said to impress Tony Blair" (Steve Richards, New Statesman), the active, mainstream Scots QC, who recaptured Asquith's old seat for the Liberals on his third try, a former athletic star, he admits to being "obsessed" by anabolic steroids

Traits: Tall, balding, "notably-stylish" (his wife), when he left a suitcase behind en-route to a party conference, he phoned Austin Reed to order a suit to be despatched to him; self-assured; clear minded; ex-runner (on Olympic team Tokyo, 1964)

History: Elected for north-east Fife, June 1987; became defence spokesman, September 1988; became defence and foreign affairs spokesman, 1994; recalled he had once raced 60 yards indoors to beat a (then) obscure American athlete called OJ Simpson, November 1996

David Clark, 60, Labour MP for South Shields

Majority: 22,153 over Conservatives

Seat: South Shields (since 1979, Colne Valley 1970-74), a coal mining and shipbuilding city at the mouth of the Tyne

fields.headline: Queen's dot.com stake falls by £1/2m
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The Queen's much-hyped stake in aerial photography website Getmapping.com has slumped in value by £1/2m, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The value of the Queen's much-hyped stake in aerial photography website Getmapping.com has slumped by £1/2m since the company floated in April.

Her Majesty now joins millions of other investors with first-hand experience of the dot.com bubble bursting.

As Getmapping.com reported first results for the six months to June 30, its share price went into freefall and has already dropped 33.5p to 58.5p since trading began today.

The fact that the website had shut down for a few days while the database was being updated was not helping the plight of the company.

News that Getmapping.com has acquired Wildgoose Publications, a provider of geo-corrected aerial photographs, for £625,000, did little to stop the downward spiral of the share price.

The Queen's 1.5% stake is now valued at £380,000, a far cry from the £950,000 it was worth immediately following the IPO. However, she is still quids in as her original investment was £100,000.

Tristram Cary, managing director of Getmapping.com, said it was "sod's law" that the website was down on the day the company reported its results. He blamed a change of database, saying that the service was back up this morning.

"We had a lot of problems with the data very early on in the year, but everything is moving in the right direction now, particularly with our affiliate programme," he said.

Mr Cary added that 95% of England had now been photographed and that the map would be finished by May next year.

Getmapping posted a pre-tax loss of £695,000 in the six months to June and a loss per share of 2.71 pence. Sales reached £428,000. The company still has £8.9m in the bank after raising £6.5m from its IPO at 200p a share earlier this year.

A spokesman for the Queen said: "It is a private matter and we have no comment to make."

fields.trailText: The FA hope to announce the new England manager by next week, reports the Star. The paper claims that the two leading contenders are Roy Hodgson and Sven Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
The FA hope to announce the new England manager by next week, reports the Star. The paper claims that the two leading contenders are Roy Hodgson and Sven Goran Eriksson.

Fulham are lining up a £6m bid for Blackburn's Matt Jansen, the Sun claims. Manager Jean Tigana was said to be "seriously impressed" with the 23-year-old striker after he scored in Blackburn's 2-1 defeat at Craven Cottage on Sunday.

Meanwhile Graeme Souness has switched his interest to Derby's Dean Sturridge after his bid to land Mark Hughes in a swap deal with Egil Ostenstad was rejected, reports the Star.

Espanyol striker Raul Tamudo will join Rangers in a £10.5m move within the next 48 hours. Tamudo will fly to Scotland today for a medica, according to his agent..

Sunderland manager Peter Reid has denied any interest in Elfsborg striker Fredrik Berglund. "I've shown no interest in him," Reid told the club's official website. "I've no idea where these stories come from. He is not a lad I have been looking at."

Newcastle are having an early season defender sale. Laurent Charvet has arrived at Manchester City to discuss personal terms over a £2m move, while Spanish centre-half Marcelino will also be allowed to leave. Celta Vigo and Depoprtivo La Coruna are said to be interested.

fields.headline: AltaVista boss quits
fields.trailText: Rod Schrock, the chief executive of net portal AltaVista, has resigned, just months before the company's target date for an initial public offering.
fields.body:
Rod Schrock, the chief executive of net portal AltaVista, has resigned, just months before the company's target date for an initial public offering.

The company says that a search for a successor is already underway, and while an IPO was still a "primary goal", it would wait until a new boss was in place.

Schrock's departure comes during a bad year for the company, following the failure to launch an unlimited access internet service in the UK and having to lay off a quarter of its staff. AltaVista postponed its IPO in the spring due to weak market conditions, and has since admitted it does not have the clout to take on top media companies like Yahoo Inc.

However, Schrock said he had actually stayed in his post longer than originally planned in order to see AltaVista through some transitions.

"For four years, I've had the goal to take a break by the Summer Olympics 2000," he said. He said he was disappointed that company obligations caused him to stay on a little longer, but was now planning on spending time with his family.

The company has become a leading net destination, and has grown from 55 employees a year ago to 675 today.

Schrock joined AltaVista last January, as the company was being expanded from a noncommercial search service to a major Internet portal. He added that for all its achievements, AltaVista had been "blessed with a sense of incredibly poor timing".

Aside from its main US site, AltaVista has seven country-specific search engines in Europe as well as an Indian site. An Australian site launched this month, and the company has plans for 35 more country-specific sites in the next year. The company claim over half of their 65 million monthly users are from outside North America.

webTitle: Figo facing a 'derbi' day horror show

fields.headline: Figo facing a 'derbi' day horror show
fields.standfirst: The former Barcelona player can expect a torrid time when he returns to the Nou Camp on Saturday
fields.trailText: The former Barcelona player can expect a torrid time when he returns to the Nou Camp on Saturday.
fields.body:
Luis Figo is trying to downplay his return to the Nou Camp ahead of Saturday night's Barcelona v Real Madrid game. But no one else is. In the cafés and bars, among the papers and the players, all talk is of Figo. Over 300,000 whistles have been distributed to Barcelona fans keen to welcome him back, and an anti-Figo website (www.antifigo.com) has been set up. Even by the standards of the 'derbi' the game promises to be something special.

"It's a big game but I believe people are speculating too much about me playing at the Nou Camp again," the Portuguese international told Real Madrid TV this week. "Barcelona are playing against Real Madrid, not against Luis Figo. The supporters can express themselves in any way they see fit but I hope it doesn't last the whole 90 minutes."

Some hope. Back in 1994, Michael Laudrup moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid. When he returned to the Nou Camp in a white shirt he found a different crowd to the one he had left. "When I looked up towards the stands I was paralysed," the former Danish international recalled. "It was two hours of horror."

Placards around the ground proclaimed "Laudrup Judas, Laudrup traitor" and fans screamed abuse every time he touched the ball - even though he had led Barca to four successive league titles. He was substituted after 66 minutes.

"I went through one of the worst moments of my life," Laudrup told Spanish sports daily As early this week. "My circumstances had nothing in common with Figo's but the hostile reception will be exactly the same."

Barca president Joan Gaspart, has encouraged the fans to be "authentic" towards Figo, while also reminding them - gently of course - not to do anything too unsporting. But the pain of losing their former idol lingers like a lost love. Spite, not sporting behaviour, will be the watchword in the Nou Camp on Saturday.

Real will enter the game full of confidence. Three consecutive wins have moved them to the top of the Primera Liga and - despite slight injury doubts over Fernando Hierro, Iker Casillas and Fernando Morientes - coach Vicente Del Bosque expects to have a full squad available.

"I am sure Madrid will give great joy to its fans," Raul claimed today. "We all want to play against Barcelona and this year with Figo we face the game with a bigger motivation than in past matches."

Meanwhile, Barcelona's World Footballer of the Year Rivaldo sounded much more downbeat in his assessment. "It will be a difficult game," he said. "But we are playing in our stadium and we are obliged to beat Madrid." And, in particular, one Portuguese international.

webTitle: We expelled Hurley, says UK Equity

fields.headline: We expelled Hurley, says UK Equity
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Hurley's problems with unions continued yesterday after it emerged she had been thrown out of Equity for failing to pay her subscriptions for five years
fields.body:
Elizabeth Hurley's problems with unions continued yesterday after it emerged she had been thrown out of Equity.

The British actors' union revealed that the Estée Lauder model had failed to pay her subscriptions for five years, despite repeated letters.

The news follows Hurley being jeered as a "scab" by 200 protesters this week at the premiere in Los Angeles of her new movie, Bedazzled, after breaking a US actors' strike.

She was expelled from Equity two years ago, a union spokesman confirmed last night. "She ceased being a member in November 1998 because we hadn't had any subs since 1995," he said. "We seek to represent the entire profession and it is always a matter of regret that anyone working in our profession is not a member of Equity.

"We would have written to her on about six different occasions reminding her about her outstanding subscription. Eventually we would have sent a letter saying we were sorry but we were taking her membership away."

The spokesman added that Hugh Grant, Hurley's former boyfriend, had resumed paying Equity subscriptions after being thrown out for non-payment.

Hurley fell foul of a strike called by the US Screen Actors' Guild, of which she is a member, when she filmed a commercial for Estée Lauder.

Hurley has since apologised and offered to pay £17,000 to the union's strike fund. She said she had been unaware of the strike and would not have made the commercial if she had known about it.

A spokeswoman for Hurley pointed out that much of the actor's work is in the US. "Elizabeth has not made a British film since 1994, so perhaps that is the reason she hasn't paid. There is no longer a closed shop or a requirement that actors have to be members of Equity."

fields.headline: Julie London
fields.standfirst: Glamorous singer and actress less confident than her roles
fields.trailText: Actress-singer Julie London, she of the sexy, whispering voice from the mid- to late-1950s, has died aged 74
fields.body:
One of the most evocative sounds of the mid- to late-1950s, issuing from juke boxes, radios and film soundtracks, was the sexy, whispering voice of Julie London, who has died aged 74. Her own view was that she had "only a thimbleful of a voice, and I have to use it close to the microphone. But it is a kind of oversmoked voice, and it automatically sounds intimate."

London's biggest hit was her first single, Cry Me A River, which was released in 1955, included on her first album, Julie Is Her Name, and sold more than 3m copies. Her voluptuous features on the album cover were described by publicists as "generating enough voltage to light up a theatre marquee".

Similarly, the cover of her Calendar Girl album featured 12 glamorous shots, and, for her 1961 album, Whatever Julie Wants, she was guarded by armed security men as she posed beside $750,000 worth of furs, jewels and piles of money. In her movies, she looked her best in period costume, especially in westerns, where she decorated many a saloon bar.

London was born Julie Peck in California. Her parents, Jack and Josephine, were a vaudeville song-and-dance team, on whose radio show their daughter sang from an early age. In 1941, the family moved to Los Angeles, and, while working as a lift operator in a department store, Julie was discovered by talent agent Sue Carol, Alan Ladd's wife, and given a screen test.

Her first role, at 18, was as a jungle girl - with flowers in her blonde hair - in the risible Nabonga (1944), whose best friend was the eponymous gorilla, until handsome Buster Crabbe showed up. London acquitted herself well, but the cheapie picture did not lead to big film roles. Meanwhile, however, she was making a reputation as a singer with the Matty Malnech Orchestra.

In 1947, she married the actor Jack Webb, later famous on the radio and television police series, Dragnet, and worked only a little while bringing up their two daughters. She had a good part as Susan Hayward's amorous younger sister in the southern saga, Tap Roots (1948), and played a navy wife in Task Force (1949), starring Gary Cooper.

After she divorced Webb in 1953, London entered a brief period during which, in her own words, she lacked self-confidence. This changed when she met jazz musician and songwriter Bobby Troup, who guided her singing career and helped her become a top female vocalist from 1955 to 1957. The couple married in 1959, and had a daughter and twin sons.

Troup once remarked: "She is not a Julie London fan. She honestly doesn't realise how good she is. She's never really been a performer, she doesn't have that need to go out and please an audience and receive accolades. She's always been withdrawn, very introverted. She hated those big shows."

However, London continued to sing in nightclubs, cut discs, and record title songs from her films, such as Saddle The Wind (1958) and Voice In The Mirror (1958), which she also composed. In the latter, she showed growing maturity as an actress, playing the wife of an alcoholic.

As a dancehall singer, humiliated and raped by Lee J Cobb, then avenged by Gary Cooper, in Anthony Mann's allegorical Man Of The West (1959), she struck a tragic note. In The Wonderful Country (1959), she was won by Robert Mitchum after her husband had conveniently been killed by Apaches, and, in Night Of The Quarter Moon (1959), she shocked San Francisco society when, as John Drew Barrymore's bride, she admitted to having a black grandparent.

In 1972, having been out of the public eye for some time, London began her role as Nurse Dixie McCall in the television hospital series, Emergency. The show, which was produced and often directed by her first husband Webb, also starred her second husband, Troup. For five years, London was a star once more, reminding fans of the days when, to quote the writer Joseph Lanza, she "was a blend of Dionysian flesh and Detroit steel, streamlined car and cocktail shaker combined".

 Julie London, actress-singer, born September 26 1926; died October 18 2000

fields.headline: Gwen Verdon
fields.standfirst: Legendary Broadway dancer and Fosse muse
fields.trailText: Gwen Verdon, who has died aged 75, was one of the last great exponents in musical theatre, both as a performer and choreographic muse to her late husband Bob Fosse
fields.body:
A great problem for today's dance students aspiring to careers in musical theatre is the shortage of role models. Gwen Verdon, who has died aged 75, was one of the last great exponents, with direct experience - both as a performer and choreographic muse to her late husband, Bob Fosse - of a dance tradition which traces its roots back to the work of Jack Cole, whom she assisted in the 1940s.

For the last two decades, the Broadway music tradition, embodied by Oklahoma! and nurtured by director/choreographers such as Agnes de Mille, Gower Champion, Jerome Robbins, Joe Layton and Fosse himself, has been deposed by the British musical, owing more to the traditions of European operetta.

So the extraordinarily successful revival of Chicago - Verdon was its original Roxie Hart in 1975 - followed by the show, Fosse, has been a revelation of the extraordinary standards of dance creativity that prevailed in musicals after the second world war. It was Verdon's tireless industry, and devotion to her husband's memory, that enabled these revivals to materialise.

She was born in Culver City, California, the daughter of British-born parents. Her father was an MGM technician, and her mother, who had trained with the modern-dance company Denishawn, opened her own school. Verdon, her legs weakened by childhood illness, got her early dance training from Ernest Belcher, who also trained Cyd Charisse.

Initially, she followed her first husband, James Henaghan, into journalism, reviewing films and nightclub acts. The marriage was over by 1947, but thus it was that she discovered the work of jazz-dance pioneer Cole, and eventually joined his nightclub act. Later, she became his assistant, replacing Carol Haney, who left to work with Gene Kelly.

Cole choreographed Verdon's Broadway debut revue, Alive And Kicking (1950), which flopped. She was not ambitious to be a star, preferring her role of choreographer's assistant, but Cole was a volatile and abusive task master, and, eventually, she took refuge with Michael Kidd, starring on Broadway in Can-Can (1953) - for which she received dazzling reviews and a Tony award. For Fosse, she starred as Lola in Damn Yankees (1955), won another Tony, and repeated her performance in the 1958 movie.

As a performer, Verdon had a unique quality of comic sexuality. This protected her endearingly innocent, vulnerable personality from slipping into outright vulgarity - unlike Fosse, who frequently strayed into conflict with his producers through his highly individual attitudes to portraying sexuality in dance.

During her time with Cole, Verdon made minor dancing appearances in movies, coached Jane Russell, and taught Marilyn Monroe the steps for her number in the movie Gentleman Prefer Blondes. She was perfect casting for the role of Charity in Sweet Charity (1966), the musical based on Fellini's 1957 film, Le Notte Di Cabiria.

Her other leads in musicals were New Girl In Town (1958), and Redhead (1959), both choreographed by Fosse, the latter show directed by him, and both winning Tonys for Verdon. When her dancing career was over, she also found success as a character actress, in such films as Cocoon (1985), The Cotton Club (1984) and Woody Allen's Alice (1990).

She had married Fosse in 1960, but he was a notorious womaniser (a fact he made no secret of in his autobiographical film, All That Jazz), though despite their agreeing to live apart, he and Verdon were never divorced. She remained devoted to the man and his work, and was with him when he died of a heart attack during a tour of a revival of Sweet Charity in 1987. She had no difficulty in collaborating with Ann Reinking, an ex-mistress and muse of her husband's, on Fosse (1999), a celebration and retrospective of his work.

Verdon was universally loved and admired by the dancers in the London production of Fosse. Neil Johnson, who dances Percussion in the show, remarked: "Gwen has a way of really stretching you, drawing strengths out of you that you didn't know you had. She once put me through that number five times in an afternoon. By the end of the rehearsal, I could scarcely walk."

Somehow that steely strength, tempered by years of emotional stress, never appeared to coarsen her vulnerable and touching personality. She is survived by a daughter from her marriage to Fosse, a son from her first marriage, four grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

fields.headline: Feltz 's video launch held back by Beeb
fields.trailText: 8am:Anne Diamond has one, so it was only a matter of time before the nation's other TV slimmer, Vanessa Feltz, brought out her own fitness video. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Anne Diamond already has one, so it was only a matter of time before the nation's other TV slimmer, Vanessa Feltz, brought out her own fitness video.

But BBC bosses have banned their TV presenter from launching the video in the shops until next year.

Sources say Miss Feltz was inundated with offers of video deals when she first went public with her new slimline look following the split from husband Michael Kurer. However, her £2m contract with the BBC prevented her from cashing in on her dieting success because she was on an exclusive deal.

One source said: "The BBC would not be passing on such huge amounts of money to her if they didn't have complete control on what she did. They cannot be seen to be promoting commercial products."

Former breakfast TV star Anne Diamond is believed to have sold 55,000 videos, netting her £110,000. She also picked up an estimated £50,000 in a newspaper deal promoting her video.
