fields.headline: Disney UK chief calls on BBC to target over-55s
fields.trailText: 8am:Disney's Paul Robinson has urged the BBC to make more digital TV programming for over-55s, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Paul Robinson, the managing director of Disney's UK pay-TV operation, has called on the BBC to make more digital TV programming for over-55s, rather than launch two children's digital channels.

Mr Robinson, speaking at the Broadcasting Press Guild lunch yesterday, said that instead of its two proposed children's services, the BBC should be developing new free to air digital channels offering music, travel and sports programming for over-55s.

He argued that the BBC should do this because it had a duty, as a licence fee funded public service broadcaster, to help drive uptake of digital TV services and provide programming for demographic groups that the market does not cater for.

Mr Robinson indicated that this argument would form part of Disney's submission to the Department of Culture, Media & Sport's public consultation on the BBC's proposed new children's services.

Over-55s make up the largest age group in the UK population - 26% of the total - and watch the most terrestrial TV, but are the most reluctant to subscribe to digital multi-channel services, he said.

Only one in four over-55s - and only one in seven over-65s - currently subscribe to pay-TV. By comparison, according to Barb figures quoted by Mr Robinson, more than 50% of under-15s now live in multi-channel homes.

Reaching culture secretary Chris Smith's target of 95% digital TV penetration was "never going to happen", he said, unless older viewers could be persuaded to make the switch.

"Chris Smith isn't concerned about 95% of the population having access to digital pay-TV, he's concerned about 95% having access to digital TV."

Mr Robinson said the BBC was already "very good at addressing this audience" in its existing TV and radio services and was therefore well-suited to taking on the task, especially as it "looks as though the market isn't going to provide" services for over-55s.

He also repeated his opposition - first aired at the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival in August - to the BBC's plan to launch two new free-to-air children's channels, on the grounds that the market was already supplying 14 services in this area.

Mr Robinson warned that if the BBC was allowed to proceed with its children's services and not provide more programming for older viewers, "what they are doing is going to undermine the licence fee".

webTitle: The rise and rise of New Zealand

fields.headline: The rise and rise of New Zealand
fields.standfirst: In the first of a new series of columns looking at international cricket abroad, Lawrence Booth examines the most up-and-coming side on the world stage
fields.trailText:
You've got to hand it to New Zealand. It has a population of just three
million, and for years most of its sporting heroes wore black. But last week
its Men in White, a side that has about as many big names as an episode of
Stars In Their Eyes, won the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya, and succeeded
where Australia and South Africa had failed: they tamed the rampant Indians.
Captain Stephen Fleming called it the greatest moment in his country's
one-day history.
fields.body:
You've got to hand it to New Zealand. It has a population of just three
million, and for years most of its sporting heroes wore black. But last week
its Men in White, a side that has about as many big names as an episode of
Stars In Their Eyes, won the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya, and succeeded
where Australia and South Africa had failed: they tamed the rampant Indians.
Captain Stephen Fleming called it the greatest moment in his country's
one-day history.

It may be a strange compliment, but New Zealand are becoming
the
Gloucestershire of world cricket - a team built on continuity of selection,
guts, self-belief, and a distinct lack of ego.

In the 1970s, New Zealand
relied on Glenn Turner. In the '80s Richard Hadlee
took virtually all their wickets, while the runs came from Martin Crowe and
John Wright. Now the responsibility is spread more widely. And everyone's
chipping in. The result is that, for the first time in their history, New
Zealand's cricketers are not to be messed with.

At the centre of the revival is
Chris Cairns, the closest thing to a star in
the Black Cap firmament. Since mauling Phil Tufnell at The Oval in 1999 with

fields.headline: eBay posts revenue rise
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Online auction giant eBay reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Online auction giant eBay provided some good news for the embattled e-commerce sector when it reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings.

The company said it expected to reach $3bn (£1.96bn) in revenue by 2005, growth of around 50% per year, with projected revenues of around $122m (£79.63m) for the next quarter.

For the third quarter, eBay reported consolidated net revenues of $113.4m (£74.02m), a 93.8% increase over the $58.5m (£38.18m) reported for the same period last year. eBay's consolidated net income, excluding special items, was $19.1m (£12.47m).

Analysts were impressed by the results, pointing out that this was a very strong quarter for eBay, and that it spelled a move back towards confidence in the e-commerce sector.

eBay added that gross merchandise sales - the value of all the goods and services traded through its site - reached $1.4bn in the quarter, up 83% on the previous year. The number of auctions hosted reached 68.5m, compared with 36.2m during the same period last year. Overall, the auction house ended the quarter with 18.9m registered users, an increase of 146% from 7.7m on September 30 1999.

The UK office of eBay said the results reinforced the company's position as the world's biggest online trading community.

Jennifer Mowat, country manager of eBay.co.uk, said: "For eBay.co.uk these results have added significance as they coincide with our first birthday. We are very proud that within just one year of launch we have met with such success in the UK and look forward to an exciting year ahead."

eBay launched a French operation earlier this month.

webTitle: TV cash dispute fuels fear of elite breakaway

fields.headline: TV cash dispute fuels fear of elite breakaway
fields.trailText: Acrimonious discussions between Premier League chairmen over how money from the next TV deal should be divided ended last night in fears that leading clubs may form a breakaway faction. By Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
Fears that leading football clubs might form a breakaway faction increased last night during an acrimonious meeting of all 20 Premier League chairmen in central London.

During discussions lasting several hours there were heated exchanges on how money from the next television deal should be divided, with smaller clubs asking for fairer distribution so that they could remain competitive in the league.

The larger clubs, led by Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool, resisted a move led by Coventry City to have the money distributed more evenly among the league's 20 clubs.

One source who was at the meeting said: "The threat of a breakaway faction was implicit in all that the bigger clubs were saying during the meeting. It was hovering over the whole meeting, and all the chairmen who want to change the way money is distributed were aware of this. At times the meeting was very heated, although nobody walked out."

Until Wednesday the new Premier League television deal was worth £1.6bn over three years from the start of the 2001-02 season. That figure now stands at £1.3bn after the decision by the cable television company NTL to withdraw from a £328m agreement to televise 40 pay-per-view matches a year from the start of next season.

Under the Coventry proposal, £200m of television money would be distributed under current arrangements, to wit 50% shared equally among the clubs, 25% paid according to television appearances and 25% paid in prize money. The remainder of the television money, currently £1.1bn, would be distributed equally among all 20 Premier League clubs.

A club source said last night: "There was no appetite for any change and we realised that we would not be able to make any difference. We are trying to bring change that is important for the future of English football. We feel passionately that if we don't make these changes then we are restricting the competiveness of the Premier League."

Other clubs opposed to changing the way television money is distributed include Chelsea, Newcastle United and West Ham. Aston Villa and Leeds United are in favour of some form of change but remain unconvinced by the Coventry proposal, claiming that too much money would be distributed equally.

At least 12 clubs are in favour of changing the way television money is distributed but under Premier League rules any changes must be agreed by a two-thirds majority, or 14 clubs.

The Premier League chairmen in favour of change had been planning to put the issue to a vote but changed their minds during the meeting after realising that they would not be able to secure a two-thirds majority.

Intense lobbying is likely to precede the next chairmen's meeting, which is expected to come in the next two months.

Yesterday's meeting also discussed the decision of NTL to withdraw from its pay-per-view agreement. The chairmen were offered several alternative options, including setting up a Premier League pay-per-view channel and putting out the contract to tender once again.

Many chairmen expressed concern over NTL's decision, urging that the situation be resolved as quickly as possible so that clubs would know how much to expect from the television deal. The favoured option appears to be to give the contract to one media company, with BSkyB the favourite.

Premier League officials will examine the various options and will discuss with their lawyers, chairmen and media advisers on how best to salvage the pay-per-view contract and generate as much revenue as possible.

webTitle: America jolted by biography showing hero DiMaggio as cruel and mean

fields.headline: America jolted by biography showing hero DiMaggio as cruel and mean
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: When Joe DiMaggio died in 1999, he was mourned by generations of Americans who felt that they had lost a part of themselves. DiMaggio's reputation as the most graceful and glorious baseball player of the 1940s was only the start of what made him into a national hero for half a century.
fields.body:
When Joe DiMaggio died in 1999, he was mourned by generations of Americans who felt that they had lost a part of themselves. DiMaggio's reputation as the most graceful and glorious baseball player of the 1940s was only the start of what made him into a national hero for half a century.

Foreigners who knew of him merely as one of Marilyn Monroe's husbands, or as a line in a Simon and Garfunkel song, can have little idea of the Yankee Clipper's status as the icon of what Americans now call The Greatest Generation.

But there was also another Joe DiMaggio, especially in the later years, one that Americans glimpsed but mostly preferred not to recognise.

This DiMaggio was vain, self-centred, suspicious, cruel and, above all, mean, even miserly. He knew exactly how good he was as a player and he also knew how important he was as a national symbol. So this DiMaggio spent most of his life coldly screwing the rest of the world for every last cent he could make from it. There were Mafia connections too, including with the Chicago mob boss, Sam Giancana.

The other Joe DiMaggio is the subject of a new biography by Richard Ben Cramer which has hit America hard. The Dark Side of DiMaggio is how Newsweek, which carried extracts in its latest issue, put it. Mr Cramer's book does more than tarnish a national idol, the New York Times reflected this week. "It will tarnish the American myth".

DiMaggio was a peerless player and that status meant he spent his life on a pedestal. "It was his destiny to stand alone," Mr Cramer writes.

"No wonder we strove for 60 years to give him the hero's life. It was always about us, alas, it was his destiny to know that as well."

Money was what DiMaggio cared about most of all. He knew both his value and his price, and he always suspected strangers of trying to rip him off. His signature on a baseball was worth hundreds and he exploited it to his dying day. He sold some of his trophies, then pretended they had been stolen, so the Yankees would give him a fresh set.

He made thousands every year from reselling hundreds of free tickets that he requested from events he had no intention of attending. When a Japanese backer gave him a Cadillac - he always had free cars - his response was "Did you fill it up with gas?" When the tank ran dry, he gave the Cadillac to his granddaughter.

DiMaggio lived in a world of freebies and tax evasion. When the Oakland A's, the only other major league team he ever worked for, invited him to attend special games, his price was a first-class return from Miami, his official home, even though he would often be in San Francisco, a $20 cab ride away from Oakland . Not that he paid for cabs.

When he accepted an invitation to a celebrity golf tournament, he would say he had no clubs and no kit. In his garage, as a result, there were dozens of sets of freshly minted golf clubs, shirts, shoes and balls, most unused, many of them still in their wrapping.

When the 1989 earthquake hit San Francisco - Di Maggio's home town where his Sicilian born father was a fisherman - Jolting Joe got special permission to go to his sister's house. He re-emerged with a binliner containing $600,000 that he had stashed away.

The publication of Joe DiMaggio: The Hero's Life comes at a moment when America's - and in particular New York's - infinite capacity for sentimental self-regard is about to enjoy a fresh flowering. Tomorrow, DiMaggio's team, the New York Yankees, take on their neighbours the New York Mets in the first game of an all-Big Apple baseball World Series that the city has dreamed of for decades.

webTitle: Today's media stories from the papers

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Italy's Rai network has come under fire after one of its correspondents identified journalists from rival network Mediaset in an open letter to Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority. (p4)
Having been heckled by striking US actors, it emerges that Elizabeth Hurley was thrown out of UK actors' union Equity in 1998 for failing to pay her subscriptions. (p5)
ITV is poised to scale down production on its Trafalgar Road soap, amid the defection of United Productions producer Matthew Bird to the BBC. (p13)

THE TIMES

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey has launched a veiled attack on former director general Sir John Birt during an interview on BBC Radio 4's Woman's Hour. Ms Heggessey said BBC1 had "lost confidence in itself" because the BBC is too focused on launching services. (p14)
United News & Media plans to change its name to United Business Media, raising speculation that a sale of the media group's newspaper assets is imminent. (p28)
A 15p surge in Vodafone shares yesterday led a revival of media and technology stocks. (p30)

MEDIA SECTION

Caitlin Moran laments Jeremy Bowen's decision to swap the Gaza Strip for the BBC Breakfast sofa. (p11)
Maureen Paton asks whether the Radio Times still carries an inherent BBC bias.(p20)
Steve Clarke says the BBC's ratings success following the move of the Nine O'Clock News has confounded the cynics. (p21)
Raymond Snoddy wonders why broadcasters and programme makers do not target older viewers. (p23)
Virginia Matthews predicts a boom for lifestyle magazines aimed at the English chattering classes living or holidaying in France. (p25)
Countdown's Richard Whitely completes his round of pre-book publicity with an interview with Lucy Elkins, in which he defends his "comfy job". (p25)
Winston Fletcher wonders whether the advertising catchphrase is dead. (p26).
And Sarah Mahaffy gives an insider's guide to setting up a web company. (p27)

FINANCIAL TIMES

Internet banks and card providers are facing tough competition from their clicks and mortar rivals. (p7)
Global advertising and marketing group WPP is in talks to buy the financial PR firm Finsbury. (p26)
United News & Media confirms it is to change its name to United Business Media. (p28)
Strong Nokia third-quarter results lead a technology stock revival. (p32)
Shares in online brokerage E*Trade have surged by 26% after better than expected quarterly results. (p34)

THE INDEPENDENT

Empire editor Ian Nathan reveals he had trouble naming the 10 scariest moments in film history. (p5)
BT to introduce a US-style free local calls package from December 1. (p14)
United News & Media is to change its name to United Business Media. (p21)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Neil Kinnock has accused the Daily Mail, Sun and Sunday Times of being "malicious and misleading" in what he calls "serial distortions" of the issue of closer European integration.

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

Nokia beats estimates in its third-quarter results. (p9)
Time Warner's publishing division Time Inc has reportedly agreed to buy Times Mirror Magazines for around £339m. (p4)
BT is introducing unmetered internet access from December. (p4)

THE MIRROR

The paper reports that Coronation Street is to get its first doctor after 40 years, in the form of former Bill heart-throb Stephen Beckett. (p11)

THE SUN

The Budweiser "Whassup" ad has had such an influence on the population that one of the Queen's elite bodyguards is to be disciplined after a TV crew forced him to bellow the catchphrase while on duty. (p3)
The paper reports that the BBC's Ten O' Clock News last night pulled in only 4.3m viewers. (p6)
Pop idol Ronan Keating has been cured of his fear of flying by TV hypnotist Paul McKenna. (p22)
The paper notes that Lorraine Heggessey, in her interview with Radio 4's Woman's Hour, "shocked listeners" by talking about getting "pissed with the lads".
The Bill is to show an unprecendented live episode in the latest ratings drive. (p29)

THE DAILY MAIL

BT will allow unlimited free local calls from December 1. (p4)
Loyd Grossman tells the Mail he quit the BBC because it is "downmarket, patronising and moronic". (p13)
The Priory co-creator and Sky presenter Tim Lovejoy has received a £200,000 pay-off after losing out on a presenter's job on the show. (p23)
Liz Hurley has no equity membership after failing to pay her dues. (p27)

THE DAILY EXPRESS

Sarah Shannon on the TV ratings war. (p13)
Sir Christopher Bland backed the decision to name the Omagh bombing suspects at a dinner in Belfast. (p17)

AND FINALLY

THE DAILY STAR

Melinda Messenger takes her greatest assets on to the web. (p32)

webTitle: Railtrack owns up to years of underinvesting

fields.headline: Railtrack owns up to years of underinvesting
fields.standfirst: Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Railtrack executives last night met heads of the train operating companies and its maintenance contractors to discuss the effects of the Hatfield rail disaster on the network.
fields.body:
Railtrack executives last night met heads of the train operating companies and its maintenance contractors to discuss the effects of the Hatfield rail disaster on the network.

The operating companies wanted to know how long speed restrictions imposed by Railtrack at 81 sites around the country would last, and how track safety could be improved. Meanwhile Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, made his first statement after his offer to quit was turned down by the company board.

Railtrack has admitted that a broken rail it had previously identified as unsatisfactory was to blame for the Hatfield crash. Mr Corbett indicated that train journeys across the 81 sites would take longer as safety work was stepped up.

"Precautionary" speed restrictions were last night in place on the 81 sites, as low as 20mph in some places, resulting in delays of varying degrees for passengers. Mr Corbett said: "We have to be realistic. The system has been underinvested in. We cannot realistically expect at the same time huge improvements in punctuality and reductions in costs. Safety and investment are the priority."

Mr Corbett also said progress had been made in reducing broken rails, but it had not been fast enough. Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, warned Railtrack in a letter to Mr Corbett 10 weeks ago that the number of broken rails was so high, and the programme to repair or replace them so unsatisfactory, that it amounted to a breach of Railtrack's licence.

On August 4 Mr Winsor wrote: "I regard the excessive level of broken rails in two consecutive years, 952 in 1998/89 and 917 in 1999/2000, as prima facie evidence of a breach of condition seven of Railtrack's network licence."

That section requires the network to be maintained in keeping with best practice and in a timely and efficient manner. Mr Winsor continued: "Railtrack has increased its forecast of broken rails in each of its three network management statements since 1998. Despite this, it has failed to reduce the number of broken rails in line with its forecasts. This raises the question of how effective its planning maintenance and renewal activities have been."

Mr Winsor also said a letter he had received from Railtrack "does not provide me with the sufficient reassurance that Railtrack is implementing best-practice stewardship of the network and will reduce the level of broken rails as fast as reasonably practicable".

The regulator called in an independent consultant to review how Railtrack's performance on broken rails could be improved. This report will be completed next month.

In his statement Mr Corbett said: "May I thank everyone who has expressed their support for me. I am determined to justify the confidence which people have placed in me."

The health and safety executive will today issue a preliminary report on the Hatfield crash, the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, told the House of Lords yesterday.

At the scene Louise Christian, a lawyer representing some of the victims of the Paddington crash, said: "Hatfield could probably provide a strong basis for corporate manslaughter charges if somebody senior enough was warned that this track needed replacing and did nothing about it."

The fourth person killed in the crash was last night named by police as Robert Alcorn, 37, a New Zealander who lived in Bayswater, west London. Last night's meeting was scheduled to be followed next week by another between Railtrack and the 25 operators.

webTitle: Cost cutting threatens safety, say contractors

fields.headline: Cost cutting threatens safety, say contractors
fields.standfirst: Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Railtrack was accused by its contractors yesterday of compromising rail safety by continuing to cut costs, as the company disclosed it was spending £2bn on maintenance and renewals this year.
fields.body:
Railtrack was accused by its contractors yesterday of compromising rail safety by continuing to cut costs, as the company disclosed it was spending £2bn on maintenance and renewals this year.

In a wounding statement only 48 hours after the Hatfield crash, where Railtrack's failure to act over a broken rail has been admitted, the contractors said the corporation's approach was unsustainable.

Brian Clancy, chairman of the Association of Consulting Engineers, said Railtrack staff "openly boast of driving down the costs of rail maintenance. As salaries and other costs rise, this is bound in the long run to result in firms not being able to offer as fast or as intensive a service as they would wish."

He said Railtrack executives "need to accept that more money needs to be spent on track and lineside maintenance to ensure the highest possible safety standards. Public safety is not a field in which we can accept a culture of compromise."

One of the main contractors, Balfour Beatty, would not comment specifically on the statement but agreed with the sentiment. Its profits have been affected by the tight controls imposed by Railtrack in the past few years. Railtrack argues that it has to be more efficient.

Les Mosco, one of its engineering directors, said: "The message is simple and stark. Railtrack has to deliver an increased volume within tough financial constraints. We are simply not going to be in a position to afford or accept inflated prices."

Mr Mosco believes the industry has to stabilise price fluctuations or it could face closures, bankruptcies and layoffs. Railtrack spent almost £2bn on keeping the railway open last year, of which £1.2bn went on renewals and £663m on maintenance. It is from this pot that the contractors get paid - by Railtrack's zonal directors, who agree to the work and when it should be completed.

The contractors agree to a budget with the zonal directors and must keep within strict limits. They can carry out small repairs without permission, but any unforeseen and costly work must be cleared with Railtrack.

Maintenance and renewal companies came into their own after privatisation. British Rail usually did its own maintenance work, but Railtrack appointed contractors, among them Balfour Beatty, Amec, First Engineering and Jarvis.

Contractors have noticed increased belt tightening by Railtrack. One complained: "We are being asked to forget about the quality of the work because it might take longer, but simply to get it done and return the railway back to Railtrack remember that in many cases we are trying to revive a clapped-out railway."

At Hatfield, Balfour Beatty does maintenance work and Jarvis the renewal work. Railtrack and its contractors will have to review their approach to keeping the railway safe. Several contractors said the situation was untenable and big sections of the railway would have to be closed for longer periods for urgent work.

webTitle: Revolution bought out by Web Connection

fields.headline: Revolution bought out by Web Connection
fields.trailText: 8am:New media agency Revolution has been bought by Web Connection. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
New media agency Revolution has been bought out by Web Connection, the e-solutions arm of Asian internet firm chinadotcom, in a part-cash, part-equity deal.

The move is Web Connection's first in Europe and is will allow Revolution to tap into the Far East, Australia and the US. Revolution, which works with Coutts, BAA and Regus, is planning to open its first offices in mainland Europe in 2001.

Ray Taylor, CEO and founder of the five-year-old Revolution, said: "We are delighted to be announcing this deal. We looked at a range of options and this was clearly the best for Revolution. For some time now we have been seeking a partner with the depth and reach to complement our high-level strategic offer."

Chinadotcom is currently pursuing a strong acquisitive strategy to enable it to move into new markets. It recently bought its way into Japan with the acquisition of Venex, and Australia with XT3.

webTitle: Herring quits Avalon for iballs Media

fields.headline: Herring quits Avalon for iballs Media
fields.trailText: 8am:PR chief James Herring has quit Avalon PR for iballs Media, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
James Herring, one of the best known PRs operating on the TV and showbusiness circuit, is quitting Avalon's PR agency.

Fast-talking Mr Herring, who is the managing director of the agency, is understood to have resigned to join new media production and marketing company iballs Media.

Mr Herring, a favourite of tabloid newspapers, has been involved in some of the biggest TV stories of the year including Big Brother and Frank Skinner's controversial departure from the BBC.

He is said to be joining iballs Media as commercial director, with an equity stake in the company.

The young PR gun stepped into the limelight as a temporary celebrity minder when a nervous Nick Bateman faced the press after his eviction from the Big Brother house.

Iballs was set up earlier this year by former Rapture TV programming boss Richard Kilgarriff. Mr Kilgarriff and Tony Greenham, finance director, who is also a shareholder are planning to unveil a ground-breaking interactive video service later this year.

Mr Herring is currently said to be working out his notice at Avalon. He has helped build up the PR arm of the Avalon Management Group, which encompasses artist representation, a TV production arm and comedy circuit bookings operation, into one of the leading UK media and entertainment specialists.

As well as handling the publicity for Avalon shows - including The Frank Skinner Show and The Pub Landlord - and live comedy acts, Avalon PR has expanded to take on accounts including Big Brother.

fields.headline: Paying through the armchair
fields.trailText: 8am:ith NTL pulling out of its pay-per-view deal for TV football, can anybody else afford it? By John Cassy.
fields.body:
The potential of pay-per-view television as a cash cow for British football clubs and broadcasters has been under discussion since Rupert Murdoch first introduced Sky TV and pay-television more than a decade ago.

NTL's decision to pull out of a £328m, three-year deal to show 40 pay-per-view Premiership football games each season, citing "commercial reasons", has led to a dramatic revision of that premise.

The cable television company's withdrawal came as no surprise to some City analysts.

From the moment the price of the deal was announced many questioned how the Nasdaq-listed operator would make it pay.

The calculations suggested that NTL needed to recoup £2.7m per match. At £4 per punter per match this meant a regular paying audience of 675,000.

Experience shows that these figures are hugely ambitious. The record pay-per-view subscriber number for BSkyB, with more subscribers than NTL, was around 600,000 - for a boxing match between Frank Bruno and Mike Tyson.

Two years ago, when the satellite broadcaster offered a Sunderland versus Oxford game as a pay-per-view event, only tens of thousands paid to watch. The north-east club said it made £30,000 at most.

Glamorous games

NTL would have opted to show the more exciting games but its hands are tied under the terms of its agreement with BSkyB, who, as the holder of the main rights, has first choice.

The latter would have undoubtedly broadcast the plum tie each week.

"This was the most enormous escape for NTL because the maths never made sense," said one well-known media analyst.

NTL believes it could have made the deal pay by using pay-per-view rights as a way to tempt customers away from BSkyB.

The company thought it could entice 500,000 BSkyB subscribers - with cable facilities outside their front door - away from Mr Murdoch by offering an attractive deal including a telephone, a pay TV, an internet package and a pay-per-view season ticket valued at £100 for free.

The cable company believed it would cover its £328m outlay with money from these new customers, and a further 500,000 football-crazy and rich BSkyB customers, who would be happy to add a £100 season ticket to their existing package. This was not to be, as NTL found.

The club chairmen balked at the proposal, saying they would not have their "premier content" given away seemingly for free, for fear of devaluing it.

Some analysts believe that the NTL figures could have worked.

They admit, however, that the strategy was risky and flawed. It failed, for example, to allow for any competitive response from BSkyB.

The only way the pay-per-view scheme can succeed is by boosting viewers' figures. It has to be made available to the maximum amount of pay TV homes as possible, according to the analysts.

Perhaps NTL had hoped for a more rapid expansion of digital cable television. Unfortunately this has not taken place. At the same time it has not been allowed to forget that BSkyB has 4m digital homes. The Premiership's insistence that NTL make its pay-per-view games avail able to BSkyB subscribers has knocked back its negotiating position.

The clubs, as the rights' holders, now have to decide whether they want to resurrect the deal or start new negotiations. NTL and OnDigital are both thought to be prepared to offer shorter term deals but at a lower price.

Continental broadcasters with pay-per-view experience, including Canal Plus, Kirch and Stream, could also enter the fray. US players can also not be discounted.

Then there is BSkyB. The Premiership's own rules currently prevent the satellite broadcaster from bidding. Those rules were devised to extract maximum value from the rights' sale, and to ensure that no one party gained too much control over football.

Strong ties

But BSkyB could now be allowed to bid as the two parties have developed a strong relationship since first becoming broadcast partners eight years ago. In addition Sky Sports could offer cross-promotional advantages.

Friends of Vic Wakeling, BSkyB's head of sports, say he greeted the collapse of the NTL deal with a "huge grin", and his employer's steadfast refusal to comment on any possible bid suggests something may be afoot.

Yet there is also a growing feeling that the Premier League could set up its own channel to maximise value from its rights. With no experience of broadcasting the league may need to partner with a media company.

It could even acquire the relevant production skills to go it alone in time for the next round of rights' negotiations in three years' time. The strategy was first suggested to the Premiership more than a year ago by former BSkyB bosses Sam Chisholm and David Chance, advisers to the clubs at the time.

Hanging over any pay-per-view proposal will be the fear that the public's obsession with football has reached saturation point.

BSkyB's own football viewing figures are declining and it is unclear how regularly fans would have signed up for extra matches on an individual basis.

fields.headline: ITV cuts down on soap
fields.trailText: 8am: ITV is poised to scale down plans for daily teatime soap Trafalgar Road amid problems at the production company that is making it, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
ITV is poised to scale down plans for a daily teatime soap amid problems at the production company that is making it.

As the ratings battle between the BBC and ITV intensifies, the commercial network is planning to screen Trafalgar Road on three days a week instead of the expected five.

United Productions, which is behind the series, confirmed that a producer on the show had defected to the BBC. Matthew Bird has become the latest in a line of drama staff to be lured from ITV to the corporation in recent weeks.

The programme is due to go on air early next year. Sources at ITV stressed that drama executives had always envisaged Trafalgar Road could run either on five or three days a week and that no final decision had been made.

ITV denied reports that it was considering moving its 6.30pm evening news when Trafalgar Road starts. The network still plans to take its 11pm bulletin to 10pm in the new year, going head-to-head with the BBC, whose Ten O'Clock News ratings fell to 4.3m on Wednesday, beaten by Tonight with Trevor McDonald, which drew 5.3m and is close to completing a deal with the parents of conjoined twins Jodie and Mary.

webTitle: Not time for euro yet, says Blair

fields.headline: Not time for euro yet, says Blair
fields.standfirst:
PM may drop currency as election issue
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday dashed hopes that the government would mount an aggressive battle to turn the tide of public scepticism over British membership of the euro when he said that he was currently against joining the single currency.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts in Seoul, Larry Elliott and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday dashed hopes that the government would mount an aggressive battle to turn the tide of public scepticism over British membership of the euro when he said that he was currently against joining the single currency.

Reflecting the new mood of caution following the Danish referendum and the recent slide in the euro to a record low against the dollar, the prime minister bluntly stated that conditions were not right for the UK to enter monetary union.

"Public opinion will make up its own mind based on the facts in the end, but if you come to me with an opinion poll and say 'do you want to join the euro today?', I would say no," Mr Blair said in a briefing to reporters en route to Seoul.

The comments initially were deemed off the record, but after speaking to Asian investors yesterday evening, Mr Blair decided to come off the fence in public.

Later, the prime minister and his official spokesmen sought to play down the comments, stressing that the government's line on the euro remained unchanged.

Asked whether he had delivered a vote of no confidence in the euro, Mr Blair replied: "Absolutely not. It isn't right for Britain to join the euro at the present time because the economic conditions are not right but it's absolutely vital for Britain to keep the option of joining the euro open.

"The government's position is that we don't recommend joining the euro today. What we are saying is that in principle we want to be part of it but the economic conditions have to be right."

However, Labour insiders said that the remarks were significant and an indication that Mr Blair was now firmly behind the strategy of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to avoid making the single currency an election issue.

With opinion polls showing voters against joining monetary union by more than 2 to 1, the pro-single currency faction in the cabinet has been pushing for the government to come off the fence and make a stronger case for joining the euro.

However, the fact that even concerted central bank intervention has failed to prop up the single currency, coupled with the defeat for the "yes" campaign in Denmark has led to a marked cooling off in Downing Street's enthusiasm for a more upbeat approach.

Mr Blair was noticeably cautious about the euro in his speech to business leaders in South Korea, delivered on the eve of the Asia-Europe summit.

The prime minister emphasised that Britain's European policy was based on national economic interest. "In principle, the government is in favour of joining a successful single currency. In practice, five economic tests have to be met," he said.

Mr Blair said his administration had reversed the perception that Britain was being marginalised. But the central role was one that focused on the fundamentals of economic reform rather than the politics of monetary union.

"Investors see us leading the way in putting economic reform at the centre of the European agenda, helping to build a strong Europe based on open markets, competition and economic reform; a superpower not a superstate," he said.

The Tory leader, William Hague, accused Mr Blair of "pretending to abandon his own policy" in an attempt to camouflage his plans to scrap the pound.

"A crude attempt to persuade the gullible that Britain's most Euro-fanatic leader ever is in fact a closet Eurosceptic backfired when Tony Blair had to eat his own words hours after uttering them," Mr Hague said.

"Of course he wants to pretend a change of heart because he knows that hardly anyone supports the government's view on the euro anymore."

The Business for Sterling chief executive, Nick Herbert, said: "It suits the government to play down the euro issue before the election but if the prime minister is saying that the conditions for entry are not right now, it would be impossible for him to claim that they have suddenly changed were he to move towards a referendum in the next year of two."

The worst week so far

Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, yesterday admitted he had made a mistake in comments that began the worst week for the beleaguered single currency.

The euro recovered ground following Mr Duisenberg's damage limitation exercise, but after Mr Blair's comments, fell back to 84.17 US cents or 58p.

Mr Duisenberg appeared on Monday to rule out further attempts to prop up the euro. Speculators took it as a green light to sell without risk of central banks intervening. On Wednesday, it hit an all time low of 83.25 cents.

Yesterday, Mr Duisenberg announced European borrowing costs are to remain at 4.75%, but efforts to stabilise the euro were undermined by Mr Blair's remarks.

webTitle: Blair's euro comments: a storm in a very British teacup

fields.headline: A storm in a very British teacup
fields.standfirst: Britain's European partners will not be overly concerned by Tony Blair's recent comments on the euro, writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.trailText: Britain's European partners will not be overly concerned by Tony Blair's recent comments on the euro, writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's widely reported rejection of the euro may have sent political shockwaves across the UK but in Europe his comments are regarded as a storm in a very British teacup.

Europe's political elite already knew that there was no immediate prospect of Britain joining the single currency and Mr Blair's comments consequently received little or no coverage in French and German newspapers.

"Is it really worth making such a fuss about this?" asks one bemused French diplomatic source in Brussels. "It looks like he said what he has always said - that the UK won't join until the economic conditions are right."

Nor is Mr Blair's entrenched position as one of Europe's leading statesmen likely to be undermined in any way by the fact that he has publicly stated that he would not join the euro if asked today.

Still basking in the reflected glory of the landmark speech he gave in Warsaw earlier this month in which he set out a mature vision of how the European Union should be reformed, Mr Blair has nothing to fear. The nuanced interpretation his comments were given in the UK simply doesn't interest anyone who's anyone in Europe.

"It's a reflection of how completely super-obsessed and fickle the British press is with the euro that they slap every single utterance on the front page," argues one senior European commission official. "It's a bland statement and does not represent a major departure for him. There is enormous understanding for Blair's position at home and a lot of sympathy with his problems."

Even veteran EU watchers expressed surprise that his remark has been seized upon with such zeal in Britain. "It's nothing new and I don't think it follows that people here will see it as him distancing himself from the euro at all," says one seasoned observer.

The French may continue to believe that one day Britain will sign on the dotted line for the euro but they are also perfectly aware that public opinion is simply not ready for such a big step.

As such, Mr Blair's rejection of the euro this weeks makes little or no difference to movers and shakers in Paris, Berlin or even Brussels.

In fact, diplomatic sources claim to even admire the way the prime minister is playing to his domestic audience.

"When 60% of the electorate is opposed to the single currency then it makes sense for a prime minister to take notice," says one.

If Mr Blair is boxing clever and trying to kick the issue into the long grass ahead of the next election, then that is fine with the Europeans - for they will continue to believe that deep down he is one of them. And maybe they're right.

webTitle: Leader: Every word out of place imperils the euro

fields.headline: Down and down it goes
fields.standfirst:
Every word out of place imperils the euro
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: If nothing else, the euro seems to have found the secret of perpetual free fall. Even when supporters of the luckless European currency open their mouths it only adds to the gloom.
fields.body:
If nothing else, the euro seems to have found the secret of perpetual free fall. Even when supporters of the luckless European currency open their mouths it only adds to the gloom. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, was asked during an interview with the Times whether it would make sense for the authorities to intervene in the foreign exchange markets in the event of a Middle East war. "I wouldn't think so," he replied. That triggered a fresh fall in the euro, not because it was not true (it would be barmy to think that modest intervention could offset the selling pressures of a war) but because he said it at all. Central bankers are not supposed to disclose in advance what few tactics they have open to them. Yesterday, Tony Blair made a similar statement of the obvious. He said that if asked by an opinion poll whether he wanted to join the euro today he would answer no. This was immediately interpreted as a vote of no confidence, even though it was merely a repetition of Labour policy - no entry into the euro until five economic conditions have been met and a referendum has been held. Mr Blair's remarks helped the euro to fall to a new lifetime low against the dollar.

But where does the euro go now? It is tempting to say that it cannot possibly fall any further, so undervalued is it on economic fundamentals. But the trouble is that it easily could, such is the madness of markets at either extreme of the cycle. It was the same madness that made two of the three leading world currencies - the dollar and the yen - move 50% by value against each other during a period of only two years. The problem is that even though the economic fundamentals - a European economy recovering from sclerosis with relatively low inflation - point to a stronger euro, the financial realities point the other way, as witness the tidal wave of investment and portfolio money that has been pouring into the US in tacit support of the dollar. In theory, sentiment ought to have changed this week. America's hi-tech stocks took a bath while some of Europe's stars like Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest mobile phone manufacturer (it announced sales up 50% yesterday), showed their US rivals a clean pair of heels. But, in reality, the slump in US technology stocks may be seen by international investors as a chance to buy into a recovery situation.

In the long term, the world must start to reform its own financial architecture by recreating zones of currency stability. Meanwhile, there is little alternative to the Group of Seven leading nations coordinating their economic policies - backed up by timely and cooperative intervention - to bring about a "soft" landing for the US economy and the dollar. The world must do all it can to avert a serious US recession which could prove very contagious. Recession could easily be triggered by a US stock market slump which would force consumers to stop spending (ie buying exports from the rest of the world) in order to rebuild their battered savings accounts and reduce the massive US trade deficit. A soft landing for the US economy is possible. Hi-tech stocks in the US have dropped from being ludicrously overvalued to being just seriously overvalued. If they come down in fits and starts rather than with a big bump, then Europe will be reassured. The worst thing that could now happen to the euro would be for its recovery to be the mirror image of a collapsing US economy. The euro is clearly undervalued, but its recovery will need very deft handling by everyone concerned. And that definitely includes the head of Europe's own central bank.

webTitle: Fuel protesters warned not to repeat blockade intimidation

fields.headline: Fuel protesters warned not to repeat blockade intimidation
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: A concerted effort to undermine the benign image of last month's fuel protesters was mounted yesterday as the government, police, oil companies and tanker drivers' union combined to produce a catalogue of intimidation during the protests.
fields.body:
A concerted effort to undermine the benign image of last month's fuel protesters was mounted yesterday as the government, police, oil companies and tanker drivers' union combined to produce a catalogue of intimidation during the protests.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said such intimidation came close to thuggery and would not be tolerated again.

Fuel protesters angrily attacked the claims as rubbish and claimed they were timed to distract from yesterday's 2p increase in the price of a litre of unleaded petrol to 81.9p, with 4p on a litre of diesel. The oil companies blamed the rise on the price of crude.

However, at the fifth meeting of the government's fuel taskforce yesterday, the oil companies for the first time charted 180 separate incidents, including bricks through drivers' windows and attacks on tanker drivers at home.

The catalogue of incidents, apparently confirmed by the police, was matched by a separate dossier, prepared by the Transport and General Workers Union, recording 30 incidents.

Bill Morris, the TGWU general secretary, said that in the event of a repetition of the protests he was confident the police and the oil companies would use tougher criminal and civil sanctions.

In recent talks with the oil company managers, he was told the companies had been reluctant to use the courts to remove the protesters for fear of exacerbating the crisis. Mr Straw described the incidents of intimidation discussed at the meeting as shocking. He claimed: "The protesting went beyond the bounds of a peaceful protest and ended, in a few cases, at straightforward thuggery.

"It was not a peaceful protest as some of them persuaded us it was. The kind of action that took place last time is quite intolerable," he warned.

Chris Fox, of the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "Intimidation, bullying and thuggery won't be tolerated." He promised that future policing would be more "vigorous".

The attack on the protesters came as leading freight and farmers' groups lobbied the government for a 15p cut in diesel fuel.

David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Protest, said the claims of intimidation were "absolute and utter rubbish".

Accusing the TGWU of being in collusion with the government, he said: "There is something very, very sinister here. In view of the way the T&G leadership supported the government during the blockades, you have to ask what is going on."

"If it was true, why has it taken so long for these people to come up with their evidence."

His group, which is trying to co-ordinate the protesters, has had a rethink on further blockades and is now proposing a mass demonstration in London scheduled for mid-November, the end of their 60-day deadline. They have also rejected suggestions of trying to shut down the national grid or blockading train depots.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is studying a range of options to cut fuel duty in the pre-Budget report due in the next few weeks.

The recent rise in oil prices boosts the government's revenues, but the Treasury appears to be resistant to demands for a big cut in the price of duty for the general motorist.

The 15p cut in duty sought by the Freight Transport Association and the National Farmers Union would cost £1.5bn.

fields.body:
That primates addicted to cocaine will self-administer pot to amelioriate cocaine withdrawal symptoms is hardly news; it happens all the time with human cocaine addicts. To construe this junkie-monkey observation into a morbid warning about pot (Monkey study finds cannabis addictive, October 16; Letters, October 17 and 18) -well, that's just meretricious politicking by the Clinton administration's tax-funded drug warriors, who are desperate to put out anti-marijuana propaganda before next month's national elections, in which medical-marijuana referendums will be held in Colorado and Nevada. You Brits are infinitely further ahead than we Yanks in implementing sensible medical regulations around cannabis; you really shouldn't be mucking it up by retailing our government's piss-poor "science" myths.
Dean Latimer
News editor, High Times, New York dlatimer@hightimes.com

webTitle: Dalai Lama's visit to Belfast 'one sided'

fields.headline: Dalai Lama's visit to Belfast 'one sided'
fields.standfirst:
Sinn Fein chief's audience with exiled Tibetan leader prompts extravagant claims by Adams and jibes from his opponents
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, cloaked his head in religious garb while the lord mayor of Belfast, Sammy Wilson, assembly member for the Democratic Unionist party, bristled with indignation. Opportunism knocked in Northern Ireland yesterday as the Dalai Lama came in pursuit of peace.
fields.body:
The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, cloaked his head in religious garb while the lord mayor of Belfast, Sammy Wilson, assembly member for the Democratic Unionist party, bristled with indignation. Opportunism knocked in Northern Ireland yesterday as the Dalai Lama came in pursuit of peace.

Opponents accused Mr Adams of hijacking the exiled Tibetan leader's three-day visit after the west Belfast MP appeared to be trying on the Dalai Lama's clothes when they met at Clonard monastery in his constituency. One sceptic mused that Mr Adams had tried for years to be Northern Ireland's very own Nelson Mandela - and now he was trying to be its Dalai Lama.

In a remarkable press release faxed to news organisations after their private meeting, Mr Adams compared the Tibetan people's peaceful struggle for independence from China to the 30-year conflict in Northern Ireland. The Troubles have so far claimed 3,600 lives, with the IRA behind half of the killings - the last, apparently, only last Friday.

Mr Adams, whose press office said the Dalai Lama had requested the meeting, said he had extended 100,000 welcomes - or cead mile failte - to him and had thanked him for his prayers for peace.

"I have watched with great admiration his struggle for freedom and justice for his people," Mr Adams's statement continued. "They have borne the oppression of foreign occupation with great dignity and fortitude. I am quite confident that all of those who meet the Dalai Lama will be inspired by his quiet strength, openness and deep dedication to the pursuit of peace and justice."

Chris McGimpsey, Ulster Unionist councillor across the west Belfast peaceline on the Shankill Road, suggested Mr Adams was becoming a tad too carried away with his own self-importance: as well as hijacking the Dalai Lama's visit, he was traipsing around the world collecting the handshakes of political and religious leaders. The only people with whom he had no interest in shaking hands were the Protestant minority in his own constituency. Mr McGimpsey said he admired the Dalai Lama but was disappointed he had met only one side of the conflict in west Belfast.

While republicans were doing their best to seize a propaganda advantage, hardline unionists were displaying familiar chippy insularity. Mr Wilson said: "I don't think many people in Belfast know who the Dalai Lama is. I don't know anything about the man or his teachings, and I've never had much of an interest in the affairs of his country. I think people can afford to be a bit cynical; I certainly am."

If any of this remotely worried the Dalai Lama there was scant sign of it. He walked through the peaceline dividing the loyalist Shankill from the republican Falls Road, affect ing to be unaware of the barely suppressed growling as his RUC minders watched civilians in bibs take over the marshalling of the small crowd.

The Dalai Lama, a Nobel peace prize laureate, was remorselessly upbeat as he planted trees on both sides of the divide.

He smiled and giggled as he shook hands with well-wishers before making for the stage for his only public address of his visit. Only 2,000 or so people gathered, but the applause was warm enough. Afterwards some even admitted feeling somehow uplifted.

As always, the Dalai Lama spoke without notes. "Use differences positively," he said. "Two contradictory forces can synthesise and find something more meaningful. Dialogue is important."

Just as the politicians reacted in predictable fashion, so did most news outlets. The most familiar joke in the plethora of colour pieces was whether the Dalai Lama was a Protestant Buddhist or a Catholic one. Sad, really.

The Troubles have so far claimed 3,600 lives, with the IRA behind half of the killings - the last, apparently, only last Friday. Mr Adams, whose press office said the Dalai Lama had requested the meeting, said he had extended 100,000 welcomes - or cead mile failte - to him and had thanked him for his prayers for peace. "I have watched with great admiration his struggle for freedom and justice for his people," Mr Adams's statement continued. "They have borne the oppression of foreign occupation with great dignity and fortitude. I am quite confident that all of those who meet the Dalai Lama will be inspired by his quiet strength, openness and deep dedication to the pursuit of peace and justice." Chris McGimpsey, Ulster Unionist councillor across the west Belfast peaceline on the Shankill Road, suggested Mr Adams was becoming a tad too carried away with his own self-importance: as well as hijacking the Dalai Lama's visit, he was traipsing around the world collecting the handshakes of political and religious leaders. The only people with whom he had no interest in shaking hands were the Protestant minority in his own constituency. Mr McGimpsey said he admired the Dalai Lama but was disappointed he had met only one side of the conflict in west Belfast. While republicans were doing their best to seize a propaganda advantage, hardline unionists were displaying familiar chippy insularity. Mr Wilson said: "I don't think many people in Belfast know who the Dalai Lama is. I don't know anything about the man or his teachings, and I've never had much of an interest in the affairs of his country. I think people can afford to be a bit cynical; I certainly am." If any of this remotely worried the Dalai Lama there was scant sign of it. He walked through the peaceline dividing the loyalist Shankill from the republican Falls Road, affect ing to be unaware of the barely suppressed growling as his RUC minders watched civilians in bibs take over the marshalling of the small crowd. The Dalai Lama, a Nobel peace prize laureate, was remorselessly upbeat as he planted trees on both sides of the divide. He smiled and giggled as he shook hands with well-wishers before making for the stage for his only public address of his visit. Only 2,000 or so people gathered, but the applause was warm enough. Afterwards some even admitted feeling somehow uplifted. As always, the Dalai Lama spoke without notes. "Use differences positively," he said. "Two contradictory forces can synthesise and find something more meaningful. Dialogue is important." Just as the politicians reacted in predictable fashion, so did most news outlets. The most familiar joke in the plethora of colour pieces was whether the Dalai Lama was a Protestant Buddhist or a Catholic one. Sad, really.

fields.headline: Final words for Donald
fields.trailText: The tastelessness and insensitivity of Francis Wheen's comments about the choice of Isaiah as a reading at Donald Dewar's funeral service is startling (G2, October 18). The comments are, moreover, totally inaccurate.
fields.body:
The tastelessness and insensitivity of Francis Wheen's comments about the choice of Isaiah as a reading at Donald Dewar's funeral service is startling (G2, October 18). The comments are, moreover, totally inaccurate. The scripture reading was chosen by Mr Dewar's son and daughter in consultation with myself. We all knew that their father appreciated the verses because they reflected his lifelong campaign for social justice. On behalf of the family, the prime minister was asked to give the reading during the funeral service. Francis Wheen's piece was a completely unnecessary attack on a dignified and moving service.
Rev Douglas Alexander
Langbank, Renfrewshire

 So after the service, the funeral cortege turns into George Square and people are there with tears in their eyes and they're clapping as if Donald's just left the stage and they're showing appreciation for his performance. Only in Glasgow. I'd bet Donald really found that funny and touching all at the same time.
Alistair Richardson
Stirling

 More British propaganda to make you feel better about living in the shadow of a more dominant and vibrant culture (BBC buys animated sitcom that shook US, October 19). God the Devil and Bob was taken off the air in the US, but not because of a moral majority backlash. It got the axe because it's not funny, the animation is dull, and - big surprise - it got lousy ratings.
Jack Barth
New York
jack@barth.net

 I agree emphatically about the cloning of Nancy Banks-Smith (Letters, October 16). Her comment that the sexual antics in some of our soaps "would make a ferret suck its teeth" is an obligatory entry in any anthology of insults.
R Keri-Williams
Redditch, Worcs

webTitle: Mayor attacks generals in battle of Trafalgar Square

fields.headline: Mayor attacks generals in battle of Trafalgar Square
fields.standfirst:
Livingstone wants statues of 'unknowns' replaced
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Major General Sir Henry Havelock looks like a man at ease with his legacy. Standing four and a half metres up on a plinth in Trafalgar Square, his right thumb hooked casually into his belt, this veteran of the first Indian mutiny manages to retain his imperial dignity, even with a pigeon on his head.
fields.body:
Major General Sir Henry Havelock looks like a man at ease with his legacy. Standing four and a half metres up on a plinth in Trafalgar Square, his right thumb hooked casually into his belt, this veteran of the first Indian mutiny manages to retain his imperial dignity, even with a pigeon on his head.

If Ken Livingstone gets his way, however, Havelock may not be enjoying his view of Admiralty Arch for much longer. At a Greater London Authority meeting on Wednesday, Mayor Livingstone suggested that Havelock - who once told his troops: "Soldiers, your valour will not be forgotten by a grateful country" - and another veteran of the Raj, General Sir Charles Napier, be moved from their plinths to make way for more recognisable figures.

Not a clue

Responding to a question about statuary in the square, Mr Livingstone said he did not know who the generals were or what they had done to deserve their prime positions alongside George IV and Nelson.

"I think that the people on the plinths in the main square in our capital city should be identifiable to the generality of the population. I have not a clue who two of the generals there are or what they did," he said.

"I imagine that not one person in 10,000 going through Trafalgar Square knows any details about the lives of those two generals. It might be that it is time to look at moving them and having figures on those plinths that ordinary Londoners would know."

The mayor did not suggest who should replace Napier and Havelock, though he did reject a suggestion from the floor - that it should be Lady Thatcher - as too controversial and too alive.

"I do not know whether you should put them up before we are all dead," he said.

But he is serious about moving them to a site closer to the Thames. "I have already investigated the possibility, and it has been indicated to me that we could move the two generals that no one has ever heard of by the river," he said.

If Mr Livingstone was more familiar with the generals' contribution to the nation's heritage, it is unlikely he would be better disposed towards them. Both were prominent in the Victorian imperial march across Asia. Havelock served in Burma, Afghanistan and India before dysentry brought his conquests, and his life, to an end in 1857. Four years later his statue was erected by public subscription.

Napier, meanwhile, was responsible for quelling the Chartist uprising in the north of England, suppressing calls for such subversive reforms as universal male suffrage and the reform of parliament. He ended his career by leading the conquest of the hill tribes of Sindh, now part of Pakistan.

The suggestion that the generals be moved brought a predictably outraged reaction from the Conservative party and military groups. "What business of his is it to remove statues?" asked Colonel Alastair Cumming, the regimental secretary of Havelock's regiment, the 78th Highlanders.

"And where do we stop? Are they planning to rip Nelson off his column? This really is indicative of where we are going as a country isn't it - consigning our history to oblivion."

Bernard Jenkin, the shadow minister for London, saw it as yet more Britain-bashing from the left. "Last week the politically correct left accused the word 'British' of being racially coded. This week Livingstone is trying to erase a fundamental part of our nation's heritage from the heart of our capital city," he said.

Few Londoners brave the tourist legions and squadrons of pigeons in Trafalgar Square, but those that did yesterday afternoon bore out Mr Livingstone's contention. All were ignorant of the generals and their achievements.

"I don't know who he [Havelock] is but I'm sure he has some historical relevance," said Judith Aguma, who works at the nearby British Council.

"What these men did in the past, whether it was good or bad, has shaped our present. If the mayor wants to put different statues up why not just build extra plinths, or have a plinth which you use to rotate figures?

"These men should probably stay - they are part of our history."

Jane Davison, 19, an art and design student from Surrey, was in favour of more statues but felt the current occupants should be allowed to stay.

"They're in keeping with the rest of the square, although they do look a bit confused, like they've been plonked in the middle of nowhere," she said.

"I think they should keep it the way it is. They may be statues of people who nobody knows but they are in keeping with the rest of the area. Everywhere you look round here there's a statue of some bloke on a horse."

Ronald and Carol Tynan, visiting from Ohio in America, wouldn't change a thing. "I've got no idea who these guys are but they look great," said Carol. "Why take 'em down? They're beautiful, very impressive."

Regardless of the outcome, Mr Livingstone's contentious suggestion has reopened a debate about statuary in the square which for years focused on who or what should occupy the empty fourth plinth in the north-eastern corner.

The mayor presumably would approve of the title of the modern sculpture by Bill Woodrow that currently occupies the spot. It's called Regardless of History.

What it takes to make it on to a plinth

Sir Henry Havelock 1795-1857

A man who devoted his life to the army, Havelock served with distinction in the first Anglo-Burmese war (1824-26) and the first Afghan war (1839-42), but his finest hour came in 1857 when, at the height of the Indian mutiny, he took command of a mobile regiment. His force was too late and too weakened by casualties to save Kanpur, but at the fourth attempt he took Lucknow, securing a knighthood, promotion to major-general and eventually a place in Trafalgar Square.

Sir Charles James Napier 1782-1853

British general, conqueror and governor (1843-47) of Sindh, now in Pakistan. Veteran of the (Iberian) Peninsular war against Napoleonic France and the war of 1812 against the US. Suppressed Chartist agitation before heading to India in 1841. While negotiating an accord with the Sindhi amirs, Napier decided they were disloyal and provoked a war for which he earned a knighthood. Introduced water systems and a police force in Karachi before leaving India after a quarrel with the governor-general.

In with the new A few ideas of our own

Richard Branson A fitting monument to free enterprise, and a deserving target for the pigeons

Barbara Windsor The cheery cockney matriarch is as popular in the East End (she was a friend of the Krays) as she is up west (everybody loves EastEnders)

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau The Dome's chief executive deserves something for steering it towards demolition with such charm

Sir Norman Foster The architect would enjoy a good view as pollution, politicians and hare-brained architects of the future wreck his great works

Liz Hurley Could become a symbol of industrial unrest

The Unknown Pigeon When Ken has had all the pigeons culled, the tourists can photograph this

Ken Livingstone and newt For Whittington's cat, read Livingstone's newt. A valuable decoy for Reclaim the Street activists

fields.headline: North-south divide to grow
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: The north-south divide is set to widen over the next five years, according to a report from independent forecasters published today, which will reignite debate over whether Labour has done enough to help its manufacturing heartlands.
fields.body:
The north-south divide is set to widen over the next five years, according to a report from independent forecasters published today, which will reignite debate over whether Labour has done enough to help its manufacturing heartlands.

While southern regions will grow more than 3% a year on average over the next five years, according to economists at Business Strategies Limited, growth in the north will be a more modest 2.4%.

The boom in new economy firms in the south is one of the main reasons for the growing gap in prosperity, BSL says. Well paid jobs in information technology and communications are concentrated in London and the south-east. Employment in the south is forecast to grow 0.9% a year on average between 2002-2005, compared with 0.5% in the north.

Even the chancellor's public spending bonanza is likely to benefit southern regions more than the north, according to BSL.

"Past population growth has built an even more substantial unfulfilled demand for government services in the south relative to the north," said Neil Blake, BSL's research director. Spending on schools, hospitals and transport infrastructure is likely to be concentrated in regions with growing populations, mostly in the south.

Although southern regions are racing ahead, there are few signs that it is sparking inflationary pressures, according to BSL.

"House price inflation has receded in the south, and consumer spending is set to grow at a more sustainable rate," said Mr Blake.

"Further growth in employment appears to be possible without generating inflationary pressures."

In fact the UK appears to be close to what BSL calls a "golden triangle" with unemployment set to drop below 1m, inflation below the government's 2.5% target and output expanding at more than 2.5% a year.

BSL is predicting growth for the whole economy of 2.9% this year and next, up from 2.1% last year.

Unemployment is expected to drop to 3.3% of the workforce by 2002, while average earnings will pick up, rising nearly 6% next year.

fields.headline: TV row over mob footage 'betrayal'
fields.standfirst:
Correspondent for Italy's state network accused of institutional anti-semitism after identifying rival journalists to Palestinian authority
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A political storm engulfed Italy's Rai state TV network yesterday after its Jerusalem correspondent was accused of betraying a rival network which captured shocking footage of Palestinians lynching two Israeli soldiers.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Rome and  Ian Black  in  Jerusalem
fields.body:
A political storm engulfed Italy's Rai state TV network yesterday after its Jerusalem correspondent was accused of betraying a rival network which captured shocking footage of Palestinians lynching two Israeli soldiers.

Institutional anti-semitism and professional jealousy were blamed for Riccardo Cristiano's decision to effectively identify Mediaset journalists in an open letter to Yasser Arafat's Palestinian authority.

Accusing him of informing, Mediaset said it had been forced to withdraw staff exposed to revenge attacks from Palestinians furious with a broadcast that helped Israeli forces to arrest several of the alleged killers.

Security sources in Israel said the frames taken from the film were crucial in allowing Israel's Shin Bet security service to track down the culprits.

The two soldiers, middle-aged reservists, blundered into the West Bank town of Ramallah last Thursday. They were detained in the local police station but then killed by a mob.

One of those reportedly captured is seen in the film standing at the window of the station with his bloodied hands raised in triumph to signal to the crowd below that the soldiers had been killed.

In Italy, the uproar was a pre-election boon to Silvio Berlusconi, head of the centre-right opposition and owner of Mediaset. A spokesman for his party, Forza Italia, said: "The letter is indicative of an anti-semitic attitude in elements of the Italian left."

Rai disowned the letter and recalled Mr Cristiano to Italy but the network's credibility had crumbled, said commentators.

Declaring a day of shame for Italian journalism, Corriere della Sera said the incident was hateful, unacceptable, unethical and irresponsible. "It is an extremely grave error, without precedent."

Unlike most other networks Mediaset avoided having film confiscated by Palestinian police after the killings.

According to Rai, Mr Cristiano, who was wounded in the head while covering earlier riots, wanted to dispel rumours that a Rai crew was responsible.

In a letter published in Al Hayat al Jadida, an official Palestinian newspaper, he said: "Let us emphasise that it is not at all the case, as we respect the work arrangements between journalists and the Palestinian authority.

"Thank you, and rest assured that this is not our way, and we would never do such a thing."

The deputy head of Rai's Jerusalem bureau went on to offer congratulations and "dear blessings" to his "dear friends in Palestine".

He accused an unnamed rival Italian agency of having produced the film, referring to the killings as "the events."

Israel's government press office suspended Mr Cristiano's credentials after Israel's ambassador to Rome officially protested.

"Mr Cristiano also wrote that his competitors in the Italian media are responsible for broadcasting the pictures of the lynching and thereby accused other foreign journalists working in the territories," it said.

Rai announced that it was immediately recalling Mr Cristiano to Rome. "He will no longer work from Jerusalem. Rai had no knowledge of the letter and its content."

webTitle: Wounded settlers trapped in gun battle

fields.headline: Wounded settlers trapped in gun battle
fields.standfirst:
Ceasefire hopes punctured as Israeli troops mount rescue mission
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops last night staged a desperate operation to rescue wounded settlers trapped in a five-hour firefight with Palestinian gunmen that further undermined hopes for a swift end   to the violence. Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, said the confrontation was a "grave breach" of a precarious ceasefire brokered only 48 hours earlier, according to a statement from his office.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Nablus and  Ian Black  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Israeli troops last night staged a desperate operation to rescue wounded settlers trapped in a five-hour firefight with Palestinian gunmen that further undermined hopes for a swift end to the violence. Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, said the confrontation was a "grave breach" of a precarious ceasefire brokered only 48 hours earlier, according to a statement from his office.

As two attack helicopters provided covering machine-gun fire, troops struggled to extricate six wounded Jewish settlers from Mount Ebal, north-west of the West Bank city of Nablus. At least one settler and one Palestinian gunman were reported to have been killed. Two other Jewish settlers were critically injured.

The gunfire erupted after the settlers allegedly opened fire on olive harvesters, killing one man and injuring 11 others. It was the second attack on olive harvesters this week.

By nightfall, scores of armed men from the Nablus area, including men in the uniform of Palestinian security forces, were clambering up the steep rocky hill. Several opened fire on the helicopters. The settlers, in a group of about 36, had visited the hilltop hoping for a view of a tomb compound in the centre of the city that had been desecrated.

As the pictures were broadcast live on Israeli television, the trapped settlers, who included elderly people and children, gave interviews on mobile phones.

"Under fire for five hours straight," Elazar Mizrahi told Channel Two television against a background of automatic fire. "There are still gunshots. Hiding. Others 30 metres from me. We came to tour the area. We came with army escort... I'm hiding behind a rock. I can't leave here."

Israeli radio stations broadcast warnings in Arabic for people in the neighbouring Askar refugee camp, at the foot of the hill, to leave their homes before punitive action was taken.

Scores of religious Jewish settlers gathered by the roadside to pray beside the 30 who had been rescued earlier.

Yesterday's confrontation was the most serious for a week, and punctures hopes that Israel and the Palestinians can ease tensions within 48 hours, a deadline set on Tuesday.

The head of Israel's central command, General Yitzhak Eitan, said members of the tanzim, the militia raised by Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation, were among the gunmen on the mountain, deepening Israeli suspicions that he does not truly want an end to the violence, or that he is losing control on the ground.

Last night, there was ferocious criticism of the settlers' decision to visit the area, which many Israelis viewed as a deliberate provocation. Gen Eitan admitted the army had approved the visit, but he said it was unclear why permission had been granted.

The gun battle is certain to further inflame rightwing Likud party leaders who have been calling for the army to crack down even harder on Palestinians, after three weeks of bloody mayhem left more than 100 dead.

Elsewhere yesterday, two Palestinian policemen were killed in an explosion at Bethlehem's main police station. Israeli officials said a bomb they were assembling blew up.

To the north of the Gaza Strip, Palestinian stone throwers clashed with Israeli soldiers, who fired teargas grenades.

There were also skirmishes in the West Bank city of Hebron after Palestinians found graffiti insulting the prophet Mohammed on walls near a Jewish enclave.

Nabil Shaath, a Palestinian minister, in Cairo preparing for tomorrow's summit,said: "Israel wants to kill the Pales tinian people and to keep them under siege, and to put them under pressure that they cannot bear."

As part of the ceasefire plan, Israel lifted the internal closure on Palestinian areas on Wednesday, and yesterday transported tanks out of the Ramallah area. But it has yet to lift a closure between Israel and the Palestinian areas, barring 110,000 Palestinians from their jobs and the Palestinian economy from its principal sustenance.
