webTitle: Labour whips up peers over RUC bill

fields.headline: Labour whips up peers over RUC bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An urgent plea has been issued for Labour and Liberal Democrat peers to rally to the government's support as the Tories and the Ulster Unionists prepare to join forces in the Lords to wreck a bill to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary.
fields.body:
An urgent plea has been issued for Labour and Liberal Democrat peers to rally to the government's support as the Tories and the Ulster Unionists prepare to join forces in the Lords to wreck a bill to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

Government whips have asked their peers to attend the Lords during the last week of this month to oppose a series of Tory amendments to the police (Northern Ireland) bill.

Ministers fear that the amendments, if successful, will undermine any prospect of winning nationalist support for the bill, thereby endangering the peace process.

The Tory amendments, supported by the Ulster Unionists, will be debated during the bill's committee stage next week and during its report stage the week after. They introduce fundamental differences between the government's bill and the Patten report on the future of policing in Northern Ireland.

The amendments would:

 Perpetuate the RUC by adding the name to the police force's new title, the Police Service of Northern Ireland;

 Ban members of Sinn Fein and the political wings of the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force from sitting on local police boards until the IRA, UDA and UVF disarm;

 Ban anyone convicted of any offence that led to imprisonment from sitting on the boards;

 Restrict the powers of the district policing partnerships so that they cannot make the district commander accountable to them; and

 Retain the RUC emblem and flag.

Lord Glentoran, the Conservative spokesman for Northern Ireland, said last night that the government had to offer further concessions to Ulster Unionists to save David Trimble's position as leader of the party. He could be unseated at an emergency meeting of the party's ruling council on October 28.

Lord Glentoran said: "Mr Trimble is the only show in town and he needs to be protected. Without him, the peace process collapses. The government has got to go much further."

Government sources last night accused the Tories of attempting to bring down the police bill.

"If the Tories pull the bill down they would pull down one of the central planks of the Good Friday agreement," one source said. "If we do not pass the Patten bill before the Queen's speech [at the end of November] the whole agreement could unravel."

Ministers hope to win the support of Liberal Democrat peers by offering concessions on the recommendation by Chris Patten, the former Tory minister, that there be 50-50 recruitment of Catholics and Protestants. Lib Dems were concerned that a shortfall in Catholic recruitment one year could lead to 100% Catholic recruitment the following year. The government has tabled an amendment which says recruitment from one community cannot exceed 75% in any year.

The arithmetic in the Lords is against the government: the Conservatives have 232 peers, Labour 200, and the Lib Dems 63. The 164 cross-bench peers could play a decisive role.

Andrew Mackay, the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, last night denied that the Tories were attempting to undermine the peace process. "We are not breaching Patten, we are just coming at it from a slightly different angle," he said.

webTitle: Playing the security game, with CIA as referee

fields.headline: Playing the security game, with CIA as referee
fields.standfirst:
US intelligence agency finds role in keeping old enemies on good terms
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: No-one has high hopes of a permanent ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians. But if any outside party can help it is probably the CIA, working closely with the security chiefs on both sides to try to ensure cooperation.
fields.body:
No-one has high hopes of a permanent ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians. But if any outside party can help it is probably the CIA, working closely with the security chiefs on both sides to try to ensure cooperation.

George Tenet, the intelligence agency's director, played a key role at Tuesday's Sharm el-Sheikh summit, though he issued no statements and did not appear in public.

Mr Tenet, happiest in the shadows, was yesterday reported to be furious after a secret security annex - the only real achievement of the emergency talks in Egypt - was leaked by the Israelis, even as the Palestinians denied its existence.

But he quickly followed up summit pledges by browbeating the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, into issuing a more strongly worded declaration calling for an end to violence after Israel considered his previous effort insufficient.

Yet even the CIA will find it hard to rebuild confidence between the two sides after the deaths of more than 90 Palestinians in clashes with Israel in the last three weeks.

Israel is angry that Hamas and Islamic Jihad terrorists released by Mr Arafat's men are still at large. A deadly and highly professional bomb used in an ambush in Gaza on Wednesday night was blamed on Islamist groups.

In Sharm el-Sheikh, Mr Tenet was joined by Col Jibril Rajoub, the head of Palestinian preventative security in the West Bank, and by Avi Dichter, of Israel's Shin Bet internal security service.

For more than two years now, Mr Tenet's men, led by the Tel Aviv CIA station chief, Jeff O'Connor, have been working behind the scenes to keep these volatile former enemies on reasonable terms.

CIA officers take part in routine meetings between the two sides in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, serving as notetakers and submitting reports for their approval afterwards.

Last week the Israelis took a CIA man up to Psagot, an isolated Jewish settlement in the Ramallah area, to prove that the other side had started shooting. "Luckily the Palestinians opened fire first," said one Israeli.

Relations between Col Rajoub, his Gaza counterpart Muhammad Dahlan and their Israeli opposite numbers have been cool to non-existent since the trouble began last month. "I don't believe that relations can go back to the same level of intimacy as before," said a senior Israeli official.

Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, made no secret of his dislike for the spy agency's role in the past. Israelis say the involvement of the CIA has always been more important for the Palestinians than for them because it keeps channels of communication open when things are bad officially. "For us, frankly, its a pain in the arse," said an Israeli expert. "When this all started, the CIA guys were like a referee who could blow the whistle and send people off if there was a foul. Now we don't even want them on the pitch."

Cooperation between Israeli and Palestinian "spooks" has always been central to making the 1993 Oslo agreement work. But when trust broke down it was clear there would have to be a third party involved.

After Oslo, the CIA began to train Palestinians in intelligence-gathering, interrogation and tracking the funds of terrorist organisations - all part of an effort to make the former PLO apparatus less thuggish and accountable.

But the US agency's role as security go-between grew after the Israeli-Palestinian accord at Wye River in 1998. "Being able to have someone to talk to who can talk to the other side and move into the area of the other side quietly and effectively... gets around the kind of conspiracy theories and blame that are prevalent in this area," said Anthony Cordesman, of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. "What both sides need is someone that can act as a discreet, professional referee. The agency has done this."

webTitle: Wowing them in pastels and pearls

fields.headline: Wowing them in pastels and pearls
fields.standfirst:
It might not appear immediately obvious to her subjects but this woman is now regarded as a fashion icon
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen is not normally regarded as a leader of fashion but yesterday, on the last day of her state visit to Italy, the hardest-nosed designers in the business gave the septuagenarian grandmother the sort of adulation that most women can only dream about.
fields.body:
The Queen is not normally regarded as a leader of fashion but yesterday, on the last day of her state visit to Italy, the hardest-nosed designers in the business gave the septuagenarian grandmother the sort of adulation that most women can only dream about.

The monarch, whose four-day visit has seen her in a series of restrained pastel twinsets and pearls, brimless hats and diamond brooches, found the world's top designers falling over themselves to pay her homage.

As he watched the Queen during a tour of the European design centre, Gianfranco Ferre gushed about how much he admired the mixture of wool and cashmere in her slate grey two-piece and how well her black shiny handbag matched her black shiny shoes. "She is always so nice, she is fantastic. You should be so proud of her," he exclaimed.

Miuccia Prada was even more effusive: "Everybody is very impressed ... I always was a big fan. She is one of the most elegant women in the world."

Carla Fendi tried to put it in words: "I think the Queen has a personal ... very facial look. She has the right look for her personality and her position. She seems very traditional in her look and that's right. I would love it if she wore one of my costumes." The bright scarlet body-hugging leather trouser suit with gold belt and fur stole being advertised in one of Milan's fashion magazines perhaps?

Rosita Missoni was plainly overcome: "I think her diamonds are ravishing. She looks so right. I wouldn't change anything. She looks lovely with all those colours."

Ms Missoni, who designs handbags, was so overcome that she did not look at the Queen's bag, unlike some Italian journalists who have been speculating what she keeps in it. They decided it was useful as an accessory to prevent her gesticulating too wildly.

Only Mariuccia Krizia injected a sober note. "The Queen is above fashion. What she wears she wears well but she is not really a fashion lady," she pronounced.

The Queen has changed her outfit several times a day. After yesterday morning's grey, she appeared for a businessmen's lunch wearing lime green. According to Buckingham Palace officials, both costumes were designed by Karl Rehse at Jon Anderson, with hats by Philip Somerville and handbags by Launer, which operates out of the East End of London.

She certainly brought plenty of outfits- so many that the baggage handlers dropped them at Rome airport when they tried to lift a rack full after her arrival on Monday. The airport authorities have sent a written apology.

The Queen appears to have won over even the general population of Milan, regarded as the rudest people in Italy by the rest of the population. Natalia Aspesi, columnist on the newspaper La Repubblica wrote yesterday: "For 24 hours the people of Milan have forgotten their quarrels and learned the rules of etiquette. They have moved from their usual arrogance and insulting behaviour and replaced it by awkward bowing, good manners and silence ... there were not even any of the usual punch-ups outside La Scala."

"It's been tremendously successful, really wonderful. The Italians have really pushed the boat out for us," murmured one gratified palace aide.

webTitle: Two enter contest to succeed Dewar

fields.headline: Two enter contest to succeed Dewar
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The battle to become the first minister of Scotland started yesterday, just a day after Donald Dewar's funeral, as two Scottish cabinet ministers declared their intention to stand.
fields.body:
The battle to become the first minister of Scotland started yesterday, just a day after Donald Dewar's funeral, as two Scottish cabinet ministers declared their intention to stand.

The contest will be as brief as it has come swiftly: the finance minister, Jack McConnell, and the enterprise minister, Henry McLeish, have until tomorrow to garner support for their campaigns.

In a controversial move, Labour has put its usual election rules to one side and set up a fast-track procedure to elect an interim leader on Saturday. The winner will be nominated as first minister.

Under the terms of the Scotland Act, a new first minister must be in place by November 7. Labour says its usual electoral college system - comprising MSPs, unions and the party's executive - cannot provide a candidate in time.

The party intends to follow up tomorrow's vote with a full election later in the year. But it is understood that whoever wins a majority from the 54 MSPs and 27 executive members who will vote in Stirling this weekend will stand unopposed in the full election.

The move has led to backbench claims that Labour is trying to bypass democracy.

The Scottish National party leader, John Swinney, said: "Labour's apparatchiks are dodging a real leadership con test and cutting their ordinary members out of the process."

In the days after Mr Dewar's death, supporters of Mr McLeish, 52, launched a campaign to have him appointed without opposition. The move played badly with backbench MSPs and Mr McConnell, 40, has refused not to stand.

Mr McLeish, the MSP for Fife Central, is the favourite to win tomorrow's vote. Supporters claim he has the backing of every Scottish cabinet minister and many of their deputies.

The swift contest may, however, benefit Mr McConnell, MSP for Motherwell and Wishaw. Some backbenchers are annoyed at what they see as an attempt to deny them a vote. Mr McConnell is also said to have less support among the full electoral college than Mr McLeish.

Mr McLeish, a former professional footballer, helped Mr Dewar steer through Westminster the legislation which created the Scottish parliament. He is the most experienced minister and has a long-held desire to be first minister.

He is believed to be the favoured choice of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, but a perceived reticence to enter political tussles when things are going wrong for Labour may play badly for him among the backbenchers.

Launching his campaign, he said: "This is a time when unity, experienced leadership and solidity of purpose will be needed most of all."

Mr McConnell is a former general secretary of the Scottish Labour party, but is relatively untested as a minister.

His supporters say he is a talented backroom fixer and he might take the Scottish party on a more radical path than Mr McLeish.

fields.headline: Budget to benefit from windfall
fields.standfirst:
Analysts predict chancellor will have a Treasury surplus of more than £20bn to play with
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Treasury's coffers could be in the black by more than £20bn this year, providing Gordon Brown, the chancellor, with significant room for manoeuvre in his forthcoming pre-Budget report.
fields.body:
The Treasury's coffers could be in the black by more than £20bn this year, providing Gordon Brown, the chancellor, with significant room for manoeuvre in his forthcoming pre-Budget report.

The last set of public finance figures before the report, expected in the first two weeks of November, showed a budget surplus of £75m in September, taking the cumulative total for the first half of the financial year to £4.2bn versus a deficit of £1.6bn at the same stage last year.

City analysts said that if the public finances continued to improve at the same rate in the next six months, the chancellor would be awash with cash when he delivers his pre-election Budget in March.

In a report published today, the economics consultancy Business Strategies estimates that the surplus could be as high as £24.2bn, almost £20bn more than the £5bn predicted by Mr Brown last March.

Other analysts are more cautious, believing the surplus will be nearer £15bn, but all agree that the healthy state of the public finances gives Mr Brown ample room to cut taxes and increase public spending in the run up to polling day without jeopardising either of his tough fiscal rules - to borrow only to in vest and to keep the debt-to-GDP ratio stable at no more than 40%.

David Walton, senior economist at the US investment bank Goldman Sachs, said: "Something drastic would have to happen for the public finances to turn out worse than last year so it seems the chancellor will have quite a bit of extra money at his disposal."

The rapid improvement this year is mainly due to the unexpected buoyancy of tax receipts, which rose by close to 8% in the year to September, according to yesterday's data, published jointly by the Treasury and Office for National Statistics.

Mr Walton said the timing of receipts had been distorted by the introduction of a new quarterly system for companies to settle their tax bills and that the impact of this may fade later in the year.

However, he noted that the government's income is being boosted by strong economic growth, expected to be confirmed by upbeat third-quarter GDP figures published today, and the high price of oil, which increases revenue from the taxation of oil producers.

On the other side of the public accounts, spending is beginning to pick up after a sluggish start to the year but is still running below the 7% increase built into government forecasts.

Jonathan Loynes of the consultancy Capital Economic said: "The bottom line is that, with more than half of the year gone, the public finances are once again set to outperform the chancellor's predictions significantly. We expect Mr Brown to revise his forecast for the full-year public sector net borrowing surplus from £5bn to around £10bn in the forthcoming pre-Budget report although we think the out-turn will be around £15bn."

The Treasury sought to dampen expectations of a giveaway Budget next year, saying it was determined not to base policy on short-term fluctuation in the public finances.

"The public finances data always vary from month to month," said a spokesman. "A considered view of the medium term prospects for the public finances will be taken in the pre-Budget report. As the chancellor has said many times over the years, he is determined not to repeat the mistakes of the past and take long term decisions on the public finances on the basis of short term fluctuations in revenue."

Scarred by the memory of the late 1980s, when Nigel Lawson mistook a temporary improvement in the public finances for a permanent one, Mr Brown is likely to err on the side of caution when he does his sums next year.

But few economists doubt he will be able to resist giving away some of the unexpected windfall.

fields.headline: Railtrack 'failed to repair track'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was warned about track faults at the Hatfield crash site last year and was urged to impose speed restrictions but refused to act, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack was warned about track faults at the Hatfield crash site last year and was urged to impose speed restrictions but refused to act, industry sources said last night.

The accusations came as Railtrack and the rail contractors blamed each other for events leading up to Tuesday's rail crash in which four people died and 34 were injured.

Sources within Balfour Beatty, the rail maintenance company responsible for the east coast main line on which the accident occurred, said wear and tear had been noticed last December.

The sources said Balfour Beatty and Railtrack became involved in an argument about who should pay for the maintenance work, leading to further delays. "We knew a derailment was going to occur if the situation was ignored," said the sources.

Balfour Beatty said it did not recognise all the details about wear and tear that the sources referred to. It agreed that it would have to get approval to carry out some work, but usually it did it and then billed Railtrack.

The clash came as another passenger train was derailed last night. The 16.57 Birmingham-Manchester Piccadilly Virgin cross-country service came off the tracks outside Stafford station. It was travel ling at 15mph and nobody was injured.

Railtrack yesterday imposed speed restrictions on 1,000 miles of track at 81 sites throughout the country where the track features are similar to the one suspected of causing the Hatfield crash.

The clash between Balfour Beatty and Railtrack was intensified by a leaked letter from Railtrack to the company complaining that 82% of faults on the east coast main line had not been rectified.

The letter, sent to Carlton Television's London Tonight programme, warned Balfour Beatty that each of the defects could have led to a derailment. It said Railtrack would reduce payment for the contract by "a substantial amount" if the matter was not put right.

Balfour Beatty said it had been notified in April about the defects and all had been put right by the end of May. It blamed Railtrack for a failure to sign off the paperwork "not a failure to undertake work on site".

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, was unanimously confirmed in his job by the board despite offering to resign after the Hatfield crash.

In a statement issued to the Stock Exchange, the board said: "Mr Corbett is the person best qualified to lead the company in the search for all root causes of the disaster and the responses."

Railtrack also confirmed that the probable cause of the Hatfield crash was cracking in the rail.

It admitted responsibility and said it should have replaced the track sooner.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, criticised the introduction of speed limits. He said: "How can it be all right to be allowed to drive at speeds of more than 100mph one day and then have to reduce them to 20mph the next day? It will add up to 25 minutes on all our trains."

fields.headline: Stand-off on West Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli settlers were last night trapped under fire by scores of Palestinian gunmen on a hillside near the West Bank city of Nablus - an attack condemned by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, as "a grave breach" of the precarious ceasefire agreed earlier this week.
fields.body:
Israeli settlers were last night trapped under fire by scores of Palestinian gunmen on a hillside near the West Bank city of Nablus - an attack condemned by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, as "a grave breach" of the precarious ceasefire agreed earlier this week.

The stand-off, which left at least one settler and one Palestinian dead, further undermined hopes of an end to the violence which has claimed more than 100 lives. The head of Israel's central command, General Yitzhak Eitan, said members of the Tanzim, a militia raised by Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation, were taking part in the attack. Few senior Israeli military officers believe Mr Arafat remains committed to the peace process.

fields.headline: Train derails in rush hour
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: A rush hour passenger train derailed outside Stafford station last night, British Transport police said.
fields.body:
A rush hour passenger train derailed outside Stafford station last night, British Transport police said.

None of the 150 passengers is thought to have been injured in the incident, just south of the station.

The 16.57 Birmingham to Manchester Piccadilly train derailed at low speed, Staffordshire police said, at 17.53.

A spokesman for Railtrack confirmed that two wheels of the two front coaches of the Virgin Cross Country train had come off the rails, but that all coaches remained in an upright position.

He said: "It was a very low speed derailment, at about 15mph. A full investigation has begun."

A spokesman for Staffordshire ambulance service said the incident happened about 400 yards from the station at Salop Sidings, just off Brunswick Terrace, off the Newport Road, Stafford.

"Paramedics were there within four minutes. A senior paramedic and doctor at the scene both confirmed there were no casualties and it is no longer an incident," he said.

"One ambulance is still at the scene as a precaution."

webTitle: Care children to get better start in life

fields.headline: Care children to get better start in life
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The government will today promise to "reinvent" social services to improve opportunities for thousands of children in the care of local authorities.
fields.body:
The government will today promise to "reinvent" social services to improve opportunities for thousands of children in the care of local authorities.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will tell the annual social services conference in Edinburgh that he is no longer prepared to accept well-meaning intervention by social workers if it does not improve the lives of people in their care.

"The health and social services must undergo a profound cultural change ... In today's world, just caring is not enough," he will say.

After figures last week showing more than two-thirds of children in the care of local authorities get no passes at GCSE, the government is preparing to more than double theQuality Protects fund for raising educational achievements of children in care.

The fund will rise from £120m this year to £292m in 2003-04, to provide more money for after-school clubs and one-to-one support for children in residential homes, - giving them the help with homework that would be available to children living with their parents.

Mr Milburn will say the policy to improve the life chances of children in care is an example of a new philosophy for reinventing the welfare state. Too often public services delivered results that were in the interests of professionals, rather than the individuals they were supposed to be helping.

"What is on offer here is a new vision of an active welfare state," he will say. "No longer just support from the cradle to the grave. No longer just services that react to illness or disability. But public services which actually promote opportunities for all."

Reform of the public services should ignore proposals from the right for rolling back the welfare state. But the government would also jettison the paternalistic attitude of the traditional left that gave people a safety net by caring for them instead of providing opportunities for success in life.

Mr Milburn is expected to tell social services chiefs that the prospects for children leaving council care were an indictment of the way public services have been delivered.

Children who have been in care account for 0.5% of the population, but 25% of people sleeping rough in London, 22% of prisoners and 39% of prisoners under 21.

The Quality Protects programme was introduced last year to raise standards of children's social services. It was to cost £375m over three years. Under the new proposals it will be extended by two years, with the budget rising to £224m in 2002-03 and £292m in 2003-04.

webTitle: Judge chastises police as lesbian officer is cleared

fields.headline: Judge chastises police as lesbian officer is cleared
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday attacked police attitudes to homosexuality after a gay woman sergeant was cleared of perverting the course of justice.
fields.body:
A judge yesterday attacked police attitudes to homosexuality after a gay woman sergeant was cleared of perverting the course of justice.

Sam Hall, 33, admitted taking the blame for her female lover, who was at the wheel of a police car involved in a collision with another car.

She admitted lying to her superiors by telling them she was driving at the time, but told Norwich crown court she was frightened other officers would find out about the relationship.

Sergeant Hall, a policeman's daughter who joined Norfolk constabulary aged 18, said she had suffered for years from a "whispering campaign" which had often left her suicidal.

The abuse worsened when she was made race and gay liaison officer in September last year, a post described in court as a poisoned chalice.

The jury of eight men and four women took an hour to decide she had not intended to pervert the course of justice when she lied about the crash.

In criticism of the attitudes of some officers in the Norfolk force, Judge Paul Downes said: "It is alarming that in the year 2000 people are still prepared to give people a hard time about their sexuality, even in Norfolk, even in a police station. Even though I recognise there have been enormous efforts from the force to combat this, it is still alarming.

"Myself and the jury took the view that the incident was entirely prompted by worries about the possible repeat of the conduct and behaviour shown to her on previous occasions about her sexual orientation."

The court heard that Sgt Hall and her companion, Carol Jones, were returning on October 17 from a conference in Oxford on the issue of challenging homophobia when the accident happened.

Ms Jones had offered to drive after Sgt Hall said she was feeling "shattered", but on the A11 at Elveden they bumped into the back of a Saab convertible car. It caused only minor scratches to the Saab but £1,409 of damage to the police Volvo, which Hall had permission to use.

Ms Jones was prosecuted for careless driving in June in connection with the crash.

After the verdict on Sgt Hall, whose address cannot be published for legal reasons, she hit out at the "evil" attitudes in society towards gay people.

She added that she wanted to return to her post.

Sgt Hall's solicitor, Simon Nicholls, said: "No words can even come close to describing the horror of the last year for Sam Hall. "The immediate return of this officer to full duty doing the job she loves will be just the tonic she needs."

The Norfolk chief constable, Ken Williams, confirmed that she could return to the force, which he said had made great strides in race and minority group relations, ironically an achievement spearheaded by the sergeant.

"Inevitably in a constabulary of over 1,400 police and over 600 civilian staff we have a broad church of views, but we will purge the constabulary for those who hold homophobic views," he said.

"There is a very clear message from me that those who engage in activities such as this put their jobs at risk."

He said he would be writing to the police complaints authority, which has a duty to consider the case, recommending that Sgt Hall should not be disciplined further over the matter.

Sgt Hall's solicitor, Simon Nicholls, said: "No words can even come close to describing the horror of the last year for Sam Hall. "The immediate return of this officer to full duty doing the job she loves will be just the tonic she needs." The Norfolk chief constable, Ken Williams, confirmed that she could return to the force, which he said had made great strides in race and minority group relations, ironically an achievement spearheaded by the sergeant. "Inevitably in a constabulary of over 1,400 police and over 600 civilian staff we have a broad church of views, but we will purge the constabulary for those who hold homophobic views," he said. "There is a very clear message from me that those who engage in activities such as this put their jobs at risk." He said he would be writing to the police complaints authority, which has a duty to consider the case, recommending that Sgt Hall should not be disciplined further over the matter.

fields.headline: Now you're talking
fields.standfirst: The bitter rivalry between talk show hosts Jay Leno and David Letterman has transfixed the US for years. But now Leno is to produce a show for his arch rival's channel. Is this the beginning of a beautiful friendship? By  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: The bitter rivalry between talk show hosts Jay Leno and David Letterman has transfixed the US for years. But now Leno is to produce a show for his arch rival's channel. Is this the beginning of a beautiful friendship? By Gareth McLean
fields.body:
Last night, George W Bush appeared on The Late Show With David Letterman in an attempt to woo voters before the presidential election in November. Al Gore had already turned up on the show in September and, as part of her election strategy for the Senate, Hillary Clinton also submitted herself to Letterman's interrogation, not to mention his leftfield sense of humour.

While late-night talk shows have never succeeded in Britain, they are mighty institutions in America - none more so than Letterman's Late Show on CBS and The Tonight Show, hosted by Jay Leno, on NBC.

Letterman and Leno's shows attract the vast majority of the 22 million viewers who watch late-night TV on the four main networks: ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox. As such, they also attract the majority of the $700m that advertisers spend on late-night commercials in the US. With their diet of comic monologues, celebrity guests and live music, Leno and Letterman are big guns in the networks' arsenals.

But as slick as their respective shows are, the American public is as transfixed by the men's off-screen rivalry - which has been spectacularly reignited with news that Leno is to develop a sitcom at the home of Letterman, CBS. When the deal was announced in Hollywood late last week, minds were cast back to when Johnny Carson faced his final audience as host of The Tonight Show some eight years ago and the Leno/Letterman feud began.

Host of NBC's late-night talk show for 30 years, Carson's departure caused a battle of succession worthy of Shakespearean tragedy. When Carson quit (with the words "I bid you a very heartfelt good night"), Letterman was heir apparent. The former TV weatherman and stand-up comedian was discovered by Carson in the 70s, and Late Night With David Letterman - which was shown every night after Carson's Tonight Show from 1982 - had gained a cult and demographically desirable following.

When the older man stepped down, Letterman expected to take up his mantle. But, unbeknown to Carson and Letterman, NBC executives had offered the job to Leno, a talented comedian three years younger than Letterman, but with more experience in comedy terms.

One US commentator said the move was the equivalent of Prince Andrew challenging Charles for the throne after the Queen dies, and the Leno-Letterman power struggle made headline news for months. It also made The Late Shift, a book by New York Times media correspondent Bill Carter, which was later turned into a film by cable channel HBO. It chronicled what became known as "The Great Talk Shows War" which, after double-dealing on the part of the networks, hardball from Leno's agent, and Letterman's misplaced faith in his friendship with Carson and the NBC chiefs, saw Leno crowned as Carson's replacement. With help from superagent Mike Ovitz, Letterman and his Late Night team defected to CBS for $14m a year and a promise that his show would be scheduled against Leno's.

From the first week that they were in competition, Letterman stayed consistently ahead of Leno in the ratings, although in recent years, Leno has usurped Letterman. Leno's Tonight Show beat Letterman's Late Night to an Emmy in 1995, and bar the occasional surge in Letterman's audience - his meeting with Hillary Clinton, the show after his quintuple bypass operation - Leno remains comfortably ahead in the ratings, especially in the all-important 18-49 demographic. (Although to be fair to Letterman, NBC has always attracted a younger audience than its rival and is generally a stronger network because of it).

What makes Leno's achievement all the more admirable is his personality. As in fiction - The Larry Sanders Show, King Of Comedy - America likes its real late-night talk show hosts to be edgy, complex creatures. While Letterman is notoriously insecure and Carson mercurial and, at turns, genial and testy, Leno is a genial good guy. He is happily married, a regular on the charity circuit, and can often be seen driving one of his vintage cars around Hollywood. Quite a contrast to Letterman, whose Porsche-driving, fast-living, living-in-sin status is well-known. So well known, in fact, he has his own stalker. While Leno is seen to have maintained his distance from (and a none too deferential view of) celebrity, Letterman is perceived as having become one in his own right. Perhaps it's this that has endeared Leno to the public at Letterman's expense. In an encounter with Letterman, Madonna once mused, "You used to be kinda cool. Now you just kiss up to everybody."

With his deal at CBS destined to irk Letterman, Leno is looking more comfortable with his lot than ever. A five-year, $100m contract and a good guy from a middle-class New England home, Leno is a prime example of the American Dream. Cementing his avuncular image, he's magnanimous whenever Letterman is mentioned. "Let's face it, this isn't one of those steel-cage death matches,' he once told an interviewer.

Perhaps not, but as celebrity death matches go, Leno v Letterman is much more interesting than Gore v Bush. Stay tuned for round three...

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Rejoice. Graham Norton is on the telly again. He's back with a fourth series on November 3 which, promises this week's Channel 4 publicity blurb, will be bringing us "more of the same".

So where has the lovely Graham been all this time? Well, we last saw him on our screens before the summer, before Big Brother and all that. And he's been a busy bee since then, filling up his time with a spot of business planning - yes, that shiny suit has a real purpose after all. Because Norton has set up his own TV production company.

Like so many stars before him (notably Mel Smith and Griff Rhys Jones, who trousered roughly £20m apiece when their indie outfit Talkback was sold earlier this year), Norton is more than just the cheeky grin he cracks up to be on screen.

Which isn't to say he's greedy. Norton's business is still small and fluffy, as you'd expect in the world of independent TV production, where the first call on petty cash is invariably a weekly ration of chocolate biscuits. He's in business with Graham Stuart, who used to work for United Productions - the people who make So Graham Norton. And their company, So Television, won't just be a vanity project for Norton; it will nurture new talent as well - the huge numbers of people on the comedy circuit whose talents are largely ignored by other TV bosses.

So, the duo have some laudable aims, but will the new business make any money? Well, that's where Graham Stuart comes in. He told Broadcast magazine this week: "We know that to run a company you need to have deep pockets, so it might be that we need to get help from someone with deeper pockets." Come on investors, hear the call...

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Soros firm buys Abbey branches
fields.standfirst: By Christmas you could bank at a Carphone Warehouse
fields.trailText: Abbey National yesterday made a £70m profit by selling its branches and other properties to a company linked to George Soros, the financier who famously forced sterling out of the European exchange rate mechanism.
fields.body:
Abbey National yesterday made a £70m profit by selling its branches and other properties to a company linked to George Soros, the financier who famously forced sterling out of the European exchange rate mechanism.

Under the terms of the £457m deal, Abbey National immediately leased back the properties, including its head office which shares the Baker Street address of fictional detective Sherlock Holmes.

The bank insisted the transaction, leaked out to the City earlier this year but only sealed yesterday, was not a precursor to branch closures.

However, Abbey said the transaction with property group Mapeley Columbus would give it more flexibility to move its branches. The bank has outlets in Safeway supermarkets and yesterday opened its second branch in a Costa Coffee shop, on the King's Road in Chelsea. By Christmas the bank intends to be sharing premises with Carphone Warehouse.

Abbey has transferred the management and ownership of its properties to Mapeley Columbus for 20 years. Mapeley Columbus is owned by Fortess Investment Group, Soros Real Estate Partners and Delancey Estates.

Mike McNamara, a partner at the Ernst & Young real estate group, which structured the deal, said this was the first transaction of its kind for a public company. He predicted other firms with large property portfolios might follow suit.

The transaction means that Abbey will be able to vacate premises early or extend leases more cheaply than in the past because Mapeley Columbus carries the risk associated with the 25-year - or longer - contracts.

Mark Pain, Abbey's finance director, said that while the bank had made a £70m profit on the sale, which will be reported in its 2000 profit figures, the longer-term benefits were more important.

"We have taken a major step towards being able to alter, radically if required, our property requirements in order to meet our future business needs."

Forty of the branches are no longer even run by Abbey, af ter it franchised them to their existing management. At the end of this month it will extend the franchise pilot to another 19 branches in Belfast, Brighton and Brent Cross. Under the franchise arrange ment, Abbey continues to employ the staff and management but gives them greater power over decisions and links their pay to their performance.

The shares rose by 15p to 880p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Insurer posts positive results
fields.body:
Insurer posts positive results

Legal & General reported a 12% increase in UK sales over the past nine months despite a slowdown in its home market.

Chief executive David Prosser said he expected the UK life and pensions market to grow about 5% this year, after growth of 10% to 15% over the previous five years.

The group aims to take a significant share of the low-margin "stakeholder" pensions being introduced next year. Management fees have a 1% ceiling.

Reuters boosts Instinet board

Information group Reuters has beefed up the board of its electronic broker Instinet ahead of expected flotation of the business.

Instinet said its Europe chief executive, Janusch Raft, had been appointed Instinet Europe chairman, and Rod Sinclair, director of global business development, would become chief executive officer, European institutional equities.

The market expects Reuters to announce a part flotation of Instinet along with its third-quarter results today. Valuations for Instinet have ranged from about £2bn to £4bn.

Virgin signs union pact

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline yesterday signed its first union recognition deal.

The British Airline Pilots Association (Balpa) struck the recognition deal on behalf of Virgin's flight deck crews. General secretary Chris Darke said: "We are pleased to have concluded this agreement, which now gives both Virgin and Balpa a vehicle to address flight deck terms and conditions of service."

A Virgin Atlantic spokesman said: "We have always said that we listen and we act on what our staff are telling us, and our pilots say they want to be represented by Balpa."

Sunderland on a high

Sunderland football club yesterday managed to shrug off a 116% increase in player wages to report a tripling of profits for last season.

A strong performance in the Premier League and capacity crowds at its Stadium of Light helped pre-tax profits in the year to May 31 climb from £1.5m to £4.8m on turnover of £37.3m. The dividend was increased to 4.8p.

Chief executive John Fickling blamed the wages jump on bonuses paid to players for finishing seventh in the league but said while wages remained at 50% or less of turnover they were a manageable cost. "Overall we've had a bloody good year," he said.

Camelot is asked to stay

The National Lottery Commission confirmed yesterday that it is negotiating for Camelot to extend its operating licence beyond September 2001.

The licence was to end next September but both contenders for it - Camelot and The People's Lottery, the consortium set up by Sir Richard Branson - have said they need 12 months to introduce a new-look lottery. Delays in deciding between the two applications mean that Camelot must be persuaded to carry on.

webTitle: Technology switch causes Panasonic to cut Cardiff workforce

fields.headline: Technology switch causes Panasonic to cut Cardiff workforce
fields.trailText: Hundreds of jobs are to be cut at the Panasonic television and microwave factory in Cardiff by the end of this year as the company speeds up the transfer of low-tech analogue TV production to a factory in the Czech Republic.
fields.body:
Hundreds of jobs are to be cut at the Panasonic television and microwave factory in Cardiff by the end of this year as the company speeds up the transfer of low-tech analogue TV production to a factory in the Czech Republic.

The company, which employs 2,400 people at the Pentwyn plant, began shifting work to the east European factory almost four years ago. But it decided to accelerate the process because of the strength of sterling and rising raw material costs.

It is the second big Japanese-owned electronics plant in south Wales to announce cutbacks this week, following Sony's decision to shed 400 jobs at its factory in Bridgend.

David Fowler, personnel director at the Panasonic plant, said the industry was continuing to see prices eroded in the market place. "We don't want to get involved in the political debate about the strength of sterling but we certainly would not be disappointed if Britain were to join the euro."

Panasonic said the job cuts being discussed with officials from the GMB union were necessary because the plant was moving from being a volume manufacturer to becoming a less labour-intensive value one.

But the company, which has been based in south Wales for more than 24 years, stressed its continued commitment to the Cardiff operation where the focus of attention will now be on research and development of digital technology and manufacture of hi-tech products.

Recent digital diversifications have included devices such as set-top boxes and plasma television screens.

fields.headline: Whitbread to sell 3,000 pubs
fields.standfirst: First the breweries went. Then the off-licences. That leaves the restaurants, health clubs and hotels
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest landlords were running their slide rules over Whitbread's 3,000 pubs and bars last night, after the leisure company signalled its intention to sell its £1.5bn estate in order to concentrate on restaurants, health clubs and hotels.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest landlords were running their slide rules over Whitbread's 3,000 pubs and bars last night, after the leisure company signalled its intention to sell its £1.5bn estate in order to concentrate on restaurants, health clubs and hotels.

Japanese bank Nomura, privately owned Punch Taverns and tenanted pub company Enterprise Inns emerged as possible bidders for some or all of the houses for sale, which include the Hogshead and Dome bar chains.

Whitbread said the estate would be better off in the hands of owners "fully concentrated" on pubs. The company's chairman, Sir John Banham, said: "We have a very attractive set of businesses going forward and we want to devote all our attention to that. We will not be able to do that, and do justice to our pubs and bars."

The group will return 75% of the proceeds to investors by the middle of next year, through a special dividend or a share buyback. The rump of the business, dubbed "Future Whitbread", will include Pizza Hut, Cafe Rouge and Beefeater restaurants, the Marriott and Travel Inn hotel chains and David Lloyd Leisure sports clubs.

The company has already sold its breweries and its share in the off-licence business First Quench this year. Chief executive David Thomas, who has been criticised in the past for lacking a clear strategy, wants to specialise on a small number of nationwide leisure brands.

Whitbread's shares jumped 37.5p to 468.25p as the City welcomed the restructuring. Analyst Charles Winston of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney said: "It's a brave move from a company which has not made enough brave moves in the past, and I applaud that."

By last night, the number of expressions of interest in Whitbread's pubs had reached double figures. However, there were concerns that the price for the estate may not reach initial estimates of £1.5bn, because of a glut of pubs on the market. Rival leisure group Bass is looking for buyers for hundreds of its neighbourhood houses, and troubled regional players such as Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries are considered to be willing sellers.

Britain's two biggest pub owners, Punch Taverns and Nomura, which both have more than 5,000 outlets, are both interested. Punch's chairman, Hugh Osmond, said: "I'm sure we'll have a look at them. When the last of the big guys gets out, I think it's a signal that the market's turning upwards."

Punch beat Whitbread in an acrimonious battle to buy Allied Domecq's 3,500 pubs last year. The defeat led to a turning point in the leisure group's strategy.

Ted Tuppen, chief executive of Enterprise Inns, said he had "plenty of cash available" and would examine Whitbread's 1,710 leased and tenanted pubs. There were also said to be many possible financial buyers.

However, news of the sale was greeted with dismay by purists. The Campaign for Real Ale pointed out that under the ownership of a former brewer, Whitbread's tenanted pubs were entitled to stock a local "guest beer". Under new ownership, landlords could face "strong-arm tactics" to sign new leases, obliging them to stick to drinks from just a handful of big suppliers.

The campaign's research manager, Iain Loe, said: "They are betraying people who've worked hardest for them, just to follow some get-rich quick tactic of buying hotels."

When the last of the big guys gets out, I think it's a signal that the market's turning upwards." Punch beat Whitbread in an acrimonious battle to buy Allied Domecq's 3,500 pubs last year. The defeat led to a turning point in the leisure group's strategy. Ted Tuppen, chief executive of Enterprise Inns, said he had "plenty of cash available" and would examine Whitbread's 1,710 leased and tenanted pubs. There were also said to be many possible financial buyers. However, news of the sale was greeted with dismay by purists. The Campaign for Real Ale pointed out that under the ownership of a former brewer, Whitbread's tenanted pubs were entitled to stock a local "guest beer". Under new ownership, landlords could face "strong-arm tactics" to sign new leases, obliging them to stick to drinks from just a handful of big suppliers. The campaign's research manager, Iain Loe, said: "They are betraying people who've worked hardest for them, just to follow some get-rich quick tactic of buying hotels."

fields.headline: Spending spurs rate fears
fields.trailText: High street spending surged ahead last month despite the fuel crisis, reawakening fears of higher interest rates to dampen demand.
fields.body:
High street spending surged ahead last month despite the fuel crisis, reawakening fears of higher interest rates to dampen demand.

Figures published yesterday by the office for national statistics showed retail sales volumes grew 0.6% in September from August and were 4.6% higher than last year.

The figures were much stronger than expected in the City, where analysts had expected the fuel crisis to limit visits to the shops.

"There was no effect overall from the fuel crisis. Some stores said sales had dropped but others said they had risen," said an ONS statistician.

Economists said the figures were likely to worry hawks on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee who were banking on a slowdown in consumer demand to keep inflation in line with the government's 2.5% target.

Ciaran Barr of Deutsche Bank in London said that after robust industrial production data, the retail sales figures suggested today's third-quarter GDP figures were likely to be higher than the City expected.

The average forecast is for a 0.7% increase but some analysts warn that it could well be over 1%.

"The economy is still clearly growing above trend. I don't know where the mythical slowdown in consumer demand is in the data. I still think rates need to rise," said Richard Iley of ABN Amro in London.

"The longer the MPC prevaricates by emphasising backward-looking wage inflation data, the bigger the ultimate rise in rates will have to be," he said.

A breakdown of the data showed that food sales rose a solid 0.4% on the month, while non-food sales increased 0.7%.

Within non-food sales, textiles, clothing and footwear were the best performer, rising 1.2% on the month.

Daniel Kaye, of Capital Economics, said that whatever the constraints on consumers in the week of the fuel crisis this was more than offset by the volume of spending in subsequent weeks.

"This should provide ample opportunity for the hawks on the MPC to regroup next month, making the next vote a much closer call than the last one," he said.

fields.headline: £1bn sale means
fields.standfirst: Perpetual may not live up to name
fields.trailText: A cloud hung over the long-term future of the prestigious Perpetual brand last night after Martyn Arbib sold the fund management company he founded 25 years ago for £1bn.
fields.body:
A cloud hung over the long-term future of the prestigious Perpetual brand last night after Martyn Arbib sold the fund management company he founded 25 years ago for £1bn.

Mr Arbib, a millionaire horse-racing fanatic, and his family received £425m for their 45% stake in a mixture of cash and shares in Amvescap, the Anglo-American company which is buying Perpetual after a five-month tempestuous courtship.

Amvescap, which owns the Invesco and AIM fund management labels in Britain, said it would retain Perpetual as a separate brand during the forthcoming sales period for individual savings accounts (Isas).

Amvescap will then review the brand, perhaps using it alongside another brand or retaining it on certain products. The group has a reputation for co-branding and using brands targeted at specific audiences.

It was also unclear precisely what role Mr Arbib would perform once the sale of the business, based in Henley-on-Thames, was completed.

After being taken over by Amvescap, Perpetual will come under the management of Hugh Ward, who is chief executive of Amvescap's Invesco UK division. Roger Cornick, deputy chairman of Perpetual, said it was too early to know how roles would be allocated. The group employs 800 people in Henley, who own approximately 15% of its shares.

The final sale tag agreed for Perpetual was less than the £45 a share many believe Mr Arbib wanted to achieve. He built the business on the back of the boom for now defunct personal equity plans. The deal with Amvescap, sealed after talks faltered in May, values each Perpetual share at £35.80. Amvescap is paying £10 in cash and two of its own shares for each Perpetual share. Amvescap share's rose 36p to £13.26 yesterday.

Mr Cornick described the price as "realistic".

Mr Brady, who flew into London from Amvescap's US base to announce the deal, revealed that the group retained its appetite for further acquisitions.

The group bought Trimark of Canada in May, the deal which appears to have derailed the discussions with Perpetual at that time.

Mr Brady said yesterday, "We have capacity for more deals."

But these are unlikely to be in Britain, where the group is now the second largest fund management group.

webTitle: The last porters at Whitbread carry bags

fields.headline: The last porters at Whitbread carry bags
fields.standfirst: Notebook Now polish up the brands
fields.trailText: Samuel Whitbread must be turning in his grave. The Bedford-born apprentice brewer who founded the Whitbread empire in 1742 based the business on "porter" - a strong, black beer popular among London's labourers.
fields.body:
Samuel Whitbread must be turning in his grave. The Bedford-born apprentice brewer who founded the Whitbread empire in 1742 based the business on "porter" - a strong, black beer popular among London's labourers.

The only porters left in the company wear gold braid caps and wheel luggage around the firm's Marriott hotels. Moving further than ever from its boozy heritage yesterday, Whitbread announced it wanted to sell its 2,998 pubs. This move attracted a rare cheer from the City, which has regarded Whitbread as a rude word in recent years. Most pin-striped snobs associate the company with greasy Pizza Hut deliveries and spartan Travel Inn rooms.

The management deserves credit for the strategic move - there has been a gradual realisation that the traditional "local" pub is an endangered species. Such outlets require time, attention and imagination of the kind which the big players such as Bass and Whitbread can rarely afford.

Entrepreneurs such as Punch Taverns' boss Hugh Osmond, Enterprise Inns' Ted Tuppen and JD Wetherspoon's Tim Martin have shown they can run boozers more efficiently than megalithic leisure conglomerates.

Unfortunately, the timing of Whitbread's exit is tricky, coming in the middle of a review of the regulatory Beer Orders, and with a glut of other pubs on the market depressing prices.

However, the pubs need to go sooner, rather than later, to leave Whitbread in more palatable shape. All the company needs to do now is to revive the performance of its more tired-looking brands such as Café Rouge and Beefeater. New chairman Sir John Banham should contribute a few few retailing tricks, having chaired Kingfisher for the last five years. Perhaps he can help persuade the City that Whitbread is in the 21st, rather than the 18th, century.

Over-egged

The mighty Goldman Sachs should be severely embarrassed over the short stock market record of Telecity, the computer warehousing firm it floated in June and which yesterday saw its shares crash by 40% after lower-than-expected quarterly revenues.

The American investment bank is both financial adviser and corporate broker to the company; its clients are full of the stock. Yet its analysts were expecting Telecity to deliver turnover figures 20% higher than the company could manage in the three months to end-September.

This could be treated as little more than a "disappointment" - a new company in a volatile industry over-egging expectations and then getting it wrong. The new economy is a risky place to do business.

But, in a stock market sense, Telecity has been a mess since the listing plans were first revealed. The float was pulled in the middle of May's dot.com sell-off and then suddenly thrown back on track a fortnight later. Some £116m was raised at a price which valued the company at £570m, but the offer was restricted to Goldman's institutional clients, with retail investors locked out, an action which used to be against stock exchange rules for an issue of this size.

The net result was an exceptionally tight market in Telecity shares, where just a little bit of interest from the share buying public was enough to send the price rocketing to £23 at one stage, against the 775p float price. Yesterday, the illiquidity worked the other way as the price careered down from £11.35 to 687.5p.

In the process, a dark cloud has been thrown over the planned flotation of three similar companies: InterXction, Global Switch and IXEurope. Goldman received a fee of just over £5m bringing Telecity to market. Nice work if you can get it.

Reason to smile

The London stock exchange did not try to bill yesterday's ballot on lifting a 4.9% stake limit on its shares as a proxy for the crucial vote on the hostile bid by Sweden's OM. But Don Cruickshank, chairman and acting chief executive, may have allowed himself a brief grin when his shareholders overwhelmingly voted down the resolution at yesterday's extraordinarily calm EGM.

The decision not to lift the restriction, which technically prevents the OM bid succeeding, appears to reflect shareholders' lack of interest in selling to anyone.

As has been said here before, however, this is no reason for Mr Cruickshank and his colleagues to be complacent. Thankfully, yesterday's second defence document shows signs of the long-awaited fight back and even contains some real strategy; a pan-European high-tech market, broader international vision, a full market flotation at some stage and the sale of the gruesome Old Broad Street tower once it can get leaseholders occupying half the building out. Such thinking has not arrived a day too soon.

fields.headline: GKN sorts out aerospace 'muddle'
fields.standfirst: 600 jobs go in Britain and US as engineering group tries to lift earnings
fields.trailText: 600 jobs go in Britain and US as engineering group tries to lift earnings
fields.body:
Engineering group GKN yesterday launched a radical restructuring of its under-performing aerospace division, including plant closures in the UK and US, designed to boost earnings.

GKN confirmed that it is to close its Avonmouth plant near Bristol, with the loss of 300 jobs, and two American plants, in Carson, California, and Wallingford, Connecticut, with the loss of a further 300 posts.

Avonmouth employees, who were told of the closure plans in April, will be offered jobs at GKN's factory in Cowes, Isle of Wight. The group is also selling on a German business, Sitec, reducing its aerospace manufacturing plants from 11 to seven. It is also paying $61m (£44m) for Boeing's military aerospace and missiles manufacturing plant at St Louis, Missouri in an effort to widen its access to the burgeoning US defence budget. This employs 1,500 but Boeing is axeing 300 jobs before GKN takes over in January 2001.

The aim is to become one of Boeing's core suppliers, particularly for work on the F18 Hornet fighter and C17 military transporter, with the prospect of lucrative contracts for the new joint strike fighter being developed for the US airforce, navy and marines.

Boeing and Lockheed Martin are in a bidding war to win the world's most expensive military contract, worth anything up to $200bn with export sales, but the incoming US President is likely to award a workshare between the two.

GKN officials said the St Louis business would be located close to planned new Boeing facilities in Missouri and the aim was to capture contracts from other manufacturers under a new American management team.

The restructuring will cost £68m and create a new GKN division under Kevin Smith, a former BAE executive, which will be separate from the helicopters business, Westland, being transferred into a joint venture with Italy's Agusta.

GKN's aerospace operations, which have doubled in size over the past four years through a series of small acquisitions, are seen by industry sources as a "muddle" which has produced growth in sales but lower profits than expected.

Yesterday's acquisition, which should generate $1.8bn extra sales over five years, will boost the new division's turnover from $500m to $800m a year. Initial profit margins should be 6% but GKN is expecting double-digit margins thereafter.

The group's existing aerospace division, including helicopters, made £138m operating profit on £1.4bn sales last year and analysts welcomed yesterday's restructuring plans, although GKN shares closed down 20p at 710p.

fields.headline: £8.5m red alert for Arcadia
fields.trailText: The struggling Arcadia retail group - whose high street brands include Dorothy Perkins, Wallis, Top Shop and Miss Selfridge - has crashed £8.5m into the red and is to close a further 55 stores.
fields.body:
The struggling Arcadia retail group - whose high street brands include Dorothy Perkins, Wallis, Top Shop and Miss Selfridge - has crashed £8.5m into the red and is to close a further 55 stores.

The new closures - on top of 400 announced earlier this year - mean an additional 450 Arcadia staff will lose their jobs, bringing the total number of redundancies to nearly 4,000. Arcadia is also scrapping its dividend.

The company, which is the UK's second biggest clothing retailer after Marks & Spencer, has been battered by the success of discounters like Matalan. It now has a stock market valuation of just £70m - less than a tenth of its value two years ago when it demerged from the Burton Group.

Arcadia, which could have collapsed earlier this year if it had not managed to renegotiate its banking facilities, is now implementing a radical recovery plan. Yesterday, as the group unveiled its dismal results, the company said it had studied its operations in all of the 527 towns in which it has outlets and that 332 need changes. So far action has only been taken in 115 and the company said there are signs that the worst is over. But finance director Nigel Hall warned: "It's too soon to draw conclusions. I am promising nothing, but we are doing everything possible to restore our profitability."

The recovery plan, called BrandMax, is hinged on making better use of the group's shopfloor space. Chains, like Principles for Men, have been axed and in many towns two outlets - like Dorothy Perkins and Burton - are being relocated into a single shop.

So far 204 stores have been disposed of and Arcadia reckons it will have shifted 300 by February next year. It hopes to be rid of the rest by February 2002. The 55 new closures will generate additional annual cost savings of £20m, said Arcadia.

But while the group's attention has been on rationalising its store portfolio, other serious problems have emerged. In 1998 the company started a mail order catalogue operation with Littlewoods, called Dial. Yesterday the company said orders have ben streaming in "with gross orders up 23%", and the number of shoppers up 13.5%. But turnover climbed just 1% as the operation ran out of stock and hit further problems delivering items it did have in the warehouse to shoppers' homes. It made a loss of £11.3m, of which £7.3m is Arcadia's share. Mr Hall described the Dial situation as "a problem we would rather not have" and said the blame was part Arcadia's and part Littlewoods'. "We are working together to solve the problems," he said but warned it could take two years to get back to break-even.

The group also lost £3m on its Zoom internet operation, and said that was unlikely to break even for three years.

The group's £8.5m loss, which excludes a one-off £144m restructuring charge, compares to a profit of £41.8m last year. But it was in line with City expectations and there were some indications that performance is improving. Like-for-like sales were ahead 4.8% in the first seven weeks of the new financial year and margins are recovering after a 0.8% dip last year.

"If they can sustain any amount of this current trading it will be good news," said one analyst, but he warned investors to take care because Arcadia had had " a wave of false dawns". Last night the shares closed up 2p at 42p.

fields.headline: Firm hands move fast
fields.trailText: Another day, another float and another opportunity for City institutions to make some easy money.
fields.body:
Another day, another float and another opportunity for City institutions to make some easy money.

This time the stock in question was nCipher, a Cambridge-based internet security firm that counts the US defence department and the internet bank Egg among its customers. As expected, the shares got off to a flying start. Placed at 275p by Deutsche Bank they hit 360p before falling back to close at 333p, valuing the company at just over £400m. Over 24m shares changed hands suggesting some of the institutions involved in the placing of 34.1m nCipher shares at 275p earlier this week had cashed in their holdings at the earliest opportunity. So much for institutional "firm hands".

Ahead of the flotation, nCipher decided not to offer any shares to retail investors presumably on the grounds that the business was too complex for ordinary punters to understand. How thoughtful.

fields.headline: Exchange promises to seek listing
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange is to move out of its landmark tower and seek a full listing if it is successful in fending off the hostile £1bn bid from Sweden's OM Gruppen.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange is to move out of its landmark tower and seek a full listing if it is successful in fending off the hostile £1bn bid from Sweden's OM Gruppen.

It will also build a pan-European stock market, expand its product range and establish a broker services group for the retail community.

The plans, contained in its third defence document which was published yesterday, came as shareholders voted against abandoning a crucial ownership limit. This could further impede OM's approach.

webTitle: Business: Nokia results move the markets

fields.headline: Wake-up call
fields.standfirst:
Nokia results move the markets
Net news
fields.trailText: Dealers in Helsinki and elsewhere watched technology share prices gain new life after Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, yesterday announced exceptionally strong sales, profits and prospects.
fields.body:
Dealers in Helsinki and elsewhere watched technology share prices gain new life after Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, yesterday announced exceptionally strong sales, profits and prospects.

Investors seized on the Finnish group's 50% rise in third-quarter sales and 39% jump in operating profits as proof that public demand for mobile phones is still growing.

Jorma Ollila, Nokia's chairman and chief executive, said: "By adding elements of mobility to the internet we see a great possibility to further enrich people's daily lives and the efficiency of companies."

He said the group was heading towards record earnings per share in the fourth quarter and it expected sales to grow by up to 35% next year. Net profits for the first three quarters of the year were up 58% at €2.7bn (£1.6bn).

Technology and telecom stocks around the world were lifted by Nokia's results.

Mr Ollila said Nokia had gained market share in new infrastructure technologies and in handsets. "Our view of the market development fundamentals remains unchanged, with more than 400m mobile phones estimated to be sold in 2000, leading to an estimated one billion users in total during 2002.

"For 2001 we expect the mobile phone market to be in the region of 550m units."

During the third quarter Nokia had continued to invest in the development of mobile internet applications which he described as "a central element in operators' revenue generation in future mobile networks".

The growth of Nokia's business is reflected in the increase in its workforce from 53,713 to 60,048 over the past year.

Its largest markets are the United States, Britain, China and Germany.

fields.headline: Telecity broker gets it wrong
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in Telecity lost more than a third of their value yesterday after the internet hosting company revealed that it had missed revenue forecasts by 20%.
fields.body:
Shares in Telecity lost more than a third of their value yesterday after the internet hosting company revealed that it had missed revenue forecasts by 20%.

Telecity shares slumped below their 775p June issue price for the first time and ended the day down 447.5p at 687.5p after warning that the roll-out of its service in continental Europe was progressing slower than expected. At their height the shares traded at £23.45p.

Analysts say the share price has swung so wildly because there are only a small number of shares in issue. Turnover of £3.8m for the three months to September 30 was £900,000 less than had been forecast by house broker Goldman Sachs, the only investment bank to have published research on the company. Losses fell from £2.9m to £2.4m.

Mike Kelly, chief executive of Telecity, blamed the revenue shortfall on the slower than expected rate at which space in its Stockholm and Amsterdam centres was being rented out.

"Telecity is not as strong a brand out there as it is in the UK and it is taking a longer time for those facilities to fill," he said. "Goldman Sachs was last night thought to be scaling back its fourth quarter revenue forecasts.

Telecity's woes are likely to be felt across the competitive internet hosting market. Several firms have raised large sums of venture money to build out across Europe centres capable of hosting the servers and switches needed by telecoms operators and large internet firms to run their websites. IXEurope confirmed on Monday that it plans to raise up to £100m through a stock market flotation but the fundraising may have to be scaled back.

Mr Kelly insisted that Telecity's strategy of using the £60m it has in the bank to build 40 centres across Europe by the end of 2002 remains intact. "Demand in the UK remains strong and we will still extend our lead over our rivals on the continent."

webTitle: Professors lured into crime by mafia

fields.headline: Professors lured into crime by mafia
fields.trailText: Extortion, drug smuggling, gun running and murder were not advertised on the campus syllabus, but that is exactly what Sicily's University of Messina was teaching, Italian police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Extortion, drug smuggling, gun running and murder were not advertised on the campus syllabus, but that is exactly what Sicily's University of Messina was teaching, Italian police said yesterday.

Thirty people were arrested and seven went on the run after a 16-year investigation climaxed on Wednesday in dawn swoops on the campus, situated on the eastern tip of Sicily. Local politicians and prosecutors were implicated in the alleged corruption, which turned lethal after a professor tried to speak out.

Administrators and academics at the university allegedly teamed up with the mafia to build a vast criminal empire, initially funded by the bribes that students paid to pass exams. Some of the brighter students also paid thugs to terrorise academics into falsely awarding degrees.

Authorities believe the scam started in 1984 with modest bribes to professors to pass exams, but it soon grew. The price for a bachelor's degree in statistics, economics and commerce became £2,500; for immunology and medical degrees it was £3,100.

The 'Ndrangheta mafia clan, usually based on the toe of Italy, muscled in even though Messina nominally falls under the control of its Sicilian colleagues, the Cosa Nostra.

Led by Giuseppe Morabito, whose nickname is Straight Ahead, the clan showed staff how to expand the scam to invest the money in drugs, some of them stolen from the university's pharmacological labs.

The breakthrough came in 1998, with the murder of Professor Amadeo Bottari, possibly because he had threatened to blow the whistle. Prof Bottari's colleague, Giuseppe Longo, was arrested the following year as the network's alleged circle of protectors began to crumble.

Angelo Giorgianni, a former Messina prosecutor, was forced to resign as interior under-secretary amid suspicion of collusion.

"We uncovered a criminal ring headed by Longo, which was connected to the mafia and exercised a huge power on the university's management," said Messina prosecutor Luigi Croce. "The ring basically had a three-pronged organisation which bribed professors, some of whom took an active part in managing the ring, controlled the university's administration and managed the local drug trade."

Giovanni Lumia, head of parliament's anti-mafia commission, said other arrests might follow.

"We have to keep working to uncover the connections between the mafia and the local entrepreneurs and notables," he said.

Seventy-nine people are under investigation.

fields.headline: Barenboim 'victim of anti-semitism'
fields.trailText: The conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim was at the centre of a blazing row over alleged anti-Semitism last night. It is a dispute that threatens to reach the highest levels of the German cultural and political establishment.
fields.body:
The conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim was at the centre of a blazing row over alleged anti-Semitism last night. It is a dispute that threatens to reach the highest levels of the German cultural and political establishment.

In a open letter to the Berlin section of the newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, a former city councillor responsible for the arts, Ulrich Roloff-Momin, depicted the Argentina-born musician, who is due to leave the German capital in 2002, as a victim of ill-disguised anti-Jewish feeling.

His claims came at a uniquely sensitive moment: a rash of attacks on synagogues earlier this month, during the holiest week in the Jewish year, left Jewish leaders in Germany questioning whether their community had any future.

The Berlin city council is also preparing to publish proposals that will seal the fate of the Staatsoper, where Mr Barenboim is chief musical director.

It is widely expected that the financially hard-pressed council will merge the Staatsoper with the Deutsche Oper under Christian Thielemann.

Heaping fuel on to the glowing coals, Mr Roloff-Momin said that it was "intolerable" that German politicians should "constantly refer to 'the Jew, Daniel Barenboim' and not the world-class artist". He asked: "Is it not, in fact, latent anti-Semitism when religion is made to count in cultural-political affairs?"

In an apparent allusion to the composer's decision not to renew his contract, Mr Roloff-Momin's article was published under the title "Stay and Fight".

His claims were given added weight yesterday by a front-page report in the city's newspaper, the Berliner Morgenpost. It said the leader of the Christian Democrat group on the council had described the future of opera in Berlin as lying between "on the one hand, the young Karajan Thielemann and on the other, the Jew, Barenboim".

The councillor, Klaus Landowsky, acknowledged having made the remark, but vehemently denied any anti-Semitic intent. He said the thrust of his comment was "not at all against Barenboim, but on the contrary, in support of him".
