webTitle: Schröder shifts his party to Blair's way of thinking

fields.headline: Schröder shifts his party to Blair's way of thinking
fields.trailText: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has called for a decisive shift in the ideological orientation of his Social Democratic party (SPD) that would commit Europe's most powerful leftwing movement to Blairite moderation.
fields.body:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has called for a decisive shift in the ideological orientation of his Social Democratic party (SPD) that would commit Europe's most powerful leftwing movement to Blairite moderation.

In a private speech to colleagues, only made public last night, the chancellor urged them to accept that "the state ought not to do what society can do better".

Although the SPD should not abandon policies intended to help society's weaker members, Mr Schröder made it clear that the state should "not force people into a straitjacket that chokes freedom and individual creativity".

Mr Schröder was addressing the Social Democrats' top strategic planners at the start of a detailed rethink of the party's fundamental values which officials said would continue for several years.

His remarks seemed to sweep away lingering doubts over his true commitment to "third way" politics.

After the fiery leftwinger, Oskar Lafontaine, stormed out of his government in early 1999, Mr Schröder's position on the right of the party appeared to be beyond question. Not long after, he infuriated SPD radicals by signing a joint declaration with Tony Blair which many regarded as a betrayal of their party's most cherished values.

Following a string of defeats in regional elections, and under mounting pressure from the left, however, Mr Schröder surprised admirers and critics alike with a blatant exercise in state intervention.

Late last year, he bailed out his country's second-largest construction firm, Philipp Holzmann, and in similar, traditionally leftwing, vein deplored hostile takeover bids like that by the British company Vodafone for Mannesmann of Germany.

In his speech on Wednesday, the tactician in Mr Schröder surfaced when he appeared to argue for periodic intervention. He told his party's strategists that it did not have to mean wholesale regulation of the free market.

But, while making frequent nods in the direction of social concern, the rest of his address was firmly rooted in what his own advisers dubbed the "new centre". Mr Schröder told his party colleagues to bear in mind that the SPD was not only Germany's oldest party and one with venerable traditions, but that it stood for renewal.

"Renewal has always been part of our tradition. It is not by chance that we have been closely involved in the discussion among European and non-European centre-left parties on modern governance in the 21st century," he added in a reference to the meetings between third way leaders.

These debates, the most recent of which took place in Berlin earlier this year, had identified the central task facing the SPD, Mr Schröder said.

It was to "find a place for social democratic and government policy in the triangle represented by the market, civil society and the state".

In defining the relationship between the last two, the chancellor continued, the German left should apply a principle employed by the European Union. In EU terms, so-called subsidiarity means entrusting to Brussels only those decisions which cannot be taken at a lower level, by national, regional or local governments.

The task facing those drafting a new set of principles for the SPD was "to define the relationship between state and society in such a way as to optimise subsidiarity", he said.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Alan Jay Lerner: The Street Where I Live | The Friday Play: The Green Man
fields.body:
Henry Goodman continues his splendid reading of the lyricist's memoirs, Alan Jay Lerner: The Street Where I Live (7.0pm, Radio 2). The rights to George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion had been owned by the late film producer George Pascal, whose estate was in predictable chaos. MGM was making a strong bid and it seemed the legal tangle would never be unwound. Eventually, composer Fritz Loewe suggested they simply write the show without the rights."Then we'll be so far ahead they'll be forced to give them to us."

It's unfair to call Doug Lucie's script plotless but its confined action is not the point of The Friday Play: The Green Man (9.0pm, Radio 4). Four friends gather early at a local pub to embark on a fishing trip. Waiting for the fifth, they casually chat and drink. With an extraordinarily fine ear for the demotic English of working-class males, Lucie probes the underlying tensions of their relationships.

webTitle: Support for Mbeki dives after Aids controversy

fields.headline: Support for Mbeki dives after Aids controversy
fields.trailText: South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, has suffered a large and sudden fall in public support almost certainly attributable to his controversial stance on the cause of Aids.
fields.body:
South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, has suffered a large and sudden fall in public support almost certainly attributable to his controversial stance on the cause of Aids.

Mr Mbeki's approval rating has dropped to a fraction above 50% from more than 70% in May, according to an opinion poll released today by the most credible of South Africa's polling organisations, the Institute for Democracy (Idasa).

The results are a significant blow to Mr Mbeki's leadership because support for the ruling African National Congress as a whole has stood up with 69% of black voters saying they will back the party in December's important elections in the vast new megacities created around Johannesburg, Pretoria and Cape Town.

When compared to his predecessor's standing, Mr Mbeki's position is even more stark. Nelson Mandela had an 85% approval rating just before he left office last year.

"There is no doubt that this is a wake-up call for Mbeki and his government," said Richard Calland, the head of political programmes at Idasa. "The survey as a whole shows a decline in people's confidence in representative institutions. It is as if people feel they are not being listened to enough."

As recently as July, two-thirds of South Africans approved of their president's performance. The decline in support has coincided with the public airing of Mr Mbeki's controversial questioning of the link between HIV and Aids, and his association with a minority of scientists who say there is no connection between the virus and the disease.

The government has refused to supply anti-Aids drugs to public hospitals after initially saying they were unproven and toxic but then, after a barrage of criticism, saying it could not afford them.

About 62% of South Africans do not have confidence in the government's attempts to prevent the spread of Aids - an issue that will be the single most important of Mr Mbeki's presidency and likely to devastate the population.

One in 10 South Africans is HIV-positive and the country has among the highest infection rates in the world.

Mr Mbeki's administration has argued that it is not its role to be overly interventionist, particularly in the economy. But the man who was once Mr Mbeki's main rival to lead the ANC, Cyril Ramaphosa, this week chastised the government by saying that the only reason it was elected was to be interventionist and transform South Africa.

Mr Ramaphosa's stance will be reinforced by the poll's finding that just 28% of those polled had confidence in Mr Mbeki's economic policies. But, given that the economy has been facing difficulties for some time, it is unlikely that is the major cause of his sudden loss of support.

Among the poll's findings was the revelation that Mr Mbeki is less trusted among his core constituency than the independent press he and his allies so frequently criticise as anti-black. Just 48% of black South Africans say they trust the president, while 60% have confidence in the press.

webTitle: Star wars technology to battle breast cancer

fields.headline: Star wars technology to battle breast cancer
fields.trailText: Thousands of women's lives could be saved by using a machine that employs star wars technology to detect the reappearance of breast cancer cells, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of women's lives could be saved by using a machine that employs star wars technology to detect the reappearance of breast cancer cells, it was claimed yesterday.

The Cancer Research Campaign unveiled the first Chromavision machine in Britain, the invention of Charles Coombes of Hammersmith Hospital, west London, who adapted the technology of war to the healing art of medicine.

Instead of pinpointing the exact spot where enemy missiles enter the Earth's atmosphere, the Chromavision can help doctors spot a single cancer cell among millions of normal ones.

It is hoped the machine will help women who have had surgery for breast cancer. At present nearly all are put on a five-year course of Tamoxifen, the nearest thing in cancer treatment to a wonder drug. Tamoxifen dramatically reduces the chances of a recurrence of cancer for most women, but in some the cancerous cells creep back.

Professor Coombes' machine, which is only at the pilot stage, will test samples of bone marrow from patients every three to six months and warn of any cancer recurrence. "Until now treating breast cancer has been like managing diabetes without checking a patient's blood sugar levels," he said. "Doctors could never be sure how well Tamoxifen was working."

The cancer returns if it becomes resistant to Tamoxifen. The CRC said yesterday that there was now a new drug, called Exemestane, which might work where Tamoxifen fails and could double the survival rates achieved by the older drug.

Prof Coombes is conducting the pilot study of the Chromavision with the help of 140 women, and is coordinating worldwide trials of Exemestane. The drug trial is expected to produce definitive answers within two to five years.

"Together these two new techniques could mean doctors will no longer have to send patients away with a bottle of Tamoxifen and cross their fingers," he said.

"In the future there might be an earlier way of monitoring women to see whether the disease returns and, if it does, they may be offered another treatment which would greatly improve their chances of survival."

Lesley Walker, director of cancer information at the CRC, said: "Research like that of Prof Coombes promises to take us two steps further and will usher in a new era in treatment and detection."

Each year 14,000 women die of breast cancer, which is the biggest killer of women aged between 35 and 54. Yet there have been big gains in the battle against the disease. Mortality rates have fallen 20% over the past 10 years.

Earlier surgery to excise lumps and radiotherapy have played a part, and public awareness of breast cancer has led concerned women to go to their GPs earlier. But use of Tamoxifen has arguably been the most significant factor.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Mask Of Zorro | The Basketball Diaries | Payback | Los Olvidados
fields.body:
The Mask Of Zorro

(Martin Campbell, 1998)

9.40am, 7.40pm, Sky Premier

More derring-dos, with Old California's own Robin Hood legend. It's overlong, but done with great verve. Antonio Banderas (pictured), a dashing hero in the Tyrone Power mould, is the rugged, buffoonish Murrieta, protégé of the now elderly Zorro (Anthony Hopkins), who trains him to fight, ride and smile wickedly, and to take on corrupt Governor Montero. Catherine Zeta Jones plays Zorro's long-lost daughter, pretty sharp with a blade herself.

The Basketball Diaries

(Scott Kalvert, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

The diaries, written by basketball player Leonardo DiCaprio, chart the boy's steady decline into theft and mugging through heroin addiction. Based on the real-life story of Jim Carroll, it's a cautionary tale that takes a simple-minded line on addiction - heroin leads on in a straight line from recreational drug use. An affecting, low-key performance from DiCaprio, nevertheless.

Payback

(Brian Helgeland,1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

A thriller that isn't as hardboiled as it would like to be, this is a rerun of Point Blank, John Boorman's version of Richard Stark's novel The Hunter, with Mel Gibson trying in vain to fill the considerable Lee Marvin role as Porter, a-hard-as-coffin-nails hood double-crossed, left for dead, and now returning to get even with The Outfit: "I just want my money back." Hefty entertainment, with James Coburn and Kris Kristofferson among the heavies.

Los Olvidados

(Luis Buñuel, 1950)

2am, FilmFour

A jarring and harsh account of streetlife in the Mexico City slums - an introverted boy gets caught up with Jaibo and his gang of young robbers. It's an unsentimental look at hopeless lives, and with its oddball characters and disturbing imagery, much more than social tract.

fields.headline: Dead on arrival
fields.trailText: Holby City | Biography: Joan Rivers | Biography: Joan Rivers
fields.body:
Picture the scene: Holby City's producer sits brainstorming with some creative types. "We need to increase the programme's popularity in the new ratings-conscious BBC or we might have Nick Berry foisted upon us," he sighs. "Any thoughts?"

A plucky script editor pipes up. "How about an outbreak of Ebola sweeps from Casualty to our wards, liquefying a couple of regulars?"

"I can nominate a couple," an associate producer interjects helpfully.

The producer shakes his head. "No. We need something more... upbeat."

"How about a children's ward?" ventures a scriptwriter nervously.

"Of course," the producer enthuses. "It'd up the cuteness quota - ill children are real ratings grabbers. And it'd give us an opportunity for heart-rending emotional manipulation. Current regulars could suffer new and uncomfortable emotions dealing with dying children."

"We could get in a quirky children's nurse," says the associate. "With pigtails. And purple cardigans. And a black woman."

"Or a black man," the script editor offers. "And a softly spoken ward manager."

"Irish gay or Scottish female?" asks the producer.

"Scottish female," the script editor and associate producer chime as one.

The producer looks chuffed. "Excellent. Now, next item. Should Charlie and Duffy get it together in time for Christmas 2002?"

Hence, more wards were added to Holby City (BBC1). We have quirky pigtailed nurses, "Whispering" Siobhan Redmond and countless ill stage school children. Ambition is admirable in a drama, but Holby City's expansion has made it more pedestrian. With an ever-expanding core cast, the programme is losing focus. Cameras wander corridors looking for drama and find only time passing, lots of venetian blinds and Tony Britten wearing the same maroon Paisley dressing gown he wore in Don't Wait Up. Even the introduction of Hunky Dr Alex has failed to restart Holby's heart. There's only the most superficial probing of the relationships between the staff, many of whom have descended into self-parody, and it would be hard to tell if the patients were replaced by cardboard cut-outs.

The most annoying thing about Holby City is that it could be really good. There are some great actors involved, and a bottomless pit of medical stories to be mined, but instead of a more thoughtful, considered version of Casualty, we have an insubstantial, soporific and aimless series, devoid of complex characters and darkly difficult storylines. Why Pretend Doctors Make Mistakes, if you will.

Joan Rivers was in hospital receiving liposuction when her husband of 20 years took an overdose and killed himself. The two things may not be entirely unconnected, as Biography: Joan Rivers (History Channel) showed. Her story was fairly bog standard - daughter of immigrants becomes successful comedienne and launches own jewellery range on QVC - but her relationship with her husband became more strained with her ascendancy into the celebrity firmament. Eventually, her success seemed to lead him to depression and then suicide.

The "grief, guilt and fear" she suffered after his death were given the briefest mention, but the documentary was a thoroughly authorised look at the life of Joan Melinksy, with daughter, manager and close friends wheeled on to testify to how wonderful Joanie is. Even the narrator's attempts at pop psychology didn't detract from the feeling that this was an airbrushed, smiley look at Joan's Triumphs Against Adversity. Interesting as a distraction, but hollow at its core. Next week, it's the turn of Joseph Stalin. Interesting to see what they make of him. "Joseph wasn't a bad man...."

Dispatches: Children Of The Secret State (C4) showed that Stalinists are nothing if not poetic. In North Korea, where the population is starving, the 200,000 orphans scavenging for food are known as "wandering swallows". While the army thrives, South Korea and the West appease the world's last Stalinist dictatorship, and hundreds die under the rule of the potato-headed Kim Jong-Il. An impressive piece of investigative journalism, this was upsetting, challenging TV. With footage shot by a man now missing in North Korea, it was also testament to the bravery of those involved. Genuinely dramatic stuff.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Weetabix ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Weetabix ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
We open on a magnificent black stallion, galloping riderless through some woods. He belts across a beautiful beach, grassy-green hill and huge corn field, to the familiar strains of the soundtrack from 70s TV series Black Beauty. Eventually the stallion charges back to his stables, and as he trots over towards the camera we suddenly cut to two blokes climbing out of a black pantomime horse. "Good that, Bob." "Aye, cracking," say the sweaty pair, as the Withabix stamp comes up on screen.

The jargon:
This ad continues the 10-month Withabix/Withoutabix campaign, jokily aimed at suggesting you can achieve amazing feats if you have Weetabix for breakfast (and can't if you don't). So far, three "with" and three "without" ads have been made, one of each running at the same time. The campaign is mainly to remind consumers about the joys of Weetabix, bringing the cereal back to the front of their minds/cupboards.

Personality:
The core target is "housewives" - or whoever does the shopping, although Weetabix want to speak to everyone from children to husbands and grannies. It's an all-round "family cereal", apparently.

Financial status:
You're likely to fall in the BC1C2 bracket. The advertising isn't "lowest common denominator"; it has a certain cleverness to it, says agency Lowe Lintas, so you are definitely not a D or E.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You are probably vaguely health-conscious - Weetabix is low-fat, high-fibre, etc, so you could fancy the idea that it's good to start the day with a nice bowl of cereal (even if you douse it with full-fat milk and sugar and then light up a fag).

Other relevant data:
The spot doesn't use the real original footage from Black Beauty, but carefully spoofs the opening sequences. It was shot on the South Downs and West Wittering beach, using two horses. The agency paid "an undisclosed sum" to use the music.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Tetbury, Gloucestershire
fields.body:
The pine marten, an attractive little cat-sized mammal with lustrous, chocolate brown fur, was once widespread in the UK, but, persecuted by gamekeepers, is now one of our rarest native mammals. Relict populations still exist in areas like the National Trust's Crom Estate in County Fermanagh, and parts of Scotland, Wales, Northumberland and the Lakes, but proponents of a plan for their re-introduction suggest the species is effectively extinct south of the Scottish Border.

Author of the propsosal is the People's Trust for Endangered Species, a wildlife charity, supported by government wildlife agency English Nature. The re-introduction project (for woodlands in Devon, Somerset, Dorset, Avon, East Sussex and Cumbria) seems attractive, but some scientists think there still exist in England and Wales some long-established populations which, though elusive and struggling, are viable. They aren't opposed to the principle of re-introduction, but believe that questions need to be asked first - notably, what is responsible for the failure of existing relict populations to recover?

The legislative advance of the right to roam is unlikely to do any favours for shy wildlife. Could we see the pine marten reaching the conservation icon status of the otter, with a poster on every schoolroom wall? I do feel that these proposals will do little to halt the pressures which humanity puts on the other tenants of this planet.

If you have a view on the proposal, now in its consultative phase, contact the People's Trust for Endangered Species on 020-7498 4533.

webTitle: Bosnian town split by pupils schooled in hate

fields.headline: Bosnian town split by pupils schooled in hate
fields.trailText: Disturbances continued for a fourth day yesterday in the north-east Bosnian town of Brcko, with Serb pupils demonstrating against sharing school buildings with Muslims.
fields.body:
Disturbances continued for a fourth day yesterday in the north-east Bosnian town of Brcko, with Serb pupils demonstrating against sharing school buildings with Muslims.

Tension ran high as busloads of Serb students arrived in the morning from nearby Bijeljina. When the buses were stopped by troops serving in the Nato-led stabilisation force, S-For, the pupils continued on foot into the town.

About 1,000 Serb students later marched on the municipal assembly, where the multi-ethnic local council was in session, hurling eggs, tomatoes and abuse. A cordon of riot police protected the building. The windows of two cafes, owned by former Muslim refugees who had returned to Brcko, were also smashed.

The head of the Brcko district police, Dusko Kokanovic, said that 10 people had been detained, two policemen injured and five buildings damaged, according to the Bosnian Serb news agency, SRNA.

"This must be stopped urgently, it is spreading like a tide. We are receiving information that it is not only the problem of the district, but that it will very soon become the problem of Tuzla, Bijeljina, Sarajevo, Mostar and Banja Luka," said the town's Mayor, Sinisa Kisic.

Some of the demonstrating pupils carried the flags of nationalist Serb parties, and the skull and crossbones banner of the Chetnik movement - Serb monarchists blamed for some of the worst excesses in Yugoslavia during the second world war, and the conflict of 1992 to 1995.

Muslim pupils attend three secondary schools during the morning; Serbs are taught in the afternoon. Police search the classrooms for bombs during the break between shifts.

The trouble began last week with abusive graffiti and physical attacks. A Muslim pupil was beaten up on Friday, prompting a demonstration by fellow pupils on Monday, demanding better police pro tection. On Monday evening, a Serb student, 20-year-old Gojka Pavlovic, was killed in circumstances which remain unclear. Her death fuelled the tension, although police deny any connection with the latest disturbances.

Before the war, Brcko, which is strategically located beside the river Sava, had a mixed community - 44% Muslim, 25% Croat and 21% Serb. In May 1992 Serb forces began rounding up Muslims and Croats. Up to 8,000 were killed, many in a concentration camp in the town, and 20,000 expelled.

During the war, some of the toughest fighting took place along the Posavina corridor, which Brcko straddles - a narrow strip only three miles wide, linking Serb-held territory in the west and east of Bosnia.

Because of the intensity of the rival claims, the town was the one place in Bosnia left out of the 1995 Dayton peace agreement. It continued as a de facto part of the Serbian republic in Bosnia, full of Serb refugees from elsewhere in the country, especially Sarajevo.

To the fury of hardline Serbs, the international arbitration commission ruled in 1999 that the whole district of Brcko should become a neutral condominium - overlapping both the Muslim-Croat federation, and the Serb republic in Bosnia. This was seen by many supporters of Bosnian unity as the first piece of the jigsaw puzzle of a united Bosnia.

The district was inaugurated in March at a ceremony attended by all three presidents of Bosnia - Muslim, Croat and Serb. A multiethnic assembly and multiethnic police force were established. "Brcko shows that seemingly irreconcilable problems can be overcome," US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said at the time.

Tension ran high as busloads of Serb students arrived in the morning from nearby Bijeljina. When the buses were stopped by troops serving in the Nato-led stabilisation force, S-For, the pupils continued on foot into the town. About 1,000 Serb students later marched on the municipal assembly, where the multi-ethnic local council was in session, hurling eggs, tomatoes and abuse. A cordon of riot police protected the building. The windows of two cafes, owned by former Muslim refugees who had returned to Brcko, were also smashed. The head of the Brcko district police, Dusko Kokanovic, said that 10 people had been detained, two policemen injured and five buildings damaged, according to the Bosnian Serb news agency, SRNA. "This must be stopped urgently, it is spreading like a tide. We are receiving information that it is not only the problem of the district, but that it will very soon become the problem of Tuzla, Bijeljina, Sarajevo, Mostar and Banja Luka," said the town's Mayor, Sinisa Kisic. Some of the demonstrating pupils carried the flags of nationalist Serb parties, and the skull and crossbones banner of the Chetnik movement - Serb monarchists blamed for some of the worst excesses in Yugoslavia during the second world war, and the conflict of 1992 to 1995. Muslim pupils attend three secondary schools during the morning; Serbs are taught in the afternoon. Police search the classrooms for bombs during the break between shifts. fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate...where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate...where to eat out for under £15

Il Forno, 63-64 Frith Street, London W1. Tel: 020-7734 4545

You've got just two days left to eat drink and do some good along the way. This week has been Action Against Hunger Week and the guzzler dedicates his support with two of around 100 restaurants all over the country that are chipping in some way (for further information ring 020-7242 5665). Not that you wouldn't be advised to toddle along to Il Forno on its own merits. The restaurant on this site has had a few incarnations over the years. Now it seems to have found its true identity: decent Italian grub - pasta, pizza and polenta in various guises - at decent prices. Small portions around the £5 mark and large going up to £8.50. Delightful service, too.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Food for Thought, 31 Neal Street, London WC2. Tel: 020-7836 0239

It looks good, tastes good, does you good, and you can do good as well. That's the long-serving Food for Thought for you, wholesome whole food and wholly vegetarian - Mexican bake; stir-fry veg with rice; tofu and shitake mushroom stew are all much-loved classics. But there's an eye and a tastebud for the less heavyweight numbers too, including Thai curry, broccoli and Cheddar cheese soup and spinach quiche, not to mention salads of various hues at distinctly lightweight prices. Be prepared to share your space, especially at lunchtime. No bookings. No smoking. And take away, if you prefer.

Just out: James White's organic raspberry and pear juice

Form: Cloudy pinky-brown liquid.

Flavour: Not quite one fruit and not quite the other.

Verdict: rather delicious for all that. Very clean tasting. Good natural sweetness, and nice balancing acidity. No cloying chemical aftershock. The pear juice brings a slight viscosity to the liquid, which is really rather seductive. Organic, naturally. Healthy, too, I shouldn't wonder.

Price: £2.49 for 75cl. Available nationwide from selected Sainsbury's stores, health food shops and delicatessens.

Food on the net

www.porkpie.co.uk

Dickinson and Morris is the maker of arguably the finest example of the Melton Mowbray pork pie, lauded by chefs, food critics and punters alike. And there's sausages, hunt cake, preserves and Colston Bassett stilton to boot.

Pros:
A whacking 1.75lb pork pie for £5.18, jars of lemon curd and hot gooseberry chutney, and sausage-flavours including Melton Smokey and Pork and Spring Onion. The firm has been making pies since 1851, so it knows what it's doing.

Cons:
Delivery charges are a tad hefty.

Delivery:
Usually within two working days, if order is placed before noon.

Charges:
For chilled products carriage is £7.75, for non-perishable items £3.95.

On the menu: crimini mushrooms

So, my merry mycophage, what is a crimini mushroom, then?
The younger brother of the portabellini and the youngest of the portobello.

You don't mean to tell me that they're all the same mushroom under different disguises?
Well, different sizes, really. If one was being truthful.

So they're all portobellos under the cap?
Well, actually, the portobello isn' t a variety.

What is it?
A grown-up field mushroom.

And crimini is a little field mushroom?
Yes.

An ordinary white mushroom by any other name, in fact.
Yes.

How sad.

fields.headline: At this price?  Turbo Genset
fields.trailText: Turbo Genset reached a milestone yesterday when it announced the first firm order for its revolutionary power generation technology. That was all the more impressive because the buyer - DTech, a subsidiary of Detroit Energy Company - placed the order before Turbo Genset has delivered a prototype.
fields.body:
Turbo Genset reached a milestone yesterday when it announced the first firm order for its revolutionary power generation technology. That was all the more impressive because the buyer - DTech, a subsidiary of Detroit Energy Company - placed the order before Turbo Genset has delivered a prototype.

So what makes one of North America's biggest energy companies part with $8.5m cash for something it has not seen?

The answer is a magnetic substance called called neodynium iron boron. Put simply, the substance has given Turbo Genset the know-how to develop a range of small, high-powered generators.

The result on paper is a device that can produce large amounts of power but is a fraction of the size of current generators. For example, a Turbo Genset generator the size of a waste paper bin could produce enough power to satisfy the demands of a small housing estate.

As yesterday's full year results make clear, the market for such "localised" power devices is huge. With profits from the generation and transmission of power being whittled away by zealous regulators, utility companies are forced to consider ways of generating power locally. In the developed world the biggest obstacle to electrification is the cost of rolling out an infrastructure.

Stockbroker WestLB Panmure points out that yesterday's statement also shows Turbo Genset making progress with other customers, namely BP, General Electric and a consortium led by De Dietrich of France.

Of course, the financial figures revealed were of little relevance. Losses in the year to July 31 were £3m but the company has £30m of cash on the balance sheet which should see it through to 2002, when its first profits are expected.

Despite a 15.54% rise yesterday, Turbo Genset shares are still some way from the £28.05 reached in late August. Worth a flutter but not for the risk-averse.

fields.headline: Waiter, there's a bug on my plate. Delicious
fields.standfirst: Fancy a snack? Then why not dip into a bag of mixed fried insects? Or sample a silkworm pupae.  Justin Hunt  on why the most fashionable food at the moment is 'critter cuisine'
fields.trailText: Fancy a snack? Then why not dip into a bag of mixed fried insects? Or sample a silkworm pupae.  Justin Hunt  on why the most fashionable food at the moment is 'critter cuisine'
fields.body:
If you are organising a dinner party and are keen to offer your guests some unusual nibbles, why don't you offer them a plate of insects? While the idea of eating crispy crickets or lightly fried beetles probably fills most of us with absolute horror, insect eating is apparently becoming highly fashionable in dot.com land. Swarms of trendy new media types are reportedly logging onto wacky Thai food websites and ordering samples of freshly cooked insects to serve at their hip dinner parties.

This bizarre form of snacking - known in some circles as "critter cuisine" - apparently goes on at Revolution magazine, the glossy bible of the new media industry where, rumour has it, journalists work with open tins of freshly cooked insects sitting on their desks. Not content with revolutionising the way we work, it now appears that the architects of the new economy want to try to revolutionise what we eat.

Christopher Edwards, an advertising executive at Revolution, would like to see insects re-appraised as food items. He argues that they are high in protein and low in fat. But until attitudes to food fundamentally change he believes there will only be a niche market for edible bugs.

"I think the British are too squeamish," he explains. "It's just a case of educating people to try them. I scoffed a cricket. I saw this bug in my hand and thought 'Oh my God, I can't eat it!' It had all its legs and its antennae. They were all there. But I shoved it in and crunched it."

So how did it taste? "It was slightly crispy and soft on the inside. It was quite a bland taste," he says, adding that insect mini-buffets could go down well at parties. "I think you need to have dips with them - probably some garlic."

To reassure highly sceptical UK consumers, the Thai food website www.dcothai.com explains that all its bugs are carefully sterilised, preserved and spiced before being packed. But news of the campaign to market insect snacks to the UK has received a mixed response from leading Thai restaurant chefs in this country.

While some of them privately admit that insects are actually quite tasty when cooked with pepper and a bit of seasoning, many believe that insect-eating will never become socially acceptable over here. They argue that a cooked Thai bug is about as welcome to the British palate as a cooked French frog.

Vidhaya Intharayaem, manager and head chef of the Bangkok restau rant in South Kensington, says: "When I was a boy I would eat crickets. It was quite a common thing. But if you asked me to eat a cricket now I wouldn't because I have been living in this country for too long."

Despite claims that fried insects are nutritional, Angela Nilsen, food editor of the BBC's Good Food Magazine, says she will not be recommending bug snacks to her readers just yet. "I can't see them becoming everyday fare in Britain where we are still fairly conservative in our tastes." "We used to eat this kind of food hundreds of years ago. But we've become a lot more choosy."

She thinks the tastes of traditional UK snack eaters could change if they continue to travel and try out more unusual food. She has been to Thailand herself, so would she happily tuck into a plate of lightly fried locusts?

"I personally wouldn't eat insects as snacks. I live in the countryside and don't want to eat any of those things," she says with a noticeable shudder.

The UK is not the only country to be on the receiving end of campaigns to attempt to re-brand ugly-looking insects as trendy exotic nibbles. In the US there are several bug-eating societies that are campaigning on the net to try to make the eating of insects more socially acceptable. Once you have overcome your instinctive revulsion, insects are a pleasure to eat, they insist.

Some of the more popular websites among the bug-eating fraternity, such as Eatbug www.eatbug.com, carry favourite recipes which are designed to tempt the unconverted. There are even ones for chocolate-covered crickets (bake at 250 degrees, dip in melted chocolate and leave to dry until they are really crunchy). And mealworm chocolate chip cookies is another yummy treat.The mealworm is supposed to enrich the cookies with a sophisticated, lingering nutty flavour.

Needless to say, the major snack manufacturers are not quaking in their boots as adverts for cheap insect grub begin to hit the UK's computer screens. For a cooking nation which practically worships at the altar of traditionalists such as Delia Smith, there is little realistic chance that dry roasted insects will suddenly become a new national dish. If a waiter discovers a big fly in someone's soup then it is still likely to mean that a restaurant's reputation will be seriously on the line.

A spokeswoman for KP snacks explains that for any new snack to be commercially successful in the UK you have to be able to eat it on the move and it must be light and tasty. So how does she rate the commercial chances of a crispy water beetle or a fried cricket on a stick?

"They would absolutely have to have a taste test first. I could not comment before then," she explains.

As in most things at the moment, it looks like the boundary-breaking dot.comers are still very much out on their own. While they swarm to the web to order insects, for most of us the idea remains repellent.

Your quick guide to bug snacking

Bug snacks below are available at $3 per tin from the Thai food website: www.dcothai.com. Having your freshly prepared insects delivered by airmail will cost you about $4.50. But it is more expensive to have the canned bugs couriered directly to your office or kitchen.

Mixed fried insects

Designed for those who can't make up their minds which bug snack to choose first. Four varieties come in one tin. Includes crickets, locusts, water beetles and mole crickets. Cooked and ready to eat. Insect snack experts claim they are the perfect accompaniment to a cold beer.

Mole cricket

This is the ultimate ugly bug but don't let its looks put you off. The mole cricket is apparently a great Thai delicacy. Highly nutritional. It has been voted the number one bug snack by the Thai food website's managing director, who says it will help you to stand out at parties.

Water beetle

Crunchy snack. Packed with protein. Tastes a bit like cooked chicken on the inside.

Silkworm pupae

Packed with energy and calcium. Close your eyes and think of crispy bacon.

Red ant eggs

Should be served on toast. Touted as a possible alternative to marmalade.

fields.headline: No: 1745
fields.standfirst: George Clooney
fields.trailText: George Clooney
fields.body:
George who?
Oh come on. Repeat after me, Cl-oo-ney. He's the man your wife is lusting after as we speak.

But I haven't got a wife.
That's irrelevant.

So why should I know this prime piece of beefsteak?
ER.

Appropriately guttural.
No, ER, short for Emergency Room. Clooney played the hunky paediatrician, Dr Ross. Manly arms and good with children. Life didn't get much better.

So what went wrong?
Dr Ross moved to Seattle after a moral- dilemma episode, and Clooney resurfaced on the silver screen in such classics as One Fine Day, Out of Sight, and O Brother Where Art Thou? All was peachy until US Elle magazine recently published an article entitled "Don't Date George Clooney".

Was there a danger of that?
Not an immediate one, no.

So why the Parental Advisory sticker?
The article suggested that Clooney had a curious fetish for sniffing young ladies' armpits.

And where's the 'arm in that?
Oh, please. The Cloonster took umbrage because the article, which included a full-page cut-out-and-keep picture of George, wasn't about him at all.

It was about another George Clooney, who looked startlingly similar but boasted superior nostrils?
Close. No, the article, written by a Ms Deanna Kizis, referred only to an actor who appeared in The Thin Red Line - a film that starred Clooney. Kizis claimed that at the end of a date with 'The Actor', he "stuck his face in my armpit. He took a deep whiff and, coming up for air, said: 'You smell sooo good.' "

And he was a bit sniffy about it?
You could say that.

But if I did he might sue me?
He would, at the very least, write to you saying, 'You don't get to screw me... not without candy and flowers,' as he did to Elle's editor-in-chief, Roberta Myers.

Do say:
"Don't bait George Clooney."

Don't say:
"A dozen red roses and a box of Milk Tray to Mr Clooney's house. Pronto."

fields.trailText: A painting by LS Lowry of a Welsh colliery is expected to fetch more than £1m at a London auction next month.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A painting by LS Lowry of a Welsh colliery is expected to fetch more than £1m at a London auction next month.

The sale at Christie's will also feature the Ives collection, started when Lawrence Ives insisted on paying for a painting his neighbour, Lowry, was trying to give away.

The 17 works he eventually bought went on public display for the first time yesterday and are expected to fetch at least £200,000.

The most important painting in the sale, owned by a private collector, is Six Bells, Abertillery. It could match the £1,926,500 paid last year for Lowry's Going to the Match.

The Ives collection comprises less valuable pieces but was described yesterday by an expert as of exceptional interest.

Mr Ives, now in his 80s, was living in Cheshire when he first met Lowry in 1959. The painter tried to give his visitor an oil, called Group of People. Mr Ives insisted on paying for it, arguing the price up to 33 shillings. It is estimated the work will fetch £30,000.

webTitle: Firefighters sent to treat heart attack

fields.headline: Firefighters sent to treat heart attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A health trust admitted yesterday that resources were so tight that firefighters had been sent to deal with a heart attack patient because of an ambulance shortage.
fields.body:
A health trust admitted yesterday that resources were so tight that firefighters had been sent to deal with a heart attack patient because of an ambulance shortage.

The family of John McEwan of Hartlepool, Cleveland, complained that the 39-year-old had "died without dignity" because NHS paramedics had not been available to treat him in time.

Neighbours said they were astonished when a Cleveland county fire service engine arrived in response to 999 calls after Mr McEwan collapsed at his home in Ilkley Grove.

Norma Dunn, the dead man's former partner and mother of his two sons, said: "I am not having a go at the firemen, they did their best to save him, but it shows a real problem with ambulances in this town. It was hard to believe there wasn't an ambulance available."

The Tees, East and North Yorkshire ambulance service NHS trust confirmed the incident and expressed regret, but said falling back on the fire service had been the best option at the time. A spokesman said: "The call was graded as 'Condition: life threatening', but all our ambulances were already committed to other calls.

"The fire brigade are equipped and trained, in collaboration with us, to use heart defibrillators and to perform cardio-pulmonary resuscitation, and they arrived within eight minutes of the call. But in spite of their efforts, we regret that they were unable to revive the patient."

The nearest ambulance was traced to Stockton-on-Tees and took 29 minutes to arrive.

Figures just published show that in the first half of this year just over 50% of 999 calls for ambulances in Hartlepool arrived within eight minutes. Regulations to be introduced next year require a 75% response rate within that time.

webTitle: 600,000 of us will march on London, Countryside Alliance vows

fields.headline: 600,000 of us will march on London, Countryside Alliance vows
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: More than half a million Countryside Alliance protesters are preparing to take to the streets of London "in the biggest civil rights demonstration Europe has ever seen" - spurred on by the deputy prime minister's recent derision of their "contorted faces" - the campaign's chairman said yesterday.
fields.body:
More than half a million Countryside Alliance protesters are preparing to take to the streets of London "in the biggest civil rights demonstration Europe has ever seen" - spurred on by the deputy prime minister's recent derision of their "contorted faces" - the campaign's chairman said yesterday.

The pro-hunting pressure group has set a date for next March - likely to be only weeks before the general election - informed the relevant authorities, and put in place contingency plans for a protest that it believes could attract double the 300,000 who attended the previous countryside march on London's streets two years ago.

The group's chairman, John Jackson, said the government would only avoid this by bowing to their demand for a department for rural affairs and by indicating both a cut in fuel prices and no ban on fox hunting.

But he suggested campaigners had already been pushed too far by John Prescott's "unfortunate remark" at the Labour party conference in Brighton this month. "Every time I see the contorted faces of the Countryside Alliance, I redouble my determination to vote to abolish fox hunting for ever," he said.

Mr Jackson added: "We are already heading in the direction of the biggest civil rights demonstration Europe may ever have seen."

Addressing 600 supporters at the alliance's second annual conference in Kensington, west London, he said: "Unfortunately, and I was very sad to see it because I personally have much affection for him, the deputy prime minister has pushed us further down that road in front of the whole nation."

Mr Jackson's threat of a fur ther display of the "seething resentment and discontent" of rural protesters came as he revealed the alliance would be providing every rural parish in England with internet access to galvanise support and coordinate protest.

Within two years, all 17,000- odd parishes would have the hi-tech hardware, together with their own campaigning coordinator, while 3,000 parishes would be given the service within the next three months.

The alliance also unveiled an 80-point rural manifesto to challenge the government's delayed rural white paper, which was originally due to be published next month.

Responding to Mr Jackson's demands, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, attempted to smooth the anger generated by Mr Pres cott's comment, insisting that there was "little between" the government and the alliance on broad strategy.

While unable to promise more money for farmers, he admitted there was "an extremely serious crisis" in the industry.

He said a bill on fox hunting, on which MPs would have a free vote, would be introduced in the next session of parliament, but gave no commitment to the idea of a department for rural affairs, insisting instead it was a decision for the prime minister.

webTitle: Leader: The doctrine of containment of

fields.headline: Rogues? Not any more
fields.standfirst:
The doctrine of containment is dying
Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: Britain's decision to establish diplomatic ties with North Korea, while welcome in itself, is another body blow for the US policy of containment of so-called "rogue states". It stems from the sensible belief that dialogue with problematic regimes, where possible, is preferable to isolation, sanctions and military threats.
fields.body:
Britain's decision to establish diplomatic ties with North Korea, while welcome in itself, is another body blow for the US policy of containment of so-called "rogue states". It stems from the sensible belief that dialogue with problematic regimes, where possible, is preferable to isolation, sanctions and military threats. Foreign secretary Robin Cook has successfully used this approach, dubbed "critical engagement", to improve relations with Iran, Libya, Cuba and Sudan. Talking to, rather than shouting at, North Korea increases the chances of persuading it to curb human rights abuses and weapons proliferation. It opens up a seductive lifeline of additional EU humanitarian aid and technical assistance for a woefully misled people plagued by famine and underdevelopment. It is a timely boost for the Korean peninsula peace process, which has stumbled since last June's epic bilateral summit. And it will help buttress regional stability. As such, Britain's move was welcomed yesterday by Seoul.

Even the US is tacitly beginning to recognise that its containment policy, a cold war hangover, is simply not working. Washington no longer uses the term "rogue states" to describe its perceived enemies; they are now "countries of concern". In the past year, it has warily followed Britain in pursuing better relations with Iran and Libya. Last month, two years after being blasted by cruise missiles, Afghanistan's Taliban were invited for coffee at the state department. This week, congress finally (finally!) moved to ease sanctions on Fidel Castro's Cuba. And this Sunday, secretary of state Madeleine Albright will make her bow in Pyongyang, a possible prelude to a legacy tour by Bill Clinton himself. To appreciate what a volte-face this is, remember that only a few months ago the Pentagon was citing roguish North Korea as the main justification for deploying a new Star Wars missile defence system.

It is too much to hope that US diplomacy is at last turning pragmatical. Nor are these shifts necessarily permanent: both Al Gore and George W Bush still seem to think that superpower is invariably insuperable. But as they constantly tell voters, it's good to talk. And out there, in the world beyond the Potomac, the diplomatic apartheid known as containment is dead in the water. If more proof is required, just look at Iraq. For all America's great pains, Saddam is out of his box, big time; and short of massive, brute force, there is little the US can do.

webTitle: 'If you rub sand in your face it will probably have the same effect'

fields.headline: 'If you rub sand in your face it will probably have the same effect'
fields.standfirst: Anita Roddick's claim that most cosmetics are 'complete pap' horrified an industry built on the promise of eternal youth. But what about all that science on the labels? And those pretty people in white coats?  Deborah Bee  reports
fields.trailText: Anita Roddick's claim that most cosmetics are 'complete pap' horrified an industry built on the promise of eternal youth. But what about all that science on the labels? And those pretty people in white coats?  Deborah Bee  reports
fields.body:
Anita Roddick lambasting the cosmetics industry? Nothing new, surely. Barely newsworthy but for a sneaky inference that having all but cut the umbilical cord with the Body Shop, she is now setting about undermining it.

"It was one of those typical tabloid things," she shrugs. "A 20-minute chat at a book launch and suddenly, boom - there's this huge furore. I wasn't saying 'all cosmetics don't work'. Of course some do. I was saying 'anti-wrinkle creams don't work' - which, of course, they don't. But I've been saying that for years."

Old hat or not, Roddick's widely reported remarks will have jangled nerves in an industry that has turned the war against ageing into a multi-million pound cash cow over the past 20 years. Criticised periodically for preying on women's insecurities - the big-name companies, Estée Lauder, Revlon, Olay, have targeted the seven signs of ageing: fine lines and wrinkles; poor skin texture; poor skin tone; lack of radiance; enlarged pores; blotches and age spots; and dryness. They claim you can reverse the ageing process with specialised ingredients that come suspended in (invariably expensive) lotions and potions. Currently, the most effective of these are said to be vitamin A derivatives, vitamin C and AHAs (alpha-hydroxy acids), which are said to speed up the natural process of desquamation (the shedding of dead skin cells) - by loosening the cement that holds the cells together. This chemical form of exfoliation is said to then reveal younger (and therefore younger-looking) skin.

Roddick is not arguing about the specific ingredients of these creams nor, indeed, how they are tested. Instead, she is incensed by the "miracle-cure sales pitch" that accompanies products and which, she believes, exaggerates the benefits.

"Lines and wrinkles are produced by psychological reaction (laughing, crying); environmental stress (pollution, sun damage), and the passage of time. If you truly believe that a pot of cream can halt the physical signs of ageing then really, you deserve to be ripped off."

Trouble is, though, millions of us are seduced by the ads. It all started back in the early 80s with fabulous line-free women holding a tub up to their faces in a "loving" way. Then, the white coats took over the commercial breaks and beauty products were all shot in "labs" where everyone was dressed as a scientist despite the fact that they only looked 16 years old and were extraordinarily beautiful. ("Hey, know what? You could get out of this stuffy old research lark and earn a fortune as an actress/model?")

Cut to shower scene - you know how it went. The message was: "We are gorgeous, young and very bright and if that's not enough to convince you to buy this pot of gloop then here comes the science bit." But no one really believes that those girls really work in a lab, do they? And shouldn't that fact alone impact on the credibility of the product and therefore our desire to buy it?

Well, um, evidently not. Revlon's latest anti-ageing product is "age defying all day lifting foundation" which "lifts fine lines up, up and away" "an incredible 30% reduction in just 2 weeks!*" and contains "soy extracts and vitamins A, C, and E". The asterisk, it says in very small print, means "based on clinical testing". Similar claims are made on the labels of countless other products, but what does this really mean, if anything? Dr Nick Lowe, consultant dermatologist at the Cranley Clinic in central London is sceptical. "The problem with over-the-counter cosmetics is that they very often exaggerate their effectiveness and the claims are not supported by careful scientific scrutiny. Sometimes the research is not made available, sometimes I suspect that the research has never been done."

He is more optimistic about prescription strength formulas currently being developed in America. "There are some creams that make claims for age reversal which do work. These include some which contain retin A or retinova, a substance derived from vitamin A. In controlled studies in California, at prescription strength these creams are able to convincingly improve fine lines, skin quality, brown pigmentation and skin firmness. But they are only available on private prescription."

So does he think all over-the-counter products are ineffective?

"No, not all products are, but most. At a meeting of the European academy of dermatology last week a new ingredient, retinaldihide, which is another derivative of vitamin A mixed with vitamin C, was approved. Products by French companies such as La Roche Posay and Vichy are often recommended by dermatologists because they have conducted proper research. But most often you are paying £200-£300 for a pot of cream that has very low quantities of active ingredients. Sometimes it is bulked up with expensive extracts - such as caviar - but no one has tested caviar so no one knows if it's going to be beneficial in any way - unless, of course, you eat it."

The modern approach to selling pots of anti-ageing cream is more emotional than scientific. Olay's latest day-and-night cream, "total effects" employs first-person testimonies to sell it. "I cannot believe how minuscule the lines on my forehead and around my eyes look." "I look younger - several years younger. Never before has an over-the-counter topical cream made such a difference in my skin texture, tone, colour and appearance." "I can't believe the difference it has made on my laugh lines."

Doesn't it make your teeth itch? Eve Lom, whose facials and skincare products at Space NK have won her the loyalty of the celeb set, wouldn't give these women the time of day. "Women need wrinkles. And even if you could get rid of them, how do you hide the crippled posture, the sagging neck, the worn hands? Anti-ageing products are a waste of time. I just think, 'don't you have anything better to do - because I do'."

Dr Peter Coburn, a consultant dermatologist in West Sussex, believes that these sort of testimonials are based purely on a temporary improvement.

"Some products will smooth out the skin and temporarily make it look smoother but can't reverse the ageing process. Most of these anti-ageing creams contain an ingredient which produces an irritant reaction. This then causes local swelling which effectively irons out the wrinkles - for a short while."

Which sounds like a pretty clever idea, doesn't it?

"No, not really," says Coburn. "If you rubbed sand into your face it would probably have the same effect.

"Retinoids," he continues, "are extremely successful at treating skin disorders but they don't have any proven anti-ageing effects. The only way to get rid of wrinkles is through laser treatment, facial peeling or surgery - cut it out and stretch what's left."

All of which leaves you feeling confused, at least. Not only do we have to put up with society's obsession with youth and beauty. But from the TV, from the billboards, from the editorial pages of magazines, women are encouraged to buy products that promise more than they deliver. As Roddick puts it: "Anti-ageing cream is God's little way of punishing the stupid."

But you know the really awful thing? We'll carry right on buying them - whatever Roddick, or anyone else says. Because if there's a dream for sale, we'll buy it. Just in case.

And here's the science bit: what's really in the pot?
Tim Radford

All cosmetics contain some or all of the following:

Surfactants to make things foam, spread or disperse; emulsifiers to make things mix together; thickeners to make them seem comfortingly thickand rich; colouring to make them look nice; and aromatics to make them smell alluring. In addition, there could be:

Preservative

All skin creams contain preservatives. These are not to preserve your skin. They are to stop confections of natural products fermenting or turning to compost as soon as you unscrew the lid. "A pot of face cream is a haven for bacterial multiplication," says one expert.

Aqua

Better known in Britain as water. Most cosmetics are based on an emulsion of oil-in-water, except for those that count more as water-in-oil.It is also possible to have a water-in- oil-in-water emulsion.

Cetyl alcohol

A fatty alcohol, made by saponifying spermaceti, found in sperm whales, with caustic alkali. Tends to be a feature of perfumes, emulsifiers, face creams, lipsticks, lotions and so on. It retards evaporation.

Stearic acid

The most common chemical ingredient in animal and vegetable fats. It turns up in shoe polish, rubber softeners, suppositories, food packaging and your friendly pot of "natural" cosmetic cream.

Thickener

This could be sodium chloride, aka salt. Sometimes it is a polyacrylate, polyurethane or polyamide. Sometimes it is gum arabic, guar or xanthan. The point is to stop the cream being too runny.

Anti-oxidant

A good thing, given that free radicals, aka oxidants, go round causing havoc in your cells, eventually shutting them down. The question is: does rubbing them into your face actually get them to where they are needed?

Glycerol

An oily, colourless by-product of soap manufacture, and a step on the road to all sorts of valuable products,such as resins, inks,anti-freeze mixtures, lubricants, pharmaceuticals and yes, cosmetics.

Avocado oil

Recommended by the American Heart Association as one of the monounsaturated fats that really are good for you (if you eat the stuff, that is).

Lactic acid

Lactic acid is found in milk. Cleopatra bathed in asses' milk, according to legend. Did she know a thing or two about allure?

AHA

AHA stands for alpha-hydroxy acid (of which lactic acid is one). These interfere with intercellular ionic bonding in the skin, speeding up cell turnover and making skin lookmore youthful. But a European Commission scientific committee recently suggested they might actually accelerate skin damage.

Fagus sylvatica

Beech tree. Big thing, covered with wrinkly bark and shedding leaves every autumn. Its cosmetic anti-ageing properties are not immediately clear.

Aloe vera, jojoba oil, peppermint, juniper, seaweed, etc

There are now 500 botanical extracts in the International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient Listing. "Natural ingredients are perceived to be 'good'(and by inference synthetic ingredients must be bad)," says the Royal Society of Chemistry's website www.chemsoc.org. "But it does sometimes seem that an ingredient has been added to a product merely to make the label look prettier."

The only way to get rid of wrinkles is through laser treatment, facial peeling or surgery - cut it out and stretch what's left." All of which leaves you feeling confused, at least. Not only do we have to put up with society's obsession with youth and beauty. But from the TV, from the billboards, from the editorial pages of magazines, women are encouraged to buy products that promise more than they deliver. As Roddick puts it: "Anti-ageing cream is God's little way of punishing the stupid." But you know the really awful thing? We'll carry right on buying them - whatever Roddick, or anyone else says. Because if there's a dream for sale, we'll buy it. Just in case. And here's the science bit: what's really in the pot? Tim Radford All cosmetics contain some or all of the following: Surfactants to make things foam, spread or disperse; emulsifiers to make things mix together; thickeners to make them seem comfortingly thickand rich; colouring to make them look nice; and aromatics to make them smell alluring. In addition, there could be: Preservative All skin creams contain preservatives. These are not to preserve your skin. They are to stop confections of natural products fermenting or turning to compost as soon as you unscrew the lid. "A pot of face cream is a haven for bacterial multiplication," says one expert. Aqua Better known in Britain as water. Most cosmetics are based on an emulsion of oil-in-water, except for those that count more as water-in-oil.It is also possible to have a water-in- oil-in-water emulsion. Cetyl alcohol A fatty alcohol, made by saponifying spermaceti, found in sperm whales, with caustic alkali. Tends to be a feature of perfumes, emulsifiers, face creams, lipsticks, lotions and so on. It retards evaporation. Stearic acid The most common chemical ingredient in animal and vegetable fats. It turns up in shoe polish, rubber softeners, suppositories, food packaging and your friendly pot of "natural" cosmetic cream. Thickener This could be sodium chloride, aka salt. Sometimes it is a polyacrylate, polyurethane or polyamide. Sometimes it is gum arabic, guar or xanthan. The point is to stop the cream being too runny. Anti-oxidant A good thing, given that free radicals, aka oxidants, go round causing havoc in your cells, eventually shutting them down. The question is: does rubbing them into your face actually get them to where they are needed? Glycerol An oily, colourless by-product of soap manufacture, and a step on the road to all sorts of valuable products,such as resins, inks,anti-freeze mixtures, lubricants, pharmaceuticals and yes, cosmetics. Avocado oil Recommended by the American Heart Association as one of the monounsaturated fats that really are good for you (if you eat the stuff, that is). Lactic acid Lactic acid is found in milk. Cleopatra bathed in asses' milk, according to legend. Did she know a thing or two about allure? AHA AHA stands for alpha-hydroxy acid (of which lactic acid is one). These interfere with intercellular ionic bonding in the skin, speeding up cell turnover and making skin lookmore youthful. But a European Commission scientific committee recently suggested they might actually accelerate skin damage. Fagus sylvatica Beech tree. Big thing, covered with wrinkly bark and shedding leaves every autumn. Its cosmetic anti-ageing properties are not immediately clear. Aloe vera, jojoba oil, peppermint, juniper, seaweed, etc There are now 500 botanical extracts in the International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient Listing. "Natural ingredients are perceived to be 'good'(and by inference synthetic ingredients must be bad)," says the Royal Society of Chemistry's website www.chemsoc.org. "But it does sometimes seem that an ingredient has been added to a product merely to make the label look prettier."

webTitle: Three Britons killed in Australian bus crash

fields.headline: Three Britons killed in Australian bus crash
fields.trailText: Three British tourists were killed and four others seriously injured in Australia yesterday after their rented minibus was reported to have veered in front of a meat lorry.
fields.body:
Three British tourists were killed and four others seriously injured in Australia yesterday after their rented minibus was reported to have veered in front of a meat lorry.

A group of seven Britons and one Australian were travelling to a picnic in the holiday town of Rockingham - 30 miles south of Perth, in Western Australia - when their vehicle crashed into the lorry at a crossroads. The Australian man was also killed. The crash took place at 11am local time.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said the holidaymakers were in their 50s and 60s and from the West Midlands. Their names have not yet been released but they are believed to have been related. The Australian police have not yet been able to contact the victims' families in Britain.

Five ambulances and three fire crews were sent to the scene of the crash. One of the British men, who was sitting in the passenger seat, died instantly. Firefighters used metal-cutting equipment to free the remaining victims from the wreckage.

Rescue crews were said to be "astounded" that despite sending several ambulances, they did not have enough paramedics to deal with the injured holidaymakers.

Mark Sampede, one of the firefighters, told ITN news that the number of people in the bus made the rescue operation "extremely difficult".

The Australian and the other two Britons died in hospital. A spokesman at the Fremantle hospital in Perth said three of the injured tourists were "serious but stable" while the fourth was stable.

He said surgery would be "very likely" for all of the patients. The lorry driver was not hurt.

According to witnesses, the minibus swerved into the path of the lorry and the wreckage was then dragged 50 yards along the busy intersection before the truck stopped.

Long black skid marks could be seen on the road leading to the crash scene.

Jasmine Jones, a reporter for Channel Nine News in Australia, said: "There wasn't much left of the minibus. When I got to the scene and had to describe the vehicle I was at a loss.

"It was very difficult to see how anyone could have walked away from that accident without injuries."

Jones said Rockingham was a popular destination among British tourists. "It's got peaceful, clean beaches. It's a wonderful spot," she said.

Sergeant John Curran of the police operation centre in Perth said the cause of the crash was still being investigated.

"It was a collision on a corner, so obviously someone did the wrong thing on a junction between a main road and a side road," he said.

The accident comes 17 months after four young men from Sussex were killed while on holiday in Queensland. They died instantly when a lorry smashed into their car while they waited at traffic lights.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: America needs to wake up

fields.headline: It's time America woke up to the rest of the planet
fields.standfirst:
US foreign policy is mainly an exercise in adhering to the past

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: US foreign policy is mainly an exercise in adhering to the past.
fields.body:
When the young Walter Lippmann, later to become the foremost advocate of American engagement in the world, travelled to Europe in June 1914, he had not even the faintest notion that a terrible war was imminent. "It was possible," he wrote, "for an American in those days to be totally unconscious of the world he lived in." He dallied in the Lake District for a while, then crossed to Belgium, planning to go on through Germany to Switzerland for a walking holiday. He remembered "being rather annoyed when I went into the railway station and found that the German border was closed because Belgium had had an ultimatum."

Lippmann recorded this anecdote in a book he wrote in 1943 arguing that the United States could no longer operate as if it was a country separate and aloof from all others, that it had a stake in world order, and that it had to respect what order existed. The tenaciousness of the American sense of separateness can be seen in the fact that the issues which Lippmann raised are, in not too different form, the same ones which face Americans today. The blissful ignorance of the world which he sketched is gone. If there is ignorance now it is wilful rather than blissful. But America still acts internationally according to its own rules and accepts only partially and reluctantly rules made by others. This tendency, now more often and more accurately called unilateralism rather than isolation ism, was in abeyance during the years when the US marshalled a network of alliances against the communist states. Even then, some argue, the appearance of collective decision making was usually misleading. In any case, once the Russian and Chinese enemies had disappeared, the US rapidly regressed, spurning treaties over which other nations had long laboured, misbehaving in international organisations, and acting with others usually only in ad hoc alliances of which it was the main organiser. And all this was under a president, Bill Clinton, who began in office committed to the UN, to international law, and to multilateralism in all spheres.

The difference between Americans and others can be illustrated by the case of the Statute of Rome, which sets up an international criminal court. The Americans, it is well known, did not like the idea that their servicemen might face charges in such a court, but their deeper objection was constitutional. The US constitution would not permit the actions which an American government might have to take under the statute. France and Germany had similar constitutional difficulties. Both chose to change their constitutions. But, in the words of one American opponent of the statute, writing in an illuminating recent publication from the Royal Institute of International Affairs, "The US ... is not going to amend its constitution to accommodate the latest international fad ... the US shall stand by its old ways which have served it well for over 200 years." There is surely no clearer case of ancestor worship in the western world than this.

A partial accounting of American delinquency during the Clinton years includes the failure to pay its full UN dues, the refusal, since Somalia, to place American troops under direct UN command, the refusal to sign the landmines treaty, the refusal to sign the Statute of Rome, the refusal to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, and the pursuit of a national missile defence scheme which, if realised, would almost certainly undermine most of the existing arms limitation agreements with Russia. While refusing to be bound by rules agreed on by large groups of nations, the US has meanwhile come up with sanctions against some 60 countries which have offended it in one way or another. The Congress, it appears, believes it has a right to legislate for the world, but the world has no right to legislate for the US.

It cannot be simply said that in choosing between Gore and Bush, the American people are choosing between an internationalist and a unilateralist road. Clinton has already been forced into serious compromises, with which Gore is associated and, if he is elected, he too would have to contend with a legislature in which unilateralism is entrenched. Bush is not absolutely shackled to the unilateralist idea and, in office, realism would no doubt often prevail. The difference is rather that Gore would fight the unilateralist tendency, while Bush would be inclined to go along with it.

The second debate between the candidates, on foreign policy, showed both men tiptoeing around the charged question of "humanitarian" military intervention. In a strange way this has become for many Americans the most important international issue. In spite of the fact that the US has committed its forces to such interventions very much on its own terms and conditions, the notion persists there, or at least is assiduously cultivated for political reasons, that America has been forced into these onerous tasks by an international community which is at the same time demanding and ungrateful. The concentration on the military question also obscures the fact that what the world needs from the US is not a constant readiness to come up with troops, but constant and responsible attention, while resisting the temptation to act in a solitary and capricious manner.

It has been disturbing in recent weeks to watch this American argument over foreign policy unfold without much awareness that a huge crisis may be just around the corner. The American effort to manage the Middle East, an effort which goes back at least 40 years and which Clinton had tried to round off with a settlement between Israelis and Palestinians, could be in terminal trouble. Yet many Americans see this only as a tragedy or a problem for the people who live there, rather than as a failure for which America may well be largely responsible and one which could affect all of us for the worse. In other regions where the US has made similar efforts to manage and control events, notably East and South-east Asia, serious trouble could also be brewing. There is hardly a region or a country where American policy could be deemed a clear success. These policies, whatever their individual worth, belong in the broad unilateralist tradition, serving American interests in ways which often ignore the real needs and the real sentiments of the countries concerned. That they may therefore not truly serve American interests either is an idea whose time ought to have come. Acts have consequences, as DW Brogan, in his introduction to Lippmann's book, implied when he called for an end to "the illusion that the United States has complete freedom of choice, that the American people can order as much peace, security and prosperity as they want, on their own terms, in their own time."

 Understanding Unilateralism in American Foreign Relations (ed Gwyn Prins), Royal Institute for International Affairs
