webTitle: America votes to switch off during election

fields.headline: America votes to switch off during election
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Tuesday's televised debate between Al Gore and George W Bush may have made the best viewing of this year's three contests, but it was watched by only 38m people, less than a fifth of the electorate and the third lowest audience in presidential debate history.
fields.body:
Tuesday's televised debate between Al Gore and George W Bush may have made the best viewing of this year's three contests, but it was watched by only 38m people, less than a fifth of the electorate and the third lowest audience in presidential debate history.

This year's two main presidential candidates may not inspire the electorate but Bill Clinton and Bob Dole did even worse in 1996, attracting only 36m viewers to their second bout, the all-time low.

The television networks did their bit too. Rupert Murdoch's Fox channel preferred to show a science fiction thriller. NBC allowed affiliates to choose between the debate and a New York Yankees-Seattle Mariners baseball game. No prizes for guessing which the New York stations chose to show.

Low interest in the debates is just one sign of a broader pattern of American political apathy. Twenty years ago, a record 81m watched the Jimmy Carter-Ronald Reagan debates. Four years ago, for the first time ever, a majority of enfranchised Americans did not vote. This pattern could repeat on November 7.

The no-show voters of 1996 offered a variety of explanations: more than one in five was either too busy or could not spare the time from work; 16% were not interested; nearly 15% were ill or dealing with an emergency; 13% said dislike for the candidates kept them away; 11% were out of town; another 4% forgot; the same number said they had no transport; and one in 100 said that the queues were too long.

The lowest proportion since before the second world war, 49.08%, actually showed up in 1996, according to the federal election commission, ranking the US at 139th for voter participation among the world's 167 democracies.

Joe Klein, who wrote Primary Colors as a work of faction about the first Clinton presidential campaign, says: "The reason people don't vote is because so many of them are happy. Affluence is probably the most powerful narcotic ever invented. This has become a great social experiment in how long and in what ways you can tolerate maintaining affluence."

Turnout has been subsiding over the past 40 years and some imagine that the only hope for greater participation is the closeness of the race.

This should be a more exciting race for the media than in 1996, when Mr Clinton was ahead of Bob Dole all year. Yet television network news coverage was down last month on figures from September 1996.

"People have a lot of trouble engaging. They need a bit of a fight or a struggle," says Professor Tom Patterson, director of the Vanishing Voter project at the Joan Shorenstein Centre on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University.

The project measures the level of interest in the campaign on a weekly basis by polling about 1,000 people. Interest stands at 44% now, the highest since candidates were chosen at the primaries.

"The parties do look at these things and they can see themselves slipping away as major television events," Prof Patterson adds. "They don't like that. We have lots of people who graduate from high school who have never watched a newscast from beginning to end."

Indeed, a recent survey of 16-21-year-olds found that one in three could not name the presidential candidates and 75% did not know the names of their running mates.

Prof Patterson identifies three main reasons for the diminishing appeal of the political process: the unwieldy structure for electing a president; the strong economy; and the proliferation of cable television channels which has cut the potential audience for political programming.

An election that takes nearly a year might satisfy the political junkies who claim that this allows for a thorough examination of the issues but it fails to enthrall the public.

"If people argue that one reason we have a long campaign is that you can chew over the issues for a long time - well, they're not doing any chewing," Prof Patterson says. "Our feeling is that this whole thing could start in June and work out just as well."

Bill Bradley, the defeated candidate for the Democrat presidential nomination, is one of the few prominent figures willing to state his opinion on the issue. "Democracy in the US is like a broken thermostat - you turn the dial but nothing works," he says. "If the economy's going good people say it doesn't matter who's the president. But if the economy's going bad they will look to the president."

Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, cites further reasons for the decline.

"It is easy to see that there is no quick fix to what ails the political system," he says. "The progressive disengagement of an ever-greater number of citizens and the lack of engagement in an ever-growing percentage of the young are rooted in changes of the last decade that have affected the attitudes of Americans whether they vote or not."

He claims that the erosion of trust caused by Watergate, Iran-contra and the Lewinsky affair, combined with the destruction of traditional communities, worsening educational standards, the importance of money in politics and the communications revolution have led to a less cohesive, less politically active society.

But, whatever the truth may be, research suggests that the outcome of recent elections would not have been any different even if the missing 100m had voted.

fields.headline: Former Rwandan PM loses appeal
fields.trailText: The former Rwandan prime minister, Jean Kambanda, lost his appeal against his life sentence for genocide yesterday. The five judges of the appeals court of the UN's Rwanda tribunal at the Hague told him his appeal had been unanimously quashed and he would begin his sentence immediately.
fields.body:
The former Rwandan prime minister, Jean Kambanda, lost his appeal against his life sentence for genocide yesterday. The five judges of the appeals court of the UN's Rwanda tribunal at the Hague told him his appeal had been unanimously quashed and he would begin his sentence immediately.

At least 800,000 Tutsis died in the three-month Rwandan genocide in 1994, in part directed by Mr Kambanda's government. His crimes included the planning of genocide at cabinet meetings, travelling around the country urging others to kill Tutsis and allowing children to be massacred. He will serve his sentence in an African prison.

Mr Kambanda, 45, dressed in a charcoal grey suit and silver tie, did not react as the bench reiterated his life sentence. A spokesman for the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda called the sentence a "message for powerful people all around the world that there will be accountability in the 21st century."

The Rwanda tribunal has had more success in bringing the big names to court than the International Criminal Court for the Former Yugoslavia. The Rwanda court has convicted or has in custody the former prime minster and 10 members of the cabinet who presided over the genocide. The Yugoslav tribunal has none of the major figures who have been indicted.

Mr Kambanda had challenged his 1998 sentence on grounds varying from not being allowed to choose his own lawyer to the allegedly oppressive conditions under which he was held while awaiting trial.

The judges ruled against him on the grounds that Mr Kambanda had not complained about either issue during the trial.

His crimes included the planning of genocide at cabinet meetings, travelling around the country urging others to kill Tutsis and allowing children to be massacred. A spokesman for the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda called the sentence a "message for powerful people all around the world that there will be accountability in the 21st century." The Rwanda tribunal has had more success in bringing the big names to court than the International Criminal Court for the Former Yugoslavia. The Rwanda court has convicted or has in custody the former prime minster and 10 members of the cabinet who presided over the genocide. The Yugoslav tribunal has none of the major figures who have been indicted. Mr Kambanda had challenged his 1998 sentence on grounds varying from not being allowed to choose his own lawyer to the allegedly oppressive conditions under which he was held while awaiting trial. The judges ruled against him on the grounds that Mr Kambanda had not complained about either issue during the trial.

fields.headline: Ivan Owen
fields.trailText: Ivan Owen, who has died aged 73, was the actor who voiced the contradiction in the British character between love of stuffiness and love of anarchy. He brought to life Basil Brush, the truculent and bouncy children's television and stage fox puppet, for which he donated his best county voice. Part of Basil's magnetism came from the misalliance between his voice - said to have been modelled on the gentlemanly caddish actor Terry Thomas - and his outrageous behaviour.
fields.body:
Ivan Owen, who has died aged 73, was the actor who voiced the contradiction in the British character between love of stuffiness and love of anarchy. He brought to life Basil Brush, the truculent and bouncy children's television and stage fox puppet, for which he donated his best county voice. Part of Basil's magnetism came from the misalliance between his voice - said to have been modelled on the gentlemanly caddish actor Terry Thomas - and his outrageous behaviour.

Though Basil, with his "Boom! Boom!" warcry, would never have taken a back seat, Owen always seemed anxious to do so. Describing himself as a "failed actor", he ran a Rolls-Royce and lived a civilised life in a large Devon house, but made it an iron rule never to be photographed or give interviews.

He got his chance to become a national non-figure in 1966, when Basil appeared on David Nixon's BBC-TV conjuring show, The Nixon Line. The tall, bald conjuror was often upstaged by the restless, relentless puppet, who was sometimes described as the best thing on the show.

In 1968, Basil and Ivan got their own BBC Saturday early-evening show. Basil's straight men were the long-suffering butts of dreadful jokes and puns: Likely Lads actor Rodney Bewes was followed by "Mr Derek" (Derek Fowlds), Roy North, Howard Williams and Billy Boyle.

The fox made Owen a millionaire and created a Basil Brush industry. This included stage tours which drew the crowds - they broke box-office records at Croydon and filled the Blackpool Opera House - and the sponsorship of more than 70 products. The television programmes sold to 15 countries, and were a particular hit in New Zealand, where the stage show also went. A dispute about time-slots caused the show to be axed in 1980: Owen had aspirations for a later evening appearance to extend Basil's range. In 1982, however, the puppet reappeared on ITV, in Let's Read With Basil Brush, and then co-hosted the BBC's Crackerjack children's programme. Guest appearances ranged from the Val Doonican Show to Fantasy Football League.

Ivan Owen was born in south London, and went to schools in Dulwich and Dartford, before joining the aircraft manufacturer Handley Page as an apprentice joiner. National service in the RAF from 1946 introduced him to the comedian Terry Scott and the idea of acting for a living, so, in 1948, he went to the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. He was flung out because he chose to watch the trooping of the colour when he should have been at work, and had to make his way in repertory theatre, including Watford at £4 a week, and as an assistant floor manager for the BBC.

In 1956, Owen started doing voices for the puppet theatre run by John Wright in Camden Town, and met Peter Firmin, who was developing ideas for television, and who made the Basil puppet, 15 inches tall, at a cost of £20. Basil's debut came in the 1963 television show, The Three Scampies. Owen then supplied the voice of the dog Fred Barker, on ITV's Music Box, but it was the wily fox that the BBC picked up on.

According to his old friend Edward Barnes, a former head of BBC children's programmes, Owen was a cheerful, ebullient and amusing man. Nonetheless, he maintained his invisibility to the end: "I suppose it's rather akin to MI5, keeping my identity secret."

Plans are afoot to screen a sitcom Basil Brush next year, involving an American couple living in London with Basil as a neighbour, though Owen knew it would have to be with a new voice. He leaves his wife Jennifer, sons Michael and Jonathan, and daughter Christine.

 Ivan Owen, children's entertainer, born August 19 1927; died October 17 2000

fields.headline: Charles Perkins
fields.standfirst: Lifelong campaigner for the rights of Australia's forgotten minority, the Aborigines
fields.trailText: Charlie Perkins was, in many ways, Australia's Mandela. Indeed, had the Australian racial composition been reversed, as in South Africa, he would surely have fulfilled that role. Instead, he struggled, right up to his death at the age of 64, for justice and dignity for his people, the Aborigines, and to alert the white majority to the truth that unless they gave back nationhood to the first Australians, they could never claim their own.
fields.body:
Charlie Perkins was, in many ways, Australia's Mandela. Indeed, had the Australian racial composition been reversed, as in South Africa, he would surely have fulfilled that role. Instead, he struggled, right up to his death at the age of 64, for justice and dignity for his people, the Aborigines, and to alert the white majority to the truth that unless they gave back nationhood to the first Australians, they could never claim their own.

Charlie became my friend on a blistering hot day in 1969, when he took me home to Alice Springs. Having grown up in Sydney, I was introduced to an Australia I barely knew existed. We picked up Hetti, his mother, who was waiting at the roadside, beneath a magnificent black hat. A queen of the Arrente people, she had given birth to Charlie on a tabletop in the disused Alice Springs telegraph office in 1936 or 1937; she was never sure which.

We drove out into the red desert, heading for the federal government reserve at Jay Creek, where 300 aboriginal people were corralled in administered squalor, often without water - in 40-degree temperatures - and proper food or housing. The children had distended bellies and trachoma, which leads to blindness. This was the Australian gulag.

The barbed wire gate was locked, and declared: "No entry, by ministerial order". "What d'you, reckon, mum?" said Charlie. "Do it," said Hetti, from the back seat. I reversed the car, revved it and smashed through the gate.

"G'day," said Charlie to the white manager, whose ablutions we had interrupted. "Where's your bloody permit?" "Lost it, mate," said Charlie. "Now, how come these children look so bloody sick...?"

It was Charlie who did much to change the conditions at Jay Creek, and begin to right Australia's great wrong by bringing the most basic human rights to aboriginal people. On behalf of the most discarded minority of any white colonial country, his trailblazing role was momentous, as was his courage.

Growing up as a mixed-race Aborigine, he was "protected" so that he might be "assimilated" - the bureaucratic language that masked the suffering of the "stolen generation", now recognised as a form of genocide, in which children were taken from their mothers and sent to institutions and as bonded labour. He remembered his grandmother as only a face behind barbed wire. One of his brothers killed himself, which was common among young Aborigines - and still is. Charlie himself was never stolen, because Hetti never took her eyes off him.

"You learned from when you were a kid to stay out of the way of whites," he told me. "Our big treat was being taken to the pictures, sneaking in after the movie had started, and leaving before it ended, so that no one would object to us black kids being there. I grew up never knowing if the goodies or baddies won. Very frustrating."

Charlie was sent to mission school in Adelaide, where he discovered soccer, and, at 16, was spotted by the English first-division club, Everton, which offered to pay his fare to England in the late 1950s. Later, he was invited by Matt Busby for a trial with Manchester United - and holds the distinction of turning the great man down. "You know, I found a kind of racial dignity in England," he told me. "But I was homesick."

Arriving back in Adelaide in 1959, he became only the second Aborigine to graduate from an Australian university. In the mid-1960s, he led white students on freedom rides into the outback of New South Wales, with much the same objective as the freedom riders who began desegregation in the American south. Charlie and his white comrades stood at the turnstile of public swimming pools, and demanded that black children be allowed entry.

In the town of Moree, they were spat at and assaulted, and menaced by a crowd. "I thought we'd had it," he said. "Then this black woman stepped forward and made a courageous speech, in which she pointed to a white man who had gone secretly with black women and fathered black children. 'Tell your wives what you've been doing, you bludgers,' she said. 'Go on, they're just over there. Tell 'em!' That evening, black kids were allowed into the pool for the first time. We had won the first battle."

Charlie went on to win - and lose - many battles. He was manager of the Foundation for Aboriginal Affairs, which helped run the campaign that produced a resounding "yes" in a 1967 referendum, giving the federal government power to legislate justice for Aboriginals - a power so often neglected and misused.

He served in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Canberra, rising to permanent secretary, but co-option never really worked for him. He invariably spoke his mind, calling racist politcians racist; in a society renowned for its outspokeness, but in reality often embarrassed by it, he gathered enemies.

Whenever he came to London, he would call me and say, "Get the media out, mate. There's a demo outside Australia House that will tell the Poms about an Australia that's just like South Africa." Knowing his reply, I would ask how many were going: "Just me". Even when Sydney University gave him an honorary doctorate recently, he used the occasion to attack John Howard's government for effectively taking away the common law rights that the high court had said belonged to Aborigines - an action the United Nations has condemned as racist. He would have exploded had he heard Howard this week paying tribute to him through clenched teeth.

Like so many Aborigines, Charlie was burdened by ill-health, although he regarded the gift of a kidney, 28 years ago, as a miracle. Most Aborigines can expect to die in their 40s and 50s. "I beat that," he said, when I last saw him. He drew lifelong strength from his remarkable wife Eileen, his children Hettie, Rachel and Adam, and his grandchildren.

I spoke to him in hospital the day after the Sydney Olympics ended, and he was cursing, typically, the muting of a "shaming campaign" in which he had hoped to participate. More than most I can think of, Charlie Perkins was a true Australian hero.

 Charles Nelson Perkins, aboriginal rights campaigner, born 1936; died October 18 2000

fields.headline: Nigeria's ethnic hatreds turn lethal
fields.standfirst: Group outlawed as north-south divide widens
fields.trailText: The Nigerian government has banned a radical Yoruba organisation which is responsible for the murders of hundreds in Lagos in days of fighting between the country's two largest ethnic groups.
fields.body:
The Nigerian government has banned a radical Yoruba organisation which is responsible for the murders of hundreds in Lagos in days of fighting between the country's two largest ethnic groups.

President Olusegun Obasanjo proscribed the widely supported Odua People's Congress (OPC) and ordered the arrest of its leadership and members amid another surge in the ethnic violence that many Nigerians fear is a further step toward the Balkanisation of their country.

Nigeria's senate empowered Mr Obasanjo to declare a state of emergency in Lagos, in the south-west of Nigeria.

Thousands of Hausa families originally from northern Nigeria have sought protection in military barracks as soldiers have been deployed in the centre and suburbs of Lagos to stop the killings by Yoruba militants. Bodies were still lying in the street yesterday amid torched cars and buses and razed buildings.

"Such brutal and irresponsible acts cannot and must not be tolerated in a civilized society," Mr Obasanjo said.

"Therefore, law enforcement agencies are hereby ordered to arrest and prosecute any person who claims or presents himself as a member of the OPC and similar organisations, all of which are hereby declared illegal, unacceptable and a serious threat to the peace and security of Nigeria."

The police say they have picked up more than 200 people, including two OPC leaders. "We are going for the OPC leaders one by one. We have a list of its leaders," the Lagos police chief, Mike Okiro, said.

The Red Cross said at least 100 people have been killed - although this figure is probably an underestimate - and 20,000 have been forced from their homes by the violence which began on Sunday as Yoruba militants pursued alleged thieves into a mainly Hausa area of Lagos. The attacks spread to many other parts of the city, including parts of the business district.

Until now, Mr Obasanjo has trodden carefully around the OPC but the latest bloodletting is expected to lead to retaliatory attacks against Yorubas living in northern cities.

It has also raised the spectre of the first attempt at secession by a Nigerian region since Biafra's failed bid for in dependence three decades ago in which more than a million died.

The OPC was founded six years ago to promote the interests of 20m Yorubas living in Nigeria's south-west, where there is widespread resentment at years of military rule under the northern-dominated army.

Popular support for the organisation surged after it emerged from the underground with the return of civilian government last year - just as northern states rushed to introduce hardline Islamic law, including amputations for theft and lashes for adultery.

The imposition of Sharia law is widely viewed as a form of ethnic persecution by the mostly Christian southerners living in northern Nigeria. It has increased public backing in Lagos for the OPC's demand for political autonomy or even outright independence for south-western Nigeria.

The ban on the OPC came after the leader of its moderate wing, Dr Frederick Fasehun, refused to sign a joint communique with Hausa leaders calling for an end to the violence. It is not clear if he is among those arrested.

The police have spent nearly a year hunting the leader of the organisation's more radical faction, a cabinet maker called Gani Adams, who has become a folk hero in Lagos.

He has eluded capture despite a price put on his head by the authorities and radical northern organisations for leading the ethnic killings of thousands of Hausas and eastern Igbos in Lagos. The murders provoked retaliatory massacres in other parts of Nigeria.

Underpinning the rise in Yoruba nationalism are fears that growing disillusionment with Mr Obasanjo's government could lead to a return of military rule. His failure to revive Nigeria's economy and his bitter battles with the country's corruption-plagued parliament have been compounded by accusations of ethnic favouritism on all sides.

Mr Obasanjo, a Yoruba, has lost support in south where he is charged with being soft on the militant Muslims behind the constitutionally questionable enforcement of Sharia law. In the north, he is accused of ignoring OPC excesses.

The information minister, Jerry Gana, rejected the latter charge by reminding Nigerians of the near-total destruction of the south-eastern town of Odi by the army when it was ordered to quell unrest there.

fields.headline: 'Designer baby' cures sister
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A groundbreaking and controversial experiment to create a genetically "custom-made" boy so that he could act as a donor for his seriously ill sister, has been declared a success by US doctors.
fields.body:
A groundbreaking and controversial experiment to create a genetically "custom-made" boy so that he could act as a donor for his seriously ill sister, has been declared a success by US doctors.

Cells taken from Adam Nash's umbilical cord after his birth on August 29 were infused into his six-year-old sister, Molly, and have begun to revive her bone marrow, which was being destroyed by a rare genetic disorder, Fanconi anaemia.

Adam was created from an embryo chosen from twelve created by in vitro fertilisation from his mother Lisa's eggs.

The embryo was selected after genetic screening for Fanconi anaemia and for compat ibility with Molly. One embryo which tested positive for Fanconi anaemia was destroyed and the rest were frozen.

The experiment drew criticism on ethical grounds from some groups who argued it represented the first step towards "designing" babies.

Mrs Nash argued that Molly's recovery was reason enough to pursue further research. "The other night, she and I were playing in her room and a song came on and she got on the floor and started dancing," she said. "And that was when we knew that this was the right thing to do."

Dr John Wagner, at the University of Minnesota, where the transplant took place, said that the infused cells were taking over the function of Molly's bone marrow, making platelets and white blood cells.

"The bone marrow graft is recovering extremely well," he said. "So we have a success."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Soldier denies murder

A soldier on home leave from Bosnia slashed a stranger's throat then killed the injured man's cousin by plunging the knife into his chest after a petty argument in a Sunderland burger bar, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday. David Tillen, 26, denies murder and wounding with intent. The case continues.

Rights warning to Straw

A senior law lord yesterday echoed a warning to Jack Straw from the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, that the courts could force him to free the Moors murderer Myra Hindley against his will, under European human rights legislation.

Jail sex change condemned

A decision to allow a convicted armed robber a £20,000 sex change and a move to a women's jail was yesterday greeted with outrage by the Victims of Crime Trust. It said the country should "hang its head in shame" after it emerged that David Cross, 39, had had NHS treatment.

Actor Archer 'guilty' at last

webTitle: Russian crusaders take to the railways

fields.headline: Russian crusaders take to the railways
fields.standfirst:
Orthodox church battles influx of western missionaries by launching prayer train to take its faith to remote areas
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: An extravagantly gilded church on wheels drew out from one of Moscow's central railway stations late last night, embarking on the first stage of an unusual evangelical crusade to some of Russia's most impoverished regions.
fields.body:
An extravagantly gilded church on wheels drew out from one of Moscow's central railway stations late last night, embarking on the first stage of an unusual evangelical crusade to some of Russia's most impoverished regions.

This mobile church is the latest weapon in an ongoing battle being waged by the Russian Orthodox church to win back believers in remote areas - many of them already being wooed by zealous missionaries from abroad.

The night train arriving in Archangel this morning will be carrying two newly-built church carriages, staffed by six priests and a team of 12 singing trainee clerics.

Moscow railway workers have spent the past six months ripping the plastic brown bunks and floors from redundant train compartments, replacing them with every thing needed to create a Russian Orthodox church: a golden pulpit and altar, a collection of richly-painted icons and bells hanging from the ceiling.

A specialist carriage refitting factory - famous during Soviet times for the luxurious train compartments it built for travelling Politburo members - was contracted to fit out the interior.

Stained glass windows have been fitted in place of the grime-encrusted originals. The gloomy brown and green of the state railway fleet have been stripped away and replaced with gold leaf. The second compartment has been converted into a travelling monastery for up to 20 priests, complete with a small library.

Beggars and drunks were removed from the freshly-scoured platforms at Moscow's Kievsky station for the consecration ceremony on Wednesday - when Patriarch Alexei II sprinkled holy water on to the train. He was joined by the railways minister, Nikolai Aksenenko (a former prime minister and one-time associate of the entrepreneur Boris Berezovsky) whose department paid an undisclosed sum for the project.

"This is the most expensive carriage in all Russia," the deputy head of the train factory revealed. "The gold leaf alone cost 2m roubles [£50,000]."

Over the next few weeks the carriages will travel by night to isolated parts of the frozen northern Archangel region, stopping at distant villages which have tiny railway stations but no church.

During the day the priests will carry out an intensive programme of weddings, funerals and christenings and conduct prayer services for the locals. The trainee clerics will sing from the in-built choir section of the church carriage.

Father Sergei Popov, the train's senior priest, said they would be travelling primarily to regions where there were high levels of unemployment, poverty and alcoholism.

"Most of the village churches were destroyed after the revolution. People like these are in 17desperate need of spiritual support," he said.

He said his mission was also to ensure that this spiritual support was not provided by representatives from the Jehovah's Witnesses movement, the Mormons or any of the international sects which have been recruiting huge numbers of followers in Russia since religious freedom returned.

"We want to bring these lost and neglected people back to the Russian Orthodox faith," Father Popov said.

This is Russia's second church on wheels. Tsar Nicholas II ordered the first to be built in 1896 to take the state religion to the heathen heartland of Siberia.

webTitle: Roof caves in on Pakistani heritage

fields.headline: Roof caves in on Pakistani heritage
fields.standfirst:
Unesco dismay at badminton courts and soccer stadium built on world heritage sites
Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: It should be the finest vantage point from which to view the city of Lahore, looking out from the opulence of the Shish Mahal, the most decorated hall in the Lahore Fort, as hundreds of muezzins call lunchtime prayers.
fields.body:
It should be the finest vantage point from which to view the city of Lahore, looking out from the opulence of the Shish Mahal, the most decorated hall in the Lahore Fort, as hundreds of muezzins call lunchtime prayers.

But the Shish Mahal - the Palace of Mirrors - is ignored and decaying. The beautiful 369-year-old ceiling of blue, red and gold tiles, glass mirrors and stucco tracery is damp and sagging, propped up by rudimentary scaffolding, planks of wood and patches of foam.

Pakistan has some of the richest historical sites on the subcontinent but most are in a dismal state after years of stifling bureaucracy, mismanagement and wasted donations.

"I am sure one day the roof of the Shish Mahal will fall down," said Shaukat Mahmood, an architectural acade mic who has been campaigning to improve Pakistan's heritage for 20 years. "Money is being squandered by unqualified people. They just don't know what they are doing. It's a tragedy."

In one case alone, at the Moenjodaro ruins in Sind, more than£16m has been raised by Unesco (United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation) through international donations over the past 20 years.

But although money has been spent on lavish scientific laboratories at the site, water still seeps into the foundations of the 4,000-year-old city and salt deposits are weakening the structures.

Six of the most important sites in Pakistan are listed by Unesco, requiring Islamabad to protect and preserve the monuments in return for financial help.

At their annual meeting later this year exasperated Unesco officials are likely to embarrass Pakistan's military regime by placing two of the worst affected sites on a blacklist of endangered world heritage treasures. If restoration work does not improve, the monuments will then be dropped altogether as listed sites.

"The government recognises cultural heritage is important ... There is rhetoric, yes, but in terms of action not very much," said Prem Kasaju, director of Unesco's Islamabad office.

The two sites at risk speak volumes for the government's neglect of centuries of heritage. At the Shalamar Gardens in Lahore, a unique set of water towers, more than 360 years old, has been partly demolished to widen a six-lane highway.

The gardens, constructed by the extravagant Emperor Shah Jahan, who also built the Taj Mahal, are now less a monument than a public playground. Permanent badminton courts have been built in the grounds.

In Taxila, near Islamabad, local bureaucrats built a football stadium on the ruins at the Bhir Mound, a centre of learning in the 6th century BC Gandhara civilisation and perhaps the most important archaeological site on the subcontinent.

Unesco managed to halt the work earlier this year but the stadium gate, walls and pavilion remain, surrounding excavated ruins. The rest of Taxila appears largely unmanaged.

Unesco is also deeply concerned about the Shish Mahal and the Moenjodaro ruins.

Work is finally due to begin on the Shish Mahal, two years after the temporary scaffolding was set up. But the £25,000 project will only be an inspection, not a restoration.

At Moenjodaro, managers have been accused of misusing their positions to appoint relatives rather than technical experts to maintain the ruins. Since the fundraising campaign ended three years ago many have complained that preservation work stopped.

Often competition between national and provincial bureaucrats is blamed for holding back preservation efforts.

Saeed-ul Rehman, who has led the government archaeology department for the past two years, said he was aware of Unesco's concerns and was trying to rectify the problems.

"It is a question of not having enough money or experts," he said. "Conservation is a time-consuming job. We are trying our best."

fields.headline: British parents 'getting a raw deal'
fields.trailText: Britain is one of the least family friendly countries in Europe, according to a report published today by the National Family and Parenting Institute.
fields.body:
Britain is one of the least family friendly countries in Europe, according to a report published today by the National Family and Parenting Institute.

In spite of increasingly flexible working arrangements, most parents are left struggling with long hours, poor childcare facilities and inadequate state benefits, the survey shows.

Britain has the second highest fatality rate in Europe for child pedestrians, leaving parents worrying that their neighbourhoods are too risky to let their children out to play.

Family travel on public transport is more expensive and less easy to manage for parents struggling single-handedly with a buggy. Pubs and restaurants are less welcoming and parents feel blamed when their children are difficult in supermarkets.

"We are in a mess about the family," the report says. "Everyone and every organisation has something to say - sometimes contradictory and often with great certainty."

The survey was based on an analysis of EU statistics and focus groups probing the experiences of a cross section of 200 British parents.

Next week has been declared parents' week and charities intend to use the opportunity to put pressure on Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who is leading a government review of support for working parents.

The report says many parents feel that the British are not tolerant of children and that being a parent is often more demanding than paid employment.

According to the report, entitled "Is Britain Family Friendly?", the UK compares badly to other European countries on a range of measures, including balancing work and family life, childcare, family travel, and road accidents.

The institute is calling on retailers, bus and rail companies, restaurants, pubs and public services to audit the service they offer to families and children.

Mary MacLeod, its chief executive, said: "Despite some good new government policies designed to support families, parents in Britain still feel left to go it alone, expected to manage raising children and working, with little allowance made for their vital family responsibilities."

The problem starts immediately for parents of newly born children. "Unlike other European countries, women in the UK are not able to take much time off after the birth of the child without financial hardship," the report says.

Maternity pay is less than half the EU average - worth eight weeks on full salary compared with 14 weeks or more in Germany, Austria, the Netherlands, Italy and Denmark.

Mothers in the focus groups said there was pressure on them to return to work as soon as possible. "You need two wages to pay a mortgage, so when you stop working to have children, you can't afford it," said one.

Another said: "I think they try and make it as hard as possible for parents to stay at home. There's no financial help there."

A third said: "The government is encouraging people to have a family and then dump the kids on someone else and go back to work."

Britain offered "one of the worst deals in Europe" on parental leave for mothers and fathers with young children. The government excluded parents of children born before December 1999 and provided for 12 weeks of unpaid leave to be shared between both parents until the child is five.

The survey found that British fathers work the longest hours in Europe and working mothers are more reliant on informal arrangements for childcare: "The summer holiday was for many a time of worry about cover and increased costs."

Parents worry that their neighbourhood is too risky to let the children out to play and too polluted and dangerous to enjoy as an amenity. The proportion of 10-year-olds walking to school fell from more than 90% in 1971 to just over half in 1990.

The report said parents in the focus groups spoke eloquently about children not being welcome in public places. Their experience of relentless public criticism of private decisions on how to live family life left them feeling beleaguered.

There were confused messages from the government. One parent said: "They say they want to bring back the family unit and they want families to be at home together. Then they encourage mothers to go back to work. They don't know what they are saying."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: In the brutal world of factual television, there aren't many of whom it can be said that, if anything (and if this is an illness, I wish more people had it) they simply care too much.
fields.body:
In the brutal world of factual television, there aren't many of whom it can be said that, if anything (and if this is an illness, I wish more people had it) they simply care too much. Esther is one, of course, Michael Buerk another, and a third is my old friend Robert Kilroy Silk. The great thing about Bob's empathy-sodden morning show is that, even after all these years, it never rests on its laurels; it's still out there hunting down the best guests. Only yesterday, a researcher rang the Bernie Grant Trust to tell Sharon Grant that they are planning a show on vandalism and to wonder if Bernie was available to... "Let me stop you there," she said. "The thing is," adds the trust's Steve King, "Bernie always refused to go on the show, even when he was alive." I can't imagine why, unless he was intimidated intellectually by Bob and his crack team. Next Tuesday, for a topical debate entitled "Can a bald man ever be prime minister?" Robert will be joined by Clement Attlee.

The schedule for the Rugby League world cup finals arrives, and the eye is caught by the match in Group Two (labelled "the Group of Death" by the experts) between the Cook Islands and Lebanon. It kicks off at 12.30pm on November 5 at Cardiff's Millennium Stadium. With capacity limited to 80,000 (63,00 more, in fact, than the Cook Islands population), fingers crossed that police and safety experts can cope.

Especially touching in Nicholas Kochan's biography of Ann Widdecombe is the interview with Colin Maltby, who recalls falling in love with her the second he saw her standing on a platform at Oxford station wearing purple hotpants. Mr Maltby was Ann's only boyfriend. There was someone else who snogged her at Oxford, but - contrary to our recent suggestion - we now believe she pounced on him and it only happened once. Happily, the privacy provisions of the new Human Rights Act mean that that person, who works for one of our more sober papers, will remain anonymous.

Having fought off fierce competition for space in the New Statesman magazine, which he owns, that Jesus-like figure Geoffrey Robinson ("I still have the utmost respect for O'Mandy Mandelson, whatever he may have done to me...."), explains why the rights to his book were sold to the Daily Mail. "With 4.5m readers, it provided the best platform for getting my side of the story across." Indeed, indeed. That's why it wasn't the Sun or even straight to the internet - and nothing whatever to do with causing maximum damage, then. Or £300,000.

Meanwhile, a dispute rumbles on about the casting of O'Mandy in Carry On Up the Cabinet. One faction (mine, in fact) plumps for Kenneth Williams, while my colleague Richard Adams favours Charles Hawtrey. It's not easy, is it? Some roles speak for themselves - Barbara Windsor for Claire Bomber Short, Jim Dale as Mr Tony, Jack Douglas as Jack Straw, Macaulay Culkin as public health minister Yvette Cooper - but suggestions are wanted for weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown, Robin Cook, Patsy Prescott and the rest.

Roads minister Larry Whitty went to Birmingham's International Motor Show on Wednesday and tested a new driving simulator, designed to teach novices. "Lord Whitty started in third gear, but over-steered the thing," reports a startled witness. "Within seconds he had careered off the road, so they restarted it for him. And then he did it again." Poor show.

A new guide to Warsaw can't fail to impress tourists planning a trip to Poland. "As for the tripe served to you at the Metropol Hotel," it recommends, "you will sing its praises to your grandchildren on your death-bed." diary@theguardian.com

"As for the tripe served to you at the Metropol Hotel," it recommends, "you will sing its praises to your grandchildren on your death-bed." diary@theguardian.com

webTitle: Britain opens links with North Korea

fields.headline: Britain opens links with North Korea
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: Britain will open up diplomatic relations with North Korea to support reconciliation on the divided peninsula, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain will open up diplomatic relations with North Korea to support reconciliation on the divided peninsula, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday.

It will be the first time there have been full relations between the two countries since the communist government came into existence more than 50 years ago.

The move was announced by Mr Cook on his way to the South Korean capital of Seoul, where he and the prime minister, Tony Blair, will attend a summit of Asian and European leaders. Mr Cook said North Korea approached Britain about establishing relations last month through its embassy in Beijing. "I think it is likely we will respond positively to that," he said.

The move is a surprise. Unlike Italy, which has already opened up an embassy in Pyongyang, Britain has until now taken a cautious stance on upgrading its relations with the North, which is slowly emerging from decades of isolation.

The Foreign Office is also in the process of re-establishing political ties with the former Yugoslavia, leaving just Iraq and Bhutan outside the diplomatic fold with Britain.

Mr Cook said the shift in policy was requested by the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last week for breaking with a history of confrontation to engage the North in dialogue.

In June, he became the first leader from the South to travel to Pyongyang, where he held a summit with his counterpart, Kim Jong-il.

"Momentous developments are under way on the Korean peninsula," said Tony Blair in Seoul yesterday. "The summit has created the real opportunity for lasting peace and reconciliation."

Human rights groups, however, warned that Britain should not ignore reports of torture and other violations in North Korean prisons. Questions are also likely to be asked about the North's ballistic missile programme.

Mr Cook said the government was going into relations "with its eyes open". The opening of full ties will not happen immediately, he said, and it will be some time before an embassy is established in Pyongyang.

At tomorrow's Asia-Europe summit, leaders from the two continents are expected to back the peace process. South Korea hopes the west will also help to develop the impoverished North and pave the way towards reunification.

In a sign of the growing thaw, Madeleine Albright will make the first visit to Pyongyang by an American secretary of state later this month.

The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, also in Seoul, said his country would also now establish diplomatic relations with the North.

webTitle: Leader: Still on the wrong track

fields.headline: Still on the wrong track
fields.trailText: So Gerald Corbett has offered himself as a sacrifice on the altar of public opinion. Your coverage (An honourable man in the firing line, October 19) appears to show that the gamble has paid off. His personal reputation remains intact. Yet we should be less concerned about Corbett's future and more concerned about the future of the railways.
fields.body:
So Gerald Corbett has offered himself as a sacrifice on the altar of public opinion. Your coverage (An honourable man in the firing line, October 19) appears to show that the gamble has paid off. His personal reputation remains intact. Yet we should be less concerned about Corbett's future and more concerned about the future of the railways. In the wake of Paddington, Corbett offered a rather different sacrifice: part-privatisation of the railways. This quickly disappeared from the agenda, despite a poll which revealed that 73% of the public wanted Railtrack brought back under public control. The false debate around Corbett's future should not mystify the real issue: how we get rid of all of those who profit in the midst of the carnage and put the railways back into safer hands.
Dr Dave Whyte
Manchester Metropolitan University D.Whyte@mmu.ac.uk

 It is not surprising the board of Railtrack have rejected Mr Corbett's offer of resignation: if he were to go they would be bound to follow. He should go, and they should follow: it is not the case that Mr Corbett is the best man to solve Railtrack's problems - the people who will solve the problem are the hundreds of engineers and workers who have been prevented from doing so by the structure of contracts that Railtrack's board has entered into.
Michael Fort
Huddersfield

 Corbett thinks Railtrack should stop paying him. Everyone else thinks he should stay and sort out the mess: let him stay and work for nothing till the rails are safe.
Tim Evans
London

 Your leader (October 19) speaks of a need to build travellers' confidence. The first step to restoring the confidence of this particular rail traveller would be a government announcement that dividend payments to Railtrack shareholders will automatically be suspended for a minimum of five years after any major railway accident in which track or signal failure is implicated.
Peter Whincup
London

 You are right to conclude that the days of British Rail were not a golden age. Perhaps we ought to admit that we get the railway we are prepared to pay for. There are four strands to achieving a first-class rail network: punctuality, price, reliability, and safety. Since 1995, politicians and the media have stressed the first two, overlooking the Japanese experience that a reliable railway is also a safe one. But reliability will cost money and the lowest cost mentality still dominates railway thinking.
Robert Gifford
Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety robert.gifford@pacts.org.uk

 You cite the 1988 rail crash as an example of a disaster under a nationalised system. Mrs Thatcher was elected in 1979 and private contractors were already widely used.
Alan Tyson
Chester

 As a continental European passing through, I am amazed by the anti-public sector accent of New Labour, even where economic competition does not follow privatisation. The last time I travelled the 35-mile journey from London to Stansted Airport, I paid £12 to a semi-monopolistic privately owned train operator: one-third of my fare for a 800-mile flight to Italy with a competitive low-cost airline. The high-speed TGV between Paris and Lyon, which is highly-profitable for its French state operator, comfortably and safely covers a 270-mile distance for £29: the same price of a bumpy 110-mile return journey from Cambridge to London.
Carlo Ratti
University of Cambridge

fields.headline: Detente in Hackney
fields.trailText: I was elected as councillor for the Northwold ward of the London borough of Hackney in 1998. It has a large Muslim community and is also well known for its large community of Hasidic Jews - the biggest in Europe and the third largest in the world after Israel and New York. Hackney is an ideal example of racial and religious harmony. Here we have people of three leading faiths, Islam, Judaism and Christianity, and they live in peace and friendship.
fields.body:
I was elected as councillor for the Northwold ward of the London borough of Hackney in 1998. It has a large Muslim community and is also well known for its large community of Hasidic Jews - the biggest in Europe and the third largest in the world after Israel and New York. Hackney is an ideal example of racial and religious harmony. Here we have people of three leading faiths, Islam, Judaism and Christianity, and they live in peace and friendship.

Muslim and Jewish religious institutions and homes are literally a stone's throw apart. However, despite events in the Middle East, both communities have maintained good relations.

The attack on a young Jewish boy in Stamford Hill has shocked and sickened both communities. Last week five men were arrested for distributing racist literature in the Stamford Hill area. These are isolated incidents and are not from people within the community. These cowardly acts are not representative of the Muslim faith and are condemned.

There is a misconception among many people that Muslims and Jews cannot live or work together due to the tensions in the Middle East. I have worked very closely with my ward councillors, who are both orthodox Jews, to represent all communities. In April 1999, the two communities joined forces to keep their streets free of nail bombs in the wake of the Brick Lane bombing. Seldom do these acts of cooperation get the publicity they deserve.
Cllr Shahid Achhala
London

fields.headline: Drugs in the dock
fields.standfirst: New small-scale research is not conclusive
fields.trailText: Only the very brave will get involved in the battle between natural childbirth advocates and women's groups over the use of painkillers in pregnancy. Yet many women, particularly those who are pregnant, may have been worried by yesterday's report linking drug abuse among children to painkillers given to their mothers in childbirth. They should not be.
fields.body:
Only the very brave will get involved in the battle between natural childbirth advocates and women's groups over the use of painkillers in pregnancy. Yet many women, particularly those who are pregnant, may have been worried by yesterday's report linking drug abuse among children to painkillers given to their mothers in childbirth. They should not be. Virtually nothing can be drawn from such a small study. Swedish researchers looking at 69 adult drug abusers discovered that 23% had been exposed to multiple doses of opiates and barbiturates in the hours before birth. They then looked at their siblings who did not abuse drugs and found that in their cases only 3% of mothers had taken these drugs at this stage of pregnancy. The more painkillers a woman gets during labour, they concluded, the more likely her child will be to abuse drugs later in life.

Not necessarily so. Do not for the moment ask whether it makes sense to track back 18 or more years to the few hours before birth to look for a causal link. Ignore all the other factors over the years that would need to be taken into account. Some serious British social scientists believe it may be worth going back to childbirth to see if precursors to anti-social behaviour can be identified. They point to one obvious cycle: difficult birth; fractious mother; fractious child; anti-social child. But they are looking at the 1970 British Cohort Study, covering all 17,000 babies born in one week, not 69 abusers. To draw any dependable conclusions, the Swedish researchers would have needed to examine four variables - difficult births, with and without painkillers, and easy births, with and without painkillers. Women who want the right to choose should rest assured. Remember, an epidural provides an anaesthetic, not an analgesic. These are not painkillers. Neither are barbiturates. They are sedatives. Pethidine and morphine are painkillers, the use of which should not be stopped on the basis of this small study.

webTitle: Letter: Wobbly history of US labour leader

fields.headline: Wobbly history of US labour leader
fields.trailText: Your obituary of Gus Hall (October 18) left out much. Firstly, and very surprisingly in an avowedly liberal paper, no mention at all of the hysteria of the cold war and McCarthyism.
fields.body:
Your obituary of Gus Hall (October 18) left out much. Firstly, and very surprisingly in an avowedly liberal paper, no mention at all of the hysteria of the cold war and McCarthyism. So, any reader could be forgiven for thinking that the jailing of Gus Hall and many other communists and trade unionists in the late 40s and early 50s was an accident of history. Whereas, the prosecution of Gus and others was neither an historic accident nor unrelated to their effective opposition to the power of the major car, steel and other production factories where they had organised the workers. (Indeed, such prosecutions could be seen - in a way - as a tribute to their work.)

And here is your second major omission: the role of the CP USA in building labour organisation. True, reference was made to Gus's pre-war union work. In fact, he was one of the founding members of the United Steelworkers of America. Yet only scant mention of the party's work in the post-war years when it carried on the tradition of the Wobblies and worked to break the long-standing tradition of the craft elitism of the American Federation of Labour (AFL) and to build an organised labour movement for all workers. This it did through its leadership of the campaign to organise the CIO (Congress of Industrial Organisations) which was not seen in opposition to the AFL but as complementary to it.

This led to the formation of the strong AFL-CIO united organisation of trade unions. Incidentally, one of the many key players was Johnny Williamson (sitting next to Gus in your picture). Johnny was jailed in the McCarthy era and, on his release, came to this country where he was CP district secretary in Essex, bringing his experience of Ford, Detroit, to Dagenham.

The AFL-CIO continues to grow in its effectiveness and organisation based on the Wobblie tradition of organising from the localities upwards and - using direct communication tools such as the internet - trade union locals (branches) and citizens committees are gaining in strength across the US. This is the communist tradition that Gus Hall was proud to represent.
Kevin Halpin
Industrial organiser, Communist Party of Britain

fields.headline: Assessing the negative transparency
fields.trailText: Richard Sennett's comments on the bureaucratisation of the universities (The suffering professionals, October 18) are welcome. However, the loss to the universities (and Britain) in this process is not just that of the individuals who flee the absurdity of the form and content of the RAE (research assessment exercise), the TQA (teaching quality assessment) and the RTE (research transparency exercise) but the negative impact of these "exercises" on the academic vitality of those who remain.
fields.body:
Richard Sennett's comments on the bureaucratisation of the universities (The suffering professionals, October 18) are welcome. However, the loss to the universities (and Britain) in this process is not just that of the individuals who flee the absurdity of the form and content of the RAE (research assessment exercise), the TQA (teaching quality assessment) and the RTE (research transparency exercise) but the negative impact of these "exercises" on the academic vitality of those who remain.
Prof Mary Evans
University of Kent M.S.Evans@ukc.ac.uk

 Richard Sennett's well-considered critique of successive governments' fixation on measurements and assessments of the performance of academics and other professionals omits three of their most unpleasant consequences. First, such measurements are highly divisive. Second, they fuel a highly consumerist attitude among students who are encouraged to treat their universities and their degrees as brand names. Third, they promote an obsession with targets and benchmarks at the expense of good teaching, research and all that is vibrant in higher education.
Prof Yiannis Gabriel
Imperial College, London y.gabriel@ic.ac.uk

 Richard Sennett correctly states that the research transparency exercise imposed upon university teachers represents another stage in the bureaucratisation of higher education, whose underlying premise is "an institutionalised form of contempt". He might have added that bureaucracy as a mode of domination has often been justified as the necessary price of democracy, insofar as it ensures transparency of decision-making and equity in outcomes. Experience at my own university and elsewhere suggests that what we are witnessing is not only secrecy among decision-makers but also disregard for students.

The question must be asked: transparency for whom and to what end? Until we receive serious answers, I advise all university staff and students to support the National Union of Students' day of action on November 15 as part of a campaign to expose the malaise which is now afflicting one of the key institutional sectors of our country.
Dr Alan Hooper
University of Hertfordshire a.hooper@herts.ac.uk

 No doubt Richard Sennett and his colleagues would find life a lot easier if left to their own devices, but his assertion that they would "hold each other to account" rings hollow. Academics are free to peddle sub-standard tuition with impunity, since the visitor system blocks recourse to the courts for students who suffer as a result. The public, moreover, has no right of access to information about the standards of a university faculty. Until universities become as accountable as other service industries, the "institutionalised contempt" complained of remains fully deserved.
Chris Bell
London cpbell@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Dragging their feet
fields.standfirst: Stone's slow grind to Stonehenge held up till spring
fields.trailText: A blighted lottery-funded project to follow in the footsteps of ancient man and drag a three-tonne rock from the mountains of north Pembrokeshire to Stonehenge has gone into hibernation because of poor weather and failing daylight.
fields.body:
A blighted lottery-funded project to follow in the footsteps of ancient man and drag a three-tonne rock from the mountains of north Pembrokeshire to Stonehenge has gone into hibernation because of poor weather and failing daylight.

Critics say the exercise should be abandoned. But the heritage lottery fund, which has committed £100,000 to the millennium stone project, says it will continue to support the scheme when it gets under way again next spring.

Volunteers embarked on their 240-mile journey from the Preseli hills in April. The stone should have reached Salisbury Plain last month, but it has gone no further than the quayside at Milford Haven, where it will sit until conditions improve.

The project, to show how the Stonehenge bluestones could have been transported from south-west Wales some 4,600 years ago, has been mishap-prone from the outset.

Volunteers dragging the stones covered only one mile a day rather than the three they had hoped for. A sled used to carry the stone was stolen. Then divers and a navy tug had to be called in to rescue the rock after it slipped off two barges and sank in 50ft of water as it was being rowed out of Milford Haven for the journey up the Bristol Channel.

Phil Bowen, head of the project, said it had to be halted because worsening weather and failing daylight could place volunteers' lives at risk.

"I am sure stone-age man did not manage the journey without a slip-up or two, and I don't think that even the ancient tribes would have tried rowing these stones across the sea in the middle of winter," he said.

"One of our aims was to put the Preseli area on the map, and there can't be anyone in the UK now who doesn't know that the bluestones at Stonehenge came from north Pembrokeshire."

But the Pembrokeshire historian Dillwyn Miles yesterday condemned the project as a fiasco. "It is utterly insane and a total waste of money," he said.

He added: "They have used modern methods to help the stone on its way, and that invalidates what they claim to be doing. Any fool could have told you this wasn't going to work."

"One of our aims was to put the Preseli area on the map, and there can't be anyone in the UK now who doesn't know that the bluestones at Stonehenge came from north Pembrokeshire." But the Pembrokeshire historian Dillwyn Miles yesterday condemned the project as a fiasco. "It is utterly insane and a total waste of money," he said. He added: "They have used modern methods to help the stone on its way, and that invalidates what they claim to be doing. Any fool could have told you this wasn't going to work."

fields.headline: Disability chief barred from plane
fields.trailText: Bert Massie, chairman of the disability rights commission, found himself the victim of discrimination yesterday when an airline at the City of London airport refused to take him on a flight to Edinburgh because he has to use a wheelchair.
fields.body:
Bert Massie, chairman of the disability rights commission, found himself the victim of discrimination yesterday when an airline at the City of London airport refused to take him on a flight to Edinburgh because he has to use a wheelchair.

The snub, as he was waiting to board a Cambridge-based ScotAirways plane, was all the more poignant as Mr Massie was due to address the annual social services conference on the work of the commission and the problems facing people with disabilities.

"It's outrageous," he told the Guardian yesterday. "Although airlines are excluded from the provision of the Disability Discrimination Act, most British airlines like BA, Virgin and even the budget airlines try their best to be helpful."

Mr Massie booked his 11.40am flight through a travel agent, and told it he would require help getting on to the plane. He arrived with his personal assistant in good time and checked in. A baggage handler was assigned to help him.

But he and his assistant were left unattended in a terminal corridor for 50 minutes within sight of the plane. As the passengers began to board the handler returned and Mr Massie, who contracted polio as a child, was wheeled on to the tarmac.

By that time the plane doors were shut and he was told by an airport supervisor that ScotAirways had a policy not to accept wheelchair users.

"I offered to board just with the help of my assistant, with the wheelchair going in the hold," he said.

"They could at least have told their staff about the rule."

He missed the conference, but was able to catch a train home to Liverpool.

ScotAirways was set up by Roy Suckling and his wife Merlyn 14 years ago as Suckling Airways. At the end of last year it changed its name to ScotAirways and started an expansion programme with finance from Brian Souter and Ann Gloag, the owners of Stagecoach. It offered a "helpful, friendly and professional service".

Commenting at the time on the change of corporate identity, Mr Suckling said: "We have always prided ourselves on the high quality of service we offer our passengers and at ScotAirways we will strive to enhance this reputation."

Last night Jerry Froggett, marketing manager of ScotAirways, denied that the airline had a policy that discriminated against people with disabilities and said it wanted to apologise to Mr Massie for the inconvenience.

Mr Froggett said the travel agency had conveyed a code on the booking form which indicated Mr Massie would need assistance but this had been overlooked. "It was a difficult situation, one which we would do our utmost to avoid," he said. "We carry thousands of disabled passengers every year.

"In this case the flight dispatcher - the airport official who supervises the plane turn-around - decided that it was unsafe for him to board. We are very upset that he has had this problem."

fields.headline: Nasty shocks for mountain bikers
fields.trailText: Male mountain bikers are being saddled with a painful problem by their sport, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Male mountain bikers are being saddled with a painful problem by their sport, according to research published today.

Constant saddle vibrations and shocks from the rough terrain mean that 96% of mountain bikers examined in a study were found to be suffering from scrotal abnormalities.

Bikers are now being advised to wear padded shorts and to invest in ergonomically designed saddles to reduce the risk of testicular problems.

The study, published in the Lancet, looked at 45 keen mountain bikers and 31 medical students who did not indulge in the sport.

Researchers from the university hospital in Innsbruck, Austria, found that 96% of the mountain bikers were suffer ing from scrotal abnormalities, compared with 16% of the medical students. Half the mountain bikers reported tenderness and discomfort when they were physically examined.

The sport has become increasingly popular in recent years, with mountain bikes accounting for two-thirds of the 2m bicycles bought in the UK each year.

The report's author, Ferdinand Frauscher, said: "New shock-absorbent saddles and full suspension bikes might help reduce saddle vibration."

A spokesman for the British Cycling Federation said: "We would support everything this study says about making sure all cyclists get a bike and equipment that fits them, wear padded shorts, and see their GP if they experience any problems."

fields.headline: Hillary 'lied' over role in sackings
fields.trailText: A seven-year-old scandal which Hillary Clinton thought had been laid to rest was resurrected yesterday in the final stretch of her New York senate campaign, after an official report found she had lied about her role in firing White House travel office staff.
fields.body:
A seven-year-old scandal which Hillary Clinton thought had been laid to rest was resurrected yesterday in the final stretch of her New York senate campaign, after an official report found she had lied about her role in firing White House travel office staff.

The controversy over the sackings, known as Travelgate, was one of the issues investigated by Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel famous for his role in the Monica Lewinsky affair. Mr Starr's successor, Robert Ray, closed the investigation in June, saying there was insufficient evidence to support charges.

However, in the full text of the report published late on Wednesday, Mr Ray concluded that Mrs Clinton had given "factually false" statements in a sworn deposition about her involvement in the dismissal of seven employees in the White House travel office, and their replacement by Clinton friends and relatives. The sackings led to charges of cronyism and a multimillion-dollar investigation.

Hillary Clinton's lawyer, David Kendall, rejected the findings as "unfair, misleading and rife with innuendo", and a White House official noted that Mr Ray's report conceded that there had been financial irregularities in the way the travel office had been run.

But Mrs Clinton's Republican opponent in New York, Rick Lazio, was swift to incorporate the report into his sustained attacks on her integrity.

In a 1993 memorandum, David Watkins, the official who sacked the travel staff, said there would be "hell to pay" if the administration "failed to take swift and decisive action in conformity with the First Lady's wishes".

Mr Watkins later testified that Mrs Clinton told him: "we need to have our people in there." Other White House aides recalled conversations with Mrs Clinton on the issue.

However in her 1995 testimony, the First Lady not only denied having "any role" in the affair, she also said she had not had "any input" in the decision to fire the seven employees.

In an argument echoing Mr Clinton's semantic arguments in the Lewinsky investigation, Mr Kendall wrote that in the Travelgate hearings there had been a disagreement over the significance of the word "role".

Mr Kendall said that Mrs Clinton "may not even have been aware of any influence she may have had on the firing decision".

webTitle: US sells half the world's arms exports

fields.headline: US sells half the world's arms exports
fields.trailText: The west's three permanent members of the UN Security Council account for 80% of the world's weapons sales at a time when it is incapable of mounting effective peacekeeping operations, according to a report published yesterday by a London-based thinktank.
fields.body:
The west's three permanent members of the UN Security Council account for 80% of the world's weapons sales at a time when it is incapable of mounting effective peacekeeping operations, according to a report published yesterday by a London-based thinktank.

The report, by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), is deeply sceptical about the EU's ability to realise its plans for an independent, 60,000-strong rapid-reaction force.

"European leaders speak of a European defence capacity but have not voted [for] the funds to finance it," said the IISS director, John Chipman.

The US increased its share of the international arms trade last year and now accounts for nearly 50% of the $53.4bn (£37bn) annual market, according to the IISS publication, the Military Balance.

Britain came second, selling nearly £7bn worth of weapons, while France was third at almost £4.6bn.

Much of these weapons systems were supplied to the Middle East, the world's biggest arms market. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest arms buyer, purchased more than £4bn worth of weapons last year.

Taiwan was the largest arms importer in East Asia.

Middle Eastern countries spent £42bn on defence last year, says the report, which also notes that the Israeli air force had set up its first anti-ballistic missile battery some 30 miles south of Tel Aviv.

The IISS damned the lack of government commitment to international peacekeeping.

"It remains the case that the UN continues to overreach, approving ambitious mandates and deploying inadequately supported forces in volatile situations," Mr Chipman said.

"The long-term aim of the UN operation in Sierra Leone is unclear and the capacity of the UN to make a sensible contribution to what is a hugely unstable situation in the Congo is questionable," he said.

UN member states were "incapable of producing the sometimes very large contingents that a proper operation would require," he said.

While defence spending increased in most regions of the world, including the US, spending by Nato's European members other than Britain and the three new entrants - Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic - continued to decline.

"Nato countries in Europe are feeling the strain of what looks like an increasingly lengthy commitment in Kosovo," the report said. "Even those with all-professional forces are finding they are over-committed in Europe and beyond."

"It remains doubtful whether the Europeans can realise their ambitions for a credible 60,000-strong independent force," it adds.

If the continent is unable to muster a credible independent force, Nato will have to remain strongly involved in EU security. "European defence, in all but the most trivial of cases, will remain a transatlantic affair," Mr Chipman said.

Britain and France have invested considerable political and diplomatic capital in setting up a joint EU military force, which would conduct peacekeeping operations without US or Nato involvement

France wants to cap its six-month stint as EU president at the European summit in Nice in December with a firm commitment to set up a credible force with at least 60,000 troops.

 100,000 people were killed as a direct result of armed conflicts in the year up to August, 60% of them in sub-Saharan Africa, the IISS says.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rescuers yesterday found a further four bodies in the Alps, raising the death toll to 35, after huge floods and landslides hit Italy and Switzerland.
fields.body:
Alps flood death toll reaches 35

Rescuers yesterday found a further four bodies in the Alps, raising the death toll to 35, after huge floods and landslides hit Italy and Switzerland.

Three bodies were pulled out in the Swiss Alpine village of Gond. Across the border in Italy, rescuers recovered a body in the Val D'Aosta region. Ten people are still missing, feared dead.
AP, Mantua

Minister caught on camera

Austria's transport minister turned himself over to the police yesterday after television showed him breaking the law by using his mobile phone at the wheel of his car.

Michael Schmid, of the far right Freedom Party, apologised for his behaviour. He now faces a fine of 300 schillings (£12.66).
Reuters, Vienna

3 die in Tamil suicide blast

A suspected Tamil Tiger suicide bomber blew himself up in the Sri Lankan capital Colombo yesterday just minutes before President Chandrika Kumaratunga installed a new cabinet to cement her shaky coalition.

Three people were killed in the blast, including the bomber, and 21 were injured.
Reuters, Colombo

Islamists win seats in Egypt

Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party looks set to sweep the first round of elections, initial results showed. The outlawed Muslim Brotherhood took two seats from the NDP.

The NDP dominates Egypt's political system, which excludes Islamist groups. Opposition parties won only 13 of 444 seats in the last parliamentary poll in 1995.
Reuters, Cairo
